pcm: Dis is all about producing crops that are high yielding under stressed conditions; di stresses are Fall Army Warm and stem borers, which are major constraints to maize production. Na to dey produce crop wey dey yield welwel under hard condition wey dey do; di stresses dem be Fall Army Warm and stem borers, wey be major block to maize production.

eng: If not controlled, it could cause up to 80 percent yield lost; and draught  if you don't manage moisture (rain) deficit very well, you may not get any yield.
pcm: If dem no control am, if fit cause loss wey reach 80 percent, plus drought if you no manage rain shortage welwel, you fit no get any yield.

eng: We have done this trial for the third time.
pcm: Na di third time be dis wey don do dis trial,

eng: We did the first trial under the dry season in March, and during the rainy season, we conducted another one from June to November.
pcm: Na for under dry season for march we do di first trial, and durin di rainy season, we do anoda one from june go enter November.

eng: This is the third trial from November to April.
pcm: Na di third trial be dis from November go enter April.

eng: So, in essence, this is what we are trying to showcase,the Principal researcher said.
pcm: Di Principal researcher tok say na wetin dem dey try showcase be dat.

eng: With the three CFT trials successful, researchers will have to test and validate them from the farmers field to show that what they recorded from their own research station equally performs well in the farmers fields on wide range of locations over wide ecological conditions, beginning from 2021 rainy season.
pcm: As di three CFT trial don dey successful, pipo wey dey do research go need to test and validate dem to show say wetin dem record for inside dem research station dey perform well for inside di farmers field for different locations and ecological conditions as e go start for di rainy season of 2021.

eng: By the end of 2022, if all things work fine, Nigerian farmers would expect these hybrids to be with them.
pcm: By di time wey 2022 go end, if all tins dem work wel, Naija farmers go expect say make all dis hybrids dem dey wit dem.

eng: Dr. Muhyideen Ayekunle, a maize breeder under the project, said from the last two trials conducted, the transgenic variety recorded yield advantage of 17 percent over non- BT despite heavy infestation.
pcm: Dr. Muhyideen Ayekunle, wey be maize breeder under dis project tok say from di two trial wey dem do last, di transgenic variety wey dem record give 17 percent advantage ova di one wey no get BT despite say dem don infest am welwel.

eng: The varieties under trials were infested three times unlike the previous ones to virtually look at the efficacy of the BT gene in the maize product.
pcm: We don infest di varieties wey we dey put for trial three times unlike di previous one make we for take look how di BT gene take dey effective reach for di maize product.

eng: With the outcome, researchers said the yield will definitely increase above 17 per cent.
pcm: With di outcome, researcher dem don tok say di yield go increase reach 17 percent.

eng: So after, we're going to analyze the data and then prepare a document to get approval for environmental release.
pcm: So afta, we go analyze di data, and go prepare document to take get approval for environmental release.

eng: We're going to submit the dossiers to the National Biosafety Management Agency (NBMA) and it will be reviewed.
pcm: We go submit di dossier give National Biosafety Management Agency (NBMA) and dem go review am.

eng: Once we get approval that these products, we can come out of the confinement
pcm: Once dem give us approval say dis product, we fit show face for outside

eng: and then we can have a national performing trial.
pcm: and then we go fit get national performing trial.

eng: The Director General/CEO of the National Biotechnology Development Agency (NBDA), Professor Abdullahi Mustapha, at the event, called on the scientists to continue to search for abiotic and biotic solutions to the challenges facing farmers in the country.
pcm: Di  Director General/CEO of di National Biotechnology Development Agency (NBDA), wey be Professor Abdullahi Mustapha, for di event, call di scientist  dem to dey kontinu to search for abiotic and biotic solution to di challenge wey dey face farmers for inside di kontri.

eng: We have tested technologies capable of providing solutions to problems that farmers face, let us take advantage of it and move forward, he said.
pcm: We don test some technology wey dey capable of providing solution to problem wey farmer dem dey face, make we take advantage o am and move forward, as im tok.

eng: Dr Rose Maxwell Gidado, the Country Coordinator OFAB Nigeria, said the impact was actually going to be much.
pcm: Dr Rose Maxwell Gidado, wey be di Country Coordinator OFAB Nigeria, tok di impact go plenty welwel.

eng: Farmers are going to have yield increase of 17 percent and you know that farming is all about productivity and harvestable yield.
pcm: Farmer dem yield go increase by 17 percent and you know say na productivity and harvest be di koko for farming.

eng: Once you have yield, of cause you're going to have bumper harvest and profit.
pcm: Once you don gree, you go get plenty harvest and profit.

eng: She said by the time these maize varieties are ready to get to the farmers, it will increase their livelihood, money and then the price of maize would come down.
pcm: She tok say by di time wey dis kind of maize go ready to enter farmer hand, e go increase dem livelihood, money, plus di price of maize would kom down.

eng: Manchester United fight back in win at Aston Villa
pcm: Manchester United fight back to take win Aston Villa

eng: Manchester United fought back to beat Aston Villa 3-1 away in the Premier League on Sunday as Bruno Fernandes, Mason Greenwood and Edinson Cavani scored in the second half to put on hold the title celebrations of champions-elect Manchester City.
pcm: Manchester United be fight back to take Aston Villa 3-1 for away inside di Premier League for Sunday as Bruno Fernandes, Mason Greenwood and Edinson Cavani score for second half  to take put di celebration of Manchester City for hold.

eng: The result left United second on 70 points from 34 games, 10 behind City who have played a game more and missed a chance to secure the title on Saturday after they suffered a 2-1 home defeat by Chelsea.
pcm: Di result leave United for 70 points from inside 34 games, 10 point behind City wey don play one game pass dem and dem miss di chance to win di title for Saturday afta dem Chelsea beat dem for home 2-1 for Saturday.

eng: Bertrand Traore fired Villa ahead in the 24th minute with a brilliant strike into the top corner from 15 metres after some sloppy defending by the visitors, who gave the ball away several times deep in their own half.
pcm: Na Bertrand Traore pu Villa ahead for inside 24th minute with one brilliant strike wey enter top corner from 15 metres afta some weak denfendin wey di visitors do, as dem troway ball for dem own half plenty times.

eng: Fernandes equalised with a 52nd-minute penalty, sending Villa goalkeeper Emiliano Martinez the wrong way with a coolly taken spot-kick after a series of clumsy challenges by Douglas Luiz sent Paul Pogba tumbling over.
pcm: Fernandes equalise for inside 52 minute wit penaty, as e send di golie for Villa, Emiliano Martinez di wrong way  wit di spot-kick wey im coolee take, dis one follow one rough challenge from Douglas Luiz wey Paul Pogba tumble.

eng: Greenwood turned the match on its head four minutes later with a neat shot on the turn from inside the penalty area after he shook off Villa centre back Tyrone Mings.
pcm: Grenwood turn di match on im head four minutes later with one neat shot on di turn from inside di penalty area afta im don shake off di centre back Tryone Mings.

eng: Substitute Edinson Cavani sealed United's victory with a glancing 87th-minute header.
pcm: Edinson Cavani wey be substitute na im seal win for United with di goal wey im take head score for inside 87 minute.

eng: After Daily Trust story, NCC bans sale, use of mobile phone boosters
pcm: After di tori wey komot for inside Daily Trust, NCC don ban sale and use of mobile phone booster

eng: The Nigerian Communications Commission (NCC) has banned the sale and use of GSM network boosters (for mobile connectivity) especially by banks, residents, government agencies, among others to improve telecommunications services.
pcm: Di Nigerian Communications Commission (NCC) don put  ban on top di sale and use of GSM network boosters (for mobile connectivity) especially by banks, residents, goment agencies, among others to take  improve telecommunications services.

eng: The Commission gave the 14-day Pre-Enforcement Notice on Tuesday, signed by the Director Public affairs, Ikechukwu Adinde.
pcm: Di Commission be give di 14-day Pre-Enfircement Notice on Tuesday, signed by di Director Public Affairs, wey be Ikechukwu Adinde.

eng: It said the warning is effective from Tuesday and on expiration of the deadline, NCC said it will begin enforcement actions against defaulters.
pcm: E tok say di warnin go carry effect from Tuesday and as e dey expire for di deadline, NCC tok say e go begin take action against pipo wey no follow instruction.

eng: This is coming less than one month after Daily Trust on April 24, 2021 reported that business owners in the Sabon Gari market in Kano and other business areas said they buy boosters to improve the reception of the poor telecommunication networks in their areas.
pcm: Dis one dey apun less than one month wey Daily Trust report on April 24, 2021 say pipo wey dey do business for Sabon Gari market inside Kano plus other business area tok say dem dey buy booster to improve di reception of di bad telecommunication network for dem area.

eng: Some of the traders said the reception is poor as the telecommunications service providers do not do much to improve services in spite of the gains they make from such places.
pcm: Some of di traders tok say di service no good as telecommunication service providers dem no dey do much to improve service on top di gain wey dem dey make for such place.

eng: According to them, more traders and their customers engage in digital and online financial transactions (data-based cashless services) and other telecommunication-based services while facing poor call/data services.
pcm: According to dem, plenty traders and dem customers dey engage for digital and online financial transaction (data-based cashless services) plus oda telecommunication-based service dem and dem still get poor call/data services.

eng: NCC in the notice said, the sale, installation and usage of GSM boosters are illegal.
pcm: For inside di notice, NCC tok say as dem dey sell, install and use GSm booster dey illegal.

eng: In the notice, NCC said it was only exercising its mandate of ensuring the protection of consumers, ensuring good quality of service and maintenance of technical standards of communication equipment, and in accordance with the provisions of Section 131 (1) of the Nigerian Communications Act (NCA) 2003.
pcm: For di notice, NCC tok say dem just dey do dem duty to make sure say dem protect consumers, to ensure good quality of service and maintenance of technical standard of communication equipmant, and na as e dey for di provision of section 131 (1) of di  Nigerian Communications Act (NCA) 2003.

eng: Such acts may lead to monetary sanction and/or imprisonment, or both (fine & imprisonment) as well as the confiscation of any equipment used in the illegal enhancement of network coverage.
pcm: Dat kind act fit lead to sanction wey go involve moneyplus/ or prison, or di two (fine plus prison) as well as dem fit seize any equipment wey dem use for di illegal enhancement of network coverage.

eng: LG polls: Protests over imposition of APC candidates
pcm: LG polls: dem begin protest ova as dem take dey impose candidate for inside APC

eng: Some members of the All Progressives Congress (APC) in Ogun State have staged a protest against the party's adoption of consensus candidature in some local government areas ahead of the July 24, local government elections in the state.
pcm: Some member for di All Progressives Congress (APC) for inside Ogun state don do protest against how di parti take adopt some consensus candidate for some local goment area  ahead of di July 24 local goment election for inside di state.

eng: The top echelon of the party had announced that the party would adopt consensus candidates in some local government areas while direct or indirect primary polls would be conducted for the emergence of candidates in some.
pcm: Top pipo for di parti don announce say di parti go adopt consensus candidate for some local goment area, and dem go conduct direct and or indirect primary votin make candidate take emmerge for some.

eng: The protesters who stormed the secretariat of the Nigeria Union of Journalists (NUJ), Ogun State, accused some leaders of the APC in Abeokuta South LGA of imposing a chairmanship candidate on them.
pcm: Di protesters dem wey enter di secretariat of Nigeria Union of Journalists (NUJ), for inside Ogun State, be accuse some leaders of APC for Abeokuta South LGA say dem impose a candidate for di post Chaiman put for dem.

eng: They carried placards with various inscriptions such as We Say No To Money Bags
pcm: Dem carry placards wey dem write many many things put wey include We Say No To Money Bags

eng: In Abeokuta South and
pcm: for Abeokuta South and

eng: Let Party Members Pick Who They Want, and said their preferred aspirant was Farouk Akintunde.
pcm: Allow Member of di Parti to pick who dem want, and said dem preferred aspirant na Farouk Akintunde

eng: One of the party leaders who led the protest, Balogun Ololade, urged Gov Dapo Abiodun to intervene in the matter to save democracy from jeopardy.
pcm: One of di parti leader wey follow lead di protest waka, Balogun Ololade, tok say make Gov dapo Abiodun intervene for di matter to save democracy waka from jeopardy.

eng: Between DSS and regional separatists
pcm: Between DSS and pipo wey wan separate for some region

eng: Repeated warnings by the DSS to persons and groups whose utterances and activities persistently constitute provocative disruptions of the ethno-religious environment and threaten harmonious co-existence of the majority common folks of this country, were beginning to sound monotonous and unconvincing until guilty conscience forced the prime suspects out of their deceptive demeanour.
pcm: As DSS don put hand for ear for group and pipo dem wey dey tok and do things wey fit provoke and distrupt di ethno-religious environment and threaten harmonous co-existence of di majority common folk of di kontri, don begin dey sound like say na one pesin tok until dem force dem komot for wia dem dey deceive pipo.

eng: Lingering questions about who or which persons and groups the security agency was referring to were promptly vapourized in the heated rhetorical outbursts of the nation's prominent geo-ethnic agitators
pcm: Question wey don dey linger about who or which pesin and group di security agent dey follow tok na im dem  promptly vapourized for di heated rhetorical outbust of di nation prominent geo-ethnic agitator dem.

eng: Afenifere, Arewa Consultative Forum (ACF), Ohanaeze Ndigbo, Northern Elders Forum (NEF)and Pan Niger Delta Forum (PANDEF).
pcm: Afenifere, Arewa Consultative Forum (ACF), Ohanaeze Ndigbo, Northern Elders Forum (NEF)and Pan Niger Delta Forum (PANDEF).

eng: It then dawned on all that indeed these were the persons and groups  that have continued to resort to inciting, unguarded and divisive statements, and acts to pit citizens against one another in order to apparently inflame the embers of tribal and religious discord, as the DSS charged in one of its warnings.
pcm: E kom clear for all of us eye say dis na di group of pipo wey don kontinu to dey resort to inciting, unguarded and divisive statement and act dem, to take set kontri pipo against demsef to take put fire of tribal and religious discord, as di DSS din charge for one of dem warning.

eng: Interestingly, none of these prime suspects in the exploitation of some fault lines to cause ethno-religious violence in some parts of the country could categorically distance itself from the treacherous and subversive activities detected by the security agency.
pcm: Interestingly, non for inside di major suspect dem for di exploitation of some fault line dem to take kos ethno-religious violence for some part of di kontri fit categorically distance demsef from di treacherous and subversive activity dem wey security agent detect.

eng: They chorused a common conviction that the DSS knows those responsible, differing only in the respective directions of their accusing fingers.
pcm: Dem chorus di same conviction say di DSS sabi di pipo wey dey responsible, dem only differ for di direction wey dem dey point dem accusing finger.

eng: While Afenifere retorted these people know those who are responsible for these acts but can't touch them because of their connections, PANDEV rehashed its grouse about many people feeling alienated and ACF feigned ignorance, asking who are the people?
pcm: AS Afenifere tok say dis pipo sabi di ones wey dey responsible for di acts, but dem no fit touch dem bikos of di connect wey dem get, PANDEV tok am again about plenty pipo wey dey run alienated and ACF dey do like say dem no know, dem dey ask who di pipo be?

eng: Since the DSS knows them and their satanic mission, they should be proactive in dealing with them.
pcm: Since di DSS know dem and dem satanic waka, make dem take action to take deal with dem.

eng: The NEF sounded unconvinced with if there are people pushing the country into deeper crises and they are known; they should be treated according to the law.
pcm: Di NEF sound like pesin wey no dey convinced with if say pipo dey wey dey push di kontri enter deep crises  and dem know dem, make dem treat dem accordin to di law.

eng: You don't have to be a spook to know what the DSS knows about each and all of these flag bearers of geo-ethnic politics in Nigeria or to understand why they all know that DSS knows them yet they insist on passing the buck outside their cliques.
pcm: You no need to be spook to know wetin di DSS sabi about dis flag bearers of geo-ethnic politics for Nigeria or to understand why dem all know say DSS sabi dem yet dem insist to pass di buck outside dem clique.

eng: The truth is that these champions of ethnic politics know of no better solution to Nigeria's myriad problems than for their sectional enclaves and chiefs to lord it over the rest of the country as rulers, not leaders!
pcm: Di truth be say dis pipo wey dey champion ethnic politics no sabi any better solution to di problem wey Nigeria dey face than make dem sectional enclave and chief dey lord am ova di remainin of di kontri as rulers, not leaders!

eng: So desperate and unscrupulous are they in pursuing their inordinate ambitions that they absurdly and frequently agitate for break-up of Nigeria.
pcm: Dem dey desperate and unscrupulous to pursue dem inordinate ambition dem dat dem dey agitate absurdly and frequently to take break Nigeria up.

eng: Ambition-powered mind games intoxicate their geographical consciousness to reduce all it takes to excising the territorial contours of their enclaves with the frenzied ease of cutting their portion of the remaining crumbs of the proverbial national cake.
pcm: Ambition-powered mind games intoxicate dia geographical consciousness to reduce all it takes to excising di territorial contours of dia enclaves with di frenzied ease of cutting dia portion of di remaining crumbs of di proverbial national cake.

eng: But, for the land-locked ACF/NEF agitators and their Afenifere antagonists, the only way out of a broken up Nigeria is to cascade down a mega sink hole, if their myopic manoeuvres are not to lead to a suicidal breaking into neighbouring Benin and Niger republics, currently hosting herds of gunmen, turbaned terrorists  and ISWAP insurgents on border patrol.

Simply put, breaking up or out of Nigeria as an ultimate political panacea or consolatory opportunity to achieve inordinate ambitions of persons or groups restlessly undermining aspirations of majority wa-zo-bia Nigerian commoners for enduring peaceful coexistence, is easier said than done.
pcm: To put am simple, to break up or out of Nigeria as one ultimate political panacea or consolatory opportunity to achieve inordinate ambition of pipo or group wey dey undermine di ambition of majority wa-zo-bia Nigeria commoner restlessly for enduring peaceful coexistence, e easy to tok pass to do.

eng: These regional groups actually constitute major hindrances to the steady attainment of unity and peaceful coexistence that Nigeria has been labouring for since flag independence.
pcm: All dis group be major block to di steady attainment of unity and to dey live together in peace wey Nigeria don dey labour for since flag of independence.

eng: For as long as they continue to parade the political terrain as ethnic champions, for so long will they regard Nigeria as an entitlement for their ethnic stake in the population, to be claimed or seized and, if all else fails, deconstructed and disowned as a failed state.
pcm: For as long as dem kontinu to parade di political terrain as ethnic champions, na for so long wey dem go regard Nigeria as an entitlement for dem ethnic stake for di population, to be claimed or seized, and if all fail, make dem deconstruct am and disown am as state wey don fail.

eng: Whenever they meet, the agenda is not for Nigeria's progress and development, unless its leadership is firmly in their grasp, otherwise it is all about heckling and jostling around with barely concealed determination to deploy the notorious Nigerian Ph.d, pull-him-down syndrome against the incumbent non-indigene President.
pcm: Whenever dem meet, di agenda no be for say make Nigeria for progress and develop, unless di leadership dey dem hand firmly, odawise na all about hecking and jostling around wit barely concealed determination to deploy di notorious Nigerian Ph.d, pull-him-down syndrome against di incumbent non-indigene President.

eng: Whether it is ACF, Afenifere, Ohanaeze, PANDEV or Northern Elders Forum, their existence and activities will always be antithetical to Nigeria's quest for unity, peace and development.
pcm: Whether na ACF, Afenifere, Ohanaeze, PANDEV or Northern Elders Forum, dem existence and activities go dey oppose di quest of Nigeria for unity, peace and development.

eng: Another undeniable indictment of these regional separatists is that they are all self-styled political pressure groups masquerading as representatives of various ethnic groups.
pcm: Anoda indicment wey we no fit deny for dis regional separatist be say all of dem na sel-styled political pressure groups wey dey pretend like representative of various ethnic groups dem.

eng: From their membership, it is plain to see that they consist of ex-this
pcm: From di membership, E dey plain to see dat dey consist of ex-this

eng: Ironically, this political deficiency gives them the impetus to come together, desperate to remain relevant in a democratic system run entirely by elected representatives through registered political parties with legislative and executive institutions constitutionally established to dispense good governance and dividends of democracy.
pcm: Ironically, dis political deficiency give dem di ginger to kom togeda, desperate say make dem remain relevant for democratic system wey elected representative dey run through registered political parti dem wit  legislative and executive institution wey dem establish wit constitution to take dispense good governance and dividends of democracy.

eng: The geo-ethnic groups only have a nasty nuisance value in our democratic setting as they persist in acts of mischief, sabotage, blackmail and subversion, all brazenly intended to make Nigeria ungovernable as they often threaten and attempt,  so that, perchance, they can regain political relevance if not control.
pcm: Na only nasty nuisance value wey di geo-ethnic groups dem get for awa democratic setin as dem kontinu with mischief, sabotage, blackmail and subversion wey dem intend to take make Nigeria ungovernable as dem dey threaten and dem dey attempt so dat if dem get chance dem fit regain political relevance plus kontrol.

eng: That is why their frequent clandestine meetings trigger security alerts!
pcm: Na why dem frequesnt meetin don dey cause security alert!

eng: With such predator-politicians lurking around the perimeters of power with dubious intent of undermining an elected government just because they are not involved, it is beyond reasonable doubt that there must be a convergence of interest linking their overt activities and the covert criminalities of kidnappers, insurgents, armed robbers, bandits and allied terrorists, combined to make Nigeria ungovernable.
pcm: Wit dis kind predator-politician dem wey dem dey waka ariund di perimeter of power wit dubious intent and dem dey undermine goment wey dem elect just bikos say dem no dey involved for di, e dey beyond reasonable doubt say convergence of interest dey wey dey link dem overt activity dem and di covert criminality of kidnappers, insurgents, armed robbers, bandits and allied terrorists, combine to take make Nigeria no dey governable.

eng: Double jeopardy aptly describes the predicament of the Buhari administration having to contend with such array of formidable foes unleashing incessant assaults on national security in a time of unprecedented economic adversity.
pcm: Na double danger fit describe di tryin situation of di Buhari administration as dem get to handle such nomba of formidable enemy wey dey unleash plenty assaults on national security for di time wey economy dey face new difficult things.

eng: To that extent, there can only be two groups of politicians: those who are positively participating in the democratic dispensation as partners in moving the nation forward against all odds and those who are negatively engaged in sowing seeds of discord and disorder to destabilize the country.
pcm: To dat extent, only two group of politician fit dey: dos wey dey participate with positive mind for di democratic dispensation wey dem be partner for movin di kontri forward against all odds and dos wey get negative mind wey dey bring discord and disorder to take distabilize di kontri.

eng: By their utterances and activities, we all know them!
pcm: By wetin dem dey tok and wetin dem dey do, we all sabi dem!

eng: At the end of the day, the majority of Nigerians are ordinary citizens whose conditions of survival were not determined by and not dependent on the geography of their origin.
pcm: At di end of di day, di majority fo Naija pipo be ordinary citizen wey dem condition to take survive no dey follow or depend on top wia dem come from.

eng: Their daily struggles to eke a living are sustained by submission to the will of One God irrespective of differences of faith.
pcm: Dem struggle evri day to make livin dey follow dem submission to di will of one God even as dem faith dey different.

eng: Nigeria is their destined fatherland to which they remain loyal, law abiding and prayerful, knowing they have no other country to call theirs, collectively showing how citizenship breeds true patriotism.
pcm: Nigeria na dem fatherland wey destiny don put dem, and dem remain loyal, dem dey follow and dem dey pray, bkos dem know say dem no get any othe kontri to call dem own, togeda dem dey show how citizenship go fit breed true patriotism.

eng: They too know that Afenifere, Arewa Consultative Forum (ACF), Ohanaeze Ndigbo, Northern Elders Forum (NEF) and Pan Niger Delta Forum (PANDEF) resort to inciting, unguarded and divisive statements and activities to pit citizens against one another in order to inflame the embers of tribal and religious discord for the political ambitions of their leaders.
pcm: Dem also know say Afenifere,  Arewa Consultative Forum (ACF), Ohanaeze Ndigbo, Northern Elders Forum (NEF) and Pan Niger Delta Forum (PANDEF) don dey use incitin, unguarded and divisive statements and activities to take put citizen against one anoda say make dem fit put fire for di tribal and religious wahala for di political ambition of dem leaders.

eng: Hence the poor man's prayer remains:
pcm: Di prayer wey remain for poor man mouth na:

eng: GOD DEY,
pcm: GOD DEY,

eng: NIGERIA GO BETTER!
pcm: NIGERIA GO BETTER!

eng: Manzo Reuben is a youth leader in Lokoja
pcm: Manzo Reuben na youth leader for inside Lokoja

eng: 10 killed as terrorists attempt to attack army formation
pcm: 10 die as terrorist attempt to attack army formation

eng: Troops of the Nigerian Army, on Saturday, neutralised not less than 10 members of Boko Haram terrorists who attempted to launch an attack on troops of Operation Hadin Kai in Rann, the headquarters of Kala Balge Local Government Area of Borno State.
pcm: Troops for inside di Nigerian Army, for Saturday, dem netralise not less 10 Boko Haram terrorist member dem wey wan attack troop of Operation Hadin Kai for Rann, wey be headquarter of Kala Balge Local Goment Area for inside Borno state.

eng: This is coming barely 24 hours after the newly appointed Chief of Army Staff, Maj.-Gen.
pcm: Dis one dey come when e neva too pass 24 hours wey di Chief of Army Staff wey dem just appoint, Maj.-Gen.

eng: Farouk Yahaya, assumed leadership of the Nigerian Army.
pcm: Farouk Yahaya enter as leader for Nigerian Army.

eng: The spokesman of the Nigerian Army, Brig.-Gen.
pcm: Di toktok manfor di  Nigerian Army, Brig.-Gen.

eng: Mohammed Yerima, in a statement made available, explained that the terrorists, who came in their numbers, mounted on gun trucks and attempted to infiltrate the main entrance to the town.
pcm: Mohammed Yerima, for inside one statement wey dey available, explain say di terrorist, wey kom for plenty number,  carry  gun trucks put for ground and attempt to infiltrate di main entrance to di town.

eng: Yerima said, The highly spirited troops were right on hand to counter the move and inflicted a humiliating defeat on the terrorists who abandoned their evil mission and took to their heels.
pcm: Yerima tok say, di troops wey dey for high spirit dey right on hand to take counter di move and dem carry humiliatin defeat give di terrorists wey abandoned dem evil mission and run.

eng: The troops chased the retreating terrorist and ensured there was no further threat to the town and its residents.
pcm: Di troops be chase di runaway terrorist and make sure say no threat dey fortown and pipo wey dey there.

eng: Troops successfully destroyed one of the gun trucks and recovered multiple weapons including one anti-aircraft gun, two machine guns and eight AK-47 rifles neutralising ten terrorists in the process.
pcm: Troops dem destroy one of dem gun truck successfully and dem kolekt plenty weapon wey include one anti-aircraft gun, two machine gun and eight AK-47 rifflr as dem neutralise ten terrorist inside di process.

eng: Daily Trust reports that the Chief of Defence Staff, Gen. Lucky Irabor, had on Friday charged the new COAS to ensure he built on late Attahiru's legacy by defeating enemies terrorising the Northeast and other regions of the country.
pcm: Daily Trust be report say Chief of Defence Staff,  Gen. Lucky Irabor, for Friday charge di new COAS to make sure say he build on top di legacy of late Attahiru as e go defeat di enemy wey dey do terror inside Northesat and oda region for di kontri.

eng: Second U.S. congresswoman tests positive for COVID-19 after Capitol unrest
pcm: Second U.S congresswoman don test positive to take get COVID-19 afta di Capitol wahala

eng: Pramila Jayapal, a member of the U.S. House of Representatives, said she contracted the Coronavirus (COVID-19) after being locked down in the same room with a number of Republican lawmakers who refused to wear masks during the unrest in the Capitol last week.
pcm: Pramila Jayapal, wey be member for U.S. House of Representatives, tok say she contact di Coronavirus (COVID-19) afta dem lock am for di same room with some Republican lawmaker dem wey no wear mask durin di wahala for di Capitol last week.

eng: I just received a positive COVID-19 test result after being locked down in a secured room at the Capitol where several Republicans not only cruelly refused to wear a mask but recklessly mocked colleagues and staff who offered them one, Jayapal said in a post on her official Twitter account.
pcm: I just kolekt COVID-19 test wey dey positive afta dem lock me down for one secure room fot di Capitol wia plenty Republican wey no be say dem wicked not to wear mask but dem mock colleagues and staff wey offer dem mask recklessly, Jayapal tok am for one post on top her official Twitter account.

eng: Earlier on Monday, U.S. Congresswoman Bonnie Watson Coleman said she also contracted COVID-19 following possible exposure during the lockdown in the Capitol on Jan. 6.
pcm: Earlier for Monday, U.S. Congresswoman Bonnie Watson Coleman tok say she sef contract COVID-19 with possible exposure durin by di time of di lockdown for inside di Capitol for Jan. 6.

eng: Jayapal, who is a member of the Democratic Party, accused the Republican lawmakers of causing a COVID-19 superspreader event and called for punishment against them.
pcm: Jayapal, wey be member of di Democratic Parti accuse di lawmakers dem from di Republican say dem cause make COVID-19 spread welwel and tok say make dem punish dem.

eng: Any member who refuses to wear a mask should be fully held accountable for endangering our lives because of their selfish idiocy.
pcm: Any member wey refuse to wear face mask na im dem go hold accountable say e dey put awa life for danger bikos of say e dey sefish and na idiot.

eng: m calling for every single member who refuses to wear a mask in the Capitol to be fined and removed from the floor by the Sergeant at Arms, she said in a post on Twitter.
pcm: I dey call for every member wey refuse to wear mask for di Capitol say make dem fine dem and make Sergeant of Arms remove dem from di floor, na s she tok for one post on Twitter.

eng: It is unclear if the two congresswomen were in the same room during the lockdown in the Capitol.
pcm: E no dey clear if di two congresswomen dem dey inside di same room durin di lockdown for inside di Capitol.

eng: Jayapal decried U.S. President Donald Trump's failure to contain the COVID-19 pandemic in the U.S. and vowed to do everything in her power to remove him from office.
pcm: Jayapal no hapi as U.S Presido Donald Trump fail to contain di COVID-19 pandemic for inside di U.S and vow say she go do evritin for her power to remove am from office.

eng: Man, 30, arraigned over assault on  woman in Edo
pcm: Dem don arraing one man wey be 30 years ova as dem take assault woman for Edo

eng: The police have arraigned one Gabriel  Fidelis, 30, before an Ogbeson chief magistrates court in Benin for allegedly assaulting a woman identified as Rebecca Izevbigie.
pcm: Di police don arraign one Gabriel Fidelis wey be 30 years before Ogbeson chief magistrates court for Benin say dem allege say im assault one woman wey be Rebecca Izevbigie.

eng: The accused was  arraigned on a three-count charge of conspiracy, unlawful assault and malicious damage punishable under sections, 516, 355, and 451 of the Criminal Code.
pcm: Dem accuse di man on three charges wey be conspiracy, unlaful assault and malicious damage wey dey punishable under section 516, 355, and 451 of di criminal code.

eng: The prosecutor, Sgt. Kehinde  Iyare, told the court that  the accused conspired with others at large to commit the offence on April  11, at Estate Quarters, along Benin-Agbor Road, Benin City.
pcm: Di prosecutor, Sgt. Kehinde Iyare tell di court say di accuse join  oda pipo wey don run to take commit di offence for April 11, for Estate Quarters, along Benin-Agbor Road, for Benin City.

eng: She further told the court that the accused, with others now at large, unlawfully assaulted one Rebecca Izevbigie by hitting and biting her.
pcm: She tell di court further say di accuse, with oda wey don run assault one Rebecca Izevbigie unlawfully by hittin and bittin her.

eng: She added that the accused also used iron rod to break her leg.
pcm: She be add say di accussed also use iron rod to break her for leg.

eng: She further told the court that on March 31, 2021 the defendant did  intentionally and maliciously damage one of the complainants wash hand basins valued at N8,000.
pcm: She further tell di court say for March 31, 2021 di accuse intentionally and maliciously spoil wash hand basin wey be di complainant own and di thing na N8,000.

eng: The accused, however, pleaded not guilty to the charge while his counsel, Mrs  E. E Idahosa, applied for his bail, saying    he would not jump bail.
pcm: Di accuse beg say im no guilty as di counsel Mrs E. E Idahosaapply for im bail and she tok say he no go jump bail.

eng: Thereafter, Chief Magistrate Mutairu Oare, granted the accused bail in the sum of N100,000 with one surety.
pcm: Wetin follow be say, Chief Magistrate Mutairu Oare grant bail for di accuse for di sum of N100,000 with one pesin wey go stand for am.

eng: He said the surety must deposit two recent passport photographs of himself and that of the defendant with the court.
pcm: He tok say di pesin wey go stand with am must bring two recent passport photo of imsef and dat of di accuse.

eng: He ordered  that the Court registrar should verify the information supplied about the surety's residence and adjourned the case to May 10, for hearing.
pcm: He give order say make di court registrar verift di informate wey dem supply and di place wey di surety dey live, he kom adjourn di case to May 10 for hearin.

eng: Why National Assembly can't impeach Buhari Oyo Senator
pcm: Why National Assembly no fit impeach Buhari Senator for Oyo

eng: The Senator representing Oyo North Senatorial District, Fatai Buhari, has said the National Assembly is yet to see a reason to impeach President Muhammadu Buhari.
pcm: Di Senator wey dey represent Oyo North Senatorial District wey be Fatai Buhari don tok di National Assembly neva see reason to take impeach President Muhammadu Buhari.

eng: The senator who stated this when he paid a Sallah visit to a former governor of Oyo State, Rashidi Ladoja, said there is a process for impeaching a president.
pcm: Do senator tok dis one wen im be pay Salah visit to former govnor for inside Oyo state, Rashidi Ladoja, he tok say e get process wey dem take impeach president.

eng: Senator Buhari's submission is coming a day after Senator Yusuf Abubakar Yusuf (APC Taraba) and chairman of senate committee on special duties said impeaching President Buhari would not end insecurity in the country.
pcm: Senator Buhari submission dey kom one day afta Senator Yusuf Abubakar (APC Taraba) and Cahir for Senate committee on top special duty tok say to komot president Buhari no go end insecurity for di kontri.

eng: There have been calls for President Buhari's resignation or impeachment following the spate of insecurity in the country.
pcm: Pipo don dey call say make President Buhari resign or make dem impeach am as insecurity dey di kontri.

eng: But Senator Buhari has asked those calling for secession in the country not to create a problem that would not be easily solved.
pcm: But Senator Buhari don tell d pipo wey wey want make di kontri break say make dem no create problem wey no go easy to solve.

eng: Impeaching the president has a process.
pcm: E get process wey dem dey take impeach president.

eng: Anybody calling for the impeachment of the president should give a genuine reason that warrants the impeachment.
pcm: Make anibodi wey dey call say make dem impeach di president give better reason wey reach to do impeachement.

eng: We are yet to see a reason to impeach the president.
pcm: We neva see reasin to take impeach di president.

eng: If there is a need, then, we shall table it, discuss it and the two houses must come together.
pcm: If need dey, we go table am, discuss am, and di two houses must kom togeda.

eng: Impeaching the president is not what someone will just wake up one day and call for.
pcm: To impeach di president no be wetin one pesin go just wake up one day and begin tok.

eng: There is a procedure for it.
pcm: E get procedure.

eng: Why do you want to cause a problem and create confusion that you cannot solve?
pcm: Why you wan cause problem plus confusion wey you no fit solve?

eng: he queried.
pcm: Na so e ask

eng: Speaking on the security challenges bedevilling the country, the lawmaker said; We have no other country than Nigeria.
pcm: On top di security wahala wey di kontri dey face, di lawmaker tok say; we no get anoda kontri pass Nigeria

eng: Nigeria is our country and our home.
pcm: Nigeria na awa kontri and home.

eng: We should try to do internal security.
pcm: Make we try to do internal security

eng: We should play our own part; we should not leave everything to the government alone.
pcm: Make we play awa own part; make we no leave everothing give government alone.

eng: There should be local police that will be able to know the terrain.
pcm: We suppose put local police wey go know all di places dem.

eng: We know ourselves no matter how it can be.
pcm: No matter how e take be, we sabi each oda.

eng: In the early 80s, we used to travel at night.
pcm: For early 80s, we dey travel for nite.

eng: But the level of insecurity in the country, something fundamental is missing.
pcm: But for di level wey insecurity dey now, something wey dey fundamental dey miss.

eng: He disclosed that the 9th National Assembly had discussed the security issue for over 50 times.
pcm: He tok say di 9th National Assembly don discuss security , pass 59 times.

eng: We discussed the security issue over 30 times in the 8th Assembly, and this present 9th Assembly has also discussed it over 50 times.
pcm: We be discuss security issue pass 30 times for di 8th Assembly, and dis 9th Assembly sef don discuss am pass 50 times.

eng: Let everybody be vigilant, even if we change our service chiefs many times, that cannot solve our security challenges, the senator said.
pcm: Make evribodi dey vigilant, even if change service chief plenty times, e still no go solve di security problem, as di senator tok,

eng: Ranchers back CBN's forex restriction for dairy imports
pcm: Ranchers dem don support as CBN take put restriction for forex on top import of dairy

eng: The Commercial Ranchers Association of Nigeria (CODARAN) has expressed support for the restriction placed on access to foreign exchange for dairy products.
pcm: Di Commercial Ranchers Association of Nigeria (CODARAN) don show  support for di restriction wey dem carry give  foreign exchange for dairy products dem.

eng: Recall that the Central Bank of Nigeria (CBN) issued a circular over a year ago on restricted companies seeking foreign exchange through the official window to import milk and dairy products.
pcm: Remember say di Central Bank of Nigeria don issue one circular wey don pass one year now on top company dem wey dem don restrict from foreign exchange to take import milk and dairy product dem.

eng: But during a recent visit to the governor of the CBN, Godwin Emefiele, the Director-General of the World Trade Organisation (WTO), Dr Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala, said the European Union (EU) had filed a complaint against Nigeria over the restriction.
pcm: But durin one visit wey dem do to di governo of Di CBN recently, di Director-General of di World Trade Organisation (WTO), Dr Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala, tok say di European Union (EU) don complian against Nigeria ova dat restriction.

eng: In a statement by Dianabasi Akpainyang, the CODARAN noted that Nigeria had the potential to harvest dairy products that would provide jobs and create investments in local production of milk.
pcm: For inside one statement wey  Dianabasi Akpainyang, wey be di CORAN tok say Nigeria be get di potential to take harvest dairy products dem wey go provide job plus create investment for local production of milk.

eng: The CBN governor is right.
pcm: Di CBN governor dey korekt.

eng: Nigeria truly has the potential to sustainably meet its dairy requirements.
pcm: True true Nigeria be get di potential to take meet, plus sustain di dairy requirement.

eng: Akpainyang noted that the milk available for collection and processing may not be anywhere near the figure at the moment, but pointed out that since the likelihood is there, it is necessary for everyone to put their feet on fire due to the urgency required to develop the local dairy sector.
pcm: Akpainyang tok say di milk wey ground for collection and processing no near that figure for now, but he note say since e dey likely, e dey necessary make evribodi put leg for fire seek of say di development of local dairy sector dey urgent.

eng: While citing a report by the CBN that Nigeria spends about $1.5billion on importing dairy products annually, he said the figure would increase as the demand for dairy products increased.
pcm: As e dey cite one report wey komot for inside CBN say Nigeria dey spend $1.5 billion evri year to take import dairy products dem, he tok say di figure go increase as demand for dairy products sef dem dey increase.

eng: He identified issues like poor productivity of local cattle breeds, cattle nutrition, animal disease management systems, lack of organised milk collection processes, limited access to finance, insecurity, poor infrastructure, insufficient extension services, inadequate processing and storage facilities, low investment in research and development and minimal adoption of modern technology as the major problems bedevilling the sector.
pcm: He be mention issue like poor productivity of local cow dem, cow nutrition, animal disease management system, as dem no get better organised system to tke kolekt milk, as dem no dey too get finance,insecurity, poor infrastructure, insufficient extension services, inadequate processing and storage facilities, low investment in research and development and and as dem no dey too dey use modern technology say na dem be di major problem wey sector dey face.

eng: He, however, said the problems were tackled by the Advancing Local Dairy Development in Nigeria (ALDDN) programme, which is currently running in four states Adamawa, Kaduna, Kano and Plateau.
pcm: However, he tok say di Advancing Local Dairy Development in Nigeria (ALDDN) programme wey dey run presently for inside four states Adamawa, Kaduna, Kano and Plateau  don dey tackle di problem.

eng: PDP kicks as APC claims registering 2.5m in Lagos
pcm: PDP frown face as APC claim say dem don register 2.5m for inside Lagos.

eng: There is uproar following the disclosure by the All Progressives Congress (APC) that it registered 2.5 million members in Lagos during the nationwide registration and revalidation exercise.
pcm: Uproar dey follow as di All Progressives Congress (APC) don disclose say dem register 2.5m members for Lagos for dem nationwide and revalidation exercise.

eng: Chairman of the APC Lagos Registration Supervisory Committee, Dr. Muhammad Bashiru, had said during the closing and presentation of recommendation letters to the supervisors that about 2.5 million members were registered across the 20 local government areas in the state.
pcm: Chaiman for di APC  Registration Supervisory Committee for inside Lagos  Dr. Muhammad Bashiru, tok for di closing of recommendation letter for di supervisor say about 2.5 million don register for di 20 local government area for inside di state.

eng: But the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) which is the leading opposition party, described the figure as false and fake.
pcm: But di People Democractic Parti (PDP) wey be di leading opposition parti, don describe di figure as false and fake.

eng: PDP said APC was in the habit of concocting figures to give an impression of acceptability.
pcm: PDP tok say APC get habit to dey cook figure to make pipo believe say dem dey popular.

eng: The PDP spokesman, Taofik Gani, in a chat with Daily Trust described the APC as a party of liars, saying it had become unpopular in the state.
pcm: Di toktok pesin for PDP, wey be Taofik Gani, for inside one chat with Daily Trust be describe di APC as a parti wey be say na liars full am, he tok say di parti no popular again for inside di state.

eng: This is not the first time they would be bandying figures around which are false.
pcm: Dis one no be di first time wey dem dey carry figures wey no be true komot.

eng: Even in the last election, the total number of votes by APC was around 600,000.
pcm: Even for di last election, di total nomba of vote wey APC get dey around 600,000.

eng: The 2.5 million claim is false and fake, he said.
pcm: He tok say di claim say dem get 2.5 million na false and fake.

eng: Our correspondent report say APC candidate Babajide Sanwo-Olu win di governorship election for 2019 with 739,445 votes while President Muhammadu Buhari get 580,825 vote for di presidential election.
pcm: Our correspondent report say APC candidate Babajide Sanwo-Olu win di governorship election for 2019 with 739,445 votes while President Muhammadu Buhari get 580,825 vote for di presidential election.

eng: Also speaking, the state chairman of National Conscience Party (NCP), Comrade Bayo Ogunleye, described the claim by the APC as the greatest lie of the century.
pcm: Di state chairman of National Conscience Parti (NCP), Wey be Comrade Bayo Ogunleye, don describe di claim by di APC s di lie wey great pass for di century.

eng: But APC spokesman Seye Oladejo told our correspondent that the party would prove its numerical strength in the forthcoming July 24 local government election.
pcm: But di toktok pesin for APC Seye Oladejo tell awa correspondent say di parti go prove say dem get nomba for di local goment election wey dey kom for July 24.

eng: Geographical Indication will promote diversification of economy  FG
pcm: FG tok say Geographical Indication go promote diversification of economy

eng: The Federal Government has stressed that Geographical Indications (GIs) will help in promoting diversification of the economy and also support participation in the African Continental Free Trade Area.
pcm: Di Federal Goment don stress say Geographical Indications (GIs) go help in promoting diversification of di economy and also support participation for di African Continental Free Trade Area.

eng: The Minister of Agriculture and Rural Development, Sabo Nanono, made this known at the capacity building workshop on GIs for public sector/policymakers in Nigeria in Abuja.
pcm: Di Minister of Agriculture and Rural Development, wey be Sabo Nanono tok this one for inside di capacity building workshop on top GIs for public sector /policymakers for Nigeria in Abuja.

eng: Nanono, who was represented by the Deputy Director of Irrigation and Crop development, Haija Sugra Mahmood, noted that the initiative if properly harnessed, will also support the preservation of the country's biodiversity that is facing an existential threat from the effects of climate change and the attendant destruction of the environment.
pcm: Nanono wey di Deputy Director of Irrigation and Crop Development, Hajia Sugra Mahmood represent, note say if dem use di initiative welwel,  go support di preservation of di biodiversity of di kontri wey don dey face existential threat as effect of climate change and di attendant destruction of di environment.

eng: According to him, it can assist in commercializing the products of food culture and other aspects of culture thus enabling the value chain actors to benefit from the commercialization, especially women and youth in the rural space who are mainly involved in the production of these products.
pcm: As e take talk, e fit assist for commercializin di product of food culture and oda culture and e go enable actors dem for  di value chain to benefit from commercialization, especially for women and youth wey dey for rural area who are mainly involved in di production of di products dem.

eng: Therefore, this workshop comes at a crucial moment when this administration is working tirelessly to diversify the country's economy away from Hydrocarbons, by promoting other sectors such as Agriculture, Manufacturing, Mining, Tourism etc.
pcm: Therefore, dis workshop dey happen for crucial moment when dis administration dey work tirelessly to take diversify di economy away from hydrocabons by oda sectors dem like agriculture, manufacturing, mining tourism etc.

eng: Initiatives such as this that promote the GIs will help to fast track the processes in the diversification of the economy and also support our participation in the African Continental Free Trade Area as well as globally.
pcm: Dis kind initiative wey dey promote GIs go help to fast track di process for diversification of di economy and also support awa participation for di African Continental Free Trade Area and also globally.

eng: GIs can be catalytic in reviving the rural economy as we have seen it happen in the case of some products that have been properly branded such as Ofada Rice, Kilishi, Dudu Osun, etc.
pcm: Gis fit kos to revive economy for rural area as we don see am apun for inside di case of some product dem wey dem don brand properly such as Ofada rice, kilishi, Dudu Osun, etc.

eng: It will also enable the documentation of our indigenous knowledge which sadly we are losing as time passes.
pcm: E go also make am di documwntation of awa indigenous knowledge wey be say e sad as we dey loose over time.

eng: The current administration stands ready to partner with all the relevant stakeholders both local and foreign in its bid to preserve the natural and bio-cultural diversity endowment in the country and also exploit it to strengthen the resilience of the economy, so as to provide a decent livelihood for all Nigerians, he stated.
pcm: Di current administration dey ready to partner wit all di stakeholder dem wey dey relevant both local and foreign in dem bid to preserve di natural and bio-cultural endowment for di kontri amd also exploit am to strengthen di resilience of di economy, so as to provide a decent livelyhood for all Nigeria pipo, as e state am.

eng: Earlier, the Minister of State Industry, Trade and Investment, Haija Mariam Katagum, in her welcome address, said that the workshop is specifically designed to train Public Sector and Policy Makers in Nigeria, with a view to examining the possibilities of adopting Geographical Indications (GIs) legislation and policy into Nigeria's industrial property and agricultural landscape.
pcm: Earlier, di Minister for Satte Industry, Trade and Investment, Haija Mariam Katagum, for her welkom address tok say dem design di workshop to specifically train public sector and pipo wey be policy maker for Nigeria, with view of say dem wan examine how e go take possible to adopt Geographical Indication (Gis) legislation and policy enter industrial property and agriculture landscape for Nigeria.

eng: She said that it is imperative to also highlight the coming into effect of the African Continental Free Trade Area Agreement (AfCFTA), which puts a responsibility on decision-makers, to begin the discourse of updating industrial property legislation.
pcm: She tok say we no fit avoid as di African Continental Free Trade Agreement (AfCFTA) dey kom into effect, wey dey put responsibility on top pipo wey dey make decision to begin dey tok about as dem go update legislation wey concern industrial property.

eng: Israeli president holds talks in search for new govt
pcm: President for Israel don hold tok to take find new govt

eng: Israel's President Reuven Rivlin is preparing for talks with top politicians on forming a government after caretaker Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu failed to do so following inconclusive elections in March.
pcm: President for Israel Reuven Rivlin don dey prepare for tok wit top politics pipo on how t take form goment afta caretaker Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu no gree to do am afta election for match no dey conclusive.

eng: According to Rivlins office, talks with Naftali Bennett of the Yamina party and the former opposition leader Yair Lapid of the Yesh Atid (Future) party is scheduled for Wednesday morning.
pcm: According to Rivlins office, talks wit Naftali Bennett of di Yamina parti and former opposition leader Yair Lapid of di Yesh Atid (Future) parti dey schedule for wednesday morning.

eng: The head of state also invited representatives of the other parties represented in parliament to present their positions on the progress of the government formation process.
pcm: Di head of state also invite representatives dem from di oda parti wey dem represent for parliament to present dem positions on di progress of di process to take form government.

eng: A deadline for right-winger Netanyahu to form a governing coalition expired overnight.
pcm: Na last nite di deadline for Natanyahu weu be right-winger to form a governin coalition.

eng: This means that the camp of Netanyahu's opponents is facing a chance to end the 71-year-old era as head of government.
pcm: Dis one mean say di camp of pipo wey be opponent to Netanyahu dey face chance to end di era of di 71-year old as heaf for goment.

eng: Whether they will succeed, however, is still completely open.
pcm: Whether dem go succeed, however, e still dey open.

eng: A new election is still not out of the question as Israel remains in a political crisis.
pcm: New election still no dey out di question as Israel still dey inside political crisis.

eng: Netanyahu remains at the head of an interim government for the time being.
pcm: Netanyahu go remain as head for di interim goment as time dey go.

eng: He has been in office continuously for 12 years and is the longest-serving head of government in Israel's history.
pcm: E don dey for office for 12 years continously and na im be d longest serving head of goment for Israel history.

eng: A corruption trial is underway against him,he, however, rejects the accusations made in it.
pcm: Dem don dey do trial for am say im corrupt, he don reject all di accuse wey dem accuse am.

eng: It was expected that Rivlin might appoint opposition leader Lapid to form the government.
pcm: Dem dey expect say make Rilvin appoint Lapid wey be opposition leader to form head for di goment.

eng: His party belongs to the political centre; at the end of March, it became the second-strongest force in the fourth parliamentary election in two years.
pcm: Na im parti be political centre; for di end of match, e don bikom di second-strongest force for di forth parliamentary election for inside two years.

eng: Rivlin could also give the mandate to the Knesset.
pcm: Rivlin fit also give di mandate to di Knesset.

eng: In this case, each Member of Parliament can try to find the support of 61 of the 120 members within 21 days.
pcm: For dis case, each member for di parliament fit try to find di support of 61 of di 120 members withing 21 days.

eng: Ganduje frees 123 prison inmates for eid-el-Fitr
pcm: Ganduje don free 123 prisoner for eid-el-Fitri

eng: Gov. Abdullahi Ganduje of Kano has granted freedom to 123 prison inmates across the state.
pcm: Gov. Abdullahi Ganduje of Kano don grant freedom to 123 prison inmates across di state.

eng: Ganduje, who witnessed the release of the inmates from Goron Dutse Prison on Thursday, said the gesture was in the spirit of the Eid-El Fitr celebration.
pcm: Ganduje wey witness di release of inmates from Goron Dutse Prison on Thursday tok say di gesture na for di spirit of Eid-El Fitr celebration.

eng: He said the beneficiaries were selected based on the gravity of offences and signs of reformation while in prison.
pcm: He tok say na how dem offence wey dem commit take big reach plus how dem don show sign of reformation when dem dey prison na im dem take select pipo.

eng: The governor said that the decision to visit the prison was to show the inmates that the state government was aware of their existence and that they were also regarded as citizens of the state.
pcm: Di governor tok say e decide to show for di prison to tell di inmate say goment for di state know say dem dey exist and dem dey see dem as citizen for di state.

eng: Ganduje said that the gesture was to complement the Federal Government's efforts to further reduce congestion in the nation's prisons.
pcm: Ganduje tok say di gesture na to to compliment di Federal Goment effort to further reduce as pipo dey take jam for national prison dem

eng: He advised the ex-inmates to change their attitudes to life and pray for peace and stability in Nigeria.
pcm: Im advice di former inmate dem say make dem change dem attitude to life and say make dem pray for peace and stability for Nigeria.

eng: The governor also gave each of the freed inmates N5,000 as transport fare to their various destination.
pcm: Di governor also give ₦5,000 to each of di inmate dem wey e free to take waka reach wia dem dey go.

eng: Earlier, the Comptroller of Prisons in Kano, Suleiman Suleiman, thanked the governor for freeing thousands of inmates since his coming into office.
pcm: Earlier, di comptroller of prisons for inside Kano, Suleiman Suleiman, thank di governor say im free thousands of inmate since im don enter office.

eng: Suleiman advised the freed inmates to stay off crime to avoid going back to prison.
pcm: Suleiman be advse di inmate wey dem free say make dem stay away from crime to avoid coming back to prison.

eng: Ganduje also visited remand homes and Kano children's home in the metropolis as part Sallah celebration.
pcm: Ganduje visit remand home dem too plus children home wey dey for Kano as part of im salah celebration.

eng: Korda breaks through on Parma clay
pcm: Korda breaks through for Parma clay

eng: On the eve of Roland Garros, 20-year-old American Sebastian Korda scored a career breakthrough when he beat Italian Marco Cecchinato, 6-2, 6-4, in Parma for a first title.
pcm: On di eve for Roland Garos, Sebastian Korda wey be 20-year old American score one career breakthrough when e beat Italian Marco Cecchinato  6-2, 6-4, for Parma for a first title.

eng: Korda, the son of former world
pcm: Korda wey be son of former world

eng: No 2 and Australian Open winner Petr Korda, had never reached a final on the ATP tour and before the Parma event, had never won consecutive matches on clay.
pcm: No 2 and Australian Open Winner Petr Korda wey neva enter ATP tour final before di event for Parma, e neva win consecutive matches on top clay.

eng: Cecchinato, who won all three of his titles on clay, comes from Brescia, 90 kilometres from Parma.
pcm: Cecchinato, wey win all im three title on top clay, be come from Brescia, wey be 90 kilometres from Parma.

eng: The fans allowed into the first-time event supported for the local boy.
pcm: Di fan dem wey dem allow enter di event for di first time be support di local boy.

eng: Today I played a really tough opponent and the crowd wasn't easy, Korda said.
pcm: Today I play one tough opponent and di no easy, na so Korda tok.

eng: They kept cheering him on, but I'm really proud of myself
pcm: Dem continu to dey cheer am on, but I dey proud for mysef.

eng: and how I handled it.
pcm: and how I  take handle am.

eng: Although his father is Czech, Sebastian Korda, who was born in Florida, chose to represent the US.
pcm: Although im papa na from Czech, Sebastian Korda, wey dem born for Florida decide say na US e go represent.

eng: Saturday's victory made him the first American player to win a clay court tournament since Sam Querrey in Belgrade 11 years ago.
pcm: Di victory make am di first player wey from America kom to win clay court tournament since Sam Querrey for Belgrade afta 11 years.

eng: This is something that I've dreamed of, Korda said, adding that he had expected to win a title sooner, naming an event in Florida in January.
pcm: Dis na sometin wey don dey for my dream, na so Korda tok, as e add say im don expect say im go win title soon as e name one event for Florida in January.

eng: I really thought I was going to get it done in Delray Beach, and I was a little heartbroken.
pcm: I be really thingk say I go do am for Delray Beach, and e break my heart small.

eng: What not to wear in public: Negating Nigeria's multiculturalism
pcm: Wetin dem no suppose wear for public: Negatin Nigeria's multiculturalism

eng: By Bashir Ibrahim Hassan
pcm: By Bashir Ibrahim Hassan

eng: Was it pure coincidence that, as trouble was brewing in Kwara State recently, a solution to its kind was being considered in the lower House of the National Assembly in the capital territory Abuja?
pcm: Shey na pure coincidence say, as trouble be dey smell for inside Kwara state recently, dem dey considr solution to am for lower House for inside di National Assembly for di capital territory wey be Abuja?

eng: The trouble in Ilorin was over the refusal of some Christian faith schools to allow their Muslim students wear hijab to the schools.
pcm: DI trouble wey dey for Ilorin na as dem take refuse of some Christian faith school dem to allow dem muslim student to dey wear hijab kom school.

eng: The solution to this impasse was the debate on the Religious Discrimination (Prohibition, Prevention)
pcm: Di solution for this predicament na di debate on top Religious Discrimination (Prohibition, Prevention)

eng: RDPP Bill, 2021, derisively tagged Hijab Bill by a section of the Nigerian media.
pcm: RDPP Bill, 2021, as dem ridicule Hijab Bill for a section of media for Nigeria.

eng: Both events sparked heated and often emotional debates that, at the bottom of it all, threaten to negate Nigeria's multicultural identity and reality.
pcm: Both event be spark heated argument and often emotional debate wey, at di bottom of evritin, dey threaten to negate multicultural identity and reality of Nigeria.

eng: The whole idea in Kwara of the proprietors of the schools banning hijab-adorning Muslim students and their sympathisers can be reduced to what not to wear in public.
pcm: Di whole idea fpr Kwara of di proprietor of school dem as dem ban Muslim student dem wey dey wear hijab nd dem sympathiser dem fit dey reduced to wetin dem no suppose wear for public.

eng: This is also the major part of the concern of the RDPP Bill before the House of Representatives the humiliation and denial of opportunities
pcm: Dis na anoda major part of di concern of di RDPP Bill before di House of Representative di humiliation and denial of opportunities

eng: female Nigerians are faced with because of what they wear in public.
pcm: Wey female for Nigeria dey face bikos of wetin dem dey wear for public.

eng: The former is clearly in breach of the fundamental human rights of the Muslim students to express their faith without discrimination; even though the school may have their defence for taking such a position.
pcm: E dey clear say di former clearly breach di fundamental human right of di muslim students to take express dem faith without discrimination; even though di school fit get defence or taking dat kind position.

eng: The latter is trying to assert this right not only for Muslims but also Christians wherever or whenever they are threatened with discrimination based on their professed faith.
pcm: Di latter dey try to assert dis right no be for Muslim dem alone but also for Christians wiaver or whenever dem threaten dem wit discrimination bikos of di fauth wey dem show.

eng: Running through the argument of the proprietors of the Christian faith schools in Kwara, one could easily understand the pragmatic appeal of the argument that Muslim children should go to other schools elsewhere if they don't want to conform.
pcm: To run through di argument wey proprietor of Christian faith schools inside Kwara, easy for pesin to understand di pragmatic appeal of di argument say make Muslim children go oda school dem fpr oda pleces if dem no wan conform.

eng: The problems with this argument are many.
pcm: Di problem wey die argument get many.

eng: First, to say Muslim students should go elsewhere unless they conform to the school's rule on uniform does very little to promote inclusiveness, which is the bedrock of our multicultural and multi-religious society.
pcm: First, to tok say make Muslim student dem go anoda place unless dem agree to rule of di school on top uniform dey do very little to promote inclusiveness, wey be di bedrock of awa multicultural and multi-religious society.

eng: Secondly, the position begs the moral question: is it justifiable to base a school rule because of Christian majoritarian nature of the school?
pcm: Secondaly, di position dey ask moral question: shey we fit justify to base rule for school on top di Christian majoritarian of di school?

eng: Then, thirdly, the go elsewhere argument appears to ignore the difficulties in changing a school for a child.
pcm: Then, di third one, di argument o go elsewia appear say e don ignore di difficulty dem wey dey inside changing school for a pikin.

eng: The inconvenience is huge.
pcm: Di inconvenience plenty.

eng: The act of changing schools for a child, educational psychologists will tell you, interferes negatively with not only its emotional but academic development too.
pcm: As dem dey change school for pikin dem, pipo wey dey education psychology go tell you say, e dey interfere negatively with not just emotional but academic development too.

eng: Finally, the Christian faith schools by themselves risk what is called ghettorization by concentrating students with the same religious beliefs in particular schools.
pcm: Finally, di christian faith school by demselves risk wetin we dey call ghettorization by concentrating students with di same religious belief dem for particular schools.

eng: The social cost this exacts on the society is enormous.
pcm: Di social cost wey dis thing go get for society plebty.

eng: The Commissioner for Education, Kemi Adeosun, argues, when speaking to the press, that the government is convinced that its policy to allow willing Muslim schoolgirls to wear their hijab in public schools will lead to sustainable peace and communal harmony anchored on mutual respect and understanding.
pcm: Di Commissioner for Education, Kemi Adeosun, argue, when she dey follow press tok, say di goment dey convinced say dem policy to allow willing Muslim schoolgirls to wear dem hijab for public schools go lead to sustainable peace and communal harmony wey build on top mutual respect and understanding.

eng: In a country that guarantees freedom of religion, signed the declaration of International Human Rights, the basic question to ask is: how justifiable is it to deny a Nigerian child access to a school of its choice on the basis of the manifestation of its religion?
pcm: For inside kontri wey guarantee freedom of religion, wey sign di declaration of international Human Rights, di basic question to ask na: how justifiable e be to deny child for inside Nigeria access to school of dem choice on top di basis of dem religion?

eng: It is a great concern because Nigeria is a signatory to the Universal Declaration on Human Rights (UDHR).
pcm: Na great concern bikos Nigeria na signatory to di Universal Declaration on Human Rights (UDHR).

eng: The UDHR insists that all human beings are free and equal, regardless of colour, creed or religion.
pcm: Di UDHR insists say  all human being dem dey  free and equal, say dem colour, creed or religion no matter.

eng: It contains 30 articles on rights and freedoms that include, among others, civil and political rights, like the right to life, free speech and privacy.
pcm: E contain 30 article dem on top right and freedom wey include, among oda dem, like di rif=ght to life, free speech and privacy.

eng: It also includes economic, social and cultural rights, like the right to health and education.
pcm: E include economy, social and cultural rights, like di right to get health and education.

eng: I find articles 18 and 26 of UDHR very relevant to the issue under consideration and quote them in full below:
pcm: I see article 18 and 26 of UDHR very relevant to di issue wey dey for consideration and we quote dem for full below:

eng: Article 18: Everyone has the freedom to think or believe what they want, including the right to religious belief.
pcm: evribodi get di freedom to thingk or believe wetin dem want, including belief wey be religion own.

eng: We have the right to change our beliefs or religion at any time, and the right to publicly or privately practise our chosen religion, alone or with others.
pcm: We get right to change awa belief or religion any time, and di right to practice awa religion for public pr private, alone or with oda pipo..

eng: Everyone has the right to education.
pcm: evribodi suppose get right to education.

eng: Primary schooling should be free.
pcm: Primary school suppose dey free.

eng: We should all be able to continue our studies as far as we wish.
pcm: We suppose fit kontinu awa studies as far as we get di wish.

eng: At school we should be helped to develop our talents, and be taught an understanding and respect for everyone's human rights.
pcm: For school we suppose dem suppose help us develop awa talents, and make dem dey teach us how to respect evrione human right.

eng: We should also be taught to get on with others whatever their ethnicity, religion, or country they come from.
pcm: Dem also suppose teach us how we go take get on with oda pipo whatever dem ethnicity, religion, or kontri dem kom from.

eng: Our parents have the right to choose what kind of school we go to.
pcm: Our parent get right to choose di kind school wey we go go.

eng: These types of laws were the instruments that gave Muslim ladies like Ilhan Omar the equality to sit in the House of Representatives in the US wearing her Hijab without any form of molestation or discrimination.
pcm: All dis kind law na dem be di instrument wey give Muslim woman dem like Ilhan Omar di equality to take sit for inside di House of Representative for inside US and she still dey wear Hijab without say dem molest or discriminate am.

eng: Ilhan Abdullahi Omar is an American politician serving as the U.S. Representative for Minnesota's 5th congressional district since 2019.
pcm: Ilhan Abdullahi Omarna America politician wey dey serve for di U.S Representative for 5th congregation for  Minnesota district since 2019.

eng: It is a bill sponsored by the Deputy Chairman of the House of Representatives Committee on Finance and member representing Bida/Gbako/Katcha Federal constituency of Niger State, Hon.
pcm: Na di Deputy Chairman for House of Representative Committee on top Finance matter, wey dey represent Bida/Gbako/Katcha Federal constituency for Niger state be sponsor di bill.

eng: Saidu Musa Abdullahi.
pcm: Saidu Musa Abdullahi.

eng: The bill is seeking to address discriminatory conducts and prohibit religious discrimination concerning hiring or recruitment, terms and conditions of employment.
pcm: Di bill dey to address discriminatory conduct dem, plus to prohibit  as dem dey discriminate on top religion matter when e concern as dem dey give pipo work and di terms and condition wey dey follow am.

eng: It will prohibit qualifying/professional bodies, educational institutions, employment agencies, and other sectors from discriminating against persons, students or personnel based on their religious belief or its manifestation.
pcm: E go stop qualifyin and proffesional joinbodi dem, education institution, pipo wey dey do employment and oda sector dem to dey discriminate against person, student or personnel based on dem religion or di manifestation.

eng: When passed, the law will bury issues such as what we saw in Kwara for good.
pcm: When passed, di law will bury issues such as what we saw in Kwara for good. When dem pass am, di law go bury issue wey be like wetin we see for Kwara patapata.

eng: It will also address the bigotry of some employers, or those executives who take their prejudice to public office and allow it to becloud their sense of judgment.
pcm: E go also address di bigot behaviour of executive dem wey dey carry dem prejudice enter public office and dem go still allow am cover dem sense of judgement.

eng: The law should be a welcome development.
pcm: Dem Suppose welkom di law.

eng: After all, it is only to expand and expatiate the provisions of Nigeria's constitution and the UDHR document as explained above.
pcm: After all, na only to expand and expatiate di provision dem wey dey for inside di Nigeria constitution and for UDHR document as we take tok am above.

eng: It is in line with similar laws passed recently in the country seeking to tackle social menace and harmful cultural practice the Disability Law and the Violence Against Persons Prohibition (VAPP).
pcm: E follow line with similar law dem wey dem pass for di kontri to take tackle social wahal and cultural practice dem wey dey harmful di law wey dey Prohibit violence against pipo and disability law (VAPP).

eng: While disability seeks to eradicate all forms of discrimination based on a persons disabilities, VAPP is addressing domestic and other gender-based violence in the country.
pcm: As disability dey try to komot any discrimination wey dey face pipo wey get disability, VAPP dey face domestic plus oda gender violence dem for inside di kontri.

eng: One at a time, our representatives in the legislative chambers are tackling the social menaces bedeviling our country through legal instruments.
pcm: One by one, pipo wey dey represent us for inside di legislative chamber dem don dey use legal instrument dey  tackle all social wahala  wey dey face awa kontri.

eng: They are addressing these social ills not because there were no prior generic laws that cover them but because they need to be addressed more comprehensively to leave no room for opacity.
pcm: Dem dey address all dis social roughness no be to say law be no dey before wey dey address dem, but dem wan carry evritin togeda make dem for no allow see finish.

eng: While UDHR may seem like a far, distant document with no instrument of enforcement, the RDPP Law and others like it are provided to allocate punishments for offenders.
pcm: As e be like say road still far for UDHR, and instrument to take enforce am neva dey, di RDPP law and oda law dem wey resemble am dey ground to carry punishment give offenders.

eng: Contrary to the view of its critics, as far as the RDPP Bill is concerned, there is nothing to show attempts at seeking the enthronement of a state religion on any state that may domesticate the law eventually.
pcm: As e dey contradict di view of critics, as far as di RDPP Bill dey concerned, no prove dey say dem wan dem wan put state of religion on top any state wey fit domesticate di law.

eng: It does not go against Section 10 of the Nigerian Constitution that says The Government of the Federation or of a State shall not adopt any religion as State Religion.
pcm: E no go against Section 10 of di Constitution for Nigeria wey support make Di Goment of do Federation or for State fit no adopt any religion as State Religion.

eng: To peddle this argument, because the bill calls on the general public to respect the rights of Muslim women that wear Hijab in public spaces smacks of Islamophobia only.
pcm: To push di argument, bikos di bill dey call for general public to dey respect di right of womn dem wey be muslim wey dey wear Hijab for public place, say na to only quench Islamaphobia.
