eng: In the final analysis, to deny a Nigerian  male or female  his or her religious freedom negates our multicultural pretenses.
pcm: For di final analysis, e dey go against awa multicultural pretenses to dey deny any Nigerian be it male or female dem religios freedom.

eng: It negates the concept of equality, and basic human right as enshrined in Nigeria's constitution and the Universal Declaration of Human Rights legal document.
pcm: E dey against equality, and basic human right as e take dey inside constitution for Nigeria and di legal document for Universal Declaration of Human Rghts.

eng: A bill that will criminalize such decimations based on religious grounds, like the RDPP bill, is a welcome development.
pcm: Bill wey go make dat kind decimation on religion bikom criminal, like di RDPP bill go get welkom nod.

eng: Bashir wrote from Abuja
pcm: Na from Abuja Bashir dey write.

eng: Nigers President Issoufou wins N1.905bn African leadership prize
pcm: President for Niger Issoufou don win N1.95bn wey be leadership prize for inside Africa

eng: Nigers President Mahamadou Issoufou has been announced the 2020 winner of the $5m (N1.905 billion)
pcm: Dem don announce say na President of Niger wey be Mahamadou Issoufou be winner of $5m (N1.905bn) for 2020

eng: Ibrahim prize for African leadership.
pcm: Ibrahim prize for African leadership.

eng: Issoufou has served two five-year terms as president from 2011 to 2020.
pcm: Issoufou don serve two terms wey be five years each as president from 2011 go enter 2020.

eng: He is set to be succeeded by former interior minister, Mohamed Bazoum, who won the presidential election last month.
pcm: Na Mohamed Bazoum wey be former interior minister go enter office afta am as e take win presidential election last month

eng: The prize committee praised the Nigerien president's leadership after inheriting one of the worlds poorest economies.
pcm: Di committee wey dey give di prize be praise di leadership of di Niger president afta im meet di economy wey dey among di one wey poor pass for di world.

eng: It said he fostered economic growth, shown unwavering commitment to regional stability and to the constitution, and championed African democracy.
pcm: Im tok say he cause economy to grow, say e show better commitment to regional stability and di constitution, and im champion democracy for inside Africa.

eng: Mr Issoufou is the sixth recipient of the Ibrahim Prize.
pcm: Na Mr Issoufou be di nomba six pesin wey go kolekt di Ibrahim Prize.

eng: He has tweeted that the prize honours all Nigerien people.
pcm: He don send tweet say di prize dey honour evribodi for Nigeria.

eng: I consider this award an encouragement to continue to think and act in such a way that promotes democratic values and good governance, not only in Niger, but in Africa and around the world, he added.
pcm: I see dis award as ecncouragement to take kontinu to thingk and act in way wey be say e go dey promote democracy value and better goment, no be for Niger alone, but for Africa and di world, as e take tok.

eng: Previous winners of the prize include Ellen Johnson Sirleaf of Liberia (2017), President Hifikepunye Pohamba of Namibia (2014), President Pedro Pires of Cabo Verde (2011), President Festus Mogae of Botswana (2008) and President Joaquim Chissano of Mozambique (2007).
pcm: Pipo wey don win di prize before include Ellen Johnson Sirleaf of Liberia (2017), President Hifikepunye Pohamba of Namibia (2014), President Pedro Pires of Cabo Verde (2011), President Festus Mogae of Botswana (2008) and President Joaquim Chissano of Mozambique (2007).

eng: KEDCO gets taskforce to enforce collection, check meter bypass
pcm: KEDCO don get taskforce wey dey enforce collection, and dey check who bypass meter

eng: The Management of Kano Electricity Distribution Company (KEDCO) has formed a taskforce to enforce payment of electricity bills.
pcm: Di pipo wey dey manage Kano Electricity Distribution Company (KEDCO) don form taskforce to take make sure dem pay for electricity.

eng: In a statement by Ibrahim Sani Shawai, the Head of Corporate Communications, KEDCO, the taskforce has been empowered to ensure that current and outstanding bills are collected as this would help KEDCO consolidate on the numerous  reforms to improve power supply.
pcm: Inside one staement wey Ibrahim Sani Shawai , wey be head of Corporate Communication, KEDCO, give, dem don give di taskforce power to make sure say dem collect all dem don dey owe plus di one wey dem just dey use to take help KEDCO to consolidate on top di plenty reform to improve power supply.

eng: The taskforce is also to check issues of meter bypass, illegal connections, energy theft and other forms of sabotage.
pcm: Di taskforce go also dey check issue of bypass of metre, illegal connections dem, tif tif of energy and oda form of sabotage.

eng: In this regard, anyone found engaging in any forms of sabotage would be dealt with in accordance with the laws of the land, it stated.
pcm: For dis regard, anybodi wey dem see say dem dey sabotage in any way, dem go deal wit dem as di law take tok.

eng: We are appealing to all customers to remain vigilant on all our installations while ensuring that their meters are properly protected against vandals.
pcm: We dey appeal to awa customer dem to open eye for all awa intallation and to make sure dem protect dem meters welwel against vandals.

eng: We also assure all our customers that our metering initiative which is aimed at ending estimated billing and giving customers the opportunity to pay for what they consume, is still ongoing, the statement stated.
pcm: We dey assure all awa customer say awa initiative to give meter wey we wan take quench estimated billing and to give customers di opportunity to dey pay for wetin dem dey use still dey kontinu, as di statement take talk.

eng: IBEDC warns traders under power lines
pcm: IBEDC don carry give pipo wey dey sell under powerline

eng: The Ibadan Electricity Distribution Company (IBEDC) has warned against trading under high-tension wire to avoid disasters.
pcm: Di Ibadan Electricity Distribution Company (IBEDC) don carry warnin out against to sell market under high-tension wire to avoid badness.

eng: Chief Operating Officer (COO), Engr John Ayodele, gave the charge against the backdrop of the increasing trading activities under high tension wires.
pcm: Chief Operating Officer (COO) wey be Engr John Ayodele give di charge against di backdrop of di increasing tradin activities wey dey unde high-tension wire.

eng: In Osogbo, the Osun State capital, mechanic shops, block industries, car wash shops, POS shops and petty trading are common features sighted under high tension wires along Power Line and Ring roads.
pcm: For inside Oshogbo, wey be capital of Osun state, mechanic shop, block industry, car wash shops, POS shops and smallsmall tradin be common things wey we see under high-tension wire along Power Line and Ring road.

eng: Engr Ayodele, therefore, pleaded with residents to take safety precautions as very important and advised those trading under high tension wires to move away to safe areas.
pcm: Engr Ayodele don beg wit residents dem to take safety precautions dem veri important and advice pipo wey dey sell under high-tension wire to move to place wey dey safe.

eng: He also pleaded with residents not to engage quacks to fix power faults and assured that IBEDC technical crew would be available to rectify any fault that might arise.
pcm: He also beg residents say make dem no call pipo wey no sabi to kom repair light and he assure dem say technical crew for IBEDC go dey available to rectify any fault wey kom.

eng: He cautioned those in the habit of harassing IBEDC staff while going about their lawful duties to desist, saying IBEDC would explore all available legal options to seek redress should any of its staff become a victim of harassment.
pcm: He caution say pipo wey get habit of harassin IBEDC staff when dem dey do dem duty as di law take tok to stop am, he tok say IBEDC go explore all available legal options to take seek redress if dem harass any of im staff.

eng: He said, It is also important that other safety precautions such as proper supervision of children is ensured to prevent electrical accidents.
pcm: He tok say, e also dey important say make dem dey take oda safety precaution, like make dem dey supervise childrem important, to take avoid eletrical accidents.

eng: 10 newborn babies die in Indian hospital fire
pcm: 10 pikin dem wey dem just born don die for fire incident inside India hospital

eng: Ten newborn babies died on Saturday in a fire at a state-run hospital in western India, officials said.
pcm: Ten new pikin dem die on Saturday for inside fire wey happen for hospital wey state dey run inside western Idia, as officials dem take tok.

eng: There were 17 infants in the unit for sick newborn babies when the fire broke out in the early hours of Saturday at the Bhandara District General Hospital in Maharashtra state.
pcm: Na 17 new pikin dey di unit wey dem put pikin dem wey sick when di fire break for early Saturday for di Bhandara District General Hospital in Maharashtra state.

eng: Seven infants died due to smoke suffocation, and three from burn injuries, Maharashtra health minister Rajesh Tope told reporters.
pcm: Seven new pikin die as smoke choke dem, and three die bikos fire burn dem, Maharashtra health minister Rajesh Tope told reporters.

eng: Seven babies were rescued by the nurses and ward staff.
pcm: Nurses and ward staff dem rescue seven babies.

eng: All the infants were aged between a few days and three months, Bhandara district health official Prashant Uike said.
pcm: Di age of all di new pikin dem na from few days to three months, as Prashant Uike wey be health district official for inside Bhandara tok.

eng: The government has ordered a probe into the incident and a safety audit of all neo-natal care units in the state.
pcm: Di goment don order say make dem probe inside di incident and to do safety audit inside unit wey dem take care of new pkini for di kontri.

eng: Initial reports indicated that the fire may have been caused by a short circuit in one of the incubators, Tope said.
pcm: Initial report don indicate say di fire fit don apun bkos of one of di short circuit wey dey inside one of di incubators, as Tope take tok.

eng: The staff said the ward quickly filled with lots of black smoke, the minister added.
pcm: Di staff tok say plenty black smoke fill di ward quick quick , as di minister take add am.

eng: Legal requirements for a post-mortem had been waived and the bodies of the children handed to their families, Tope added.
pcm: Dem don waive legal requirement for post-mortem, and dem don carry di children bodi give dem family, as Tope take tok.

eng: Families of the victims would be given compensation of 500,000 rupees (about 6,814 dollars) each.
pcm: Family of di victim dem go get compensation of 500,000 rupees (wey reach 6,814 dollars) for each family.

eng: Police go after newspaper vendors over reports on IPOB
pcm: Police don pursue pipo wey dey sell newspaper bikos of dem report on top IPOB

eng: Newspaper vendors and readers in Aba, the commercial hub of Abia State, are currently being harassed by the police.
pcm: Police don dey harass pipo wey dey sell newspaer and pipo wey dey read am for inside Abia State.

eng: Daily Trust gathered since the weekend, policemen from the Aba Area Command  have been carrying out arrest of newspaper vendors and readers over reports on the Indigenous People of Biafra (IPOB).
pcm: Daily Trust be get news say na since weekend police from Aba Area Command don dey arrest pipo wey dey sell newspaper and pipo wey dey read am concerning dem report on di Indigenous Pipo of Biafra (IPOB).

eng: Residents said there was tension at Ama-Ogbonna Junction in the commercial city when police raided the place on Sunday.
pcm: Resident tok say fear be dey for Ama-Ogbonna Junction inside di commercial city when police raid di place on Sunday.

eng: An eyewitness said residents scampered for safety, as police officers shot sporadically, while trying to arrest a newspaper vendor and readers.
pcm: One pesin wey di matter apun for im eye tok say residents dey run to safety, as police pipo dey shoot anyhow, when dem dey try to arrest pipo wey dey sell newspaper and pipo wey dey read am.

eng: The vendors were accused of distributing newspapers which had stories on the sit-at-home order by the Indigenous People of Biafra (IPOB).
pcm: Dem accuse di pipo wey dey sell newspaper wey carry di tori wey contain di sit-at-home order wey di  Indigenous Pipo of Biafra (IPOB) give.

eng: Dr. Elendu Ukoh, one of the eyewitness, appealed to the state government and Igbo leaders to call the police authorities rein in on their men so as not to create crisis in the city.
pcm: Dr. Elendu Ukoh, wey di matter apun for im eyes, beg di state goment and igbo leaders to call di police authority to call dem pipo make dem for no cause wahala for inside di city.

eng: The kind of people we put into police these days make me wonder if we really want anything good out of this country called Nigeria.
pcm: Di kind of pipo wey we dey put for police dey make me wonder f we want anything wey good to from dis kontri komot.

eng: How can someone be chasing newspaper vendors around in Aba, in this modern world?
pcm: How pesin go dey pursue pipo wey dey sell newspaperfor Aba, inside di mordrn world?

eng: If you stop people from reading hard copies of newspapers, will you also stop them from reading the same stories on Facebook, Twitter, WhatsApp, Telegram, among others?
pcm: If you stop pipo say make dem no read hard copy of newspaper, shey you go still stop dem say make dem no read di same tori on top Facebook, Twitter, Whatsapp, Telegram, plus oda pipo?

eng: What manner of primitive policing is this?
pcm: Which kind old police style be dis?

eng: They caused panic on Sunday by their shooting and noisemaking.
pcm: Dem cause panic on Sunday as dem dey shoot and make noise.

eng: The whole neighborhood thought that they were chasing kidnappers.
pcm: Di whole neighborhood thingk say dem dey chase kidnappers.

eng: It was later that we discovered that police came to arrest a vendor and readers, who gathered in his newspaper stand.
pcm: Na later dem discover say kom arrest one vendor and pipo wey dey read, weu gather for im newspaper stand.

eng: How can police be fighting newspaper vendors?
pcm: How police go dey follow pipo wey dey sell newspaper fight?

eng: What manner of problem can paper cause that Social Media cannot cause 20 times over.
pcm: Which kind problem paper fit kos wey social media no fit kos time 20.

eng: This people are not normal, he said.
pcm: He tok say: dis pipo no normal.

eng: Michael Anorue, another resident, said almost all the vendor stands he visited in Aba
pcm: Micheal Anorue wey be anoda resident tok say almost all di pipo wey dey sell newspaper wey im visit for Aba

eng: on Tuesday were empty.
pcm: Dem dey empty for Tuesday.

eng: He said, We learnt they were saying on Saturday and Sunday that the newspapers had stories on the sit-at-home order in honour of Biafran heroes and my question is what is wrong with it?
pcm: He tok say, we hear as dem dey tok for Saturday and Sunday say di newpaper dem carry tori wey concern di sit-at-hom order wey dem take honour hero for Biafra matter, and my question be say, wetin wrong with am?

eng: The early political leaders in South East, remind these reckless police officers that Biafra is bigger than IPOB the better for them.
pcm: Di early political leaders dem for South East, dey remind dis reckless police officers say Biafra big pas IPOB, di better for dem.

eng: Does proscription of IPOB mean that Biafra has been proscribed too?
pcm: Shey as dem proscribe IPOB mean say dem don proscribe Biafra too?

eng: We're all Biafrans!
pcm: All of us na Biafra pipo.

eng: On the 30th of May, the World Igbo Congress (WIC) held a zoom conversation, talking about Biafran fallen heroes.
pcm: On di 30th of May, do World Igbo Congress (WIC) hold zoom conversation, wehere dem dey tok about hero wey fall for Biafra.

eng: Why can't police go to YouTube, Zoom and other social media that aired it?
pcm: Why police no go Youtube, Zoom and oda social media wey carry di matter for air?

eng: All they do is to come to streets and start looking for unnecessary trouble.
pcm: All di thing wey dem do na to kom street and begin make trouble wey no necessary.

eng: I wish the leaders in Igboland will warn those reckless police officers not to allow what's happening in Imo State to enter Aba, because it will be worst for everybody.
pcm: I wish say di leader for Igboland go warn dis reckless police officer dem make dem no allow wetin dey apun for inside Imo State to enter Aba, bikos e go worst for evribodi.

eng: SP Geoffrey Ogbonna, Abia State Police Public Relations Officer (PPRO), denied that the police arrested newspaper vendors and readers in Aba.
pcm: SP Geoffrey Ogbonna, wey be Abia State Police Public Relations Officer (PPRO), deny say police dey arrest pipo wey dey sell newspaper and pipo wey dey read am.

eng: NAMA kicks as air traffic controllers lament poor tools
pcm: NAMA dey frown face as air traffic controller dey lament poor tools

eng: Air Traffic Controllers (ATC) in Nigeria on Sunday cried out over dilapidated navigational equipment at most airports in the country.
pcm: Air Traffic Controllers (ATC)) for Nigeria on Sunday cry out concernin di dilapitated navigational equipment wey dey for most airport inside di kontri.

eng: The ATCs under the aegis of the National Air Traffic Controllers Association (NATCA), said the situation posed a threat to air safety.
pcm: Di ATCs wey dey under di National Air Traffic Controllers Association (NATCA) tok say di situation na threat for air safety.

eng: They also claimed that the Kaduna International Airport had no control tower which would aid safe aircraft navigation.
pcm: Dem also tok say di International Airport wey dey for inside Kaduna o get control tower wey fit help aircraft to navigate without wahala.

eng: The President of NATCA, Yomi Agoro, in a chat with newsmen at the weekend, said what existed at the Kaduna airport was a watch room used by other aviation personnel and not a control tower exclusive for air traffic controllers.
pcm: Yomi Agoro wey be President for NATCA or one chat with news pipo for di weekend, to say di thing wey dey for Kaduna airport na watchroom wey oda aviation personnel dey use, say no be control tower wey dey for only air traffic controllers.

eng: He also said other airports in the country lacked the necessary equipment for seamless navigation.
pcm: E also tok say oda airport for di kontri no get di equipment wey dey necessary to take navigate without wahala.

eng: He explained that Some airports do not even have functioning equipment.
pcm: He explain say some airport no even get equipment wey dey function.

eng: Even Kaduna does not have a control tower.
pcm: Even Kaduna no get control tower.

eng: What they are using there is a watch room (for firefighters), which is not built for that purpose, and we have been calling on the government to do something.
pcm: Wetin deym dey use dere na watch room (for firefighters), and no be dat purpose dem build am for, and we don dey call goment to do something.

eng: We go to Sokoto, once it rains today, controllers will go to look for umbrellas to sit at the control tower, and what is it, some of the control towers attached to the terminal buildings were ceded to FAAN, while those standing alone were with NAMA, but we have approached the two organisations.
pcm: We enter Sokoto, if rain fall, controller go carry umbrella to sit for di control tower, and wetin apun, dem don seed some of di control tower wey dem attach to di terminal building give FAAN, while di one wey dey stand alone dey with NAMA, but we don follow di two organisations dem tok.

eng: We are still battling with terrestrial radio frequency, communication here and there.
pcm: We all still follow terrestial radio frequency fight, communication here and there.

eng: Calabar is there; there is no airport you will go to today that you would say things are working 80 per cent.
pcm: Calabar dey dere; no airport wey you fit go today wey you go fit tok say dey work up to 80 per cent.

eng: NAMA had recently employed and trained 40 new controllers, but NATCA said the number was too low to meet the shortfall.
pcm: NAMA don employ and train 40 new controllers recently, but NATCA said di nomba dey too low to meet di shortfall.

eng: However, the Managing Director of the Nigerian Airspace Management Agency (NAMA), Capt Fola Akinkuotu, told Daily Trust that the claims were not true.
pcm: However, di Managing Director of di Nigerian Airspace Management Agency (NAMA), Capt Fola Akinkuotu, tell Daily Trust say di claim dem no be true.

eng: He said the federal government had invested hugely in improving navigational aids and aiding safe flight operations.
pcm: He tok say federal goment don put huge investment to take improve navigational aids and to take help safe flight operations.

eng: He said, It is mere politics.
pcm: He said, It is mere politics. Im tok say na ordinary politics.

eng: The government has spent so much in the recent past in improving aviation infrastructure.
pcm: Goment don spend plenty not too long to take improve aviation infrastructure.

eng: I am saying this not because I am the MD of NAMA.
pcm: I no just dey tok dis thing bikos say I be MD for NAMA.

eng: If you want to hear the truth, my suggestion has always been, ask the people on the streets, ask the people in NAMA, they would tell you, they have never had it so good under this administration.
pcm: If you wan hear di true tori, my suggestion always be say, ask pipo wey dey street, ask pipo for NAMA, dem go tell you, dem neva see good wey reach like dis under dis administration.

eng: It is painful that people would be talking this way.
pcm: E dey painful say pipo go dey tok like dis.

eng: We never had a Category Three (CAT3), this government put two in place, two others are coming.
pcm: We neva any Category Three (CAT3), dis goment don put two for ground, anoda two still dey come.

eng: Government has just spent N1.7bn on a mobile control tower.
pcm: Goment don spend N1.7bn on top mobile control tower.

eng: Also there is an ongoing revitalisation of the safe tower.
pcm: Also revitalisation of di safe tower sef dey ongoin.

eng: We are revamping the TRACON (Total Radar Coverage of Nigeria) system.
pcm: We don dey reconstruct di TRACON (Total Radar Coverage of Nigeria) system.

eng: Other sectors should be jealous of us.
pcm: Oda sector dem suppose dey jealous us.

eng: E-commerce in Nigeria: Legal framework, challenges and prospect
pcm: E-commerce for Nigeria: Legal framework, challenges and prospect

eng: E-commerce refers to the use of communications technology particularly the internet to buy, sell and market goods and services to customers.
pcm: E-commerce dey refer to di use of communication technology especially di internet to buy, sell and market goods and services to customers.

eng: As committed members of the APC, we are convinced that since May 29, 2015, when the government of President Muhammadu Buhari was inaugurated, landmark initiatives have been and are being implemented.
pcm: As  per say we bi committed member of APC we dey convinced since May 29, 2015 wey di government of president Muhammadu Buhari just start, di wey dem dey put am on top pipo head.

eng: In comparative terms, President Buharis government has recorded more achievements within six years than all the previous governments under the PDP between 1999 and 2015.
pcm: If we for compare, President Buhari goment don record more achievement within di six years wey hin don use pass all di former goment wey dey under PDP around 1999 and 2015.

eng: We intend to present these achievements with facts and empirical evidences.
pcm: We get am for mind to show all di achievement wey he don do with better evidence and experience for hin regime.

eng: On weekly basis, we will invite Nigerians to engage the issues based on specific highlights of work being executed.
pcm: Na every week we go dey invite Nigerians to kom talk about di issue as per di work wey he don do.

eng: In particular, we will invite all committed party members to participate in the campaign.
pcm: As he dey so, we go  invite all di pipo wey dey committee for di party to kom put mouth for di campaign.

eng: We will also invite opposition parties, especially the PDP to engage the issues by presenting especially what they comparatively were able to achieve when they were in power or in states where they control, they said.
pcm: We go even invite di other parti wey dey tackle, especially PDP make dem kom tok about di issue and make dem tok wetin dey don do wen dem dey power abi di state wey dem don control wen dem dey for power.

eng: The PDP National Publicity Secretary, Kola Ologbondiyan, his deputy, Diran Odeyemi and another top party man were not available for comments.
pcm: Di PDP National Publicity Secretary wey him name bi Kola Olagbondiyan and hin deputy wey him bi Diran  Odeyemi and anoda man wey dey for top wey he no gree show for comment

eng: Govts urged on roads, others for housing projects
pcm: Goment don put hand for road and other housing project.

eng: A land developer and Chief Executive Officer of Perfect Estate Developers Limited, Arch.
pcm: One land developer and di Chief Executive Officer of Perfect Estate Developers Limited, Arch

eng: Dayo Babatunde, has urged governments to deepen the provision of infrastructure to enable estate developers to deliver more housing projects.
pcm: Dayo Babatunde don tell di government to shuk deep hand for di provision of infrastructure so dat di estate developers go deliver better housing project

eng: Speaking with pressmen in Abuja, the real estate developer said such infrastructures like road, drainage, electricity and water supply, open up sites where developers can leverage to make houses available and affordable for Nigerians.
pcm: Di tori wit di pressman for Abuja bi say, di real estate developer tok say infrastructure like road, drainage, electricity and water supply go open up sites where di developers fit leverage, wey go make house available and affordable for Nigerians.

eng: He also said it was important for the government to own such infrastructures as politicians often lay claim to them.
pcm: He continue hin tok say, he dey important make di goment get dat kind infrastructure as politicians go won claim am.

eng: Babatunde cited a case of an access road in Kuje town in the Federal Capital Territory (FCT) which is being taunted as a political achievement.
pcm: Babatunde shuk in one mata of one access road wey dey for Kuje town for di Federal Capital Territory (FCT) wey dem see as political achievement

eng: He however said his firm built the road for N200 million to connect the 600 unit Perfect Estate in the area.
pcm: He tok say na hin firm build di road for #200 million to connect di 600 unit Perfect Estate wey  dey for di area

eng: And the Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) project was done after a futile effort to get the government to do it.
pcm: And di Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) Project wey we do afta di goment no fit show bitter result.

eng: The housing developer lamented the high cost of providing infrastructure by the private sector to aid urban development.
pcm: Di developer wey dey for housing lament say, di money for di infrastructure wey kom from di private sectors to kom gain urban development.

eng: The financial aspect is a challenge.
pcm: Di financial aspect na yawa.

eng: Out of what we are using to do the project, we are also taking a large chunk of funds for the road.
pcm: Out of wetin we dey use do di project, we go also cari plenty moni do di road.

eng: Without a good access road, you discover that marketing an estate becomes a big challenge.
pcm: if we no get better road you go see say to advertise di estate go kom bi a big kasala

eng: So we are also under pressure to make the road a reality while also building the houses, Babatunde said.
pcm: We kom dey under pressure say make di road dey ready and make we build di houses too as per Babatunde tok.

eng: Seven issues that will make or mar Nigeria to 2023.
pcm: Na  seven things go make or destroy Nigeria for 2023.

eng: Buffeted by deep-seated existential challenges which the leadership has proved incapable of tackling, many are coming to the belief that Nigerias future survival as a country is not certain.
pcm: Buffeted by deep – seated existence challenge wey di leaders no fit tackle, many people don belief say di future survival of Nigeria no dey sure.

eng: The signs certainly are there clearly manifested in all facets of life; large swathes of the country are now under the control of non-state actors, a shrinking economy characterised rising inflation and poverty, and social sectors in free falling collapse.
pcm: Di sign don dey certain and clear for di aspect of life; Many people wey dey under di country don dey under di control of non – state  actors , shrinking economy wey result to rising of inflation and poverty and social sector wey don fall yakata.

eng: But the most dangerous of all is the growing lack of trust between the leadership and the led as well as among the various ethnic groups and social classes making up the country.
pcm: But  di one wey dangerous pass na di lack of trust wey dey among our leaders, pipo and all di ethnic groups and di social class of pipo wey make up di kontri.

eng: That Nigeria is currently hurtling towards a decisive defining moment in its existence as a country cannot be denied.
pcm: Di fact say currently Nigeria don dey go toward a delicate moment of hin existence as a kontri wey no fit bi denied.

eng: To be sure, there is no country that is immune from challenges at whatever period of its existence.
pcm: To dey sure, no kontri wey dem no face challenges from di start.

eng: But the difference between success and failure to manage these challenges lies mainly with the leadership and how it copes with the issues of governance that come up from time to time in the life of a nation.
pcm: But di different wey dey between success and failure na di leaders wey no sabi manage di challenges and di way dem dey cope wit issues of di nation.

eng: In this regard, looking at the degenerating situation in Nigeria across all facets of our life, the abject failure of leadership at all levels to engender confidence in their ability to come to grips with the deep challenges facing the country is glaring.
pcm: As he dey go, as we dey look di soso deteriorate wahala including di mata of our life all failure of our leaders of all levels of situations make dem take better hand hold di mata  wey dey face the kontri make he better.

eng: Hence the dangerous but understandable doubts among a growing number of Nigerians that the countrys future existence is uncertain.
pcm: Soso many Nigerians dey doubt say di future of di kontri fit no bitter again.

eng: This feeling is gaining greater traction as we inch towards the next circle of elections in 2023 which many believe might be more problematic than the previous ones.
pcm: Di thought of di people bi say di election wey go take place for 2023 go get plenty palava pass the ones wey we don get before.

eng: Proceeding from the principle that a problem identified is a problem almost solved, I have identified seven major issues confronting the country not necessarily by pecking order, which require urgent attention, failing which may finally tip the country into the abyss.
pcm: Dey notice say di problem wey we see na him dey get solution, I don gather seven problems wey dey cause wahala wey need quick attention to solve and failing to solve doz problem fit make di kontri fall apart.

eng: The Fulani question is one of the raging issues in the country which requires a nuanced perspective and approach.
pcm: Di Fulani problem na him bi di number one koko wey of di matter wey dey cause kasala wey we gat take eye look into.

eng: It is not just about the frequently reported cases of clashes between Fulani herders and farmers in the country or the seeming ambivalence and even mutual antagonism between sedentary Fulanis and their nomadic kith and kin.
pcm: Di soso fight we don dey hear about di Fulani herders and di farmers in kontri dey cause contradictory and hatred between normal pipo and di aimless families of di Fulani’s.

eng: It is more to do with the place of the Fulani in the historical, political and social evolution of Nigeria.
pcm: We gat put mouth for di position wey Fulani hold in di histrorical, political and social evolution of  Nigeria.

eng: In many ways, Nigeria can be described as a joint legacy of nineteenth century Fulani Jihadist Sheikh Usman dan Fodio, and Sir Frederick Lugard, the architect of amalgamation and first British colonial Governor-General of Nigeria.
pcm: We fit describe Nigeria as country of joint legacy of nineteenth century Fulani Jihadist Sheilk Usman dan Foldio and Sir Frederick Lugard wey bi di architect of amalgamation and di first British colonial Governor-General of Nigeria

eng: Sheikh dan Fodio
pcm: Sheilk dan Fodio

eng: it was who first established the Fulani hegemony over an area roughly the size of two-thirds of Northern Nigeria through the Fulani led Jihad of 1804.
pcm: na di first person wey establish Fulani dominance for an area wey get di size of two – third of di Northern Nigeria for di Fulani’s wey lead di Jihad of 1804

eng: It was on the political and social structure of this dan Fodio creation that the Britons built their colonial enterprise in Nigeria, a legacy that subsists to a large extent to this day.
pcm: Na for di political and social structure of dis dan Fodio creation wey di Britons build dia colonial enterprise for Nigeria, a legacy wey subsists to a large extent to dis day.

eng: As a group, the Fulani are the single most powerful and influential factor in Nigerian politics.
pcm: As a group, di Fulani wey bi single most powerful and influential factors for Nigeria politics.

eng: They control one half of the traditional/spiritual realm through the Islamic religion as well as the temporal turf of Nigerian politics and governance.
pcm: Na dem dey control one half of di traditional/spiritual realm through di Islamic religion as well as di temporal turf of Nigeria politics and governance.

eng: That the Fulani have deployed this unique advantage in the struggle for the control of the soul of Nigerian politics opens them to accusation with some reason of wanting to perpetually control political power in the country to the exclusion and detriment of other ethnic groups.
pcm: Di Fulani don arrange dis special advantage in di struggle for di control of di soul of Nigeria politics opens dem to accusation wit some reason wey dey one use to control forever for political power in di kontri to comot and damage other ethnic groups

eng: Now, who the hell put that there?
pcm: Now who kom put dat thing for they?

eng: I was so heavy laden and to think that I would see this here of all places!
pcm: I dey so heavy Ladena and to say i go see dis kind for here!

eng: This was a place with people who have a lot more face-value reasons than I to despair and this fact threw me off balance.
pcm: Dis place nah d place wey people wey get plenty face-value dey reason than I despair and dis fact no make me dey balance.

eng: An epiphany was before my eyes.
pcm: I kon realize wetin dey before me.

eng: I could fly away and mooch off the sweat of others.
pcm: I fit fly and run away with oda people sweat.

eng: I could surrender and fight no more and my life would be that of consummate comfort.
pcm: I fit surrender fighting and my life go kon dey comfortable.

eng: But here I am, and I can see that I will not stand alone
pcm: But nah here I dey and I con see say I no fit stand alone.

eng: should I choose to stand.
pcm: Shey make I stand alone

eng: I could fly away, live and then die.
pcm: I fit fly, live and die.

eng: But here, before me, in the land of my ancestors, was the prospect of immortality.
pcm: But na, here before me, on my ancestors land di aspect of not wanting to die.

eng: Here I can actually live a life full of event and excitement, of building and breaking; breaking records and barriers that have never been broken elsewhere and defeating despair.
pcm: Here I fit live life wey go full of event and so so enjoyment, of building and breaking to record and d barriers wey pesin neva break anywhere and to dey live to defeat hopelessness.

eng: Where else can anyone defeat despair so completely than in the Heart of Darkness?
pcm: Where people fit defeat hopelessness expect in d heart of darkness?

eng: Maybe I will die trying, but how can a man die better than by facing odds so fearful as the ones before me?
pcm: Maybe I go die while trying, but how man go die better wen he dey face challenges wey dey fear pesin like d one wey I dey face?

eng: We dont have to build skyscrapers, or nuclear power stations or maglev trains  we will build the next best thing, and maybe Conrad will be the one wanting a piece of those.
pcm: We no need to build skyscrapers, d station for nuclear power or maglev trains, Nah we go build d next best thing. Maybe Conrad fit want a piece of doz things.

eng: He has reached saturation, but we are only at ten percent.
pcm: He don reach his highest satisfactions but we dey ten percent.

eng: We can rise and rise until lambs become lions and by the time the sun sets on my generation, I would be a fulfilled man.
pcm: We fit rise and rise sote Lambs go turn to Lions and by dat time d sun go dey shine on my generation, I go kon bikom a fulfilled man

eng: I will endure the long March and then maybe reap from it too.
pcm: I go endure di  whole thing and maybe I fit see something chop from ham.

eng: If not, I will still be a fulfilled man on my deathbed someday.
pcm: If no be so, I go still be a fulfilled man even if I dey on my death bed oneday.

eng: Nothing beats being fulfilled on your deathbed.
pcm: Nothing sweet pass d happiness and joy wey person dey feel on deathbed.

eng: So then, here are my new terms of surrender: none.
pcm: Nah him make me bring out new terms of my surrender.

eng: We fight on.
pcm: We go dey fight dey go.

eng: Huzaifa is a management consultant and writes from Abuja
pcm: Huzaifa na di management consultant wey dey write from Abuja.

eng: Officer who sneaked drugs, phones into prison nabbed in Kano
pcm: Officer wey dey carry drugs and phones inside d prison nabbed Kano operative of Nigeria.

eng: Operatives of the Nigerian Correctional Service (NCoS) have nabbed one of their officers who reportedly sneaked in over 4.8kg of cannabis sativa and eight Android phones into the correctional facility in Kano.
pcm: Correctional service (NCoS) don catch one of their officers who dey always carry hard drugs wey dey weight over 4.8kgs and eight big phones inside d correctional facility wey dey Kano

eng: There was an uproar at the correctional centre on Thursday after the prison wardens detected and seized the cannabis allegedly brought to some inmates on death row at Kurmawa prison.
pcm: Yawa dey dI correctional centre on Thursday afta di warders wey dey di prison see and collect di hard drugs wey dem dey bring for d prisoner’s wey dey death row for kurmawa prison.

eng: The seizure, according to reports led to resistance and the uproar from the inmates, while authorities promised to investigate how the illicit drugs got into the facility.
pcm: As per di report wey dem gather  wen di warder collect d hard drugs from d prisoners, d prisoners dey shout up and down and di authority don promise say dem go look into d matter wella  to know how doz things take enter di facility.

eng: The spokesperson of the NCoS in Kano state, Musbahu Lawal Kofar Nassarawa, confirmed to Daily Trust that one of their staff (name withheld) was nabbed for colluding with other dealers outside to sneak the seized items into the prison.
pcm: Di person wey dey tok to di NCoS wey dey Kano, wey be Musbahu Lawal Kofar Nassarawa, tok to di daily trust say na one of dia staff (wey dem no tok hin name) na di person wey dey steal for d oda pipo wey dey outside to dey carry di hard drugs outside di prison

eng: He said, We have arrested one of our staff who connived with these people to bring in 4.8kgs of cannabis and eight android phones to some inmates on death row, and that was why we had uproar on Thursday after our operatives have seized it.
pcm: He tok  say dem don arrest one of dia staff wey dey among di pipo wey dey carry di hard drugs wey reach 4.8kg and di eight  android phone go give di prisoners wey dey death row, say na di reason why yawa dey on Thursday afta dI police don collect ham.

eng: This staff who works in the facility was recruited just two years ago in 2019.
pcm: He tok say dI staff wey dey among dem just get work for two years ago in 2019.

eng: We have already handed him over to National Drugs Law Enforcement Agency (NDLEA) for further action.
pcm: We don hand ham over to di NDLEA so dat dem go fit carry out further action on di matter.

eng: He will be arraigned before court, and if he is found guilty, he can be suspended.
pcm: Dem go carry him matter go court and if he dey guilty dem go suspend ham from work

eng: We will find out for how long this has been happening and whether there are other people involved in similar scandal, Kofar Nassarawa said.
pcm: Kofar Nassarawa tok say dem go find out since wen doz things  don dey apun and check if oda pipo dey involve in di yawa.

eng: He added that the service will continue to work hard to detect similar practices in the facility.
pcm: He add to hin tok say di service go continue to work hard  to see if dat kind thing still dey apun for di facility.

eng: Daily Trust recalled that in 2020, a woman was arrested for sneaking a phone to another prisoner on death row.
pcm: Daily trust even note ham say in 2020, dey arrest one woman wey dem see as she dey carry phone for di prisoner wey dey death row

eng: Similarly, another woman was apprehended with cannabis concealed in a carton of instant noodles.
pcm: He also tok say dem catch one man wey dem see with hard drugs wey she put inside noodles carton.

eng: Centre lauds INEC for creating gender, inclusivity depts
pcm: Di centre dey hapi as INEC create gender inclusivity department

eng: The Centre for Transparency Advocacy (CTA) has commended the Independent National Electoral Commission (INEC) for its re-organisation that led to the creation of the Gender and Inclusivity Department (GID)
pcm: The centre for transparency advocacy (CTA) give kudos to di pipo wey dey INEC for di rearrangement wey dem do, wey kom lead to di creation of gender and inclusivity department (GID)

eng: that hitherto was a unit in the commission.
pcm: say dem dey unit for di commission.

eng: The Executive Director of the centre, Faith Ossai Nwadishi, in a statement, expressed joy that INEC was poised to reposition itself bearing in mind the realities of today and the need to promote inclusiveness in its operations.
pcm: Faith Ossai Nwadishi  wey be di Executive director for di centre tok say she dey hapi say INEC don reposition itself, she know say di need to promote very well dey di operation wey dem just start.

eng: She also noted that in this new arrangement, INEC created two departments out of the present Department of Legal Services, Clearance and Complaints (LSC&CC) and that the new departments are Department of Litigation and Prosecution (DL&P) and Department of Legal Drafting and Clearance (LDCD).
pcm: She tok say di new arrangement wey INEC just create so, say dem (INEC) don create two department from di wey dey di department of Legal service, di department of clearance and complaint (LSC&CC) and tok di new department, na department of Litigation & prosecution (DL&P) and di department of legal drafting

eng: The other MDAs which made the list include the Ministry of Works, Hydrocarbon Pollution Remediation Project (HYPREP), Nigeria Sovereign Investment Authority (NSIA), National Library of Nigeria, Nigerians in Diaspora Commission (NIDCOM); Ministry of Women Affairs, and Ministry of Niger Delta.

The rest are the Ministry of Petroleum Resources, Nigerian Content Development and Monitoring Board (NCDMB), Nigerian Communication Commission (NCC), Nigeria Ports Authority (NPA), Nigerian Maritime Administration and Safety Agency (NIMASA), Nigerian National Petroleum Company (NNPC), Niger Delta Power Development Company Ltd, Ministry of Health, Ministry of Aviation, and the Voice of Nigeria (VON).
With only few days to the commencement of Ramadan fast for the Islamic lunar year of 1442AH, it is no longer news that the holy month is by the corner.
pcm: wit small days to di start of Ramadan fast for di Islamic lunar year of 1442AH, e no be news again say di holy month don dey near.

eng: It is in this sacred month that the holy Quran was revealed to Prophet Muhammad (Salla-llahu Alayhi Wa Sallam, SAW) for the guidance of humanity.
pcm: Na for dis sacred month wey di holy Quran get revealed to Prophet Muhammad (Salla-llahu Alayhi Wa Sallam, SAW) for di guidance of humanity.

eng: Within the month of Ramadan is a night that is better than a thousand other months.
pcm: For inside di month of Ramadan be one night wey dey better than thousands of month.

eng: Because Ramadan is a unique spiritual season, it is important to effectively prepare ourselves for it so that every opportunity availed by Ramadan is optimally utilized; without taking anything for granted.
pcm: Bikos say Ramadan be one unique spiritual season, e dey important to effectively prepare hawasef for am so dat evri opportunity wey dey Ramadan dey optimally utilized; make we no take anything wit sipini hand.

eng: Ramadan is a month that Muslims happily look up to.
pcm: Ramadan be di month wey Musllims always dey hapi to look up to.

eng: It is a month like no other.
pcm: Im be month wey no get contender.

eng: It is a holy month in which Allah (SWT) has promised to forgive every repentant Muslim; grant mercy to every seeker of clemency; and pardon those who ask to be pardoned.
pcm: Im be holy month wey Allah (SWT) promise say hin go forgive evri Muslim wey don repent; give mercy to evri seeker of clemency; and hin go forgive dos wey ask for forgiveness.

eng: Preparing for Ramadan requires us to know when to watch out for the crescent of the Islamic lunar month of Ramadan.
pcm: Make person dey prepare for Ramadan require make we know wen to dey watch out for di cresent of di Islamic lunar month of Ramadan.

eng: Going by the current count of the month of Shaban on the Timing Chapter calendar, the search for the crescent is expected to begin on Monday April 12, 2021 which is equivalent to 29th day of Shaban.
pcm: By di current count of di month of Shaban on di Timing Chapter calendar, to dey look for di cresent is expected to start for Monday April 12, 2021 wey dey equivalent to 29th day of Shaban.

eng: Abu Hurayrah (RA) reports from the Prophet (SAW) that the gates to hell fire shall remain closed throughout each Ramadan period just as the gates to paradise are left open during the same period so that the wish and prayer of those who desire the latter (paradise) would graciously be granted.
pcm: Abu Hurayrah (RA) report say di Prophet (SAW) di gates to hell fire go dey close for evri Ramadan period just like how di gates to paradise go dey open durin the same period make di wish and prayer of dos wey like paradise get answerd.

eng: Where the crescent of Ramadan is not sighted on the 29th day of Shaaban, the month would be deemed to have naturally completed its circle on the 30th day in which case Ramadan fast automatically begins the following day, which would be the 1st day of Ramadan.
pcm: For place wey di cresent of Ramadan no dey sighted on the 29th day of Shaaban, di month go count say im don complete im circle of 30th day where Ramadan fast automatically start di next day, wey go be 1st of Ramadan.

eng: We are not required to begin the Ramadan fast until we have heard of the sighting of the crescent of Ramadan from credible sources.
pcm: We no suppose begin Ramadan fast until we hear say dem don see di cresent from correct sources.

eng: In our case in Nigeria, the tradition is for Muslims to wait for the announcement of the sighting of the crescent from His Eminence the Sultan of Sokoto, Alhaji Muhammadu Saad Abubakar.
pcm: For Naija, di tradition be say Muslims go wait for di announcement say dem don see cresent from His Eminence di Sultan of Sokoto, Alhaji Muhammadu Saad Abubakar.

eng: Allah (SWT) states in Quran 4:59
pcm: Allah (SWT) tok for Quran 4:59 say

eng: O ye who believe!
pcm: All of una wey believe!

eng: Obey Allah, obey the Messenger, and those charged with authority among you
pcm: Obey Allah, obey di Messenger, and dos wey dey places of authority among una.

eng: The more we remain steadfast and patient to wait for and obey Sultan's words, the more united and stronger we remain as a Muslim community.
pcm: Di more we dey kampe and we dey patient and wait and obey Sultan tok, di more united and strong we go dey as Muslim community.

eng: We advise members of the Muslim community to be wary of unsubstantiated pieces of information that may emerge from social media sources on the commencement of Ramadan.
pcm: We advise pipu wey dey part of di Muslim community to dey wary of unsubstantiated pieces of information wey fit show face for social media on wen Ramadan go start.

eng: We also urge the general public to abstain from circulating unconfirmed news about moon sighting.
pcm: We advise di general public make dem stay away from news wey dem no sabi who tok am wy dey tok about seeing di moon.

eng: Misleading information can throw Muslim communities into confusion.
pcm: Information wey no correct fit throw Muslim communities inside confusion.

eng: Remember that Allah's wrath awaits rumour mongers.
pcm: Remember say Allah wrath dey wait for rumour mongers.

eng: The teachings of the Prophet Muhammad (SAW) discourage the observance of voluntary fast close to the start of Ramadan fast.
pcm: Di teaching of di Prophet Muhammed (SAW) discourage di observance of voluntary fast wey dey close to di start of Ramadan fast.

eng: This is to avoid a situation where voluntary fast, which is a prophetic injunction, is seen to be part of Ramadan fast; the latter being an obligatory act of worship sanctioned by Allah (SWT).
pcm: Dis na to avoid situation where voluntary fast, wey be prophetic injunction, is seen to dey part of Ramadan fast; di latter wey be obligatory act of worship sanctioned by Allah (SWT)

eng: For those who are used to observing voluntary fast every Monday, they are advised to skip Monday next week because of its proximity to Ramadan; being 29th day of Shaaban.
pcm: For dos wey dey observe di voluntary fast evri Monday, e dey advise make dem skip Monday next week bikos of di closeness to Ramadan; bikos e be 29th day of Shaaban.

eng: As part of deliberate preparations for Ramadan and in order to take utmost advantage of the spiritual benefits of Ramadan, it is vital for us to review our daily routines so as to create enough time for engaging in devoutional activities.
pcm: As part of delibrate preparation for Ramadan and make we see chance take advantage of the spiritual benefits of Ramadan, e dey important make we review awa daily routines to create plenty time for engaging in devolutional activities.

eng: This will enable us have more time to recite the Glorious Quran (in the case of those who never had it as a routine) or more time for reciting and understanding the Quran.
pcm: Dis go allow us have more time to take recite di Glorious Quran (for dos wey no get am as routine) or more time to dey recite and understand the Quran.

eng: Let us also decide on the time for observing Tarawih prayers in consultations with individuals that traditionally make up the prayer congregation at the family level or conventionally at a public mosque.
pcm: Make we decide quick quick to observe Tarawih prayers in consultations wit individuals wey traditionally make up di prayer congregation for di family level or conventionally for public mosque.

eng: Let us also define the kind of tasks we engage in during the daytime of the entire period of Ramadan so that we do not miss out from observing Tarawih prayers after breaking the fast or Tahajjud prayers after midnight.
pcm: Make we also define di kain task wey we dey engage during the day for Ramadan period, make we no miss out from observing Tarawih prayers afta we break fast or Tahajjud prayers afta midnight.

eng: In order to preserve the sanctity of our Ramadan fast, there's need to review our usual interactions with ICT platforms especially the social media.
pcm: For us to preserve di sancuary of awa Ramadan fast, need dey to review awa usual interaction wit ICT platforms especially di social media.

eng: The Government has banned Twitter
pcm: The goment don ban Twitter

eng: It is important to identify and avoid specific websites, television channels and radio programmes that would impact negatively on our Ramadan fast.
pcm: Im dey important to indentify and avoid some kain websites, television channels and radio programmes wey fit bring negative impact on awa Ramadan fast

eng: We should be prepared to also avoid certain conversations in our respective places of work to prevent us from expressing or hearing obscene phrases.
pcm: Make we dey prepare to also avoid some kain toks for awa respective work place, make e prevent us for toking and hearing some bad toks.

eng: Muslim scholars, preachers, prayer leaders, presenters and anchors of radio and television programmes are urged to eschew the use of provocative and discourteous expressions during preaching sessions.
pcm: Dem advise Muslim scholars, preachers, prayer leaders, presenters and anchors of radio and television programmes to avoid di use of provocative and discourteous expressions durin preaching sessions.

eng: They are expected to exhibit a good sense of maturity in the course of educating their audience on the teachings of Islam.
pcm: Dem suppose exhibit good sense of maturity as dem dey educate dia audience on how dem dey teach Islam

eng: Wisdom and good speech, not name-calling or insults, are central to effective and popular religious proselytization.
pcm: Wisdom and good tok, do yeye or insult, be central to effective and popular religious proselyzation.

eng: With the country still struggling to overcome several challenges, it is wise for Muslim clerics to abstain from sandwiching their religious preaching with political and ethnic sentiments.
pcm: Di kontri still dey struggle to overkom plenty wahala, e dey wise for Muslim clerics to abstain from sandwiching dia religion preaching wit politica and ethnic sentiment.

eng: We advise dealers and retailers of consumer goods against taking undue advantage of the Ramadan season to increase prices of essential commodities.
pcm: We advise dealers and retailers of consumer goods make dem no do yeye inflation of market price bikos of Ramadan season.

eng: It is wicked for any trader to see Ramadan as an opportunity to hike prices of foodstuffs for the simple reason of the high demand for certain commodities especially sugar and fruits during Ramadan.
pcm: E dey wicked for any trader to dey see Ramadan as opportunity to dey skyrocket food price bikos demand of food plenty, especially sugar and fruits durin Ramadan

eng: Let us be God-fearing in all that we do and say to earn a living.
pcm: Make we dey fear God for evrithing wey we dey do and say to make moni.

eng: Philanthropic individuals, groups, and NGOs are encouraged to organize or support public breaking of Ramadan fast , at least for less-privileged Muslims.
pcm: We encourage philanthropic individuals, groups and NGOs to dey organise or support public breaking of Ramadan fast, at least for less priviledge Muslims.

eng: It is time in Ramadan for every Muslim  to extend hand of friendship, charity, and kindness to fellow Muslims.
pcm: Na time be dis for Ramadan for evri Muslim to extend hand of friendship, charity, and kindness to dia fellow muslims.

eng: May Allah (SWT) guide us to begin and end the Ramadan fast in peace and with ease; amin.
pcm: May Allah guide us to start and end di Ramadan fast in peace and wit ease. Amin.

eng: The leadership of some major socio-cultural groups from the Southern and Middle Belt part of the country on Monday adopted a common position and called for an emergency national conference that would lead to the emergence of a new constitution and restructuring of Nigeria.
pcm: Di leaders of some socio-cultural groups wey kom from South and Middle Belt part of the kontri for Monday don tok wit one voice say make emergency national conference dey wey go lead to di emergence of a new constitution and restucturing of Nigeria

eng: The groups, comprising the Afenifere, the Ohanaeze Ndigbo, the Middle Belt and the Southern Kaduna Peoples Union (SOKAPU) made the call in Abuja at a dialogue session titled The Nigeria's 2023 Presidential Transition Inter-ethnic Peace Dialogue.
pcm: Di groups, wey include Afenifere, di Ohanaeze Ndigbo, di Middle Belt and di Southern Kadunaa pipo Union (SOKAPU) tok am in Abuja for one dialogue session wey dem call Di Nigeria's 2023 Presidential Transition inter-ethnic Peace Dialogue.

eng: According to them, it is possible to reverse the current challenges facing and prevent Nigeria from breaking into pieces if the federal government listens and implements the recommendations they are putting forward.
pcm: According to wetin dem tok, e dey possible to reverse di current challenges wey dey face and dey prevent Nigeria from breaking into pieces if Federal goment listen and dey do wetin pipo recommend as solutions to dem.

eng: President of Afenifere, Chief Ayo Adebanjo, while presenting the position of the Yorubas, which was also adopted by both the Ohaneze and Middle Belt Forum, said the process for a genuine consensus on an acceptable national constitution should henceforth begin with the production of position documents by all nationalities between now an December.
He said going forward, Nigerians should be allowed to exercise their mandate and sovereignty on how they want to live together under mutually beneficial terms.
pcm: Hin tok say moving forward, make all Nigerians get chance to dey exercise dia mandate and soverneignty on how dey wan live together and how evribodi go benefit from am.

eng: Speaking on behalf of the Ohaneze, Chief Chukwuemeka Ezeife, said while it fully endorsed the proposals by Afenifere, there was a need for an emergency national conference to consider the proposals of various ethnic groups and also to review the reports of previous national conferences so as to come up with a new constitution accepted by all.

He said the problems being witnessed in the country started when the military took over power in 1966 and removed the federal constitution that would have guided the country to a viable economic and political entity.
pcm: Hin tok say the wahala wey we dey see for di kontri don start wen di military grab power in 1966 and remove di federal constitution wey for don guide di kontri to a viable economic and political entity.

eng: Also speaking, the leader of the Northern Consensus Initiative, Dr Awal Abdullahi, said: The North before now was saying we don't believe in separation
pcm: Di leader of di Northern Consensus Initiative, Dr Awal Abdullahi tok say : Di North before now dey tok say dem no believe in seperation.

eng: but as I'm standing, I'm telling you that if there's going to be separation tomorrow, the North is ready for it, we're also ready, let's go our different ways
pcm: but as I dey tok, I dey tell you say if seperation go apun tomorrow, di North dey ready for am, we dey ready, make we all waka our different ways

eng: and I'm telling you this with all sincerity.
pcm: and I dey tell you dis wit all sincerity.

eng: Northern Nigeria before now did not want to hear anything separation, but as at today, as I speak to you, the North is equally ready.
pcm: Northern Nigeria before now no wan hear anythin seperation, but today, as I dey tok, di North sef don ready.

eng: What I'm saying might be controversial, but I'm speaking the mind of northerners
pcm: Wetin I dey tok fit dey controversial, but I dey tok di mind of northerners.

eng: and I have no apology to anyone in this hall.
pcm: and I no get any apology wey I wan give anyone wey dey dis hall.

pcm: In reply, the president of di Middle Belt Forum, Pgu Bitrus, tok say Middle Belt no go pull out of di kontri wit di core north.

eng: He said: So if my brother says the north is going, be sure the middle-belt is not going with you, you're on your own.
pcm: in tok say: if hin brother dey tok say di north is going, make dem dey inform say Middle Belt no dey follow dem waka togeda, una dey on your own.

eng: We've served and sacrificed for this country.
pcm: We don serve and sacrifice for dis kontri

eng: The war that occurred, the middle-belt was used to fight while the North sat back to enjoy.
pcm: Di war wey apun, di middle belt dey di fight wit full bodi but di north dey dia area dey enjoy.

eng: Also speaking, a former speaker of the House of Representatives, Umar Ghali Naabah observed that the leadership of the country was not serving the people properly.
pcm: Former speaker of di House of Repesentative, Umar Ghali Naabah observe say leaders of di kontri no dey serve di pipo properly.

eng: We have weak and irresponsible leadership in the country.
pcm: We get weak and irresponsible leadership for dis kontri.

eng: We need to talk as one Nigeria and not people from the North or from the South, Naabah, who is also the chairman of the National Consultative Forum(NCF) said.
pcm: We need to dey tok as one Nigeria, no be like pipo from di North or from the South, Naabah, wey also be chairman of di National Consultative Forum (NCF) tok.

eng: Smoking kills 29,472 Nigerians annually  FG
pcm: Smoking dey kil 29,472 Nigerians evri year, FG tok am.

eng: The Minister of Health, Osagie Ehanire on Monday said a research finding published in 2021 by the Centre for the Study of the Economies of Africa showed that 29,472 deaths in Nigeria were attributable to smoking.
pcm: Di minister of Health, Osagie Ehanire for Monday tok say the research wey dem publish for 2021 by di Centre of di Study of di Economies of Africa showed dat 29,472 deaths for Nigeria wey attributed to smoking.

eng: He said this in Abuja while quoting the 2018 Tobacco Atlas report, during the commemoration of the World No Tobacco Day.
pcm: He tok am for Abuja as e dey quote di 2018 Tobacco Atlas report, durin di commemoration of di World no Tobacco Day.

eng: He said the theme for this year's World No Tobacco Day, Commit to Quit came at a good time when the global community was battling the COVID-19 pandemic.
pcm: Hin tok say di theme of dis year Woled no Tobacco Day , ' Commit to Quit' kom for better time wen di global community dey battle COVID-19 pandemic.

eng: This is especially so, as evidence has shown that tobacco users and those with underlying non Communicable Diseases (NCDs) are at higher risk of severe Covid-19 outcomes.
pcm: Na wetin dey apun be dis, as evidence don show say pipo wey dey use tobacco and pipo wey get underlying non communicable diseases (NCDs) get high risk of severe Covid-19 outkoms.

eng: Assisting people to quit tobacco use will therefore improve COVID-19 treatment outcomes,he said.
pcm: To assit pipo wey dey use tobacco to quit go improve Covid-19 treatment outkom, he tok.

eng: According to him, Nigeria records over 16, 100 deaths from tobacco-related diseases every year.
pcm: According to wetin hin tok, over 16,000 pipo don die for Nigeria from diseases wey dey reated to tobacco evri year,

eng: He said tobacco use or exposure to second-hand smoke is the leading preventable risk factor for non-communicable diseases (NCDs) like hypertension, stroke, cancers, diabetes and chronic obstructive pulmonary diseases.
pcm: E tok say tobacco use or exposure to second-hand smoke be di leading preventable risk factor for non-communicable diseases like hypertension, stroke, cancer, diabetics and chronic obstructive pulmonary diseases.

eng: The World Health Organisation (WHO) Regional Director for Africa, Dr Matshidiso Moeti, said  Nigeria was selected as one of the 22 countries for support by WHO (HQ/AFRO) to scale-up programmes to help people quit tobacco, especially at the primary health care and community levels.
She called on the minster to identify a space within the ministry to set-up a call center office from which the counsellors will respond to caller needs.
pcm: she tok say make minister identify a space for ministry to set-up call center office wey councellors go dey respond to caller need.

eng: France suspends use of AstraZeneca COVID Vaccine
pcm: France don suspend di use of AstraZeneca COVID vaccine.

eng: President Emmanuel Macron of France has suspended the use of AstraZeneca COVID-19 vaccine in the country, pending a review of its safety by the European Medicines Agency (EMA).
pcm: president Emmanuel Macron of France don suspend di use of AstraZeneca COVID-19 vaccine in di kontri, pending di time wey Europen Medicines Agency go finish di review of it safety.

eng: The decision has been made to suspend the use of the AstraZeneca vaccine as a precaution, hoping that we can resume it quickly if the judgement of the EMA allows it, Macron told a press conference, adding that an announcement by the EMA was expected on Tuesday afternoon.
pcm: Di decision to suspend di AstraZeneca vaccine be precaution, hoping say we go resume back quick quick if EMA stamp am say e good, Macron tok am for press conference, also tok say EMA suppose give announcement on Tuesday afternoon.

eng: We have a simple guide, to be informed by science and the competent health authorities and to do it as part of a European strategy, he said.
pcm: We get simple guide, make we dey inform by science and di competent health authorities and to do am as part of European strategy, he tok.

eng: He said the suspension will be effective until tomorrow (Tuesday) afternoon when the EMA will make its position known.
pcm: Hin tok say di suspension go dey ground till tomorrow (Tuesday) afternoon wen di EMA go make where e stand show.

eng: Several European countries, including Germany, Ireland, the Netherlands, suspended usage of the shot after reported blood clotting incidents.
pcm: Plenty European kontri, includin Germany, Ireland, di Netherlands, don suspend make pipo dey use di shot afta report show blood clotting incidents.

eng: At this stage, we must have confidence in this vaccine, Castex said on Sunday.
pcm: For dis stage we suppose getv confidence in dis vaccine, Castex tok on Sunday.

eng: If not, we'll have delays with our vaccinations and French people will be less protected and the health crisis will last longer.
pcm: If not, we go get delay wit awa vaccinations and French pipo go dey less protected and di health crisis go last long.

eng: Speaking alongside Macron at the press conference in southwest France, Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez announced no change for Spain, but said it was importantto give a message of guarantee and safety to the whole of the European population regarding the vaccination process.
Macron also said the French government would have decisions to take in the next few days in order to control the spread of COVID-19 cases after an uptick in cases and a rise in hospitalisation.
pcm: Macron also tok say di French goment go take decisions for next few days in order to control di spread of COVID-19 cases afta an uptick in cases and a rise in hospitalisation.

eng: We will probably have new decisions to take in the coming days, Macron said.
pcm: We go probably get new decision to take for di coming days, Macron tok.

eng: He said the government needed to look at the reality of the epidemic, town by town, region by region: it's what we are doing.
pcm: He tok say goment need  look at di reality of di pandemic, town by town, regioin by region: na wetin we dey do.

eng: Hospitals in the Paris region are close to capacity, with patients being transferred out of the capital region to other parts of France, while other hotspots of infection are in the north around Calais and the Cote d'Azur.
pcm: Hospitals for paris region don dey full, dem dey transfer patient out of di capital region to oda parts of France, oda hotspots of infection dey for di north area for Calais and di Cote d'Azur.

eng: Macron decided against a third national lockdown at the end of January, saying instead a policy of 6pm nation-wide curfew and a partial shutdown of bars, restaurants and other social and entertainment meeting places should continue.
pcm: Macron decide agasint third national lockdown for end of january, hin tok say instead of 6pm nation-wide curfew and partial shutdown of bar, make restaurants and oda social and entertainment meeting places continue.

eng: Fiscal discipline, key to our success Okowa

pcm: Hin tok say hin administration success durin di period be out of great coordination in administation and superior thought-process.

pcm: E recall say prior hin administation, di budget wey di state get dey around N400 billion, wey naira dey change for N180 per dollar wey dey against current budget of di state wey be N300 billion wit changing of dollar for N492

pcm: Okowa tok say following di devaluation of di naira over di years, di value wey naira fit impact on project dey less.

eng: He said, In the past we had bigger budgets and greater value for money because the naira was relatively strong at N180 per dollar compared to now we are at N492 to a dollar with a budget of N300 billion per annum.
pcm: E tok say before before we get bigger budget and gretaer value for moni bikos say di naira sey strong at N180 to a dollar but now we dey N492 to one dollar and budget be N300 billion per year

pcm: Unfortunately, di current budget wey dey related to salaries dem don skyrocket, e don kos kasala to recurrent budget wey don make awa capital portfolio smaller.

pcm: Say devaluation don dey on naira don make am have less value on projects and as we don know dis now, we need dey plan.

pcm: Di governor tok say early passage and implementation of di state budget as part of di thing wey make hin administation dey sucessful.

pcm: We monitor di seasons and act by di season, dat sef help us

pcm: We make sure say awa budget get pass on time and we do watin we suppose do on time

pcm: We sign awa budget for december so we go get chance use window of january to May do most of di contruction jobs wey we wan do.

pcm: e mean say you go contend wit di rain to deliver project, e tok.

pcm: e add say di strategy don help but e dey take lpot of prudence, you go need to think well and get time to be able to do all dis thing well.
