pcm: E tok say na all hand dey deck to deliver di first ogbonge Deep Sea Port for Nigeria as one of di shareholder, wey be Nigeria Port Authority, don commence to dey initiate maritime service for inside di site

eng: He also expressed confidence that the Lekki Deep Sea Port would change the narrative of Nigerias maritime sector and consequently impact Nigerias economic development.
pcm: E tok say e get confidence say dio Lekki Deep Sea Port go change di narrative for Nigeria maritime sector and em go impact economic development for Nigeria

eng: According to him, Lekki Port is estimated to have an aggregate economic impact of $361 billion over 45 years, creating no less than 169,972 jobs and generating revenue for both state and federal government agencies through taxes, royalties and duties in the process.
pcm: According to wetin e tok, dem don estimate say Lekki Port go generate economic impact of $361bilion ova 45 years, wey go create 169,972 jobs and revenue for state and federal goment agency dem through taxes, royalties and duties in di process.

eng: The MD explained that the project has succeeded in providing employment opportunities for about 1,200 Nigerians with 50 of them from the host community.
pcm: Di MD explain say di project don suceed to dey provide employment opportunity for about 1200 Nigerians wit 50 of dem wey kom from di host community dem

eng: Huawei CEO: We wont give up the ideal of globalization
pcm: Huawei CEO: We no go give up di ideal of globalization

eng: Huaweis CEO Ren Zhengfei has pledged to stick to a globalization strategy despite external pressure.
pcm: Ren Zhengfei wey be Huawei CEO don pledge say dem go stick to globalization strategy despite di pressure wey dem dey get from outside

eng: He has called on the new US administration to come up with more open policies that are in the interests of US companies and the US economy as a whole.
pcm: E don call di new US administration make dem do more open policy dem wey dey wit di interest of US company dem and US economy as a whole

eng: These are the first public remarks the founder of Huawei has made since the change of the US administration.
pcm: Na wetin di Huawei founder first tok be dis since di change of di US administration

eng: Ren was speaking during a press briefing in Taiyuan, the capital city of Chinas northern Shanxi province, after launching the Intelligent Mining Innovation Lab.
pcm: Ren dey tok for one press briefing for Taiyuan, di capital city of China northern Shanxi Province, afta dey launch di intelligent Mining Innovation Lab

eng: Trade benefits both sides.
pcm: Trade dey benefit di two side dem

eng: Allowing US companies to supply goods to Chinese customers is conducive to their own financial performance.
pcm: To dey allow US company dem supply goods to chineses customers dey conducive to dia own financial performance

eng: If Huaweis production capacity expands, US companies could sell more.
pcm: If Huawei production capacity expand, US company dem go fit sell plenty

eng: Its a win-win situation.
pcm: Na win-win situation di thing be

eng: I believe the new administration will weigh these interests as they consider their policies, said Ren.
pcm: I believe say di new administation go weigh dis interest as dem dey consider dia policy, ana wetin Ren tok

eng: Ren stated that Huawei creates value to the whole ecosystem and the wider economy.
pcm: Ren tok say Huawei create value to di whole ecosystem and di wider economy

eng: He cited the example that Huawei has built 5G networks in many cities in Europe, Asia and the Middle East.
pcm: E cite example say Huawei don build 5G network for many city dem wey dey Europe, Asia and di Middle East.

eng: As humanity keeps making progress, no company can develop a globalized industry alone.
pcm: As humanity dey make progress, no konpany fit develop gloibalise economy alone

eng: It requires concerted efforts around the world, Ren added.
pcm: Na wetin wey require effort from around di world, na wetin Ren tok

eng: The United States government has been campaigning against Huawei in the past two years alleging Huaweis equipment could be used to spy on Americans, without presenting any evidence.
pcm: Di United State goment don dey campaign against Huawei for di last two years dey tok say Huawei equipment fit dey use to dey spy on America and dem no present evidence.

eng: Huawei has repeatedly denied the claims, and few other countries have given in to US pressure.
pcm: Huawei don deny di claim ova and ova, and few oda kontri dem don give in to US pressure

eng: Farmers, herders in Ekiti to register with government or get expelled
pcm: Farmer and Herder dem for Ekiti go resgister wit goment or make dem expel dem

eng: Ekiti State government has given farmers and herders another two-week window to register with the state government or be ready to leave the state.
pcm: Ekiti State goment don give farmer and herder dem two weeks chance to use resgiter wit di state goment or make dem get ready to leave di state.

eng: The two-week grace begins on Sunday, March 22.
pcm: Na Sunday, March 22 di two weeks state.

eng: In February, the state conducted a two-week registration of farmers and herders, but not all those involved seized the opportunity.
pcm: Di state conduct two weeks registration for farmer and herder dem for february, but no be evri bodi seize di opportunity

eng: Commissioner for Agriculture and Food Security, Dr Olabode Adetoyi, said in a statement issued in Ado-Ekiti on Saturday that the exercise was expedient to ensure that all farmers and herders could be accounted for.
He added that the registration was also aimed at ensuring peace between the two groups and bringing incessant clashes between them to an end.
pcm: E add say di registration na also to ensure peace between di two group and bring end to clashes wey dey apun netween dem

eng: He noted that the exercise was in consonance with the National Livestock Transformation Programme of the Federal Government.
pcm: E note say di exercise dey consonance wit di National Livestock Transformation Programme wey di Federal goment dey do

eng: Dr Adetoyi observed that clashes between farmers and herders posed dangers to human and food security.
pcm: Dr. Adetoye observe say di clash wey dey apun between farmer and herder dem be danger to humanity and food security.

eng: Special Adviser to Gov. Kayode Fayemi on security matters and chairman, herders-farmers peace committee, retired Brig.-Gen. Ebenezer Ogundana, warned in the statement that whoever failed to register would be treated as a criminal.
pcm: retired Brig.-Gen. Ebenezer Ogundana wey be Special Adviser to Gov. Kayode Fayemi on security matters and chairman, herders-farmers peace committee warn say persin wey no register, dem go do am like criminal

eng: Such persons, he said, would be compelled to leave the state.
pcm: Pipo like dat go commot di state, na wetin e tok

eng: Director-General, Office of Transformation and Service Delivery, Prof. Mobolaji Aluko, told the News Agency of Nigeria (NAN) that identity cards would be issued to registered farmers and herders free of charge, (NAN).
pcm: Prof. Mobolaji Aluko wey be Director-General, Office of Transformation and Service Delivery, tok give  di News Agency of Nigeria (NAN) say identity card go dey issue to farmer and herder dem wey register for free of charge.

eng: On October 13, 2020, President Muhammadu Buhari nominated one of his aides, Lauretta Onochie and three others as commissioners in the Independent National Electoral Commission (INEC).
pcm: President Muhammadu Buhari for  October 13, 2020, nominate one of hin aide, Lauretta Onochie and three oda pipo for commissioner in di National Electoral Commission

eng: Apart from the chairman of the commission, Professor Mahmoud Yakubu, there are 12 national commissioners that run the administration of the electoral umpire.
pcm: Apart from the chairman of di commission, Professor Mahmoud Yakubu, na 12 national commissioner dey wey dey run di administation of di electoral umpire

eng: Yakubu, whose first tenure ended on Monday, November 9, 2020, was re-appointed as the chairman of the commission for a record second term in office.
pcm: Yakubu, wey em first tenure finish for Monday, Novermber 9, 2020, dey re-appointed as chairmo of di commission for second term for insode office

eng: There was also the voluntary retirement of Abubakar Ahmed Nahuche, an engineer, thus leaving the electoral impire with six vacant seats for national commissioners.
pcm: Voluntary retirement of Abubakar Nahuche wey be engineer sef dey, which mean say six vacant seats dey for di electoral impire for national commissioners

eng: Apart from Yakubu as chairman of the commission, the remaining six national commissioners are Air Vice Marshal Ahmed Muazu (retd), Malam Mohammed Kudu Haruna, Professor Okechukwu Ibeanu, Mrs May Agbamuche-Mbu, Dr Adekunle Ogunmola; who were sworn in on December 5, 2016, and Festus Okoye, a lawyer, who was sworn in on July 21, 2018.
This may have prompted President Buharis nomination of his Special Assistant on Social Media, Lauretta Onochie, for confirmation by the Senate as a national commissioner representing Delta State.
pcm: dis fit prompt President Buharis nomination of hin Special Assistant on Social Media, Lauretta Onochie, for confirmation by di senate for national commissioner wey dey represent Delta State.

eng: Others nominated are Professor Mohammed Sani (Katsina), Professor Kunle Ajayi (Ekiti) and Seidu Ahmed (Jigawa).
pcm: Oda pipo wey dem nominate be Professor Mohammed Sani (Katsina), Professor Kunle Ajayi (Ekiti) and Seidu Ahmed (Jigawa).

eng: Senate President Ahmad Lawan, on October 13,  2020, while reading the presidents letter of request at plenary in the Senate, said the nomination was pursuant to paragraph 14 of part 1F of the First Schedule of the 1999 Constitution.
pcm: October 13,  2020 wen  Ahmad Lawan wey be Senate President, dey read di president letter of request at plenary in the Senate, tok say di nomination dey  pursuant to paragraph 14 of part 1F of the First Schedule of the 1999 Constitution.

eng: However, five national commissioners whose tenure expired and are not eligible for re-appointment were Mrs Amina Bala Zakari (Jigawa, North West) who had acted as INEC chairman before Yakubu took over Professor Antonia Taiye Okoosi-Simbine (Kogi, North-Central); Alhaji Baba Shettima Arfo (Borno, North-East); Dr Mohammed Mustafa Lecky (Edo, South-South) and Prince Adedeji Solomon Soyebi (Ogun, South-West).
Members of civil society organisations who spoke with Daily Trust were unanimous that President Buhari should respect the provisions of Nigerias constitution and without delay.
pcm: Civil society organisation member dem wey tok wit Daily Trust dey unanimous say President Buhari should respect di provisions of Nigeria constitution and make e no delay.

eng: Speaking on the development, the executive director, Resource Centre for Human Rights and Civic Education (CHRICED), Dr Ibrahim M. Zikirullahi, told Daily Trust on Sunday that the issue of vacancy at the level of INEC national commissioners is very disturbing.
pcm: Dr Ibrahim M. Zikirullahi wey be di executive director, Resource Centre for Human Rights and Civic Education (CHRICED), tok give  Daily Trust for Sunday say di issue of vacancy for INEC national commissioner level dey very disturbing

eng: According to him, if the president is having difficulty in finding the right candidates to fill the vacancies, he could advertise the positions and let qualified people apply.
pcm: According to wetin e tok, if di president dey get difficulty to find di correct candidate to fill di vancancies, make e advertise di position make pipo wey dey qualified apply.

eng: To allow a vacuum in an institution very critical to our democracy sends a worrisome signal.
pcm: To allow vacuum for institution wey dey important to awa democracy sey send worrisome signal

eng: On the nomination of his aide, which was roundly condemned, the president appears to imply that he does not know people beyond his narrow circle in government.
pcm: On di nomination of hin aide, wey pipo conderm, di president dey look like person wey no know popi for outside hin circle wey dey goment

eng: the director of programmes, Yiaga Africa, Cynthia Mbamalu, told Daily Trust that the INEC was yet to be fully constituted since some seats of some national commissioners are vacant.
pcm: Cynthia Mbamalu wey be di director of programmes, Yiaga Africa, tok give Daily Trust say INEC neva dey fully constituted since di seat of some national commissioner don dey vacant

eng: The National Assembly has the power to decline to confirm a nominee who does not meet the required criteria to serve as national commissioner.
pcm: Di National Assembly get power to decline and to confirm persin wey meet di require criteria to serve as national commissioner

eng: The lawmakers should have screened other nominees who passed the test of non-partisanship and integrity while waiting for a replacement for those who did not pass the test.
pcm: Di lawmaker dem should screen oda nominee wey pass di test of non-partisanship and integrity as dem dey wait for replacement for pipo wey no pass di test

eng: This delay has a severe impact on the operations of the INEC, with just 21 months away from the 2023 elections.
pcm: Dis delay get impact on di operations of INEC wit 21 months away from 2023 elections

eng: When contacted, the Presidency kept mum on the decision of the Senate not to confirm the nominees.
pcm: Wen we contact dem, di Presidency dey quiet on di decision of di senate not to confirm di nominees

eng: Senator Babajide Omoworare, the Senior Special Assistant to the President on National Assembly Matters (Senate), neither picked his calls not replied a text message sent to him by our correspondent.
pcm: Senator Babajide Omoworarewey be Senior Special Assistant to the President on National Assembly Matters (Senate), no pick hin calls and e no reply di text message wey awa correspondent send give am.

eng: A similar message sent to the Senior Special Assistant to the President on Media and Publicity, Garba Shehu, after phone calls, was not replied at the time of going to press.
pcm: A similar message wey we send to di Senior Special Assistant to the President on Media and Publicity, Garba Shehu, afta phone calls, no get reply at di time of going to press.

eng: Secondus accused of N10bn fraud in fresh crisis rocking PDP
pcm: Dem accuse Secondus of N10bn fraud for fresh crises wey dey apun for inside PDP

eng: A fresh crisis has hit the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) as the Prince Uche Secondus-led National Working Committee (NWC) of the party has been accused of mismanagement of N10bn generated from the sale of forms for four years.
pcm: Fresh crises don burst for inside pipo Demoratic parti (PDP) as dem don accuse di Prince Uche Secondus-led National Working Committee (NWC) of mismanagement of N10bn wey dem generate from di slaes of forms for years ago

eng: The countrys anti-corruption agencies, EFCC and ICPC have been petitioned by one of the chieftains of the party over the matter.
pcm: EFCC and ICPC wey be di anti-corruption agencies for di kontri don get petition wey one of di chieftain dem for di parti write ova di matter.

eng: The petitioner, Prince Kassim Afegbua, alleged that the leadership has mismanaged close to N10bn which accrued from the sale of nomination forms for the presidential, gubernatorial, house of assembly and senatorial elections from 2017 to date.
pcm: The petitioner, Prince Kassim Afegbua, allege say di leadership don mismanage close to N10bn wey dem get from di sale of nomination form dem for the presidential, gubernatorial, house of assembly and senatorial elections wey apun for 2017 to date.

eng: Responding to the petitioner, the National Publicity Secretary of the PDP, Kola Ologbondiyan, described the claim asspurious andirresponsible.
pcm: the National Publicity Secretary of the PDP, Kola Ologbondiyan wey respond to di petitioner tok say di claim dey asspurious andirresponsible.

eng: The PDP did not raise Afegbuas fictitious sum of N10 billion as alleged by him.
pcm: PDP no raise N10bn as Afegbua allege am

eng: For the avoidance of doubt, the PDP generated the sum of N4.6 billion and raised a budget for its expenditure.
pcm: To take remove doubt, PDP generate di sum of N4.6 billion and dem raise di budget of dia expenditure.

eng: She added that the appointment of the remaining commissioners was crucial for a duly constituted INEC, which will ensure a successful conduct of the 2023 elections.
pcm: She add say di appointmentof di commisonner wey remain dey crucial for a duly constituted INEC, wey go ensure successful conduct of di 2023 election.

eng: She said,It is crucial that the president reconsiders his nomination and increases the number of women as national commissioners.
pcm: she tok say e dey crucial make di president reconsider hin nomination and make e increase di number of woman dem for national commissioner

eng: Commenting on the issue, the executive director, Civil Society Legislative Advocacy Centre (CISLAC), Auwal Musa Rafsanjani, said Nigerians had noted Onochies support for President Buhari and other members of the All Progressives Congress (APC).
pcm: Auwal Musa Rafsanjani, wey be di executive director, Civil Society Legislative Advocacy Centre (CISLAC) commenton di matter, E tok say Nigerians don note Onochies support for President Buhari and oda member dem for All Progressives Congress (APC).

eng: It is even more important for the president to listen to voices of the civil society and the general Nigerian citizenry to rescind the appointment of Onochie as INEC commissioner.
pcm: Em dey more important make di president listen to voice dem of di civil society and di general Nigerian citizenry to reacind di appointment of Onochie as INEC commissioner

eng: Failure to do this would have a negative effect on citizens perception of the commission and its composition, Rafsanjani said.
pcm: If e fail to do am, e go get negative effect on di way citizen dem dey see di commission and di composition, na wetin Rafsabjani tok

eng: In time, Nigerians were given one of the strictest visa regimes to the UAE and we were excluded entirely from certain types of long-stay visas.
pcm: dem give Nigerian dem one of di strictest visa regimes to di UAE and dem exclude dem entirely from certain type of long-stay visa

eng: The next level perhaps, is for the UAE to start inviting Nigerians for physical interviews before visas are granted.
pcm: For di next level, na for UAEto start dey invite Nigerian dem for physical interview before dem grant dem visa

eng: The programme was organised by the NDLEA in collaboration with a non-governmental organisation in Ilorin.
pcm: Na NDLEA organise di programme in collabo wit non-gomental organisation dem for Ilorin

eng: Umoru said for the first time in the last 10 years, 22 and 26 grammes of cocaine were recovered from one Sherifat Yusuf and Yusuf Abdullahi respectively.
pcm: Na from one Sherifat Yusuf and Yusuf Abdullahi dem recover 22 and 26 grammes of cocain, Uoru tok say na first time inside di last 10 years be dis

eng: He noted that over 46 of the suspects arrested during raids who are drug users have been counseled and released.
pcm: He tok say ova 46 of di suspect wey dey use drug wey dem carry durin raid don be counsel and released.

eng: Europe and the USA remained suspicious and difficult for us to visit.
pcm: Europe and USA dey suspicious and difficult for us to visit.

eng: The Commissioner of Police, Kwara State Command, Muhammed Lawal-Bagega, represented by CSP Fayola Temitope, urged parents to have interest in the activities of their children to prevent them from abusing drugs.
pcm: CSP Fayola Temitope wey dey represent the Commissioner of Police, Kwara State Command, Muhammed Lawal-Bagega, urge parent dem make dem get interest for inside wetin dia children dey do to take prevent dem from drug abuse

eng: The coordinator of the workshop, Mr Samuel Rotimi, said the essence of the programme is to share ideas on how to reduce the cases of drug abuse to the barest minimum.
pcm: Mr Samuel Rotimi wey be di coordinator of the workshop, tok say di essence of di programme na to share ideas on how dem go take reduce drug abuse case to barest minimum

eng: OCP Africa and the Nigerian Institute of Soil Science (NISS) have signed a Memorandum of Understanding on management of problematic soils in Nigeria.
pcm: OCP Africa and di Nigerian Institute of Soil Science (NISS) don sign Memorandum of Understanding on how dem go manage problematic soils for Nigeria.

eng: The OCP Africa Country Manager is Mr Caleb Usoh
pcm: Mr Caleb Usoh be OCP Africa kontri Manager

eng: Represented by Oluwatoba Clement Asana, the production and Technical manager, he said that OCP, a Morrocan fertilizer giant, which supplies phosphate to NPK blending plants in the country under the Presidential Fertilizer Initiative, will fund the entire project.
This project aligns with other numerous OCP Africa farmer-centric projects, he added.
pcm: E add say di project dey align wit oda plenty OCP Africa farmer-centric project

eng: So, I don't understand what prompted such reaction from the senate president.
pcm: I no sabi wetin prompt such reaction from di senate president

eng: It shows that he has a pre-meditated mind
pcm: Em show say e get pre-meditated mind

eng: Last week, news came out that some $601 million of airline funds were stuck in Africa.
pcm: For last week, we get news say $601 million of airline fund dey stuck for inside Africa

eng: In December 2019, I wrote an article about Thomas Cook, arguably the first-ever travel agency and how that firm accidentally established tourism as we know it today.
pcm: For December 2019, I write article about Thomas Cook, wey be di first-eva travel agency and how dat firm accidentally establish tourism as we know am today

eng: Opposition, partly among herders, predominantly from the Fulani ethnic group but also among farmers who resent the Plans benefits to pastoralists, hinders reform efforts.
pcm: opposition wey dey kom from di herders, though na from di Fulani pipo e plenti pass, e kom still dey among di farmers wey no want make pastolist dem enjoy di benefit of di plan sef, dey spoil di reform effort

eng: Distrust is widespread in the Middle Belt, which has been the scene of violent disputes over land between herders and farmers, notwithstanding peacemaking and military efforts that since 2018 have reduced the bloodshed.
pcm: Distrust don plenti for Middle belt, place wey be say fight between farmers and herders too plenti bikos of land, even though peacemakin and effort wey di military dey take since 2018 don reduce di blood shed

eng: Federal and state budgets are pinched, partly due to the pandemics economic fallout, and the country lacks sufficient technical expertise for managing ranches and grazing reserves.
pcm: Shortage don dey federal and state goment budget, small part na bikos of di economy wey spoil bikos of di pandemic, and bikos di kontri no get technical experts wey know how dem take dey manage ranch and grazin reserve

eng: In many states, especially in the North-West, the proliferation of criminal gangs and other armed groups is cutting off access to grazing reserves and scaring away potential investors.
pcm: For many states, especially for North-West, di way wey criminal gang and group dem wey get arm dey grow dey spoil access to grazin reserves and e dey make pipo wey wan invest before no do am again

eng: Unless addressed, these and other problems could delay or even scuttle the Plan, leaving the country vulnerable to an escalation of herder-farmer conflict, which could degenerate into wider ethnic, regional and religious violence.
pcm: unless dey do somethin about am, dis kasala and oda ones fit delay or make e spoil di plan, wey go make di kontri dey helpless wen di fight between farmers and herders dey serious pass before own, wey fit kom turn fight between ethnic group, region and religion

eng: Tackling these challenges requires a concerted effort by federal and state authorities, with help from donors and investors.
pcm: To tackle dis kasala,e go dey important make Federal and State authority join hand make effort, wit donors and investors help.

eng: First, Abuja and supportive state governments should provide stronger political leadership and improve public communication to dispel misgivings and misperceptions about the Plan.
pcm: First, make Abuja and oda states wey dey support am provide political leadership wey strong pass before, make dey kom increase dia communication wit public, so dem go fit spoil pipo doubt and wrong understanding of di plan

eng: These are especially prevalent among pastoralists, who will be asked to change a centuries-old nomadic lifestyle, and who legitimately doubt the Plans promises about available pasture.
pcm: Dis one dey common pass for pastoralists dia side, wey go ask dem make dem change dia nomadic lifestlye wey dey wit dia pipo for centuries, wey still get serious doubt say di plan promise about pasture na lie.

eng: But many farmers are fearful too, that they may lose land to livestock producers.
pcm: But many farmers dey fear say dem go lose dia land give pipo wey dey produce livestock.

eng: Many in the Middle Belt and southern states remain deeply suspicious of the Plans long-term goals, which they see as creating privileges for herders, and more broadly, the Fulani.
pcm: Many pipo for di middle Belt and oda states for di South still dey suspect di plan long-term goals, wey dem dey see as opportunity for herders and di Fulani people particularly

eng: With Abuja and other partners support, state governments must build expertise and technical capacity, especially for managing ranches and grazing reserves, dairy production and meat processing.
pcm: Wit di support from Abuja and oda partners, state goments go need find pipo wey go be expert, wey go know technical aspect of thins, especially pipo wey go dey manage di ranch and grazin reserve, dairy production and meat processin

eng: Federal and state governments should also up budgetary commitments, hasten the release of funds and provide financial transparency to ensure accountability, working with donors and investors as necessary.
pcm: Make Federal and State goment sef increase dia budget for di plan, release di fund quick and make dey kom create financial transparency to make sure say evrithin dey accounted for, to dey work wit donors and investors wey necessary

eng: Addressing rural insecurity, curbing impunity and rehabilitating communities adversely affected by earlier violence in participating states are also vital.
pcm: E dey important sef to dey deal wit insecurities wey dey rural area, to dey curb impunity and to dey kom rehabilitate communities wey di fight affect seriously for di states wey dey participate.

eng: Plus, authorities will need to consider climate changes likely impact and reach a decision about how the transhumant herders who cross into Nigeria seasonally should or should not benefit from the Plan.
pcm: Authorities go need consider weather change mata join, make dem decide if herders from oda kontris sometimes go benefit from di plan sef

eng: While some of these steps will take time, the Plans proponents should focus on delivering concrete, visible results on a relatively short-term basis.
pcm: As some of dis step go take time,make di pipo wey dey plan am focus on how dem go fit bring result wey strong, wey pipo go fit see for small time

eng: Less than two years from now, the country will hold general elections.
pcm: less dan two years from now, di kontri go hold general election

eng: If the Plan is to survive the change of government that will follow, politicians may need to be able to produce clear proof of its benefits (Having served two terms, President Buhari and many state governors are ineligible to compete, meaning that change is certain.)
pcm: if di plan go survive di change of goment wey go follow, Politians go need bring proof wey clear say e get benefit (Change dey certain, as president Buhari and many state governor dem no go fit compete again as dey don serve two term)

eng: Ideally, by the time campaigning heats up in late 2022, the Plans backers should be able to point to at least a handful of newly constructed ranches or rehabilitated reserves, strong donor and investor commitments, and the first of a cadre of newly trained livestock management professionals.
pcm: By di time wey champaign for election don dey hot for 2022 endin , di pipo wey dey back di plan suppose fit show some of di ranch wey dem build or di reserve wey dem repair,strong donor wey dem get and dia investors commitment and di first group of pipo wey dey don train to be professional for Livestock mamagement

eng: None of this will be easy, but the Plan is worth the effort.
pcm: Nothin for dis thin dey easy but di plan worth di effort

eng: While far from perfect, it offers an important chance to reform Nigerias livestock system with a strategy that addresses the needs of both herders and small-scale farmers.
pcm: No be say e perfect, but e bring chance wey dey important, chance to change Nigeria livestock system wit strategy wey go address wetin both herders and small-scale farmers need.

eng: About 70 per cent of Nigerias workforce earns an income through agriculture.
pcm: About 70 percent  pipo wey dey work for Nigeria dey get moni from Agriculture

eng: Modernising the livestock sector could boost the countrys prosperity overall at the same time that it takes a big step toward resolving one of Nigerias most dangerous conflicts.
pcm: To modernise di Livestock sector go boost di kontri prosperity and for di same time, na one big way to solve one of Nigeria kasala wey dangerous

eng: With the clock ticking down to the 2023 elections, federal and state authorities will need to move quickly to make a visible mark, lest the work they have done to create this moment of opportunity be lost.
pcm: As time dey reach for di 2023 election, both federal and state authority go need do quick so pipo go see wetin dem dey do, or else all dia work to create dis kind moment of opportunity go spoil.

eng: This piece is an executive summary of a report on the National Livestock Transformation Plan (NLTP) and how to hasten its implementation, published by the International Crisis Group.
pcm: Dis na executive summary of di report on top di National Livestock Transformation Plan (NLTP) and how dia work go fast, na International Crisis Group publish am

eng: The 1999 Constitution of Nigeria is one done hurriedly and does not deserve the credence it has.
pcm: Nigeria Contitution of 1999 na di one wey dem hurry do and e no deserve di trust wey pipo get on top am.

eng: Gbaja: 1999 Constitution is a product of hurried national consensus
pcm: Gbaja: 1999 constitution na product of national consensus wey dem do quick quick

eng: The Speaker, House of Representatives, Femi Gbajabiamila, has said the recent move to amend the 1999 Constitution is necessary to address its shortcomings.
pcm: Di Speaker, House of Assembly, Femi Gbajabiamila, tok say di 1999 constitution wey dey wan correct recently na to tok about di place dem wey no good.

eng: Gbajabiamila was quoted to have said this in his address at the ongoing zonal public hearing on constitution review in Lagos State.
pcm: Dem quote Gbajabiamila say hin tok am for hin address for di Zonal public hearing on top constitution review mata wey dey apun for Lagos state

eng: He said the 1999 Constitution was a product of a hurried national consensus taken to return the country to democracy.
pcm: He tok say di constitution na product of national consensus wey dem rush do to return di kontri go democracy back.

eng: Our constitution falls short of this standard because the 1999 Constitution is the product of a hurried national compromise that we entered into two decades ago in order to ensure that the military returned to the barracks and that we returned to democratic government,he said.
pcm: he tok say awa constitution no dey standard bikos 1999 constitution na national compromise wey dem rush do two decades ago bikos dey wan send soldiers dem go barracks back make we for return go democratic goment

eng: While noting that it was not the first time the task was taken, he said the present one by the 9th assembly might be the most important constitutional amendment process in the nations recent history because the decisions that would be taken will have far-reaching consequences for the future of Nigeria.
pcm: As he take note say no be di first time wey dem go change constitution be dis, he tok say na dis one wey di 9th assembly do be dey important pass for how di constitution amendent dey go for di kontri recent history as e be say di decision wey dem go take go get plenti consequence for Nigeria future.

eng: A nations constitution is the foundation of its existence.
pcm: National constitution na di foundation of hin existence

eng: It is supposed to set the terms of our nationhood and define who we are in a manner that reflects both our common truths and highest aspirations.
pcm: E suppose set terms of how awa nation go be, make e define wu we be for manner wey go show awa common truth and aspiration wey high pass

eng: It was always the intention that we will one day as one people and one nation, return to amend this document so that it gives voice to the yearnings of the Nigerian people and sets out in clear details how we intend to achieve the shared ambitions of our nationhood.
pcm: To kom back kom change di constitution as one pipo and one kontri na wetin dem get for mind dat time so e go hep di pipo get wetin dem want and e go hep show di kind way wey we want awa kontri be for detail.

eng: Providence has cast upon the 9th National Assembly the responsibility to write such a constitution for the Nigerian people,he said.
pcm: He tok say; E dey important make di 9th National Assembly take responsibilty, make dem write dat kind constitution for Nigeria pipo

eng: If the future of Nigeria does not look so bleak, the diaspora wouldn't seem like the next stop to a lot of the youths
pcm: If no be say Nigeria future no dey luk good, to dey travel out no go be wetin many youth put for mind as dia next stop

eng: 2023: Offa backs Kwara gov for second term
pcm: 2023: Offa don back Kwara goment for second term.

eng: Indigenes of Offa LGA of Kwara State on Thursday threw their weight behind the second term bid of Governor Abdulrahman AbdulRazaq.
pcm: Pipo from Offa LGA for Kwara state on Thursday don tok say dem support Governor Abdulrahman AbdulRazaq for hin second term

eng: This is coming a week after the Olofa of Offa, Oba Mufutau Gbadamosi Esuwoye II, publicly endorsed the governor and months after a similar one by some stakeholders in Kaiama, Kwara North.
pcm: Dis na afta one week wey di Olofa of Offa, Oba Mufutua Gbadamosi Esuwoye II, tok say hin back am for public and months afta some important pipo for Kaiama, Kwara North tok di same thin.

eng: According to the indigenes who expressed full support for the monarchs action, the new endorsement was hinged on what they described as the superlative performance of AbdulRazaq in the last two years.
pcm: Accordin to di indegenes wey tok say dey support wetin dia monarch do, dia endorsement na bikos of wetin dey describe as di superlative performance of AbdulRazaq for di past two years

eng: Describing Abdulrazaq as a goal getter, the people said the difference in the development in the state is very clear, compared with what obtained in the past.
pcm: Dem describe AbdulRazaq as goal-getter, di pipo tok say di difference for development for di state dey veri clear compared to wetin dey der for di past

eng: Speaking at a town hall meeting, the APC chairman in Offa, Abdullateef Afolayan, said, come 2023, there
pcm: As he dey tok for one town hall meetin, APC chairman for Offa, Abdullateef Afolayan tok say for 2023

eng: s no vacancy in Kwara government house as were determined as a people to return Governor Abdulrahman Abdulrazaq for a second term in office.
pcm: Chance no dey for di Kwara Goment house as all di pipo don get di mind to put govenor Abdulrahman AbdulRazaq for office again

eng: The meeting had critical stakeholders in the affairs of Offa, including representatives of Olofa, the Chief Imam of Offa, Christian Association of Nigeria
pcm: important pipo for di mata dem wey concern Offa dey der, like di representative of Olofa, di Chief Imam of Offa, Christain Association of Nigeria

eng: (CAN) and Muslim leaders, youths as well as business community in attendance.
pcm: (CAN) and Muslim leaders, youths and business community dey der

eng: Afolayans declaration was greeted with ecstasy by the Deputy Governor, Kayode Alabi, Special Advisers on Political, Political Communication and Strategy, Gidado Alakawa, Bashir Adigun and Saadu Salau, respectively, who graced the event.
pcm: wetin Kayode Alabi declare make di Deputy goment, Kayode Alabi, Special Advisers on top Political Communications and Strategy, Gidado Alakawa, Bashir Adigun, Saadu Salau, respectively, wey kom di event dey veri hapi

eng: The representative of Olofa, the Asalofa of Offa, Alhaji Isiaka Shittu, said ongoing development efforts in the state by the governor, especially in Offa town should be commended, adding that renovation of the Offa General Hospital, rehabilitation of Offa roads and Offa water works are some of the areas where the governor has impacted on the town.
pcm: Pesin wey represent Olofa, di Asalofa of Offa, Alhaji Isiaka Shittu tok on top di development mata wey dey ground for di state wey di governor do, especially for Offa town say na good work, e kom add di Offa General Hosital, di road wey dem repair and Offa water works na some of di area wia di governor done hep di town.

eng: The women, represented by the market women leader, Alhaja Idiat Yesufu, said the people know the level of development the present administration has achieved since assuming office.
pcm: Di women, wey di Market women leader,  Alhaja Idiat Yesufu dey represent, tok say di pipo know di level of development wey di present administration don achieve since dey enta office

eng: She commended the governor for financial empowerment and support to traders in the state.
pcm: chance no dey for di Kwara Goment house as all di pipo don get di mind to put government Abdulrahman AbdulRazaq for office again.

eng: She said Offa women supported the endorsement of the governor by the Olofa, because we know how the present administration met Kwara and how it is today.
pcm: She tok say Offa women follow support di endorsement wey  di Olofa give di goment, bikos we know how Kwara be before and how e be now.

eng: Being ruled by a bunch of fanatics is Nigeria's biggest problem.
pcm: Di kasala wey big pass for Nigeria na di fact say na fanatic dey rule am.

eng: 5 years after: Why Nigeria still cant export beans to Europe
pcm: 5 years afta: why Nigeria no still see beans export

eng: Nigerias hope of importing dry cowpea (beans) to the European Union countries has again been dashed this year.
pcm: Nigeria hope to dey export dry cowpea(beans) to kontri dem wey dey European Union don spoil

eng: This is as a result of the extension of an earlier ban on the countrys dry beans by the European Union (EU) subsisting till 2022.
pcm: Dis na bikos of di extension of di ban wey dey ground before on top di kontri dry beans by European Union wey go end by 2022

eng: The EU food safety authority had in 2015 banned Nigerian beans because it contained between 0.3mg per kg and 4.6mg per kg of Dichlorvos, a pesticide, when the maximum acceptable residue limit is 0.01 mg per kg.
pcm: Di EU food safety authority don ban Nigeria beans for 2015 bikos he get like 0.3mg per kg to 4.6mg per kg Dichlorvos, one pesticide, wey be say di type wey suppose remain no suppose pass na 0.01mg per kg

eng: Dichlorvos is considered to be highly toxic and can cause difficulty in breathing, diarrhoea, vomiting, convulsions and dizziness among others.
pcm: Dey consider say Dichlorvos get poison wey fit kos diffuculty for breathin, diarrhoea,vomitin, convulsion, dizziness  and oda sickness sef

eng: Experts say like many organophosphate (OP) insecticides, it also inhibits the enzyme cholinesterase, which results in disruption to the nervous and muscular systems.
pcm: experts tok say like many organophosphate (OP) insecticide,e get enzyme cholinesterase sef wey dey kos disruption of di nervous system and muscular system

eng: Some experts also claimed that some farmers and middlemen use Sniper, another deadly chemical, to preserve their beans.
pcm: some expert sef claim say some farmers and middlemen dey use Sniper, anoda chemical wey dey deadly use preserve dia beans

eng: An independent investigation conducted by this paper last year showed that most of the beans in the country are preserved with chemicals that are dangerous to human health.
pcm: Independent investigation wey dis paper conduct last year show say most of di beans for di kontri dey perserved wit chemical wey dey dangerous to human health

eng: A food scientist, Idowu Amusa, listed the consequences of consuming foods preserved with Sniper and other harmful chemicals to include gastro-intestinal health issues, brain and other internal tissue damage, blood poisoning, food poisoning and could also lead to death.
pcm: One food scientist, Idowu Amusa , list di consequences wey dey di consumption of food wey dem use sniper and oda harmful chemical preserve wey include gastro-intestinal issues, brain and oda internal damage, blood poisonin, food poisonin and e fit kos death

eng: The EU had in 2018 extended the ban on importation of dry beans from Nigeria until June 2019 owing to the continuous presence of the pesticide.
pcm: Di EU don extend di ban from 2018 on importation of dry beans from Nigeria until June 2019 bikos of di pesticide wey dey always dey der

eng: The Nigeria Agricultural Quarantine Service (NAQS), the countrys produce regulator, had earlier assured farmers and other stakeholders that the country was working hard to ensure the ban is lifted in 2021.
pcm: Nigeria Agricultural Quarantine Service (NAQS), di kontri produce regulator, don assure di farmers and oda stakeholders before say di kontri dey work hard to ensure say dem lift di ban for 2021

eng: However, a recent document from the EU has announced an extension of the ban, claiming that Nigeria failed to implement the unions food safety action plan submitted in 2018.
pcm: One recent document from EU don announce extension of di ban, he tok say Nigeria no implement di Union food safety plan wey dem submit for 2018

eng: With the extension, beans produced in Nigeria will still not be allowed into any member country of the European Union.
pcm: wit di extension, beans wey dem produce for Nigeria  no go fit enta any member kontri for European Union.

eng: This has been the situation for the past five years.
pcm: Na like dis e don be for five years

eng: How it started
pcm: How e take start

eng: In 2015, a consignment of Nigerian beans was rejected under the EU export regulations.
pcm: For 2015, dem reject some beans from Nigeria bikos of di Eu export regulations

eng: An official of the NAQS told our Agric Editor that upon arrival at Tin Can Island, the NAQS team went to inspect the consignment and it was discovered that some of the containers were already powdery and the rejection was on the premise of chemical residue.
pcm: One official for NAQS tell awa Agric Editor say as e reach Tin Can Island, di NAQS team go check di consignment and dey discover say some of di containers don dey turn power and dey reject am bikos of di chemical residue

eng: We took our own analysis from there and discovered that aside from the pesticide residue, there was also the presence of pests, which occasioned the powder form of the beans.
pcm: We take awa own analysis from there, kom discover say aside from di pesticide residue wey dey, pest sef dey and na dem kos di powder form of di beans

eng: He said the agency has been carrying out aggressive campaigns to explain how and the need for farmers, as well as middlemen to preserve their beans with the acceptable chemical level.
pcm: He tok say di agency don dey carry out serious campaign to explain how and di reason for farmers and middlemen make dem dey preserve dia beans wit acceptable chemical level

eng: The official, who did not want his name in print, said aside from the export problem, consuming such highly preserved beans is dangerous to human and animal health.
pcm: Di official, wey no write hin name down, tok say aside from export wahala, to dey chop beans wey dey don too preserve dey dangerous to human and animal health.

eng: Nigeria is losing billions  Expert
pcm: Expert tok say Nigeria dey lose billions

eng: Mr. Segun Ayeni, an agric economist, yesterday, told Daily Trust that Nigeria is losing billions of naira to the continued ban on the countrys beans since 2015 by the EU.
pcm: One agric economist, Mr Segun Ayeni, tell Daily trust yesterday say Nigeria dey lose billions of naira sake of di ban wey dey kontri beans mata wey EU give dem for 2015.

eng: He said farmers, traders as well as the government could no longer make much money from the beans value chain because of the ban.
pcm: He tok say traders and goment no dey see moni from beans value chain bikos of di ban

eng: All the traders in between, the warehouse people, the transporters and us, who are involved in the inspection and certification, that aspect has been broken down because they cannot generate any revenue along the value chain anymore, he said.
pcm: He tok say all traders wey dey between, di warehouse pipo, di transporters and we, wey dey involve for di inspection and certification, dat aspect don dey broken down bikos e dey no fit generate any revenue for di value chain.

eng: Reactions
pcm: Pipo reaction dem

eng: The National President of the All Farmers Association of Nigeria (AFAN), Architect Kabiru Ibrahim, while reacting to the ban by the EU, said it may not be unconnected with the countrys nonconformity with the Global Good Agricultural Practices protocol.
pcm: Di National president of All Farmers Association Nigeria (AFAN), Architect Kabiru Ibrahim, as he react to di ban wey EU give dem, tok say he fit say he no dey connected wit di kontri noncomformity wit di Global Good Agricultural Practice Protocol

eng: In the production, we need to deploy good agricultural practices and in the preservation, we should not use large volumes of chemicals that will provide residual contents unacceptable for wholesome foods in Europe.
pcm: For di production, we need deploy good agricultural practice, and for di preservation, make we no use plenti volume of chemicals wey go dey leave residual content wey dem no go accept as wholesome foods for Europe

eng: A general ban by the EU is not very well thought out because there are some farmers already complying with GAP standards.
pcm: Dem no think di general ban for EU well bikos some farmers don already dey comply wit di GAP standard dem

eng: He added: We are working with some farmers to ensure compliance with GAP.
pcm: He add say dem dey work wit some farmers to ensure  say dey comply wit GAP

eng: As the National President of AFAN, I am the chairman of the National Technical Working Group on Global GAP in Nigeria inaugurated in 2017 by then minister of Agriculture and Rural Development.
pcm: As di National president of AFAN, I be di Chairman of di National Technical Working Group on Global GAP for Nigeria wey dem inaugurate for 2017 by Di Minister of Agriculture and Rural Development dat time

eng: He said the various exporters, agribusiness groups, Ministry of Trade and Investment, SON, NAFDAC and Quarantine Department have to work together and act in unison to make our produce acceptable globally.
pcm: He tok say various exporters, agribusiness groups, Ministry of Trade and Invesment, SON, NAFDAC, Quarantine Department go need work together, make dem act as one to make wetin we produce acceptable globally

eng: Mr. Idowu Amusa, a food scientist, advised that farmers should grow organic foods only and if they must use pesticides on their farms, they should use only recommended pesticides brands and dosage.
pcm: Mr Idowu Amusa, one food scientist, don advice say make farmers dey grow only organic food and if na must make dem use pesticide on top dia farm, make dem use only pesticide brand and di dosage wey dem recommend

eng: Allow enough time between application of pesticides and use of the food produce and where possible, the food product should be rightly labelled with relevant information on cultivation to consumers, he said.
pcm: He tok say make dem dey allow time between wen dey use di pesticide and wen dey use food produce, and if he possible, make dem label di food product wit information wey dey relevant about di food cultivation for consumers

eng: I love Nigeria, things change and remain the same all the time
pcm: I love Nigeria, things go change, still remain di same evritime.

eng: Tuchel eyes first Chelsea trophy as Leicester chase FA Cup history
pcm: Tuchel dey eye Chelsea first Trophy as Leichester dey chase FA Cup history

eng: Thomas Tuchel plans to ruin Leicesters bid to make history, as the Chelsea manager eyes the first trophy of his reign in Saturdays
pcm: Thomas Tuchel plan make hin win Leichester as dey wan make history, as hin be Chelsea manager, he dey eye di First Trophy fo hin reign on Saturday

eng: FA Cup final at Wembley.
pcm: FA Cup for Wembley

eng: Tuchel has enjoyed a superb run since replacing the sacked Frank Lampard in January.
pcm: Tuche don enjoy hin work wella since hin replace Frank Lampard for January

eng: The German has led Chelsea to the FA Cup and Champions League finals, while taking them back into the Premier Leagues top four.
pcm: Di German don lead Chelsea go FA Cup aand Champions League final, as he dey take dem go Champions League top-four back

eng: Winning his maiden silverware in English football would be further evidence of Tuchels impact.
pcm: If hin win hin Maiden Silverware for English football, e go be evidence of Tuchel impact

eng: But Leicester, two points above Chelsea in the Premier League, will pose a significant threat to Tuchels ambitions under the astute guidance of boss Brendan Rodgers.
pcm: But Leichester wey get two points pass Chelsea for Champions League, go be serious threat for Tuchel ambition, as he be say na under dia boss Brendan Rogers correct guidance dem dey

eng: The Foxes are aiming to win the FA Cup for the first time in their first final appearance since 1969.
pcm: Foxes dey aim to win FA Cup for the first time for dia first appearance since 1969

eng: No club have appeared in more FA Cup finals without lifting the trophy than Leicester, who have lost four times in the showpiece match.
pcm: No club don reach plenti FA Cup final  wey no kom carry Trophy pass Leichester, dey don lose four times for the showpiece match

eng: In contrast, Chelsea have won the FA Cup eight times, with their last victory coming against Manchester United in 2018.
pcm: For di oda hand, Chelsea don win di FA Cup eight times, dia last win na against Manchester United for 2018

eng: The Blues, beaten in last years final against Arsenal, will be making their fourth appearance in the competitions denouement in the last five years.
pcm: Blues wey Arsenal beat for last year final, go show face di fourth time for the competition final for di last five years

eng: Having already beaten managerial luminaries Pep Guardiola, Jurgen Klopp, Jose Mourinho, Diego Simeone, Zinedine Zidane and Carlo Ancelotti since arriving at Chelsea, Tuchel will pit his wits against Rodgers for the first time as Blues boss.
pcm: Afta he don beat star manager dem like Pep Guardiola, Jurgen Klopp, Jose Mawainho, Diego Shineon, Zinedine Zidane, Carlo Ancelotti since he reach Chelsea, Tuchel go go against Rodgers for di first time as Chelsea boss

eng: After a frustrating end to his spell at Paris Saint-Germain  where he won the French title and reached last seasons
pcm: Afta one frustratin end for hin spell for Paris Saint-Germain, wer hin win French Title, wey hin reach last season join

eng: Champions League final before being forced out following a power struggle with sporting director Leonardo  Tuchel has quickly erased any doubts about his suitability for Chelsea.
pcm: Champions league final before dey force am comot afta one power struggle wit Sport Director Leonardo, Tuchel quick comot any doubt for hin mind about hin sustainability for Chelsea

eng: He does not respond to attacks or abuse on his person, despite the fact he has in abundance, the brash and dare-devil underlings.
pcm: He no dey answer pipo wey dey attack or abuse di kind person wey hin be, upon say he get plenti agbero and wobe pikin under hin control.

eng: New technologies, researches that may lessen your farming drudgery
pcm: New tecnology, wetin dem find wey fit reduce yawa wey dey farm labor.

eng: For many farmers in Nigeria, the absence of improved technologies to make farming easy and smooth, particularly for the younger generation, has been very challenging.
pcm: For many farmers for Nigeria, improved technology dem wey go make farming easy and smooth, wey no dey before, especially for di young pipo, na serious challenge

eng: Despite having 16 agricultural research institutions and four conventional universities of agriculture in the country, research and development has been on the slow pace.
pcm: Upon say na 16 agriculral Institutes and four conventional University dey di kontri, research and development don dey veri slow

eng: Recently, Daily Trust Spoke with Professor Ishiyaku Mohammed,the Executive Director of the Institute of Agricultural Research(IAR), Ahmadu Bello University, Zaria and he
pcm: Recently, Daily trust speak wit Professor Ishiyaku Mohammed, di executive director for di Institute for Agricultural research(IAR), Ahmadu Bello University, Zaria and he

eng: explained some of the newest researches and technologies the institute developed for farmers.
pcm: explain some of di new research and technology wey di Institute develop for farmers

eng: Recent varieties released
pcm: Recent variety wey dem release

eng: In the most recent situation, about 28 different varieties of sorghum were released.
pcm: For di most recent situation, na like 28 different Sorghum dem release

eng: About the same number was released for groundnut varieties.
pcm: Na like di same number dem release for groundnut sef

eng: The institute also released up to 20 varieties of cowpea and 66 different maize varieties, then 13 different varieties of cotton.
pcm: Di institute release like 20 variety for cowpea sef and 66 different maize variety, afta, 13 different variety of cotton

eng: They have very important economic attributes that increase the income of farmers and provide a different product for utilisation, either as food, fiber, or for making textile products in the case of cotton, or even for providing oil in the case of groundnut and cotton.
pcm: Dey get economic attributes wey dey veri important wey go increase di income of farmers and provide different product for utilisation, whether na as food, fiber, or for makin textile products for cotton case, or even if na to provide oil groundnut and cotton case.

eng: The IAR has also generally awoken the conscience of farmers to the existence of modern agricultural technologies.
pcm: Di IAR don wake di concience of farmers generally make dem know say modern technologies dey

eng: Our scientists have, over the years, fabricated machines and tools towards reducing drudgery.
pcm: awa scientists dem don dey create machine and tool wey we go fit use reduce drudgery for some years now

eng: For example, there are hand held planters and tractors.
pcm: For example, planter and tractors don dey wey dem fit use hand hold

eng: And  we are in the process of perfecting roll weeders  because people have been complaining that farmers still use hand held hoes for weeding.
pcm: And we don dey find way wey we go use perfect rollin weeders bikos pipo don dey complain say farmers dey use hoe wey dem dey use hand hold comot weed

eng: So we have responded by introducing the development of mechanical weeders.
pcm: Na so we answer dem wit di mechanical weeder wey we dey develop

eng: We have threshers for maize, beans, sorghum and groundnut.
pcm: we get thresher dem for maize, beans, sorghum and groundnut

eng: Dryers are important when you produce crops when theres still rainfall, so you need to find a place where you would at least dry them.
pcm: Dryers dey important wen you produce crop wen rain still dey fall, so you need find place wia you go fit dry dem

eng: Drying is also useful in storing products like tomatoes, he stated.
pcm: hin tok say dryin sef dey important if you wan store product like tomato

eng: Something new on ginger seed
pcm: somethin new for ginger seed

eng: He continued, The IAR also delved into an emerging area of science called biotechnology.
pcm: He kom continue tok say IAR sef enta one area for science wey just dey emerge wey dem call biotechnology

eng: Our scientists are developing ways of rapidly propagating crops.
pcm: awa scientists don dey develop wetin dem go use propagate crops fast

eng: For example, right now, we have an order to micro-propagate ginger.
pcm: For example, we get order make we for micro-propagate ginger .

eng: Production of ginger is determined by how much planting material you have, and the planting material is very expensive, so our scientists have developed ways that inside a bottle you can develop from 1 to 2 inches piece of ginger.
pcm: Na how your plantin material plenti reach go determine di ginger production, di plantin material dem dey veri expensive, na hin make awa scientist dem develop way wey be say you fit develop like 1 to 2 inches of ginger piece inside bottle

eng: You can produce more than 200 plantlets that can be grown in the field.
pcm: You fit produce more dan 200  plantlets wey dem fit grow for field

eng: Right now, we are receiving orders from some farmers who are looking for this.
pcm: Right now, we dey receive order from some farmer wey dey find am.

eng: We do it for sugarcane also.
pcm: We dey do am for sugarcane sef

eng: This technique helps in propagating disease- free crops, sometimes planting materials can be infected by disease.
pcm: Dis technique dey help to propagate disease-free crop, sometimes, plantin materials fit don get disease

eng: The more you plant, the more the disease is propagated into others.
pcm: Na as your plant reach, na hin di disease sef dey propagate for odas

eng: But these techniques try to purify the materials to be disease-free.
pcm: But dis technique dey try purify material make dem dey disease-free

eng: So it is called tissue cultural techniques, where the crop is planted inside a bottle and made to proliferate.
pcm: Na Tissue Cultural Technique dey call am, na der dem dey plant for bottle, make e for proliferate

eng: Each plantlet can now give rise to several plantlets etc.
pcm: Each plantet fit give rise to plenti plantet now etc.

eng: New technology for bio-fertiliser, irrigation
pcm: New technology for bio-fertiliser, Irrigation

eng: Technologies as we develop them go through two stages.
pcm: Technology as we develop am dey go through two stage

eng: The first stage is scientific.
pcm: Di first stage dey scientific

eng: Here, scientists get convinced that these techniques have become a technology or a tool of solving a problem, then it will go to the farmers to test themselves.
pcm: For this part, scientist dem go don dey sure say dis technique get di kind technology or tool wey dem go fit use solve di kasala, afta, di farmers go test am diasef.

eng: Then based on the opinion of the farmers, it can be propagated further.
pcm: Den, based on farmers opinion, dem fit still propagate am

eng: So in the area of the crop varieties I have counted to you in the last few years, we have released varieties of cowpea that is insect-resistant.
pcm: So, for di area crop variety wey i don dey count give you for di last few years now, we don release variety of cowpea wey dey insect-resistant.

eng: It is called SAMPEA20T for maize; the same year we released six different varieties of maize with yield potentials of 6-8 tonne per hectare and then in 2020.
pcm: Na SAMPEA20T dem call maize own; na di same year wey we release six different maize wey get potential to yield 6-8 tonne per hectare and for 2020 den.

eng: Three varieties of improved sorghum (sweet sorghum) were released, together with an additional six varieties of maize.
pcm: Dem release three types for improved sorghum (sweet sorghum), wit anoda six type of maize

eng: So in the recent times, this is what we have released.
pcm: For dis recent time, na wetin we release be dat

eng: We are about releasing a technology for bio-fertiliser, which is a capsule of some materials that contain some useful microorganisms that can assist in fixing nitrogen, which will benefit the plant in its growth and development as if it had been added with fertiliser.
pcm: We wan release one technology for bio-fertiliser, na capsule wey get of some kind material,wey kom still get some kind microorganism wey dey useful as e be say dem fit help fix nitrogen, wey go benefit how plants take dey grow and develop as dem add fertilizer sef

eng: We have developed improved techniques for irrigation so that it will reduce wastage of water by farmers, he added.
pcm: He tok say we don develop develop technique for irrigation wey we improve so e go dey reduce how farmers take dey waste water.

eng: As a rule, Journalists do not use long sentences while a short one will serve
pcm: One rule wey Journalists dey use na to use short sentence instead of long one if e go work.

eng: The Guild at 60, inspiring the living, honouring the dead
pcm: Di Guild at 60, inspirin di livin, honorin di dead

eng: By Lanre Idowu
pcm: Wey Lanre Idowu write.

eng: Sixty years ago, on Saturday, May 20, 1961, the Nigerian Guild of Editors was born, a child of great hope at the old National Press Club located then at Abibu Oki in the heart of Lagos.
pcm: Sixty years ago,on Saturday, May 20,1961, dem born Di Nigerian Guide of Editors, Pikin wey get great hope for di old National Press Club wey dey Abibu Oki for di heart of Lagos den

eng: It was named the Guild of Newspaper Editors of Nigeria, designed to serve as an exclusive club of professional news managers where editors as the ultimate gatekeepers on media content could come together seasonally to interrogate issues of professional media practice unfettered by labour matters.
pcm: Dem name am Di Guild of Nigerian Editors

eng: The editors had been effectively sidelined from the Nigeria Union of Journalists, which predated the Guild by six years, on account that as management staff, they could not be trusted to effectively represent the interests of the rank and file journalists.
pcm: Dey don sideline di editors well from di Nigerian Union of Jornalists wey don dey exist like six years before Guild, bikos dem bi management staff, dey no fit trust dem make dem represent di interest of di rank and file journalists

eng: So in response to the reverse discrimination of the NUJ, the need to instill professional guidance, and protect their interests in light of the unfolding socio-political developments in the early days of independent Nigeria, the Guild emerged to occupy the strategic middle ground of professional managers between owners and the general rank of journalists.
pcm: As answer for di reverse discrimination wey NUJ dey do, dia need to make Professional Guidance, make dey kom stil protect dia interest for di socio-economic development wey dey unfold for the early days of nigeria wey dey independent, di Guild emerge make dem fit occupy middle ground of professional managers wey dey strategic between owner and di general rank of journalist dem

eng: Lateef Jakande (1929-2021) of the Nigerian Tribune was its first founding president.
pcm: Lateef Jakande (1929-2021) for Nigerian Tribune be di first foundin president

eng: His cabinet had the likes of Babatunde Jose (1925-2008) of the Daily Times as the vice president, Abiodun Aloba (1921-2001) of the Morning Post as the secretary, and Nelson Ottah of the Drum as the assistant secretary.
pcm: hin Cabinet get pipo like Babatunde Jones (1925-2008) of Di Daily times as Vice president, Abiodun Aloba (1921-2001) of mornin Post as di Secretary and Nelson Ottah of Di Drum as vice Secretary

eng: The Guild was established to advance the interests of the profession, deepen editors relationships with their various publics ranging from the media itself, to governments, professional and trade associations and other groups that make up civil society.
pcm: Dem establish Di Guild make dem use advance di interest of di profession, make e deepen editors dem relationship wit public, from media, goment, association wey dey professional and di one for trade and oda groups wey dey civil society

eng: It was to be a proactive agent of development to anticipate problems and tackle them, and clarify issues before they got out of hand.
pcm: Na make e for be proactive agent for development, wey go dey expect kasala, dey tackle am and make e clarify issues before e too serious.

eng: The promise of its birth was soon tested by the crisis that erupted in the early life of the First Republic.
pcm: Dey test di promise of hin birth soon for di crisis wey start for di early time of di First Republic

eng: A good number of the editors became casualties of the cat-and-mouse politics of the era.
