eng: Taming Nigerias oil spillage and gas flaring scourge
pcm: To tame Nigeria oil spillage and gas flarin scourge

eng: By Jerome-Mario Utomi
pcm: E kom from Jerome Mario-Utami

eng: The recent news report that the Okordia-Rumekpe 14-inch crude truck line operated by Shell Petroleum Development Company (SPDC) discharged some 213 barrels of crude oil into the Ikarama community in Bayelsa, has again brought to our consciousness that though Nigeria prides itself as the giant of Africa and the most populous black nation in the world, yet, it is still riddled with third world challenges.
pcm: Di recent news report say Okordia-Rumekpe 14-inch crude truck line wey Shell Petroleum Development Company (SPDC) dey operate discharge 213 barrel crude oil for Ikarama community for Bayelsa don reach awa side say though Nigeria wey been dey proud say dey be giant of Africa and di black kontri wey get pipo pass for di world stil dey get plenti third world kasala

eng: Essentially, while clarifying that an estimated 1.34 hectares of land was polluted by the leakage, which followed a rupture on the pipeline, SPDC among other things confirmed that probe into the incident had been concluded, noting that out of the 213 barrels of SPDCs bonny light crude stream leak, some 110 barrels are recoverable from the ongoing recovery exercise at the site, leaving an estimated spilled volume at 109.12 barrels.
pcm: As dem dey clarify say na like 1.34 hectare land dem pollute wit di leakage wey rupture for di pipeline follow, SPDC confirm say dey finish di investigation of di incident, dey tok say out of 213 of SPDC bonny light crude leak, na like 110 barrel dem see recover for di recovery exercise wey dem dey do for di site, e kom remain 109.12 barrel of di volume wey spill.

eng: Admittedly, these claims by the Dutch oil giant are verifiable facts but may not be the only explanation.
pcm: Admittedly, wetin Dutch oil giant claim na fact wey dem fit verify but e fit no be di only explanation

eng: Their clarification notwithstanding, there are indeed reasons that qualify such happening in Nigerias oil and gas industry as a reality that demands holistic analysis.
pcm: Notwitstandin dia clarification,reasons dey wey qualify dis kind apunin for Nigeria oil and gas industry as reality wey dey suppose analyse generally

eng: Lets begin with reality.
pcm: Make we start wit reality

eng: Aside from the awareness that spillage occurs, communal rights to a clean environment and access to clean water supplies are violated in such cases and the oil industry, by its admission, has abandoned thousands of polluted sites in the region, which needs to be identified and studied in details while communities adversely affected are adequately compensated for their losses, this latest spill is coming weeks after a similar one from a ruptured pipeline facility managed by one of the International Oil Companies operating in the Niger Delta that reportedly ravaged Benikrukru and adjourning communities in Warri South West Local Government Area of Delta State.
pcm: Aside from di awareness say spillage dey happen, communal right for environment wey clean and access for clean water supply na hin dey don violate for dat kind case, wit dia admission, dey don abandon thousands of site wey dey don pollute for di region, wey dem nid identify and study for detail as dey compensate di community wey e affect well for dia loss wella, dis lastest spill apun weeks afta one wey resemble am for one pipeline facility wey rupture wey one International Oil company wey dey  operate for Niger Delta dey manage, wey dem report say destroy Benikrukru and commuinty wey dey around am for Warri South-west local goment Area for Delta state.

eng: And another in the early hours of Sunday, March 14, 2021, at Polobubo/Opuama Communities, Warri North Local Government Area of the state, could settle.
pcm: And anoda one for early momo on Sunday, March 14,2021 for Polubobu / Opuama, Warri North local Goment Area for di state, go fit settle.

eng: Such litany of spillages also include but not limited to, namely; the historic large scale spillages in places such as the Ogoni Land, Rivers State and the Erovie community in Ozoro, Isoko North Local Government of Delta State 1990s, both in the Nigerias South South geopolitical zones, of which their negative impacts linger.
pcm: Dis kind big scale set of spillage also include but e no dey limited to; di big spillage wey dey history for place like Ogini land, Rivers State and Erovie community for Ozoro, Isoko North Local Goment for Delta state for 1990s, di two for Nigeria south south zone and negative impact still dey der.

eng: Are these the only explanations/examples?
pcm: Shey na di only explanation /example dem be dis?

eng: The answer is a definite
pcm: Di answer na ogbonge

eng: no, as there exist yet
pcm: no, as oda ones dey

eng: other critical reasons/concerns why we should view the situation as a crisis.
pcm: Oda critical reason / concern dem why we suppose see di situation as crisis.

eng: First and very fundamental is the inability of Nigeria and Nigerians to appreciate and treat crude oil spillage and environmental pollution resulting from exploration/crude oil production related activities as a national calamity.
pcm: Di first and veri important na di inability of Nigeria and hin pipo to appreciate and treat activity wey relate to crude oil spillage and environment pollution wey dey kom from exploration/crude oil production as national calamity

eng: The second is the stunning consciousness that gas flaring/environmental degradation resulting from crude oil prospecting/production-related activities in the country is under reported.
pcm: Di second na di stunnin conciousness wey gas flarin/ environment degradation dey apun bikos of activities wey dey related to crude oil prospectin/ production for di kontri dey under-reported.

eng: This second concern stems from a recent comment, which according to media report was credited to the Director-General, National Oil Spill Detection and Response Agency, (NOSDRA), Idris Musa, who stated that findings by his agency showed that an average of five oil spills was recorded daily in Nigeria.
pcm: Dis second concern dey kom from one recent comment, wey be say from media report na from di Director-General, National Oil Spill Detection and Response Agency (NOSDRA), Idris Musa, wey tok say wetin hin agency find show say average of five oil spills na hin Nigeria dey record evriday.

eng: Musa, who spoke to journalists in Abuja, said, In 2018 we had about 600 oil spill incidents and in 2019, we had over 700 oil spill-impacted sites across the country.
pcm: Musa, wey follow journalists tok for Abuja, tok say for 2018, we get 600 oil spill incident and for 2019, we get about 700 oil spill-impacted site actross di kontri.

eng: This wakeful comment becomes even more relevant to the present discourse when one remembers that Nigeria according to reports is dotted with about 139 gas flare locations spread across the Niger Delta both in onshore and offshore oil fields where gas which constitutes about 11 percent of the total gas produced are flared.
pcm: Dis comment wey dey open brain dey more important for wetin we dey discourse if pesin remember say Nigeria accordin to report don get about 139 place wey gas don flare across Niger Delta both for di oil fields wey dey water and di one wey no dey, wer gas wey dey flare dey reach 11% of evrithin wey dem dey produce.

eng: More than anything else, it brings to mind the questions as to; what exactly impedes the development of the petroleum sector and Niger Delta region?
pcm: Pass anything, na di question dem wey e bring kom mind be; wetin dey stop di development of petroleum sector and Niger Delta region

eng: Are there no legislative works?
pcm: Shey Legislative work no dey?

eng: Why is such a legislative framework not providing a strong source of remedy for individuals and communities negatively affected by oil exploration and production in the coastal communities?
pcm: Why dis kind legislative framework no dey provide strong source of solution for pipo and community wey oil exploration and production affect badly for coastal comminity dem?

eng: If these frameworks exist, why is it not effective and enforceable?
pcm: If dis framework dey, why e no dey work or make dem do am?

eng: Is the framework as comprehensive as a legal solution to the issues of oil-related violations?
pcm: Shey di framework get evrithin  like legal solution for di issues of violations wey relate to oil?

eng: Why has the nation not learned a valid lesson from the Dutch government where all operators are required to restore their areas of operation back to how nature intended?
pcm: Why di nation neva learn serious lesson from Dutch goment wia all di pipo wey dey operate must restore wia dem dey operate back to how dey meet am?

eng: Regardless of what others may say, the truth is that if as a nation we are desirous of developing policies that will engineer prosperity in the oil and gas sectors while saving the people of the region, then, we must be ready to locate the strategic triangles that hold the key to success.
pcm: Regardless of wetin oda pipo tok, di truth be say if all of us get am for mind to develop policy wey go bring prosperity for oil and gas sector, while we go still save di pipo for di region, we ready to find di strategic triangles wey hold di key to success for hand.

eng: Separate from the fact that success requires a careful analysis of the various kinds of knowledge needed to make innovation possible, the need for the nation to straddle the middle ground has become necessary since both the ministry and sector have for a very long time manifested signs of an institution with neither primed nor positioned potentials.
pcm: Apart from di fact say success need make dem analyse am wit care, of di different kind of knowledge wey dem need to make innovation possible, e don necessary for di nation make dem hold di middle ground since both di ministry and sector don dey manifest signs for long time now say dem go be institution wey no get potential wey strong.

eng: And as we know, any organisation, be it private or public that fails to search for its potentials leaves its survival to chance.
pcm: And as we know, any organization, whether private or public wey no gree search for hin potential, hin survival na by chance.

eng: At this instant, looking at both the operational templates of the ministry and how the up, mid and the downstream players of the petroleum industry have become reputed for non-compliance to set rules,  it will not be a wrong assertion to conclude that the critical factors fueling crude oil spillage/gas flaring can be divided into the following; the existence of  multiple but obsolete regulatory framework, which characterises the oil and gas exploration and production in Nigeria; federal governments failure to get the nations refineries back to full refining capacity; the petroleum ministrys inability to get committed  to making International Oil Companies(IOCs) adhere strictly to the international best practices as it relates to their operational environment; And finally, non-existence of clear responsibility/work details and action plans for agencies and parastatals functioning under the ministry.
pcm: For dis level, if we luk di operational template of di ministry, and how dey don know say di up, mid and down stream players of di petroleum industry say dem no dey follow rules, e no go dey wrong make pesin conclude say dem fit divide di serious reasons wey dey kos Crude oil spillage/gas flarin to; regulatory framework wey plenti wey no dey work, oil and gas exploration and production for Nigeria dey; federal goment failure to make di kontri refineries dey work to dia full capacity back ; petroleum ministry inability to make International Oil Companies dey follow di international best practices as e relate to di environment wey dem dey work; Di last one, clear responsibility/work details wey no dey and action plans for agencies and parastatals wey dey function under di ministry.

eng: The above failures have as a direct consequence; cast a long dark shadow on the ministry, the sector and the region.
pcm: Di failures dem wey dey up get direct consequence, na bad influence for di sector, di ministry and di region.

eng: To explain these points beginning with the first challenge, it is worth commenting that the business of crude oil exploration and issues of oil production in the country is regulated by multiple but very weak laws and Acts of which most of these laws not only complicate enforcement but are curiously too old-fashioned for the changing demands of time thereby, creating loopholes for operators, especially the International Oil Companies (IOC) to exploit both the government and host communities.
pcm: To take explain dis points, make we use di first challenge start, e dey important to dey tok about di law dem wey regulate crude oil exploration and oil production issue wey plenti law dey regulate but too dey weak and di Acts wey dey law wey no dey just complicate how e dey work, but e don too old as time don dey change, e dey create corner corner way for pipo wey dey operate for der especially the International Oil Companies (IOC)  make dem fit use exploit both di goment and host communities.

eng: Some of these laws/Acts in question that have been in operation since the 1960s but currently not achieving their purpose includes but not limited to; the Petroleum Act of 1969, The Harmful Waste(Special Criminal Positions etc), Act 1988, Mineral Oil Safety Regulation 1963, Petroleum(Drilling and Production) Regulation 1969
pcm: some of dis laws/acts wey we dey tok about don dey since 1960 but dey no dey achieve dia purpose wey Di Petroleum Act of 1969, Di Harmful Waste(Special Criminal Positions etc), Act 1988, Mineral Oil Safety Regulation 1963, Petroleum(Drillin and Production) Regulation 1969 dey but no be oly dis one dem.

eng: (Subsidiary Legislation to the Petroleum Act) and the off-shore Oil Revenue (Registration of Grants)Act 1971 among others.
pcm: (Subsidiary Legislation to Petroleum Act) and di off-shore Oil Revenue (Registration of Grants) Acts 1971 among odas.

eng: Without minding their number, concepts, provisions and definitions, these laws have become obsolete, old-schooled and out-fashioned to the extent that they now provide leeway for the operators in the sector to exploit both the government and host communities.
pcm: As dey no mind di number, concept, provision and definition dem, dis law dem no dey useful again, dey don old to di extent say dem dey give pipo wey dey work for di sector corner corner to dey chop both di goment and host community dem.

eng: Utomi is the Programme Coordinator (Media and Policy), Social and Economic Justice Advocacy (SEJA), Lagos
pcm: Utomi na di Programme Coordinator (Media and Policy), Social and Econnomic Justice Advocacy (SEJA) , Lagos.

eng: Crystal and Davy (1969) explain that journalese language ia an important aspect of journalism.
pcm: Crystal and Davy (1969) explain say di language wey journalist dem dey use dey important for di journalism work.

eng: SEC bans unregistered CMOs from operations May 31
pcm: SEC ban CMO wey dey no register from operation May 31

eng: The Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) says it will stop operations of the Capital Market Operators (CMOs) yet to renew their registration on May 31.
pcm: Di Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) tok say dem go stop Capital Market Operators (CMOs) operation wey neva renew dia registration for May 31

eng: The commission disclosed this in a circular signed by the management on Monday in Abuja.
pcm: Di commission tok am for one circular wey di management sign on Monday for Abuja

eng: The commission said that the CMOs yet to renew their registration at the expiration of late filing on May 31, would not be eligible to operate in the capital market.
pcm: Di commission tok say any CMO wey no renew dia registration before late fillin expire for May 31 no go fit operate for capital market.

eng: Consequently, the commission said that late filing for renewal of registration would only be entertained from May 1 to May 31.
pcm: Bikos of wetin dey apun, di commission tok say to dey fill di renewal of registration late go dey between May 1 to May 30

eng: It said that the CMOs were required to have completed the renewal process on or before April 30.
pcm: E tok say di CMOs need complete renewal process on or before April 30.

eng: The commission noted that names of the CMOs that had renewed their registration would be published on SECs website and national dailies.
pcm: Di commission note say dem go publish di name of di CMOs wey renew dia registration of SEC website and national newspapers dem.

eng: It added that the names of eligible CMOs would be communicated to the relevant Securities Exchanges and Trade Associations.
pcm: E kom add say dem go declare di name of CMOs wey dey eligible give relevant security exchange and Trade Associations.

eng: The News Agency of Nigeria (NAN) reports that the SEC had in March issued a circular to the general public and the CMOs for the reintroduction of the periodic renewal of registration by operators.
pcm: Di News Agency of Nigeria (NAN) report say SEC for March don share circular give general public and di CMOs for di periodic renewal of registration by di operator wey dey wan introduce again

eng: The basic quality of the Language of Journalism is clarity, and its most desired effect is for the language to be understood.
pcm: Di simple quality wey journalism language get na to dey clear, and wetin e wan show pass na make pipo fit understand am.

eng: Kano Pillars go top after 1-1 draw at Katsina United
pcm: Kano Pillars dey top afta 1-1 draw for Katsina United

eng: Former champions, Kano Pillars have assumed leadership of the 2021 NPFL table even as they were forced to 1-1 draw by Katsina United in the week 22 match played Sunday at the Muhammadu Dikko stadium in Katsina.
pcm: Former Champions, Kano Pillars don dey top chart back for 2021 NPFL as Katsina United force dem go 1-1 draw for week 22 match wey dey play on Sunday for Muhammed Dikko Stadium for Katsina.

eng: Five minutes after Suraj Ayeleso saved Ahmed Rasheeds penalty kick, Pillars inspirational captain, Rabiu Ali popped up at the other end to give the Masu gida boys the lead from a direct free kick in the 26th minute.
pcm: Five minute afta Suraj Ayeleso save di penalty wey Ahmed Rasheed play, Pillars captain wey dey Inspirational, Rabiu Ali show for di oda side score wey make Masu gida boys dey lead from one direct free kick as e reach 26 minute

eng: However, Pillars lead was short-lived as Ahmed Rasheed made amends for his earlier miss from the spot by heading home Usman Baraus cross to level scores in the 34th minute.
pcm: Pillars win no tey as Ahmed Rasheed kom later score di goal wey he lose before from di spot as he dey go home, Usman Bara cross to go level scores for di 34th minute.

eng: The draw put Pillars on top of the log with 41 points but their reign may not last more than 24 hours, if Akwa United who are on 40 points would beat Rangers today in Uyo.
pcm: Di draw put Kano Pillars for di top wit 41 points but dia reign fit no last 24 hours, if Akwa United wey dey 40 points beat Rangers for Uyo today.

eng: In Jos, it was a good day in the office for Plateau United who rubbed more salt into Wikki Tourists injuries with a 4-1 victory.
pcm: For Jos, na beta day for Plateau United as dey put pepe for Wikki Tourist eye wit dia 4-1 victory.

eng: Ibrahim Mustapha scored in the 3rd minute from a tight spot to start the rout before Jibrin Abubakar equalised for the hapless Tourists in the 9th minute.
pcm: Ibrahin Muhammed score for di 3rd minute from one bad corner take start di game, before Jibrin Abubakar Equalise for di yeye Tourists wen e reach 9 minute.

eng: Thereafter, it was one way traffic as Mohammed Zulkifilu scored a brace (17, 55) before Oche Ohowechi put the icing on the cake for Plateau United in the 90th minute.
pcm: Na one way traffic as Muhammed Zulkifilu score brace (17, 55) before Oche Ohowechi kom show dem who di baba be as he score for 90 minite for Plateau United

eng: Nasarawa United also overwhelmed visiting Heartland 3-1 after Aliyu Abdullahi scored a brace (27, 50) and Marthings Owolijah tripled the lead in the 61st minute before Chijoke Akuneto reduced the deficit with a screamer in the 85th minute.
pcm: Nasarawa United sef pepe Heartland wey dey visit 3-1 afta Aliyu Abdullah score brace (27, 50) and Martins Owolijah score di third one wen e reach 61 minute, before Chijioke Akuneto kom boost hin team morale as he score wen e reach 85 minute.

eng: In Gombe, host Adamawa United chased Wolves to a 3-3 draw, FC IfeanyiUbah topped Sunshine Stars 1-0 in Nnewi in the battle of relegation teams, MFM piped Lobi Stars 1-0 in Lagos and Abia Warriors
pcm: For Gombe, Adamawa United wey dey host pursue Wolves go 3-3 draw, FC Ifeanyi Ubah win Sunshine stars 1-0 for Nnewi for di battle of Relegation team, MFM sama Lobi stars 1-0 for Lagos and Abia Warriors

eng: forced Rivers United to 0-0 draw in Port-Harcourt.
pcm: Force Rivers United go 0-0 draw for Port-Harcourt

eng: At the Ahmadu Bello stadium Kaduna, Jigawa Stars left it late to draw 1-1 with visiting Dakkada FC.
pcm: For Ahmadu Bello Stadium Kaduna, Jigawa Stars follow Dakkada Fc wey dey visit draw.

eng: While the match between Enyimba and Kwara United didnt hold due to the formers continental engagement, Akwa United will seek to reclaim the top spot from Pillars when they host Rangers this afternoon.
pcm: As Enyimba and Kwara United no play dia match bikos of Enyimba continential engagement, Akwa united go find way reclaim dia top-spot from Pillars wen dey host Rangers dis aftanoon.

eng: The simplicity of the language of Journalism makes the reader to have confidence in the kind of newspaper he choose to read.
pcm: Di way wey journalism language simple reach na hin dey make pesin wey dey read am get confidence chose di kind newspaper wey he go read.

eng: Golf doesnt depend on govt for foreign journeys  Oyinlola
pcm: Oyinlola tok say Golf no dey depend on goment for foreign journey.

eng: The chairman, caretaker committee, Nigeria Golf Federation (NGF), Prince Olagunsoye Oyinlola has said since they came on board in 2017, his federation has been attending international competitions without government support.
pcm: Di Chairman, caretaker committee, Nigeria Golf Federation (NGF), Prince Olugunsoye Oyinlola don tok say since hin and hin pipo enta post for 2017, hin federation been dey attend International competition witout goment support

eng: Speaking during the inauguration of the caretaker committees by the Minister of Youth and Sports Development, Sunday Dare on Tuesday, Oyinlola said Ever since we came on board to administer the federation, we have been up and taking part in international competitions and ensuring our golfers are well exposed.
pcm: As  he dey tok for di inarguration of Caretaker committee by di Minister of youth nd spot development, Sunday Dare on Tuesday, Oyinlola tok say, since we don dey administer di federation, we dey do evrithin, we dey take part for international competition and we dey ensure say awa golfers dey exposed well.

eng: As president, I have always been taking part in international competitions.
pcm: As President, I don always take part for international competition.

eng: We have taken our players to Morocco, Ireland, Botswana, Argentina and Mauritius on our own,he said.
pcm: He tok say; we don take awa players go Morroco, Ireland, Botswana, Argentinga and Mauritius on awa own.

eng: He further said the standard of the game has improved and efforts have been made to improve and discover new talents.
pcm: He kom still tok say di standard of di game improve and dey done make effort  to find new talent and na to improve am.

eng: I think we have gone a step higher than when we came on board.
pcm: I think say we don dey high pass wen we first start.

eng: We have been organizing age-grade competitions to discover new talents.
pcm: We don dey use age-grade competition wey we organise take find new talent.

eng: We have been keeping faith with our programs as far as golf is concerned.
pcm: We still get faith wit awa program for golf mata.

eng: If we find ourselves going to the Olympics, Im sure I can get golfers that will do us proud,he stated.
pcm: He tok say; If we fit reach Olympics, I dey sure say we get golfers wey go play well.

eng: It is the peculiarities of the field that set it apart from others.
pcm: Na di plenti special tins wey di work get make am different from di rest.

eng: Cult clashes: Man arrested over killing of cousin in Edo
pcm: Cult Clash: Dem arrest one man for Edo say he kil hin cousin

eng: Operatives of the Edo State Police Command have arrested a man identified as Igboje Victor, for allegedly taking part in the killing of his cousin brother during a rival cult fight.
pcm: Pipo wey dey operate for Edo State Police command don arrest one man wey hin name na Igboje Victor, bikos dem think say he get hand for di kilin of hin cousin brother wen two rival cult dey fight.

eng: Igboje was among the 54 suspects paraded by the Edo State Police Commissioner, Philip Aliyu Ogbadu, for involving in various crimes in the state.
pcm: Igboje dey among di 54 suspect wey Edo state Police Commissioner parade, Phillips Aliyu Ogbadu, say dem dey various crime for di state.

eng: According to the commissioner, the suspects were arrested for armed robbery, kidnapping, murder, cultism, rape among others.
pcm: As per wetin di Comissioner tok, dey arrest di suspect for armed robbery, kidnappin, murder, cultism, rape and oda tins.

eng: The incident, it was learnt, happened in Sabogida-Ora Opuje community Owan West local government of Edo State.
pcm: Dey later know say di incident apun for Sabogida-Ora Opuje community for Owan west local goment for Edo state

eng: Im innocent
pcm: I dey innocent

eng: In an interview with Daily Trust, Igboje denied involvement in the killing.
pcm: For one interview wit Daily trust, Igboje deny say he get hand for di kilin

eng: I was not involved in the killing of my brother but was arrested because I am a member of Eiye cult group while my late brother is in Aiye group.
pcm: I no get hand for my brother death but dem arrest me bikos I be Eiye cult group member while my late brother dey Aiye group.

eng: In our community, we used to sell Indian Hemp to make money but the Aiye group used the drug business to arrest Eiye members through the police.
pcm: For awa community, we been dey sell Igbo take make moni, but Aiye group use di drug business use police arrest Eiye members.

eng: The leader of both group scheduled a meeting at night to resolve the issue,he said.
pcm: He tok say di leader of di two group plan to meet dat night solve di gbege

eng: He however added that, on the day of the meeting, Aiye members laid an ambush and shot at Eiye members while on their way to the venue of the meeting, killing one of them who was later taken to the mortuary.
pcm: He kom later add say, For di night of di meeting, Aiye members set trap for dem, dey kom shot Eiye members as dem dey go di meetin venue, dey kil one of dem wey dey later carry go mortuary.

eng: The brother of the deceased, who is a military officer, said they should go and bury the boy because of his mother
pcm: Di pesin wey die brother na soldier, he say make dey go bury am bikos of hin mama.

eng: After the burial, I went to the neighbouring community to buy food but when I returned, I learnt that Eiye members had gone to attack an Aiye member who happened to be my cousin and he died as a result of the injury he sustained.
pcm: Afta di burial,  I go di neighbourin community go buy food but wen I kom back, I hear say Eiye boys don go attack one Aiye guy and di guy na my cousin, he die bikos of di injury wey hin get

eng: He said he was not among the group that attacked his brother, adding because we belong to rival cult groups, they said I was the one that killed him
pcm: He tok say he no dey for di group wey attack hin brother, he add say na bikos dem dey different group make dem tok say na hin kil am

eng: and I was arrested by police alongside others.
pcm: And police kom arrest me wit di rest

eng: I was not even there when my brother was attacked.
pcm: I no even dey der wen dey attack my brother

eng: I didnt kill my brother,he said.
pcm: He tok say: I no kil my brother

eng: The commissioner of police, however, said the suspects would be charged to court as soon as the investigation is completed.
pcm: Di commissioner of police kom tok say, dem go go court if dey don finish dia investigation

eng: Nigeria's economic woe worsens as most food item doubled in price over the weekend and the bikers decided to grace us with their 30% increase too on every item made with flour
pcm: Economy kasala for Nigeria don worse as plenti food item don double dia price for di weekend and pipo wey dey bake sef join dem as dey add 30% for evritin wey dem dey use flour do.

eng: Economic woes deepen as bakers hike bread, biscuits prices by 30%
pcm: Economy kasala dey plenti as bakers increase bread and biscuit wit 30%

eng: The economic hardship in the country has taken a new dimension as the Association of Master Bakers and Caterers of Nigeria (AMBCN) has directed its members to increase the prices of bread, biscuits and other baked items by 30 percent due to the rising cost of production.
pcm: Di kontri economy wey hard don show face for anoda mata as di Association of Masters Bakers and Caterers of Nigeria (AMBCN) don tell dia members say make dem increase bread, biscuit and any oda tin wey dem dey bake price wit 30 percent bikos of di cost of production wey don high.

eng: Bread and biscuits are common consumable items in many Nigerian households and before the association gave this directive, many had lamented the sharp increase in cost of items across the country.
pcm: Bread and biscuit na food wey common for plenti house for Nigeria, and before di association announce wetin dem tok, plenti pipo for di kontri don dey complain bikos of how tins cost.

eng: At the National Executive Council (NEC) meeting of the association held in Abuja recently, members lamented the cost of production and reached the resolution of raising prices.
pcm: For di National Executive Council (NEC) meeting wey di association do for Abuja recently, dia members dey complain about how tins cost and dey gree say make dem increase di price of wetin dem dey sell.

eng: The national president of AMBCN, Mansur Umar, said the price adjustment was as a result of the sudden increase in the cost of production as well as prices of sugar, butter, yeast and flour.
pcm: AMBCN national president, Mansur Umar, tok say di price wey dem change na bikos of  di way wey cost of production take increase suddenly and how sugar, butter, yeast and flour moni sef increase

eng: While commending the federal government for resuscitating the cassava flour programme, the association bemoaned the skyrocketing price of regular flour in the last six months with one truck of flour which cost less than N6 million is now N9m.
pcm: As dem dey commend federal goment say dey revive di cassava flour programme, di association dey complain bad bad about regular flour price wey just increase anyhow since di last six month, wey be say one flour truck no reach 6 million before kom be 9 million now.

eng: After considering the impact of the skyrocketed prices of baking ingredients/materials for the survival of our noble business, which is presently bleeding, the association came to the conclusion to adjust our prices by 30 percent,he said.
pcm: He tok say; afta we consider di bakin/ingredient and material price wey don too increase, sake of say make dis awa noble work wey dey bleed fit survive, di association conclude say make we just increase awa price wit 30 percent

eng: The association also resolved to ask the federal government to reverse the tariff regime imposed by the National Agency for Food and Drugs Administration and Control (NAFDAC) and to streamline bakers regulation by NAFDAC only.
pcm: Di association sef conclude say dem go ask federal goment make dem reverse di tariff regime wey National Agency for Food Administration and Control (NAFDAC) force dem dey pay and make only NAFDAC dey steamline bakers regulation.

eng: Also speaking, the national secretary, Jude Okafor, was hopeful that the federal government will meet their demands to avert the increase.
pcm: Dia national secretary , Jude Okafor wey tok sef say he dey hope say feredal goment do wetin dey want so dem go fit avoid di moni wey dey wan increase.

eng: Nigeria's senior male basketball team once again prove that they are from the giant of Africa as they nabbed the Highest rank African team title at the Olympics.
pcm: Nigeria senior male basketball team don prove say na from Giant of Africa dey take kom as dey collect Highest rank African team title for Olympics.

eng: DTigers draw kenya, Mali, Cote dIvoire for 2021 Afrobasket
pcm: Tigers follow Kenya, Mali, Cote d'Ivoire for 2021 Afrobasket.

eng: Nigerias senior male basketball team, DTigers have been drawn against Kenya, Mali and Cote dIvoire in the group stage of the 2021 FIBA Afrobasket.
pcm: Nigeria senior male basketball team don follow Kenya, Mali and Cote d'Ivoire draw for di group stage for 2021 FIBA Afrobasket.

eng: At yesterdays brief ceremony, the 2015 Afrobasket champions landed in group C for the tournament to be held between 24th, August and 5th, September.
pcm: For di cermony wey dem do yesterday briefly, di 2015 Afrobasket champion land for Group C for di tournament wey dem go do between August 24 and September 5.

eng: With many already tipping the DTigers as one of the title contenders, Nigeria will still face Cote dIvoire (ranked 50), 77th ranked Mali and Coach Liz Mills inspired Kenya who pulled off an upset against Angola with a buzzer beater to qualify after 28 years wait.
pcm: As many pipo don dey tok say Tigers na strong team wey fit win di title, Nigeria go still face Cote d'Ivoire wey dey number 50 for rank, Mali wey be number 77 and Kenya wey beat Angola anyhow afta dey don wait 28 years bikos of dia Coach Liz Mills.

eng: The 2021 Tokyo Olympics bound team will hope to go a step further than their 2017 achievement where they won the silver medal.
pcm: Di team wey go go Tokyo Olypmics for 2021, go nid play well pass wetin dey play for 2017 wen dey win Silver medal.

eng: The team who lost to host-Tunisia had since evolved to become number one in Africa and number 22 in the world.
pcm: Di team lose to Tunisia wey dey host dat time and since dat time, dey be number one for Africa and number 22 for di world.

eng: DTigers in 2019 became the first country in the world to qualify for the FIBA World Cup.
pcm: Tigers na hin be di first kontri wey go qualify for FIBA World Cup for 2019.

eng: Despite narrowly missing out of the quarter finals, the team were able to punch their Olympics ticket as the highest ranked team out of Africa at the tournament.
pcm: Although e remain small wey dem go enta quarter finals, di team collect di Olympic ticket say na dem be di oga for Africa for di tournament.

eng: NDLEA hardworks pays off: The depth of illicit drugs trafficking and usage is uncovered in Nigeria as NDLEA has uncovered N30bn slush funds and drugs worth over N90bn
pcm: NDLEA work don pay: Drug traffickin and de rate wey dem dey use am don show as NDLEA don see N30bn illegal moni collect and N90bn illegal drug sef join.

eng: Illicit drugs: NDLEA uncovers N30bn slush funds
pcm: Illicit drugs: NDLEA reveal N30bn unlawful moni.

eng: The chairman of the National Drug Law Enforcement Agency, Buba Marwa, says the NDLEA is currently investigating N30bn slush funds believed to be proceeds of drugs.
pcm: National Drug Law Enforcement Agency Chairman, Buba Marwa, tok say NDLEA dey investigate N30bn slush fund wey dem feel say na moni for drugs.

eng: He disclosed this in Abuja on Monday while giving commendation letters to 45 outstanding officers as well as best performing commands award for the months of March and April, 2021.
pcm: He tok am for Abuja on Monday mornin wen hin give 45 officers wey dey work well commendation letter and best performing command award for March and April, 2021.

eng: He said the agencys offensive action would not stop until the nations streets, communities, towns and cities had been cleaned up of any remnant of illicit drugs.
pcm: He tok say di strong action wey di agency dey take no go stop until  all di street,community, town and city wey dey di kontri no get drugs wey dey illegal again

eng: He said: While we keep up the offensive in the field, the leadership of the agency will daily continue to work out effective strategies and tactics to sustain the momentum.
pcm: He tok say: As we continue to dey fight how dem dey use illegal drugs for outside, awa leaders for di agency go dey find how dem go maintain di situation.

eng: That is why weve strengthened our Directorate of Assets and Financial Investigations to go after all assets or funds linked to drug trafficking which had led to interim and final forfeiture orders on assets and funds worth billions of naira linked to drug traffickers and barons.
pcm: Na di reaseon why we don make awa Directorate of asset and Finanacial Investigations, go make sure say dem collect all di moni and property wey get link wit drug traffickin, wey lead dem go meet di pipo dem and final order to forfeit property and moni wey worth plenti billion naira wey get link wit di pipo wey dey traffick di drugs and dia baron dem.

eng: Marwa said the vigour with which the agency was targeting drug cartels had led to the seizure of 2,050,766.33kg of assorted illicit drugs and cash worth over N90bn as well as arrest of 2,175 drug traffickers.
pcm: Marwa tok say di strength wey di agency dey use target drug cartel don make dem fit seize different illegal drug wey reach 2,050,766.33kg, moni wey reach N90bn and dey don arrest 2,175 pipo wey dey carry di drug.

eng: He stressed the need to deny criminal elements all benefits of their proceeds of crime in addition to sending them to jail.
pcm: He emphasize on top di fact say e dey important make di criminals dem no go fit collect any moni wey dem get from dia drugs dey go still kom go jail.

eng: The matter of Kidnapping in Zaria and the country as a whole is now turning to a nightmare
pcm: kidnappin mata for Zaria and whole kontri don dey worse.

eng: Vigilantes arrest 2 kidnappers in Zaria
pcm: Vigilante arrest 2 kidnappers for Zaria

eng: Two suspected kidnappers have been arrested by vigilantes at the Low-Cost area of Zaria in Kaduna State, Daily Trust reports.
pcm: Daily trust tok say vigilante don arrest two pipo wey dem suspect say be kidnapper for one ghetto area for Zaria, Kaduna State.

eng: The incident occurred around 10 pm on Sunday when an unspecified number of kidnappers stormed the low-cost in an attempt to kidnap the residents but were confronted by the local vigilantes.
pcm: Di incident apun around 10 on Sunday wen some kidnappers enta di place wit force say dey wan kidnap pipo wey dey stay for der but local vigilante face dem.

eng: A resident, who did not want to be named, said the kidnappers were shooting sporadically to scare the people but the vigilantes engaged them in a gun duel before the arrival of the police.
pcm: One pesin wey dey stay der wey no wan tok hin name, tok say di kidnappers dey shoot anyhow to make pipo fear but di vigilante face dem wit dia gun before police kom later.

eng: Daily Trust however gathered that four residents were abducted by the other members of the kidnap gang while some youths sustained injuries in the encounter that lasted for about two hours.
pcm: Daily trust later find out say some of di kidnappers dem kidnap four pipo wey dey der as some youth injure diasef for wen e apun, di kidnappin last for about two hours.

eng: Kaduna State Police Command spokesman ASP Mohammed Jalige said the two arrested suspects were undergoing interrogation while their fleeing accomplices were being trailed by the police.
pcm: Kaduna State Police Command Spokeman ASP Muhammad Jalige tok say dem dey interrogate di two pipo wey dem arrest and police dey find di oda ones wey run.

eng: IPOB leader has threatened to turn the country to a zone riddled with bloodbath for people that don't see reason with him
pcm: IPOB leader don threaten pipo say hin go dey kil pipo wey no reason wit am

eng: Interrogating IPOBs Emma Powerful threat to spill blood
pcm: IPOB Emma Powerful don threaten pipo say he go spill blood.

eng: The threat to murder in cold-blood by one Emma Powerful, media and publicity secretary of the Indigenous Peoples of Biafra (IPOB) of any Igbo who neglects his warning is certainly going too far and should not be ignored, except we have finally descended into anarchy, where the powerful  as the little fascist, Mr. Emma Powerful as he called himself  can drag people out for merely disagreeing with him or his organization and have them dispatched to their ancestor as he boasted.
pcm: Emma Powerful wey be media and publicity secretary for IPOB threat to dey kil any Igbo pesin wey no follow hin warning don dey too serious, and dey no suppose ignore am except say we no get goment, wer small small fascist like Mr Emma Powerful as he call himsef go dey tok say hin go dey drag pipo kom out, dey send dem go meet Baba God as he tok bikos dey no follow am or hin organization.

eng: He did not seem to boast empty; as the mayhem that is enveloping the South East region of Nigeria is obviously orchestrated.
pcm: Di mouth wey hin dey run no be play; as e be say di kasala for Nigeria South-east show say na plan dey plan am.

pcm: Melania Trump chief of staff don resign

eng: Stephanie Grisham, U.S. First Lady Melania Trumps chief of staff, says she is resigning effective immediately.
pcm: Stephanie Grisham, wey be chief of staff of U.S. First Lady Melania Trump, don tok say she dey resign immediately.

eng: A longtime associate of Mrs Trump, Grisham was also a former White House spokeswoman.
pcm: Grisham na former White House tok-tok pesin and longtime pesin of Mrs Trump.

eng: She said it had been an honour to serve the Trump administration.
pcm: She  tok say na honour e be for her to serve di Trump administration.

eng: Grisham gave no reasons for her unexpected move.
pcm: Grisham no give any reason for her decision.

eng: It remained unclear whether her departure was related to the storming of the Capitol by supporters of outgoing president Donald Trump.
pcm: We still neva know weda her resignation na becos of di attack on di Capitol by pipo wey dey support outgoing president Donald Trump.

eng: Traffickers conceal drugs inside statue of Blessed Virgin Mary
pcm: Traffickers hide drugs for inside statue of Blessed Virgin Mary

eng: Drug traffickers looking for a fail-proof way to smuggle illicit drugs decided on the religious route by stuffing their stash in a statue of the Blessed Virgin Mary, Mother of Jesus.
pcm: Drug traffickers wey dey find easy way to smuggle illegal drugs don follow di religious route as dem load di statue of di Blessed Virgin Mary, Mother of Jesus wit drugs.

eng: NDLEA operatives embedded in two courier companies intercepted the drugs concealed in the statue and some in auto spare parts to be dispatched to Canada and the United Arab Emirates.
pcm: NDLEA operatives wey dem plant for two courier companies seize di drugs wey dem hide inside di statue, and som odas for inside motor spare parts wey dem wan ship go Canada and  UAE.

eng: A stash of 140 grammes of methamphetamine stuffed inside a statue of Mary headed for the Philippines was intercepted in one of the courier companies.
pcm: About 140 grammes of methamphetamine wey dem wan send go Philippines, inside di statue of Mary na im officers seize for one of di courier company.

eng: Another 500 grammes of heroin concealed in auto spare parts headed for Canada was intercepted in a second courier company.
pcm: Anoda 500 grammes of heroin wey dem dey send go Canada for inside motor spare parts na im dem seize for di second courier company.

eng: A separate package of 3.1kg of Indian hemp concealed inside spices and another one kilogramme of Indian hemp concealed in local herbs head for the UAE were also seized, according to Femi Babafemi, director of media and advocacy at the National Drug Law Enforcement Agency.
pcm: Accordin to Mr Femi Babafemi wey be di director of media and advocacy for NDLEA, dem seize anoda two separate package of Indian hemp wey dem wan send go UAE. 3.1kg wey dem hide inside spices and anoda one kilogramme wey dey inside local herbs.

eng: In a related development, the NDLEA in sting operations arrested 31 suspects in Ondo State for being in possession of 276 kg of assorted illicit drugs.
pcm: For anoda development, di NDLEA for different sting operation arrest 31 suspects for Ondo State, unto say dem catch dem wit 276 kg of assorted illegal drugs.

eng: Those arrested included seven females.
pcm: Som of dose wey dem arrest na seven female.

eng: They were arrested during a two-week raid which began on April 6.
pcm: Dem arrest dem durin a two-week raid wey begin for April 6.

eng: Babafemi said that the sting operations were carried out to curb the increasing rate of drug abuse among youths and even the elderly in Ondo State.
pcm: Babafemi tok say dem do di sting operations to stop di rate of drug abuse wey dey increase among youths and even di elderly for Ondo State.

eng: He added that the illicit drugs seized were 74.285kgs of Indian hemp, 267grammes of other psychotropic substances;
pcm: E add am join say di illegal drugs wey dem seize na 74.285kgs of Indian hemp, 267 grammes of oda psychotropic substance;

eng: 201kgs of skuchies (a combination of Indian hemp, tramadol, ethanol, and Zobo).
pcm: 201kgs of skuchies (combination of Indian hemp, tramadol, ethanol, and Zobo).

eng: NDLEA dismantled or destroyed most of the vending spots where the drugs were being dispensed, he said.
pcm: NDLEA scatter or destroy most of di spots wia dem dey sell di drugs. E yarn.

eng: In Akwa Ibom, the NDLEA also seized 62.150kg of illicit drugs in Oron and Uyo.
pcm: Inside Akwa Ibom, di NDLEA also seize 62.150kg of illegal drugs for Oron and Uyo.

eng: Babafemi quoted the NDLEA commander in the state, Obot Bassey, as saying that four suspects were arrested in two sting operations conducted on April 22 and April 23.
pcm: Babafemi yarn wetin di NDLEA commander for di state, Obot Bassey tok, say na four suspect dem arrest inside two sting operations wey dem do for April 22 and April 23.

eng: He stated that NDLEA chairman, retired Brig.-Gen.
pcm: E tok am say di NDLEA chairman, retired Brig.-Gen.

eng: Buba Marwa, had commended operatives in the two states and those of Operations and General Investigations Directorate in Lagos for their steadfastness.
pcm: Buba Marwa, don commend di operatives for di two states and dose wey dey Operations and General Investigations Directorate for Lagos on dia steadfastness.

eng: Pastor Adefarasin, if Nigeria is a scam; then were all scammers
pcm: Pastor Adefarasin; if Nigeria na scam; den all of us na scammers

eng: It is the bounden duty of every citizen to hold the government to account.
pcm: Na di compulsory duty of everi citizen to hold di government to account.

eng: In fact, citizenship is a call to duty  for the state.
pcm: In fact, citizenship na call to duty for di state.

eng: And there is no compelling duty which supersedes citizens subjecting their employees  the government  to scrutiny and constant vigilance.
pcm: And no compulsory duty wey pass make citizens dey scrutinize and monitor dia employees “ di government“ frequently.

eng: Criticising the government is within the rights of every citizen, and active citizenship demands taking the government through its paces.
pcm: Criticising di government na part of di rights of everi citizen, and active citizenship get to do wit takin di governmentthroughe pace.

eng: No government is without criticism, and none is too special for criticism.
pcm: No government wey dem no dey criticise, and no government too special for pipo to criticise.

eng: However, we must distinguish between any government and Nigeria as a country.
pcm: But, we need differentiate between any government and Nigeria as a kontri.

eng: Governments will come and go, but Nigeria remains.
pcm: Government go kom and go, but Nigeria go remain.

eng: We must understand Nigeria is its people.
pcm: We need understand say Nigeria na di pipo wey dey inside.

eng: So, when we cast pejoratives at the country we are only slinging shots at ourselves.
pcm: So, wen we belittle di kontri, we just dey shoot awasef for leg.

eng: If we say, Nigeria is a scam, inadvertently we are implying, Nigerians are scammers.
pcm: If we tok say Nigeria na scam, indirectly wetin we mean be say, Nigerians be scammers.

eng: Nigeria did not become a scam, as some of those reviling the nation say, by accident; it became whatever it is by the machination of all of us.
pcm: Nigeria no be scam, like som of dose wey dey abuse di nation dey always tok, unknowingly; Na we turn Nigeria to anytin wey e be.

eng: Nigeria is not a mere geographical expression.
pcm: Nigeria no be just a place somwia.

eng: Nigeria is its people.
pcm: Nigeria na di pipo.

eng: The good, the bad and the ugly  we made it so.
pcm: Di gud, di bad and di ugly “ na we make am be laidat.

eng: Whatever is ailing the country we are a vector of the causative factors.
pcm: Anytin wey dey affect di kontri, na we be di agent wey cause am.

eng: If Nigeria is a scam  as alleged by Pastor Paul Adefarasin  then we are all scammers.
pcm: If Nigeria na scam as Pastor Paul Adefarasin tok, den we all be scammers.

eng: Though I concede that Adefarasins outburst might have come from a place of patriotism, his cataloguing of Nigeria as a scam and fraud falls short of tact and critical reasoning.
pcm: Even say I agree, say Adefarasin anger na becos of di love wey e get for di kontri, im comment say Nigeria na scam and fraud no dey reasonable.

eng: If Nigeria is a fraud; then we are all fraudsters  leaders and followers alike.
pcm: If Nigeria na fraud; den all of us be fraudster, leaders and followers join.

eng: We all have contributed in no small measure to the discomfiture of the entity.
pcm: All of us don contribute to di dissapointment of di entity.

eng: We live in a country where pastors run their ministries like conglomerates.
pcm: We dey live for a kontri wia pastors dey run dia ministry like business.

eng: They run them like business enterprises  but evading tax in the process.
pcm: Dem dey run am like business enterprise but dem no dey pay tax for dere.

eng: CAMA; a law to regulate the business undertakings of the religious industry and to bring some transparency and accountability into the spiritual business was introduced by the government.
pcm: CAMA; Government introduce a law wey go regulate di business undertaking of di religious industry and wey go bring som transparency and accountability inside di spiritual business.

eng: However, the staunchest antagonists of this law have been pastors.
pcm: But na pastors dey against dis law pass.

eng: Yet, these same people who do not want to live by the law are the loudest voices when passing capital sentences on Nigeria.
pcm: Still, na dis same pipo wey no wan follow di law be di loudest voice wen dem dey pass capital sentence on Nigeria.

eng: Interestingly, these pastors run their churches in conformity with the law in other countries.
pcm: Funny tin be say, dis pastors dey follow di law of oda kontri dey run dia church for dose kontri.

eng: They submit their finances for regular checks by the authorities in the UK, the US and other places.
pcm: Dem dey submit dia finance for regular check by di authorities for UK, US and oda places.

eng: But in Nigeria they live in triumph of the law.
pcm: But for Nigeria dem dey live above di law.

eng: Pastor Chris Oyakhilome has been spreading injurious falsehood regarding COVID vaccine.
pcm: Pastor Chris Oyakhilome don dey spread harmful lies about COVID vaccine.

eng: He claims it is the concoction of the anti-Christ.
pcm: E claim say na di concoction of di anti-Christ.

eng: He was fined 125,000 pounds for making potentially harmful and unsubstantiated claims about the vaccine by the UK.
pcm: Dem fine am 125,000 pounds for Uk, sake of say e dey tok harmful and unsubstantiated tins about di vaccine.

eng: But in Nigeria where he continues to traffic in COVID conspiracies, he has not been made to account for his transgressions because he is a man of god.
pcm: But for Nigeria wia e dey kontinue to bring different COVID conspiracy, dem neva call am to kom explain im offence, sake of say na man of god e be.

eng: Perhaps, this is why Nigeria is a scam.
pcm: Maybe na why Nigeria be scam.

eng: If Nigeria is a scam, then it is because of pastors who sit on high and trample on the laws governing the land.
pcm: If Nigeria na scam, den na becos of pastors wey dey siddun for top, kom dey step on di law wey dey govern di land.

eng: If Nigeria is a fraud, then it is because of pastors who go into concordats with politicians every election season; campaigning for them on the pulpit and commanding the bloodhounds of hell against those who do not accept their anointed candidates.
pcm: If Nigeria na fraud, den na becos of pastors wey dey sign agreement wit politicians everi election period; dey campaign for dem on di altar, dey command di demons of hell untop dose wey no gree accept dia anointed candidate.

eng: The clergy is as tainted as the political class.
pcm: Clergymen dey as corrupt as di politikal class.

eng: Also, a civil servant, who earns N150,000 monthly but has kids in UK schools and with real estate dotting major cities in the country, will revile Nigeria submerging his own hypocrisy in lamentations and jibes at the state.
pcm: Also, civil servant, wey dey collect N150,000 per month, but get pikin for UK school, and property for all ova di major cities of di kontri, go abuse Nigeria and carry all im hypocrisy put for lamentation and insult to di state.

eng: He ignores conveniently his complicity in the corruption ravaging the country.
pcm: E go calm down ignore e own contribution for di corruption wey dey destroy di kontri.

eng: In addition, some citizens spurn laws, rules and regulations.
pcm: Also, som citizens dey reject laws, rules and regulations.

eng: Where there are traffic lights, they ignore them; where there are procedures, they bypass them, and where there are standards put in place for effective service delivery and operations, they abandon them.
pcm: Wia traffic light dey, dem go ignore am; wia protocol dey, dem go bypass am, and for places wia dem don get standard for gud service delivery and operations, dem go abandon am.

eng: Yet, they all blame â€˜Nigeria for the jeopardous status quo as if the country exists without its people.
pcm: Still, all of dem go blame Nigeria for di bad status quo as if say di kontri dey exist witout di pipo.

eng: The problem with Nigeria is a people problem.
pcm: Di problem wey Nigeria get na pipo problem.

eng: But the tragedy is that no one wants to accept liability for the appalling state of things.
pcm: But di bad tin be say nobodi wan take responsibility for di terrible way wey tins be.

eng: We cast the blame at the feet of abstract Nigeria.
pcm: We dey blame di Nigeria wey no exist.

eng: We are all complicit in the degenerative emasculation of Nigeria.
pcm: Na all of us get hand for inside di bad situation of Nigeria.

eng: Instead of abiding in wilful fatalism about Nigeria, we should project goodness and positivity into the system while working at making our country what we want it to be.
pcm: Instead make we dey follow di tin wey we don conclude about Nigeria, make we forsee goodness and positivity into di system, and make we dey work to make awa kontri di tin wey we want make e be.

eng: Nigeria is what we make of it.
pcm: Nigeria go be wetin we want make e be.

eng: The political class is flawed.
pcm: Di politicians get comma.

eng: But that is the reason a new generation of leaders must emerge and take the reins.
pcm: But dat na di reason why new generation of leaders must come up and take kontrol.

eng: None but ourselves can free our minds.
pcm: Nobodi fit free awa mind except us.

eng: Citizenship is a call to duty.
pcm: Citizenship na call to duty.

eng: NIGERIA IS NOT A SCAM.
pcm: NIGERIA NO BE SCAM.

eng: Why secession is not the Silver Bullet to Nigerias challenges
pcm: Why separation no be di Silver Bullet to Nigeria challenges

eng: The principle of self-determination as enshrined in the UN charter and which our secessionists latch on to was enacted at a time many peoples of the world were under colonial yoke or other forms of domination by outside powers.
pcm: Di principle of self-determination as e dey for di UN charter wey awa pipo wey wan separate hold-on to, take effect for a time wey many pipo for di world dey under colonial yoke or oda form of kontrol by outside power.

eng: The principle was to give fillip to independence and liberation movements in order for them to gain their freedom and determine their path of future development.
pcm: Di principle na to give chance to independence and liberation movements so dem go fit gain dia freedom and determine dia path of future development.

eng: In our world today, this principle applies only to a handful of peoples as an overwhelming majority of the world are now free from colonial subjugation and self-governing.
pcm: For di world wey we dey today, dis principle only apply to few pipo, becos majority of di world don dey free from colonial kontrol and sef-governing.

eng: Thus the principle of self-determination, which was enacted under the UN charter, will have to be amended to accommodate the demands of our secessionists because going by its intendment and wordings they hardly qualify.
pcm: So dem go need adjust di principle of sef-determination, wey dem establish under di UN charter, so e go fit accommodate di demand of awa pipo wey wan separate, becos if we follow wetin dey dere, dem no qualify.

eng: First of all, they have to prove constructively and convincingly that the areas they purport to represent are under some form of subjugation and that they lack the basic freedoms that all peoples should enjoy as required under the UN charter.
pcm: First of all, dem go need to prove carefully and convincingly say di area wey dem claim to represent dey under som form of kontrol, and say dem dey lack di basic freedom wey everibodi suppose enjoy as e dey di UN charter.

eng: And in the unlikely case of proving that, they will also have to convince the UN of the steps they have taken from the national (National Assembly), sub-regional (ECOWAS) and continental level (AU) to press their case.
pcm: And for wia dem wan prove dat one, dem go need convince di UN on di steps wey dem don take, from di national (National Assembly), sub-regional (ECOWAS) and continental level (AU) to present dia case.

eng: And the UN will not just take their word for it.
pcm: And di UN no go just take dia word laidat.

eng: There will be fact finding committees to determine whether indeed Nigeria as a country practises the basic requirements of democracy or not.
pcm: Dem go get committee wey go confam di fact to know weda true-true, Nigeria as a kontri dey practise di basic requirement of demokracy or not.

eng: The case is even made trickier by the fact that those areas are neither disputed territories nor under any trusteeship requiring a UN referendum to either confer direct independence to them or ask them which of the competing powers they wished to join.
pcm: Dem don even complicate di case wit di fact say dose areas no be area wey dem dey fight untop, and no be area wey dey under any trusteeship wey go need UN referendum to give dem direct independence or ask dem who dem wan join inside di pipo wey dey fight untop di place.

eng: If our secessionists cannot provide these basic requirements, the farthest their case could get within the UN system will predictably be the waste paper basket because the UN is not for frivolities.
pcm: If our secessionists cannot provide these basic requirements, the farthest their case could get within the UN system will predictably be the waste paper basket because the UN is not for frivolities.

eng: It does not lend its very elaborate and transparent processes to be abused by movements that hardly know what they are about.
pcm: E no dey give chance make som movement wey no know wetin dem dey about abuse im wide and transparent process.

eng: The case of marginalisation, which is also cited as one of the reasons for secession, is too trivial to even waste our time on.
pcm: Di case of marginalisation, wey dem mention as part of di reason for separation, dey too simple to waste awa time untop.

eng: Every democratic system provides for winners and losers in elections.
pcm: Na everi democratik system dey get winner and loser for election.

eng: And as imperfect as our political system is, the constitution compels mandatory representation in government and its institutions for as many ethnic nationalities and geo-political zones as possible.
pcm: And as awa politikal system no perfect reach, di konstitution make am compulsory say as many ethnic group and geo-political zones as possible must get representative for government and im institutions.

eng: The secessionist would have a tough time convincing the outside world that their case for marginalisation is more compelling than those of the over 300 other ethnic nationalities inhabiting Nigeria.
pcm: E go tough for di pipo wey wan separate to convince di outside world say dia case of marginalisation dey more compelling pass dat of more dan 300 oda ethnic group wey dey Nigeria.

eng: In other words, why would the international community, to which the secessionists address their grievances and from which they seek support for their cause, single out just two out of the hundreds of such cases ringing in the Nigerian media for action?
pcm: Wetin dis one mean be say, why di international community, wey di pipo wey wan separate dey report and seek support from go single out jus two out of like hundred of dat kind case wey dey ring for di Nigerian media say na im dem go work on ?

eng: What makes their cases so special and urgent above those of others in Nigeria who have conversely chosen not to follow the path of secession?
pcm: What makes their cases so special and urgent above those of others in Nigeria who have conversely chosen not to follow the path of secession?

eng: On all the three premises that our secessionists base their agitations, none is convincing or compelling enough to justify their actions.
pcm: Out of all di three tins wey make awa secessionists dey agitate, no one dey convincing or compelling enough to justify dia action.

eng: On the amalgamation argument, Nigeria is not a unique case in Africa or indeed the world.
pcm: On di amalgamation argument, Nigeria own no be special case for Afrika or for di world.

eng: If Nigeria has to be broken up because it was wrongly amalgamated by Britain, then this applies to virtually all but a few countries in Africa.
pcm: If Nigeria go need break up unto say Britain no join am well, den dis go be di case of almost all di kontris for Afrika.

eng: In essence if this principle were to be applied it will set the course for the commencement of a new scramble for Africa by the old and emerging powers of the world in which Africans as before will be the victims.
pcm: In short, if dem use dis principle, e go start di course to begin a new scramble for Africa by di old and upcoming world powers, and like befor, na Afrikans go be di victim.

eng: Let us not deceive ourselves for the disintegration of Nigeria if it happens (God forbid) will result in the emergence of entities
pcm: Make we no deceive awasef, becos if di break-up of Nigeria happun (God forbid), e go lead to di birth of kontris

eng: too weak such that they will find themselves at the mercy of foreign powers.
pcm: wey go dey weak sotey, dem go dey beg from di foreign powers.

eng: Some arguments have been made of a break up of Nigeria along the lines of Eastern European states and in the Balkans.
pcm: We don get som argument wey dey compare di break up of Nigeria wit dat of Eastern European states and di Balkans.

eng: In this regard, it will serve us well to discern that what works for Europe may not necessarily work for Africa.
pcm: Untop dis one, e go beta make we undastand well say di tin wey work for Europe fit no work for Africa.

eng: In the case of the aforementioned countries, it was part of great geo-strategic games of the major world powers who had direct cultural, economic and political links and interests in the emerging scenarios.
pcm: In di case of di kontris wey we mention, na part of di great geo-strategic games of di major world powers wey get direct cultural, economik and politikal link and interest for di emerging scenario.

eng: And these countries had defined borders before they agreed to come together for mutual defence in the uncertain situation of the Second World War.
pcm: And dis kontris don get clear boundary befor dem agree to kom togeda for mutual defence durin di uncertain situation of di Second World War.

eng: Once the Soviet order, which held them together, began to unravel the need arose for the peripheral countries to revert to the status quo ante.
pcm: Immediately di Soviet order, wey join dem togeda begin dey scatter, all dis kontris need go back to di status quo ante.

eng: And, more importantly, these developments had the backing and guarantees of the principal powers in Europe and the world in the quest for a balance of power.
pcm: And, more importantly, dis developments get di backing and guarantee of di important powers for Europe and di world.

eng: Do Nigerian secessionists have such reckoning and profile in the calculations of the principal powers of the world to warrant their time?
pcm: Se Nigerian secessionists get dat kind recognition and profile in di face of di principal powers of di world wey go make dem answer dem?

eng: The answer obviously is zilch.
pcm: Surely, di answer na zero.

eng: This is, however, not dismissing that the agitations for secession in the country do not have some justifiable basis.
pcm: Dis no kom mean say di agitation of pipo to separate for di kontri no get som gud reason.

eng: Anybody living in this country with the rising case of insecurity, poverty, corruption, nepotism, economic uncertainties amidst the unbelievable incompetence and near criminal indifference of the government to these challenges will conclude that indeed we have a state that is failing in its basic constitutional duties and responsibilities.
pcm: Anybodi wey dey live for dis kontri wit dis rising case of insecurity, poverty, corruption, nepotism, economic uncertainty and di unbelievable incompetence and near criminal indifference of di government to dis challenges go conclude say truly, we dey for a kontri wey dey fail for im basic konstitutional duties and responsibilities.

eng: And in a fragile country like ours with gaping fault lines, tendencies or preferences for dissolution of the union are bound to emerge and grow exponentially along with the clear dysfunctionality of the government of the day.
pcm: And for a fragile kontri like awa own, wey get plenti fault, e dey normal for tendency or preference for separation to arise and grow fast wit di clear dysfunctionality of di government wey dey.

eng: And these feelings are all round.
pcm: And na everybodi get dis dis feeling.

eng: But daunting as the outlook is and tempting as the prospect appears, secession cannot be the solution to our existential challenges as a nation.
pcm: But as discouragin as di outlook be, and as temptin as di outcome dey appear, separation no fit be di solution to awa current challenge as a nation.

eng: Indeed it is a prospect fraught with lurking uncertain dangers not least for its proponents but for the country as a whole.
pcm: Indeed na prospect wey get som unknown dangers, danger wey no be for di secessionists alone but for di kontri as a whole.

eng: Nigeria is not imperfect.
pcm: Nigeria no dey perfect.

eng: Even some of the advanced countries have shown that despite years of existence and well defined systems, they are not immune from crises arising from internal contradictions.
pcm: Even som of di advance kontris don show say despite dia years of existence and dia gud systems, dem no dey free from crises wey dey kom from internal conflict.

eng: We should not delude ourselves that in trying to break up our country, some countries will benevolently assist us.
pcm: Make we no dey deceive awasef say as we dey try break up awa kontri, som kontris go graciously assist us.

eng: What they will do is provide us with the means to destroy and weaken ourselves in the process and then proceed to profit from that at our own expense.
pcm: Wetin dem go do na to give us di means to destroy and weaken awasef, so dem go fit benefit while we go suffer am.

eng: That is the reality of the international system.
pcm: Na di truth about di international system be dat.

eng: As the distinguished German beamter at the beginning of my article said and advised; we are at once our own problems and our own solutions.
pcm: As di popular German beamter tok for di beginnin of my paper; Na we be awa own problem and solution join togeda.

eng: We must put our thoughts, talents and efforts collectively to developing Nigeria rather than breaking it up.
pcm: We need put awa mind, talent and effort togeda to develop Nigeria instead say we wan breaking am.

eng: Fidelity marks Childrens Day with N9.3m cash gift to customers
pcm: Fidelity celebrate Children Day wit N9.3m money gift to dia customers

eng: To mark this years Childrens Day, Fidelity Bank paid N150,000 to 62 Sweet Account (SWEETA) holders across the country amounting to a total of N9.3 million through its ongoing savings loyalty programme.
pcm: To celebrate dis year Children Day, Fidelity Bank pay N150,000 to 62 pipo wey get Sweet Account (SWEETA) tru-out di kontri, wey be di total of N9.3 millionthroughdia savings loyalty programme wey dey go on.

eng: The bank presented cheques to the beneficiaries at various childrens events in Katsina, Niger, Abuja and Lagos.
pcm: Di bank present cheque to di beneficiaries for different children events for Katsina, Niger, Abuja and Lagos.

eng: Commenting on the initiative, Fidelity Bank CEO, Mrs Nneka Onyeali-Ikpe, said, All-round quality education remains a strong anchor in raising tomorrows children and breeding exceptional children who can compete globally.
pcm: About di initiative, Fidelity Bank CEO, Mrs Nneka Onyeali-Ikpe, tok say all-round quality education na im be di strong way to train di children of tomorrow and to train special children who go fit compete wit odas for di world.

eng: This is why we have decided to contribute our quota as a bank by offering school fees support to select Nigerian children.
pcm: Na why we don decide to contribute awa own as a bank, by giving school fees support to selected Nigerian children.

eng: The bank has given out N4.1bn to 10,280 customers from the inception of the loyalty scheme to date.
pcm: Di bank don dash out N4.1bn to 10,280 customers since dem start di loyalty programme till today.

eng: Investing in young people: The Ahmed Bobboi example
pcm: Investin in young pipo: Ahmed Bobboi example

eng: In July, 2017, I had the singular honour of spending an evening inside a British bank called Coutts as part of the many activities lined up for us as the 2017 Queens Young Leaders.
pcm: For July, 2017, I get di honour to spend one evenin inside one British bank wey dem dey call Coutts, as part of di plenti activity wey dey for us as di 2017 Queen's Young Leaders.

eng: You may wonder why I would be writing about attending an event in a place as boring as a bank.
pcm: U fit dey wonder say why I go dey write about event wey I go for place wey dry like bank.

eng: However, Coutts is no ordinary bank.
pcm: Anyway, Coutts no be ordinary bank.

eng: Apart from being one of the eight oldest banks in the world (founded some 329 years ago in 1692), Coutts is a private bank known for its high ranking clientele like Her Majesty the Queen.
pcm: Apart from say na one of di eight oldest bank for di world (dem start am som 329 years ago for 1692), Coutts na private bank wey dey popular for im big customers like Her Majesty di Queen.

eng: Walking inside the vast hall, we were welcomed by two men under a great dome in the centre of the building.
pcm: Inside di big hall, na two welcome us under a big dome for di centre of di building.

eng: I immediately recognised one of the two men who stood with a familiar wide smile.
pcm: Na sharp-sharp I recognise one of di two men wey stand wit a familiar wide smile.

eng: It was Sir John Major, a former British Prime Minister and Chairman of the Queen Elizabeth Diamond Jubilee Trust.
pcm: Na Sir John Major, befor-befor British Prime Minister and Chairman of di Queen Elizabeth Diamond Jubilee Trust.

eng: We had met earlier at a dinner in our honor in the Australian High Commission in London where he congratulated us for our recognition by Her Majesty.
pcm: We don meet befor, for one dinner wey dem organize for us for di Australian High Commission wey dey London, and na dere e congratulate us for awa recognition by Her Majesty.

eng: The other man was introduced to us as Lord William Waldegrave of North Hill, Chairman of the Board of Coutts Bank and Chairman of the Royal Mint Advisory Committee.
pcm: Dem introduce di oda man to us as Lord William Waldegrave of North Hill. Na im be di Chairman of di Board of Coutts Bank and Chairman of di Royal Mint Advisory Committee.

eng: We had a splendid evening full of entertainment; eating and drinking.
pcm: Dat evening dey full of entertainment; eatin and drinkin. E sweet well-well

eng: But beyond the pomp and glamour were the speeches and interactions with Lord Waldegarve and Sir Major, two outstanding leaders in the United Kingdom (UK).
pcm: But apart from di display and glamour, we tok and gist wit Lord Waldegarve and Sir Major, two outstandin leaders for di United Kingdom (UK).

eng: They expressed delight at celebrating our achievements and described us as extraordinary individuals, charging us to develop our skills even further and create lasting legacies for our countries and the Commonwealth at large.
pcm: Dem show dia happiness to celebrate awa achievement, and dem describe us as special pipo. Dem encourage us to develop awa skills more and create long legacy for awa kontri and di Commonwealth togeda.

eng: Subsequently, I spoke privately to both Sir Major and Lord Wadegrave, asking them specific questions ranging from public service to banking and finance to innovation and young people.
pcm: Afta, I follow Sir Major and Lord Wadegrave yarn for private, I ask dem som question about public service, banking and finance, innovation and young pipo generally.

eng: I learned immensely from them
pcm: I learn a lot of tins from dem

eng: and I left Coutts
pcm: and I komot for Coutts.

eng: that night tremendously inspired and motivated to be an even more active change agent, innovator and young leader back in Nigeria.
pcm: Dat night seriously inspire and motivate me more as a change agent, innovator and young leader for Nigeria.

eng: Whether you are in government or in business, and especially as an innovator or entrepreneur, I cannot overemphasise how crucial these types of inspirations can be for the work you do.
pcm: Weda u dey for government, or u dey business, and especially as innovator or entrepreneur, I no fit tok am finish, how important dis kind inspiration fit be for di work wey u dey do.

eng: Some may write off these validations as irrelevant, forgetting how instances like such provide a great deal of mentorship, motivation, as well as create examples for aspiring leaders to see champions among people like themselves.
pcm: Som pipo fit komot face for dis confirmation say e no dey relevant. Dem don forget how dis kind tok fit be beta way of mentorship and motivation for upcomin leaders, and e fit serve as example for dem to see champions among pipo wey be like dem.

eng: The feeling of validation and motivation coupled with guidance and support is an absolutely necessary ingredient for all leaders and especially young people.
pcm: Di feeling of validation and motivation, wit guidance and support na necessary ingredient for everi leader, especially young pipo.

eng: The earlier our older generation in Nigeria realises it and wholeheartedly embraces this culture of support, mentorship and indeed celebration of our achievements, the better for the future of this country and its burgeoning population of young people.
pcm: Di earlier awa older generation for Nigeria realise and accept dis culture of support and mentorship wit dia full chest, and truly celebrate awa achievements, di beta e go be for di future of dis kontri and di growin population of young pipo.

eng: Forgive my digression.
pcm: Make u forgive my digression.

eng: The reason I am narrating this encounter is that for a long time since it happened, I did not quite experience anything like it until recently when I sat with another public servant in Nigeria, the Executive Secretary of the Petroleum Equalisation Fund
pcm: Di reason why I dey narrate dis experience na say, since wey e don happun, I no experience dat kind tin again, until recently wen I siddun wit anoda public servant for Nigeria, di Executive Secretary of di Petroleum Equalisation Fund

eng: (Management) Board (PEF-M-B), Alhaji Ahmed A Bobboi.
pcm: (Management) Board (PEF-M-B), Alhaji Ahmed A Bobboi.

eng: Whereas oil and gas is not my main industry of discipline or practice, I am of the firm opinion that not being knowledgeable about it is very reckless since the sectors revenue contribution
pcm: Even say oil and gas no be my main industry of discipline or practice, I get strong opinion say make pesin no sabi am dey very careless since di contribution of di sector to revenue

eng: far outweighs any non-oil revenue source to the country.
pcm: pass any oda sector for di kontri.

eng: So I have kept myself abreast of the industry even as I advocate for a transition and dedication to non-oil sources of income.
pcm: So I don dey try sabi wetin dey happun for di industry, even say I want make we shift and focus on non-oil sources of income.

eng: I was delighted by the opportunity to engage with a crucial stakeholder in the person of the executive, especially because the organisation is a pacesetter in deploying cutting edge technology to improve efficiency and performance in the sector.
pcm: I dey happy say I get di opportunity to yarn wit a crucial stakeholder like di executive, especially becos di organisation na pacesetter for di use of advance technology to improve efficiency and performance for di sector.

eng: However, what I got from this encounter was even more valuable than just further understanding of the industry.
pcm: Howeva, wetin I gain from dis experience even dey more valuable pass my understanding of di industry more.
