eng: We discussed on topics ranging from history to governance and from job creation to innovation and entrepreneurship.
pcm: We discuss difrent topic; from history to government, and from job creation to innovation and entrepreneurship.

eng: It was so exhilarating and refreshing and it transported me directly to Coutts once again.
pcm: E dey very excitin and refreshin, and e carry me straight go Coutts again.

eng: I had met Mr Bobboi for the first time when I joined a team which he co-champions, working on a regional entrepreneurship acceleration programme under the auspices of Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) where communities around the world engage with MIT in an evidence-based practical approach to strengthening innovation-driven entrepreneurial ecosystems.
pcm: I meet Mr Bobboi for di first time wen I join one team wey e follow kontrol, we dey work untop one regional entrepreneurship acceleration programme under di supervision of Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) wia different community for di world join MIT for evidence-based practical approach to make di entrepreneurial ecosystems strongthroughinnovation.

eng: I was immediately struck by the vision and dedication that this spells for PEF-M-B to be involved in this project as it is certainly visionary and more beneficial to help build a formidable entrepreneurial ecosystem with a partner like MIT than the usually mundane and often barely impactful Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) programmes most institutions engage in.
pcm: I dey suprised by di vision and dedication wey dis go bring for PEF-M-B to dey involve for dis project, as e surely dey visionary and more beneficial to help build a formidable entrepreneurial ecosystem wit partner like MIT pass di ordinary Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) programme wey most organization dey do, wey no dey get impact most times.

eng: During that particular encounter with him, we discussed about our two-year programme with MIT and the huge burden of truly accelerating entrepreneurial development as a remedy to lack of jobs and a catalyst for prosperity.
pcm: For dat particular encounter wey I get wit am, we yarn about awa two-years programme wit MIT and di big responsibility of truly acceleratin entrepreneurial development as remedy to lack of jobs and catalyst for prosperity.

eng: The He spoke about various pain points for him as a leader and the approach to solve them.
pcm: The He spoke about various pain points for him as a leader and the approach to solve them.

eng: One of my most brilliant takeaways was his idea on the National Youth Service Corps (NYSC) and how it could be hacked to serve young graduates and the nation better.
pcm: One of di wonderful takeaway wey I collect na im idea about di National Youth Service Corps (NYSC) and how we fit use am serve young graduates and di nation beta.

eng: Noticing the idleness of some of the corps members serving at PEF-M-B, the executive secretary said he had been devising ways of not only ensuring that they were engaged, but that they left with lasting skills and knowledge that would inform career paths for them beyond government jobs.
pcm: Becos e don dey notice say som corps members wey dey serve for PEF-M-B dey always dey idle, di executive secretary tok say e don dey find way to ensure say di corp members no just dey engaged, but say dem komot wit skills and knowledge wey go last, and wey go give dem career wey pass government job.

eng: This includes an elaborate programme to turn them into innovation-driven entrepreneurs through a dedicated and well curated innovation and enterprise training during their service year at PEF-MB.
pcm: Part of dis go be to do one big programme wey go turn dem to entrepreneurs wey get passion for innovation,througha dedicated and well planned innovation and enterprise trainin durin dia service year for PEF-MB.

eng: The ingenuity and candid disposition of Mr. Bobboi was apparent and permeated throughout our discussion and I was left with an equally firm will to do my best in not only continually innovating across sectors but also ensuring continuity in cascading the inspiration and support for younger leaders and innovators, which could make all the difference for our dear country Nigeria.
pcm: Di honesty and sincere disposition of Mr. Bobboi dey visible and penetrating truout awa discussion and me sef kom get di strong will to do my best, no be only to kontinue dey innovate for different sector but to also dey ensure kontinuity for di inspiration and support of younger leaders and innovators, wey go fit make all di difference for awa dear kontri Nigeria.

eng: Lagos LG polls: Aspirants to face direct primary as consensus option fails
pcm: Lagos LG polls: Aspirants go face direct primary as consensus option don fail

eng: Ahead of the July local government election in Lagos State, the ruling All Progressives Congress (APC) will conduct an open primary for aspirants in the 20 local government areas (LGs) and 37 local council development areas (LCDAs), Daily Trust can report.
pcm: In preparation of di July local government election for Lagos State, di rulin All Progressives Congress (APC) go conduct open primary for aspirants wey dey di 20 local government areas (LGs) and 37 local council development areas (LCDAs), Daily Trust report.

eng: It was, however, learnt that there are some local governments where consensus option had been agreed upon.
pcm: Howeva, we hear say som local governments dey wia dem don agree to use di consensus option.

eng: Our correspondent gathered yesterday that the resort to the open primary followed the inability of aspirants to step down for one another amidst tension and disquiet among the LG chapters.
pcm: Awa tori-pesin hear am yesterday say di decision to use open primary na becos di aspirants no gree step down for demsef, plus di tension and unrest wey dey among di LG chapters.

eng: It would be recalled that 1050 aspirants comprising 250 chairmanship and 800 councillorship aspirants are vying for the 434 positions in the 57 LGs.
pcm: We go rememba say 1050 aspirants wey be di combination of 250 chairmanship and 800 councillorship aspirant dey contest for di 434 positions wey dey di 57 LGs.

eng: The party had been in a fix over a large number of aspirants while setting up a screening committee headed by the Deputy Governor, Dr Obafemi Hamza.
pcm: Di party don dey for confusion untop plenti aspirants, as dem dey set up screening committee wey  go dey unda di supervision of di Deputy Governor, Dr Obafemi Hamza.

eng: As of the time of filing this report, aspirants were anxiously awaiting the result of the screening.
pcm: As at wen we dey write dis report, aspirants dey wait anxiously for di result of di screenin.

eng: A local government chairman who is contesting for a second term in a chat with our correspondent said an open primary would take place on Saturday, May 29, 2021, saying he is ready to face two other aspirants challenging him to the ticket.
pcm: One local government chairman wey dey contest for second term, yarn wit awa tori-pesin for chat, e tok say open primary go happun on Saturday, May 29, 2021, and say im dey ready to face two oda aspirants wey dey challenge am for di ticket.

eng: Daily Trust reports that the party had already issued guidelines to the aspirants ahead of the open primary in a local government where consensus could not be agreed upon.
pcm: Daily Trust make us know say di party don already give di aspirants guideline befor di open primary wey go happun for local government wia consensus no fit happun.

eng: According to the guidelines sighted by Daily Trust, Accredited members shall vote by open ballot at the designated venue by queuing up in front of the poster of their preferred candidate and
pcm: As e dey for di guideline wey Daily Trust see, Accredited members go use open ballot vote for di venue, dem go stand for front of di poster of di candidate wey dem like, and

eng: the aspirant with the highest number of votes shall be announced as the winner accordingly.
pcm: di candidate wey get di highest numba of votes na im dem go announce as di winner.

eng: Following the widespread report about the endorsement of some candidates by the APC National Leader and strongman of Lagos politics, Asiwaju Bola Ahmed Tinubu, the former governor had come out to debunk the claim, saying he has no preferred candidate.
pcm: Afta di popular report say di APC National Leader and strongman for Lagos politics, Asiwaju Bola Ahmed Tinubu don endorse som candidate, di former governor don deny di claim, say im no get candidate wey im prefer.

eng: In a chat with Daily Trust, the Publicity Secretary of the state Caretaker Committee, Seye Oladejo said, The guidelines are explicit that open direct primaries should be conducted.
pcm: For one chat wit Daily Trust, di Publicity Secretary of di state Caretaker Committee, Seye Oladejo tok say, di guidelines dey clear, say na open direct primary make dem do.

eng: The party is irrevocably committed to internal democracy and provide a level playing ground for all aspirants.
pcm: Di party dey strongly committed to internal demokracy and dem provide a level playin ground for all aspirants.

eng: UK MPS Demand Boycott of 2022 Beijing Winter Olympics
pcm: UK MPS want make dem Boycott 2022 Winter Olympics for Beijing

eng: Calls to boycott the 2022 Winter Olympics have been intensifying steadily due to Chinas alleged human rights abuses, particularly in the Xinjiang region against the Uyghur Muslims.
pcm: Request don dey plenti untop say make pipo boycott di 2022 Winter Olympics, sake of say dem accuse China for human right abuse, especially for di Xinjiang region against di Muslim pipo of Uyghur.

eng: The evidence that a genocide is now occurring in western China is so clear, that the UK and the whole world must now stand up to Beijing and use every available tool to stop it, Ed Davey, the leader of the Liberal Democrats, and Labour MP Chris Bryant, a member of the foreign affairs select committee and a former junior foreign minister wrote on the Liberal Democrats website this month.
pcm: Di evidence say genocide don dey happun for western China dey veri clear, sotey di UK and di whole world go need stand up against Beijing and use everi tin wey dey available to stop am.  Ed Davey, di leader of di Liberal Democrats, and Labour MP Chris Bryant, one member of di foreign affairs select committee and one befor-befor junior foreign minister write on top di Liberal Democrats website dis month.

eng: We must remember when we failed to stand up against human rights abuses in the past, and recall the images from British sporting history like the England football teams
pcm: We need rememba wen we no gree stand up against human rights abuse for di past, and rememba di image from British sportin history like di England football team,

eng: Nazi salutes in the 1930s and the rebel cricket tours to South Africa in the 1980s, Davey said while calling upon the government and the British Olympic Association to act.
pcm: Nazi salute for di 1930s and di rebel cricket tour to South Africa for di 1980s, Davey yarn while e dey call on di government and di British Olympic Association to do somtin.

eng: Team GB (Great Brittain), ParalympicsGB and the Government have a moral responsibility to consider if sending a team to these Games
pcm: Team GB (Great Brittain), ParalympicsGB and di Government get moral responsibility to look at, so dem go know if make dem send dia team to dis Game

eng: is really the right thing to do.
pcm: na di correct tin to do.

eng: The 2022 Winter Olympic and Paralympic Games will be used as a propaganda tool for a regime committing genocide, he added.
pcm: Di 2022 Winter Olympic and Paralympic Games go be di propaganda tool for dat kind regime wey dey commit genocide, e tok.

eng: Recently, Canadas main opposition party, the Conservative Party, urged Prime Minister Justin Trudeau-led government to pressure the International Olympic Committee to move the 2022 Winter Olympics out of Beijing, arguing China is committing genocide against more than one million Uyghurs in Xinjiang.
pcm: Recently, di main opposition party for Canada, di Conservative Party, tell Prime Minister Justin Trudeau government say make dem pressure di International Olympic Committee say make dem carry di 2022 Winter Olympics komot for Beijing, say China dey commit genocide against more dan one million Uyghurs for Xinjiang.

eng: This comes after a coalition of 180 human rights groups urged governments around the world to boycott the Beijing Winter Olympic Games slated for next year due to Chinas reported human rights abuses towards minorities.
pcm: Dis na afta 180 join-bodi of human rights group tell governments around di world say make dem boycott di Beijing Winter Olympic Games wey go start next year, sake of say China dey abuse di human right of minorities.

eng: The letter calls on countries to refuse participation in the games and to ensure they are not used to embolden the Chinese governments appalling rights abuses and crackdowns on dissent.
pcm: Di letter dey call on kontris say make dem no participate for di games and make dem no allow China use dem kontinue dia wicked abuse of rights and discipline on di minority.

eng: The IOC said in a statement that the committees policy for its organising committees is to hear all concerns directly related to the Olympic Games.
pcm: Di IOC tok for one statement say di committee policy for im organisin committee na to hear all di consign wey relate to di Olympic Games.

eng: For the Beijing Winter Olympics specifically, the IOC said its Evaluation Committee listened to the views of several NGOs, including concerns about human rights.
pcm: For di Beijing Winter Olympics specifically, di IOC tok say im Evaluation Committee don hear wetin plenti NGO tok, plus dia consign about human rights.

eng: The committee cited its position that it shared with groups that IOC must remain neutral on all global political issues although it may not agree with the political structure, social circumstances or human rights standards in its country.
pcm: Di committee tok dia own stand on di mata, say dem agree wit groups say di IOC go need stay neutral on all global politikal issues. Even say e fit no agree wit di politikal structure, social circumstances or human right standard for im kontri.

eng: Chinas Foreign Ministry spokesperson Wang Wenbin, on the other hand labelled the calls for boycott as highly irresponsible.
pcm: Howeva, China Foreign Ministry tok-tok pesin Wang Wenbin, tok say di request to boycott di Games dey veri irresponsible.

eng: The calls for boycotting next years winter Olympics came after Secretary of State Antony Blinken said he agrees with the former President Donald Trump administrations characterization of the abuse of Uyghurs in China as genocide.
pcm: Di request to boycott next year winter Olympics kom afta Secretary of State, Antony Blinken tok say e agree wit wetin former President Donald Trump administration tok about di abuse of Uyghurs for China as genocide.

eng: We are working on post-harvest techs  Provost, Kano Agric College
pcm: We dey work on post-harvest techs -Provost, Kano Agric College

eng: Dr Halima Alimi, the Acting Provost, Federal College of Agricultural Produce Technology (FCAPT), Kano, says the institute would develop quality post-harvest technologies for the country.
pcm: Dr Halima Alimi wey be di Acting Provost, Federal College of Agricultural Produce Technology (FCAPT), Kano, tok say di institute go develop quality post-harvest technologies for di kontri.

eng: Alimi told newsmen in Kano that the new management of the institution had adopted proactive programmes to encourage research as well as create enabling teaching and learning environment for growth of post-harvest processing.
pcm: Alimi yarn tori-men for Kano say di new management of di institution don adopt proactive programmes to encourage research and create enablin teachin and learnin environment for di growth of post-harvest processin.

eng: She said the management was geared to change the narrative through the introduction of new preservation technologies, reduce wastes and boost agricultural processing.
pcm: She tok say di management dey committed to change di narrativethroughdi introduction of new preservation technologies, reduce waste and boost agricultural processin.

eng: We will ensure sanity among the staff and students, we shall improve on staff development geared to ensure conducive working and learning environment, she said.
pcm: We go make sure say sanity dey among di staff and students, we go improve on staff development so dem go fit get a conducive workin and learnin environment.

eng: According to her, the college offers Ordinary National Diploma (OND) and Higher
pcm: As she yarn, di college dey do Ordinary National Diploma (OND) and Higher

eng: National Diploma  (HND) programmes in various fields of agriculture.
pcm: National Diploma  (HND) programme for different aspect of agriculture.

eng: Our mandate is on post-harvest science; how to handle agricultural produce after harvest and this includes storage, preservation as well as processing.
pcm: Awa focus na on post-harvest science; how we fit handle agricultural produce afta we don harvest am, and dis include storage, preservation and processin.

eng: This is the only school in the country that has this mandate, she said.
pcm: Dis na di only school for di kontri wey get dis mandate, she tok.

eng: The provost therefore urged farmers to utilise innovations and other studies being executed by the college to improve their productivity.
pcm: Sake of dis, di provost dey encourage farmers say make dem use di innovations and oda tins wey di college dey do take improve dia productivity.

eng: Tuition hike: Police prevent students protest at Kaduna Government House
pcm: Shool Fees Increase: Police prevent protest for Kaduna Government House

eng: Police and State Vigilantes Service personnel on Tuesday prevented the protesting students of Kaduna State University from marching towards the Government House.
pcm: Police and State Vigilante Srvice prevent di students of Kaduna State University wey dey protest, on Tuesday say make dem no enta di government house.

eng: The students were protesting against the tuition fees increase by the state government.
pcm: Di students dey protest becos of di school fees wey di state government increase.

eng: Daily Trust observed that the angry-looking students were singing solidarity songs as they marched towards the government house before they were blocked by the police.
pcm: Daily Trust observe say di angry students dey sing solidarity songs as dem dey march go di government house, befor police kom block dem for road.

eng: Heavily armed police personnel in vehicles and vigilantes operating under KADVIS were seen on the main road keeping vigil while the students sat on the floor in the middle of the road.
pcm: Heavily armed police officers for inside vehicle, and vigilantes wey dey operate under KADVIS na im we see for main road dey monitor, while di students siddun ontop floor for di middle of di road.

eng: It could be recalled that the state government and management of the university had refused to reverse the fees despite pleas by students and their parents in the state.
pcm: U go rememba say di state government and management of di university don refuse to reverse di money, even say students and parents for di state dey beg.

eng: One of the students representatives, Comrade Auba Mohammed, said they were marching towards the government house to just submit a letter of complaint to Governor Nasir El-Rufai.
pcm: One of di student representative, Comrade Auba Mohammed, tok say dem dey march go di government house to just go submit letter of complaint give Governor Nasir El-Rufai.

eng: He said the majority of them are orphans and that their parents cannot afford to pay for them.
pcm: E yarn say majority of dem be orphan and dia parents no fit pay for dem.

eng: Zimbabwes VP resigns amid sexual misconduct allegations
pcm: Zimbabwea VP don resign untop allegation of sexual misconduct

eng: Zimbabwes Vice President, Kembo Mohadi, resigned on Monday in the face of sexual misconduct allegations, apologising for tasks he failed to do well.
pcm: Vice President of Zimbabwe, Kembo Mohadi don resign on Monday untop allegations of sexual misconduct. E tender e apology for di work wey e no do well.

eng: Local news outlets have since late last month been awash with audio recordings of phone conversations allegedly of Mohadi soliciting sex from several women, including a subordinate in his office.
pcm: Na since last month local news stations don dey roar wit audio recordings of fone conversation wia Mohadi dey ask different women for sex, one of dem wey be im junior for office.

eng: First published by online publication ZimLive, the clips included one where a man can be heard scheduling to meet for sex at his office.
pcm: Di recordings first show for online publication, ZimLive website , Inside di audio, you fit hear wia one man dey book appointment for sex inside im office.

eng: I am stepping down as the Vice President of the Republic of Zimbabwe â€¦with immediate effect, the 71-year-old leader said in a letter posted on the information ministrys
pcm: I dey step down as di Vice President of di Republic of Zimbabwe wit immediate effect, di 71-year-old leader tok for inside one letter wey dem post for di ministry of information

eng: He had decided to leave office not as a matter of cowardice but out of respect for the office of the presidency so that it is not compromised or caricatured by actions that are linked to my challenges as an individual.
pcm: I don decide to komot for office, no be sake of say I be coward, but unto say I get respect for di office of di presidency, so dem no go fit compromise am, or represent am wit actions wey dey connected to my challenges as a pesin.

eng: I have been going through a soul searching pilgrimage and realised that I need the space to deal with my problems outside the governance chair, he said.
pcm: I don dey reflect and tink about mysef, and I see say I need space wey I go take deal wit my problems outside governance. E yarn

eng: He repeated his denial of any wrongdoing, saying he was a victim of information distortion, voice cloning, and sponsored spooking and political sabotage.
pcm: E repeat am say im no do any bad tin, say im be victim of information distortion, voice cloning, and sponsored spooking wit political sabotage.

eng: Mohadi, a retired soldier and veteran of the countrys liberation war, was one of Zimbabwes two vice presidents.
pcm: Mohadi, wey be retired soldier and foreman of di kontri liberation war, na one of di  two vice presidents for Zimbabwe.

eng: He served in several ministerial positions under former president Robert Mugabe and was appointed vice president in 2017 following Mugabes ouster.
pcm: E don serve for different ministerial position under befor-befor president, Robert Mugabe and dem kom appoint am as vice president for 2017 afta dem komot Mugabe.

eng: Technologies arm professional farmers in China
pcm: Technology don make professional farmers for China strong.

eng: Human resources are of huge importance for Chinas rural vitalization.
pcm: Human resources dey veri important for China rural vitalization.

eng: At present, there are over 17 million high-calibre farmers working in the countryside to prosper the rural regions.
pcm: Currently, na more dan 17 million high-class farmers dey work for villages, so dem go fit improve di rural areas.

eng: The improved scientific literacy of Chinese farmers has laid a solid foundation for their overall development and is offering stronger support for the countrys rural economy.
pcm: Di knowledge of science wey Chinese farmers get don lay solid foundation for dia general development and e dey give stronger support for di kontri rural economy.

eng: Bao Yuan is a young man running an aquatic product company in Qujing, southwest Chinas Yunnan province that he established in 2014 after graduating from Yunnan Normal University in 2014.
pcm: Bao Yuan na young man wey get aquatic product company wey e establish 2014 for Qujing, Yunnan province for southwest China afta e graduate from Yunnan Normal University for 2014.

eng: Artificial breeding not only diversifies peoples choices, but also helps protect endangered local fish species, he said.
pcm: E tok say "Artificial breedin no just dey give pipo option of different choice, e also dey protect different kind of fish wey don dey komot for water.

eng: Song Xueqin is a Gen Y female who has made her name in the Lvliang Mountains, north Chinas
pcm: Song Xueqin na Gen Y female wey don get name for North China Lvliang Mountains,

eng: Shanxi province by flat peach grafting techniques.
pcm: for Shanxi province sake of say she sabi different flat peach graftin technique.

eng: After graduation from college, Song was successively engaged in catering business, gypsum processing and sheep husbandry, but didnt succeed in any of those.
pcm: Afta she graduate from college, Song don do different businness like catering, gypsum processin and rearing of sheep, but she no make am for any of dis business.

eng: In 2009, she heard that Chinese wild peaches can be turned into flat peaches through grafting techniques, so she asked one of her friends to bring her scions of flat peaches from northwest Chinas Xinjiang Uygur autonomous region and invited an expert to impart relevant skills to her.
pcm: For 2009, she hear say dem fit turn Chinese wild peach to flat peachthroughgraftin, na so she tell one of her friend say make dat one help am bring flat peach scion from di independent Uygur region, Xinjiang province of Northwest China. Afta, she invite one expert say make e kom teach am di tins wey she need to know.

eng: A year later, Song and her husband grafted flat peach scions onto over 4,000 wild peaches on a hillside near Hetaozhang village, Fenxi County, Shanxi province, but the fruiting wasnt good.
pcm: Afta 1 year, Song and her husband graft flat peach scions on more dan 4,000 wild peach for one hillside near Hetaozhang village, Fenxi County, for Shanxi province, but di result no good.

eng: After consulting relevant materials and experts, we finally realized what cross-pollination was.
pcm: Afta she konsult di relevant materials and experts, she finally realize wetin cross-pollination be.

eng: The yield goes high only when varieties grafted match, she said.
pcm: Di yield go only go up wen di type wey dem join togeda match. She yarn.

eng: Last year, the woman received her first certification of her life â€“ a certificate for new professional farmers.
pcm: Last year, di woman collect di first certificate for her life, a certificate for new professional farmers.

eng: The countryside is never short of resources.
pcm: Rural areas no dey eva lack resources.

eng: In recent years, as peoples living standards have been raised, they are developing a larger demand for green and high-quality agricultural products.
pcm: Recently, as pipo standard of living dey high, dem dey get larger demand for fresh and high-quality agricultural products.

eng: This trend is mobilizing more and more well-educated entrepreneurs who are technically skilled and know how to operate and manage businesses to go back to the countryside, said Zuo Chenming, a senior researcher with AliResearch, a research arm of Alibaba Group.
pcm: Zuo Chenming wey be senior researcher for  AliResearch, a research branch of Alibaba Group tok say "Dis trend dey make more and more educated entrepreneurs wey get technical skill and know how to do businesses, to go back to di rural area.

eng: Early in the morning, Mi Xiaohong from Yuzhong County, Lanzhou, northwest Chinas Gansu province started working in a cowshed, serving the cattle with new fodder and water and cleaning the cowshed.
pcm: For early morning, Mi Xiaohong from Yuzhong County, Lanzhou, Gansu province for Northwest China start work for cowshed, she dey clean di cowshed, and give di cow new feed and water.

eng: The making of cattle fodder is complicated, as we must calculate how much grass and other materials we add in it and fairly decide the ratios of bran, glacial flour and salt, she told Peoples Daily, adding that the ingredients have to be adjusted according to different growth periods of the cattle.
pcm: E no easy to make cow feed, becos we need calculate how many grass and oda materials wey we go add for inside. We go need to know di ratio of bran, glacial flour and salt, wey go dey inside. She tell People's Daily, say dem go need dey adjust di ingredients wey dey inside di as di cow dey grow.

eng: Mi, always attending training programs held by the county government, has become a specialist in cattle husbandry.
pcm: Mi, dey always go trainin programs wey di County government organise, and she don turn specialist for cattle husbandry.

eng: I made many detours as a layman, but now Im often consulted by fellow villagers, she said, adding that only by continuous learning can she solve more problems.
pcm: I divert plenti times wen I still be novice, but now my fellow villagers dey always come meet me for advice. She add am join say, na onlythroughkontinuous learnin she go fit solve more problems.

eng: Today, local authorities across China are issuing new policies and measures to encourage farmers to study technologies.
pcm: Today, local authorities all ova China don dey give new policy and technique to make sure say farmers study new technologies.

eng: Shandong province has launched a professional title evaluation system for professional farmers, and Jiangsu provinces Kunshan is offering free college education for professional farmers.
pcm: Shandong province don begin one professional title evaluation system for professional farmers, and Jiangsu province Kunshan dey offer free college education for professional farmers.

eng: In Gansu Province, training sessions are launched for heads of professional cooperatives and animal epidemic prevention coordinators, in an effort to bring technologies to the farmland and find solutions to agricultural problems.
pcm: For Gansu Province, dem dey organise trainin session for di leaders of professional cooperative and coordinators of animal epidemic prevention. All dis na effort to bring technology to di farm and find solution to agric problems.

eng: 2023: Group launches #BringBackGEJ project, pledges to fund campaigns
pcm: 2023: Group Begin #BringBackGEJ project, pledge to fund campaign

eng: A group under the aegis of Youths Earnestly Demand For
pcm: A group under di sponsorship of Youths Earnestly Demand For

eng: Goodluck E.Jonathan (YED4GEJ 2023) has asked former President Goodluck Jonathan to contest the 2023 presidential election.
pcm: Goodluck E.Jonathan (YED4GEJ 2023) don tell former President Goodluck Jonathan say make e contest for di 2023 presidential election.

eng: Jonathan lost power to the candidate of the then opposition All Progressives Congress (APC), Gen. Muhammadu Buhari (rtd) in the 2015 general election, thus, putting an end to the 16 years of Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) reign in the country.
pcm: Jonathan wey lose power to di candidate of befor-befor opposition party, All Progressives Congress (APC), Gen. Muhammadu Buhari (rtd) for di 2015 general election. Dis na im end di 16 years wey People's Democratic Party (PDP) don dey rulefor di kontri.

eng: National Chairman of the group, Prince Teddy Omiloli and National Director Operations, Comrade Douye Daniel in a statement on Sunday expressed optimism that Jonathan would tackle the challenges bedeviling the country if given the mandate.
pcm: Di National Chairman of di group, Prince Teddy Omiloli and National Director Operations, Comrade Douye Daniel tok on Sunday for inside one statement say, dem get hope say Jonathan go tackle di challenges wey torment di kontri if dem give am di power.

eng: The group explained that Jonathan saw the need to restructure Nigeria while in power and called for a national confab in 2014, but was not allowed to implement it, as he was voted out of office, hence the need to give him another chance.
pcm: Di group explain say Jonathan don see di reason why we need to restructure Nigeria wen e dey power, and na why e organise national confab for 2014, but dem no allow am implement am, sake of say dem komot am for office. Na why we need give am anoda chance.

eng: At this point in time, after a vivid look into the ideologies and activities of our present political players which includes the youths and elders, we saw in Goodluck Jonathan, a true democrat, a nation builder, a divine inspired goal oriented leader of integrity that has the solution to the present Nigeria problems.
pcm: Right now, wen we check di ideology and activity of awa present politicians, di youth and elders join togeda, we see say Goodluck Jonathan wey be true democrat, nation builder, and leader of integrity wey get beta goal na im get di solution to di problem wey dey face Nigeria presently.

eng: He (Jonathan) has proven that he can sacrifice anything to ensure the unity, peace and development of our great nation Nigeria.
pcm: E (Jonathan) don prove say e fit sacrifice anytin to ensure di unity, peace and development of awa great nation Nigeria.

eng: We, as youths of this great nation after discovering the Nigeria problems and found the solution in Goodluck Jonathan, we are calling on all Nigerians including our political elites, present administration and religious leaders to join the call for the return of Goodluck Ebele Jonathan and also join our #BringbackGEJ project.
pcm: We, as youths of dis great nation, afta we don discover Nigeria problem, and we don see say Goodluck Jonathan na di solution, we dey call on all Nigerians, plus awa politikal elites, present administration and religious leaders say make dem join di call for Goodluck Ebele Jonathan to kom back and make dem also join awa #BringbackGEJ project.

eng: We the youths are ready to purchase President Jonathans form in any party he chooses to flag from and we will fund his electioneering campaign from the beginning to end the moment he accepts this divine call, the group said.
pcm: We di youths dey ready to buy President Jonathan form for any party wey e choose to contest from, and we go fund im campaign from di beginnin to di end, once e don accept dis divine call. Di group tok.

eng: Rice sufficiency: Nigeria has a long way to go Expert
pcm: Rice sufficiency: Nigeria get long way to go Expert

eng: Dr Philip Idinoba, a rice commodity specialist with AfricaRice, has raised concerns over increasing population that is eroding Federal Governments effort toward boosting rice production.
pcm: Dr Philip Idinoba, wey be rice commodity specialist for AfricaRice, don show im consign untop di increasin population wey dey affect Federal Government effort to boost rice production.

eng: Idinoba expressed the concern in an interview with the News Agency of Nigeria (NAN) in Gombe on Tuesday.
pcm: Idinoba yarn dis one for interview wit News Agency of Nigeria (NAN) for Gombe on Tuesday.

eng: He said that there is need for more government investment on rice to boost Nigerias food security.
pcm: E tok say government need to invest more on rice, so e go fit boost Nigeria food security.

eng: According to him, the government is doing a lot to boost rice production, being a staple food, but the growing population of the country is eroding such gains.
pcm: As e yarn, di government dey do plenti tins to boost rice production, sake of say na staple food, but di growin population of di kontri dey bring down di effort.

eng: He said that the rate of urbanisation, which is one of the key drivers of rice consumption in Nigeria, was far higher than the rate at which rice cultivation was being improved.
pcm: E tok say di rate of urbanisation, wey be one of di key factors of rice consumption for Nigeria, dey veri high pass di rate wey we take dey use plant rice.

eng: Nigeria still has a long way to go in terms of rice sufficiency.
pcm: Nigeria still get long way to go for rice sufficiency.

eng: We are making efforts every year through the Anchor Borrowers Programme, special intervention programme and other donor funded projects.
pcm: We dey make effort everi yearthroughdi Anchor Borrowers Programme, special intervention programme and oda donor funded projects.

eng: These are to bring certain things that will help farmers increase yields and productivity.
pcm: All dis na to bring som tins wey go help farmers increase dia yield and productivity.

eng: But in spite of these Federal Government efforts, the number of new mouths we are adding yearly writes off all these improvements, Idinoba said.
pcm: But even wit all dis Federal Government effort, di numba of new mouth wey dey join evri year cancel all dis improvement. Idinoba yarn.

eng: A lot to be done
pcm: Plenti tins to do

eng: The agronomist added that a lot needed to be done through increased investments, especially in dry season farming.
pcm: Di agronomist add am join say we need to do plenti tins by increasin awa investment, especially for dry season farmin.

eng: Dry season farming, according to him, can be leveraged on to boost rice productivity.
pcm: As Idinoba tok, we fit take advantage of dry season farmin to boost rice productivity.

eng: We will have better result in rice production if we will be able to close the gaps that dry season often writes off in rice cultivation.
pcm: We go get beta result for rice production if we fit close di gaps wey dry season dey always cancel for rice cultivation.

eng: According to him, if you have eight million farmers cultivating rice in the wet season and only two million of them cultivate rice in the dry season, then the efforts are not enough yet.
pcm: E yarn say, if u get eight million farmers wey dey plant rice for wet season, and only two million out of dem dey plant rice for dry season, den di effort never reach yet.

eng: Idinoba, who is also a water management specialist, advised farmers in flood-prone areas in the country to plant flood-tolerant varieties that could survive in water between three and four weeks.
pcm: Idinoba, wey still be water management specialist, advise farmers wey dey areas wit flood for di kontri say make dem plant di kind seed wey go fit tolerate flood and go fit survive for water between three to four weeks.

eng: These varieties, which were released three years ago and being multiplied by the National Seeds Council of Nigeria and other seeds companies, he said, were available and could be accessed by farmers.
pcm: He tok am say All dis varieties, wey dem release three years ago, and still dey multiply by di National Seeds Council of Nigeria, wit oda seeds companies, dey available, and farmers go fit get am.

eng: This year, the kind of stories we heard from farmers in Kebbi, Jigawa and Adamawa, with this kind of varieties, you may not have total failure like that.
pcm: Dis year, wit di kind tori wey we hear from farmers for Kebbi, Jigawa and Adamawa wey use dis kind varieties, u fit no get complete failure laidat.

eng: Hence, integrating such technologies will help in a way.
pcm: Derefor, make we combine dis kind technology go help one way.

eng: The rice specialist added that in such areas, there should be improvement in the cropping environment through the construction of water structures to control, retain or evacuate water.
pcm: Di rice specialist add am say for dose kind areas, improvement go need dey di cropping environmentthroughdi construction of water structures to kontrol, retain or evacuate water.

eng: Volleyball: JVC Bauchi eye Premier League ticket
pcm: Volleyball: JVC Bauchi get eye for Premier League ticket

eng: The Coach JVC volleyball club of Bauchi, Monday Dada has said his team is eager to gain promotion to the Nigerian Premier League.
pcm: Monday Dada wey be di Coach JVC volleyball club of Bauchi, don yarn say im team dey eager to collect promotion enta di Nigerian Premier League.

eng: The coach made this known Wednesday after his side defeated Oyo State 3-1 (25-23, 25-21, 28-30, 25-22) at the ongoing 2021 National Division 1 Volleyball League in Kaduna.
pcm: Di coach yarn dis one on Wednesday afta im side beat Oyo State 3-1 (25-23, 25-21, 28-30, 25-22) for di ongoin 2021 National Division 1 Volleyball League for Kaduna.

eng: He said based on the calibre of players in the team, JVC of Bauchi belongs to the Premier League class.
pcm: E tok say base on di kind players wey dey di team, JVC of Bauchi belong to di Premier League class.

eng: JVC of Bauchi is in the Division 1 league to gain promotion to next seasons premier league because that is where the big guns are and that is what we are aiming for.
pcm: JVC of Bauchi dey di Division 1 league, and dem go collect promotion enta next season premier league, unto say na dere di big guns dey, and na wetin we dey aim for be dat.

eng: We do not expect anything apart from getting the ticket, he said.
pcm: We no dey expect anytin more dan to get di ticket, e yarn.

eng: Dada also took responsibility for the failure of his team to beat Kwara State on Tuesday as he said it was due to his technical mistakes.
pcm: Dada sef take responsibility for di failure of im team to beat Kwara State on Tuesday. E explain say na becos of im own technical mistakes.

eng: In other matches played yesterday, Spartans Spikers of Yola lost 2-3 (21-25, 22-25, 25-17, 25-21, 12-15) to Kwara United, Katsina United spanked Caliphate Spikers of Sokoto 3-1 (25-23, 25-19, 22-25, 25-12) while Kada Kings thrashed Equity Spikers of Kebbi 3-0 (25-14, 25-15, 25-14).
pcm: For oda match wey dem play yestaday, Spartans Spikers of Yola lose 2-3 (21-25, 22-25, 25-17, 25-21, 12-15) to Kwara United, Katsina United flog Caliphate Spikers of Sokoto 3-1 (25-23, 25-19, 22-25, 25-12) while Kada Kings scatter Equity Spikers of Kebbi 3-0 (25-14, 25-15, 25-14).

eng: What Kano needs in 2023
pcm: Wetin Kano need for 2023

eng: Kano needs to chart a new path to development in 2023.
pcm: Kano need create new path to development for 2023.

eng: This is because the state is sliding into the pit of poverty.
pcm: Dis na becos di state don dey enta di pit of poverty.

eng: Our rich pre-colonial history indicates that Kano was the richest of all Hausa states because of state involvement in the economy.
pcm: Awa rich pre-colonial history show say na Kano rich pass for all di Hausa states, becos di state dey involve for di economy.

eng: Although, the colonialists destroyed the economic foundation of Kano and other colonised societies the policies of those who led the Native Authority from 1926 to 1963 contributed to maintaining Kano as the leading economic centre of Northern Nigeria.
pcm: Even say di colonialists destroy di economic foundation of Kano and oda society wey dem colonise, di policy of di pipo wey lead di Native Authority from 1926 to 1963 contribute to make Kano remain as di leadin economic centre of Northern Nigeria.

eng: For example, they established the first modern water treatment plant in the region in 1931, the first independent power plant in Northern Nigeria of 15mw and for over 80 years, no similar one has been established in Northern Nigeria.
pcm: For example, dem establish di first modern water treatment plant wey dey di region for 1931, di first independent power plant for Northern Nigeria, wey get 15MW, and for more dan 80 years, dem neva establish any one wey resemble am for Northern Nigeria.

eng: They established the first industrial estate in the Northern Region, they inherited one primary school in 1926 and by 1963 every village had a primary school (hundreds), they established secondary schools, they inherited no hospital (but one dispensary) and by 1963 there were two general hospitals and hundreds of dispensaries in every village headed by Dagachi had one.
pcm: Dem establish di first industrial estate wey dey di Northern Region, dem inherit only one primary school for 1926, and for 1963 everi village don get primary school (more dan hundred), dem establish secondary schools, dem no meet any hospital (except one dispensary) and for 1963 dem don build two general hospital and more dan hundred dispensaries for everi village.

eng: They laid the foundation of modern Kano.
pcm: Na dem lay di foundation of modern Kano.

eng: Politically, they made the NPC to become the ruling party of Nigeria.
pcm: Politikally, na dem make di NPC becom di rulin party for Nigeria.

eng: From 1966 to 1979 and 1984 to 1999, Kano still maintained its position as second to Lagos.
pcm: From 1966 to 1979 and 1984 to 1999, Kano still maintain im position as di second to Lagos.

eng: Kano does not have control over macro-economic policies but its leaders can provide the enabling environment for economic growth.
pcm: Kano no get kontrol ova macro-economic policy but e leaders fit provide di right environment for economic growth.

eng: For example, the Dawanau Market, which is the largest grains market in West Africa bringing people from all parts of the continent from as far as Gabon and Congo.
pcm: For example, di Dawanau Market, wey still be di biggest grain market for West Africa, e dey bring pipo from all part of di kontinent, even from far place like Gabon and Congo.

eng: This was all as a result of the foresight of Alhaji Bashari Garko (may Allah bless his soul), who established the market.
pcm: All dis na result of di foresight wey Alhaji Bashari Garko (may Allah bless im soul), wey establish di market get.

eng: The three administrations that governed Kano from 1999 to date, could all claim that each one of them was the best thing that has happened to Kano but why has Kano degenerated to number nine in Nigeria?
pcm: Di three administration wey don rule Kano from 1999 till today, fit claim say all of dem be di best tin wey don happun to Kano, but why Kano don reduce to numba nine for Nigeria?

eng: There is no single project that has brought any significant economic change in Kano despite several efforts by concerned individuals.
pcm: One single project no dey wey don bring correct economic change for Kano, even afta plenti effort of consign pipo.

eng: If there is elite focus and determination, with state leadership as it was in the pre-colonial period, Kano would not have gone down to number nine in Nigeria with a GDP of $13.30b after Lagos ($46.03b), Rivers ($32.14b), Delta ($25.48b), Oyo ($21.64b), Imo ($20.64), Edo ($17.50b), Akwa Ibom ($15.26) and Ogun ($13.82).
pcm: If di elite dey focus and determine, wit state leadership as e dey for di pre-colonial period, Kano no go go down to numba nine for Nigeria wit GDP of $13.30b afta Lagos ($46.03b), Rivers ($32.14b), Delta ($25.48b), Oyo ($21.64b), Imo ($20.64), Edo ($17.50b), Akwa Ibom ($15.26) and Ogun ($13.82).

eng: The catastrophe in the next 10 years if not averted now, will be beyond our imagination.
pcm: If we no prevent am now, we no go fit imagine di disaster wey go kom in di next 10 years.

eng: This is because of many reasons, one of which is we have over four million pupils in public basic schools (primary and JSS) and by 2033 they would have completed secondary education.
pcm: Dis na becos of many reasons. One of dem be say we get more dan four million pupils for public basic schools (primary and JSS) and by 2033 dem go don finish secondary education.

eng: Assuming only 10 percent of them (400,000) will proceed to higher-level can the government fund their education?
pcm: Assume say na onli 10 percent of dem (400,000) go go higher-level, di government go fit sponsor dia education?

eng: After completing higher education, can the economy absorb them with gainful employment?
pcm: Afta dem complete higher education, di economy go fit give dem beta employment?

eng: At the current state of development, it cannot.
pcm: As e be so, e no fit.

eng: This is because, there are over 250 medical doctors and over 1000 nurses sponsored by the state government, who could not be absorbed despite the need.
pcm: Dis na becos, more dan 250 medical doctors and more dan 1000 nurses wey di state government dey sponsor, na im dem no fit employ.

eng: We keep deceiving ourselves with so-called skills acquisition programmes that train artisans who will not get any job after acquiring the skills because the local economy cannot absorb them.
pcm: We go dey deceive awasef wit di skills acquisition programme wey dey train artisans wey no go get any job afta dem learn di skills, sake of say di local economy no fit employ dem.

eng: Every day we hear billions allocated by the federal government for one economic programme or the other and yet our ideas are never beyond training plumbers, carpenters, mechanics etc.
pcm: Everi day we dey hear billions wey federal government allocate for one economic programme or di oda, and still, we no dey reason pass to train plumbers, carpenters, mechanics etc.

eng: Our ideas, so far, are not about harnessing resources for the employment of a larger population as Gajimasu (1095-1135) did when he started the city walls.
pcm: Since, awa idea no dey about how we go use resources employ di large population as Gajimasu (1095-1135) do wen e begin di city walls.

eng: We have to think out of the box.
pcm: We need tink outside di box.

eng: Kano does not need a superhuman being with the best qualifications and experience or a saint as the next governor.
pcm: Kano no need genius wey get di best qualification and experience, or saint as di next governor.

eng: This is because the governors in the last 20 years possessed some of the best qualities and might have even done their best but as we can all see, the outcome has not been the best for the state.
pcm: Dis na becos di governors wey dey for di last 20 years get som of di best quality, and dem fit even don do dia best, but as all of us dey see, di result no be di best for di state.

eng: Therefore, we must think out of the box.
pcm: So, we need reason outside di box.

eng: The two parties APC and PDP cannot provide the desired leadership because they are controlled by godfathers, not ideologically driven, but mainly concerned with sharing of state resources.
pcm: Di two parties, APC and PDP no fit provide di kind leadership wey we want, sake of say na godfathers dey kontrol dem, and dem no get idea on wetin to do, but dia main focus na how to share di state resources.

eng: The best they can offer is to negotiate for a governor who will serve the interest of a godfather or a clique.
pcm: Di best tin wey dem fit do na to negotiate for governor wey go serve di interest of a godfather or cabal.

eng: Therefore, the two parties are not the best options.
pcm: So, di two parties no be di best option.

eng: A very good person could emerge using his resources or with the help of other well-meaning patriotic people.
pcm: Beta pesin fit kom outside on e own, or wit di help of oda beta patriotic pipo.

eng: He could win through any efforts including negotiating with even any of the two parties or another party.
pcm: E fit use any way win, even if e negotiate wit any of di two parties or anoda party sef.

eng: This is a possibility.
pcm: E dey possible

eng: It has happened before.
pcm: E  don happun befor.

eng: An example, in the neighbouring Kaduna State, is Nasir Elrufai.
pcm: One example wey dey near us na Nasir Elrufai for Kaduna State.

eng: He is one of the best in his generation but security in the state is beyond him because he depends on his personal intelligence and capacity.
pcm: Im be one of di best for im generation, but di security situation for di state don pass im power, sake of say e dey depend on im personal intelligence and capacity.

eng: A better person than him in Kano will not make it the desired place unless certain fundamentals are changed.
pcm: Pesin wey beta pass am for Kano no go make di place beta unless dem change som important tins.

eng: I do not claim to have all the answers or even to be exclusively original in the ideas below.
pcm: I no claim say I get all di answer or even say na me get all di idea wey dey down.

eng: Some of them are even modifications of Aminu Kanos ideas.
pcm: Som of dem na part of Aminu Kano idea.

eng: There are many better ideas in the minds of more intelligent people.
pcm: Plenti beta idea dey for di mind of more intelligent pipo.

eng: The ideas I am suggesting are based on my little experience as a labourer of politicians and some training outside this country.
pcm: Di idea wey I dey suggest na base on my small experience as labourer of politicians and som trainin wey I get outside dis kontri.

eng: Kano is on the crossroad, therefore, these ideas could be useful.
pcm: Right now, Kano dey crossroad, and dis ideas fit dey useful.

eng: Some people need to come together and organise a political movement not owned by any individual but people willing to sacrifice.
pcm: Som pipo need kom togeda to organise one political movement wey no dey in kontrol of anybodi but pipo wey wan sacrifice.

eng: It should kindly consider the suggestions below:
pcm: Make dem look di suggestion below:

eng: There is a need to initiate political organisation at the lowest level and making the members own it.
pcm: Need dey for us to start political organisation at di lowest level and make sure say na di members dey in kontrol.

eng: No material reward but sacrifice.
pcm: Material reward no go dey, but sacrifice.

eng: This is possible with mobilisation and the right messages.
pcm: Dis dey possible wit mobilisation and di right message.

eng: Before the election, the movement or party must take a comprehensive inventory of the state and design a comprehensive action plan with specific measurable targets.
pcm: Befor di election, di movement or party need take detail inventory of di state and design comprehensive action plan wit specific targets wey dey measurable .

eng: There should be operational guidelines for all appointees including the governor, which must be popularised for every citizen to know and challenge if breeched.
pcm: Operational guidelines go dey for all appointees plus di governor, and dem go need announce am so every citizen go fit know and challenge, if dem no follow am.

eng: No one who seeks any position should be given such a position in the movement or party from the lowest level to the highest.
pcm: Anybodi wey dey find position inside di movement or party, go begin from di lowest level to di highest.

eng: Some will argue this kills ambition.
pcm: Som pipo go argue say dis strategy go kill ambition.

eng: What is needed now is not ambition but a sustainable system owned by the people.
pcm: Wetin we need now no be ambition but sustainable system wey dey in kontrol of di pipo.

eng: Similarly, no one should be given any position until he fulfils certain basic conditions of competence and honesty as well as bringing references and guarantors.
pcm: Also, make dem no give anybodi any position unless e don fulfil som basic condition of competence and honesty, and e go bring reference and guarantor.

eng: All public officials must publicly declare their assets and those of their family members on the assumption of office, which must be verified by forensic experts.
pcm: All public officers must declare dia asset publicly, and dia family members own join, immediately dem reach office. And forensic experts go need verify everytin .

eng: Their salaries, expenses (including travels, entertainment etc) must be made public periodically.
pcm: From time to time, di public need dey know dia salary and expenses (plus travel, entertainment etc).

eng: No one who becomes a governor or attains any position should ever be allowed to act unilaterally.
pcm: Anybodi wey becom governor or reach any position no go ever do tins on e own.

eng: The governor must never be allowed
pcm: Di governor no go ever

eng: To make appointments unilaterally.
pcm: Make appointment alone.

eng: There must be criteria, expectations or set targets for such appointments for periodic assessments and evaluations;
pcm: Criteria, go dey, dem go need set expectation or target for dose kind appointment, and dem go need dey assess and evaluate am from time to time.

eng: All contracts must be transparently awarded after evaluation by experts from within and outside the bureaucracy.
pcm: All contract wey dem go award go dey fair and transparent, and expert inside and outside di government bureaucracy must evaluate am.

eng: Allocations of plots must also be transparent.
pcm: Allocation of plots must dey transparent too.

eng: No governor should be allowed to have absolute control of the treasury and it should be administered by competent staff.
pcm: No governor go get total kontrol of di treasury and na competent staff go dey in charge .

eng: The governor should only be seen as the leader who guides institutions to develop and end one-man rule.
pcm: Di governor go be di leader wey go guide all di institution to develop and end one-man rule.

eng: If the governor is liberated from this prison of power, he will lead the state to greatness.
pcm: If di governor dey free from dis prison of power, e go lead di state to greatness.

eng: He will lead by example and corruption will be minimised because the avenues of abuse of power have been blocked.
pcm: E go lead by example and corruption go reduce becos dem don block all di way wey e fit use abuse power.

eng: A governor should be seen to supervise public servants and ensure everyone performs his duties diligently.
pcm: Governor suppose dey to supervise public servants and make sure say everybodi do im duty well.

eng: He should inspire his people with exemplary lifestyles, commitment to service and transparency.
pcm: E suppose inspire im pipo wit good lifestyle, commitment to service and transparency.

eng: By Ibrahim Ado-Kurawa, the Editor,
pcm: By Ibrahim Ado-Kurawa, di Editor,

eng: Nigeria Year Book and Who is Who
pcm: Nigeria Year Book and Who is Who

eng: Niger republic, 6 other countries lose right to vote in UNGA -Guterres
pcm: Niger republic and 6 oda kontries don lose di right to vote for UNGA -Guterres

eng: Niger and six other nations lost their right to vote in the United Nations General Assembly (UNGA) because they have not paid their dues, UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres has said.
pcm: UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres don tok say Niger and six oda nations don lose dia right to vote for di United Nations General Assembly (UNGA), sake of say dem neva pay dia dues.

eng: The other countries losing their UNGA voting rights are Iran, Libya, the Central African Republic, Congo Brazzaville, South Sudan and Zimbabwe, the Jerusalem Post reported on Tuesday.
pcm: Di oda kontris wey lose dia UNGA votin right na; Iran, Libya, di Central African Republic, Congo Brazzaville, South Sudan and Zimbabwe, di Jerusalem Post report on Tuesday.

eng: Three more countries  Comoros, Sao Tome and Principe and Somalia  will be allowed to continue to vote despite missing dues payments, because they sufficiently demonstrated that they are incapable of paying.
pcm: Three more kontris “ Comoros, Sao Tome and Principe and Somalia “ go get di chance to kontinue to vote, even say dem no pay dia dues too, but sake of say dem show say dem no get di capacity to pay.

eng: Guterres wrote a letter to General Assembly President Volkan Bozkir of Turkey that the countries in arrears to the UN will have their UNGA voting rights suspended in accordance with the UN Charter.
pcm: Guterres write letter give di General Assembly President, Volkan Bozkir of Turkey say dem go suspend di UNGA votin right of kontris wey dey owe di UN, accordin to di UN Charter.

eng: The Charter stipulates the suspension of voting rights if a member state fails to pay its fees for more than two years, the report said.
pcm: Di Charter tok say make dem suspend di votin right, if one member state no pay im fees for more dan two years.

eng: Under the article, a member-state in arrears in the payment of its dues in an amount that equals or exceeds the contributions of two preceding years can lose its vote in the General Assembly.
pcm: Inside di article, a member-state wey owe dues wey dey equal or pass di amount of im contribution for two years fit lose im vote for di General Assembly.

eng: Iran owes 16.2 million dollars, more than any other country.
pcm: Iran dey owe 16.2 million dollars, money wey pass any oda kontri own.

eng: Meanwhile, Iran has blamed U.S. sanctions for blocking the Islamic Republic from paying its required contribution to the UN, the newspaper reported.
pcm: Meanwhile, Iran don blame U.S, say na dia sanctions no make di Islamic Republic pay im contribution to di UN.

eng: Iranian Foreign Ministry spokesman Saeed Khatibzadeh said the funds designated for UN payments are frozen in two South Korean banks, due to the U.S. sanctions.
pcm: Iran Foreign Ministry tok-tok pesin, Saeed Khatibzadeh yarn say di money wey dem wan use pay UN dey frozen for two South Korean banks, sake of U.S. sanctions.

eng: He said the Islamic Republic has a total of USD 7 billion in those banks, the report said.
pcm: E tok say di Islamic Republic get a total of USD 7 billion for dose banks, di report tok.

eng: Khatibzadeh demanded that the UN guarantee the payments are safely transferred without using U.S. banks.
pcm: Khatibzadeh tok say make di UN guarantee dem say dem go transfer di payments successfully witout using U.S. banks.

eng: Given that the United States has encroached upon Irans international assets before, the Islamic Republic of Iran insists that the UN not use an American intermediary bank to receive our countrys membership fee.
pcm: Sake of say di United States don seize Iran international asset befor, di Islamic Republic of Iran don insist say make di UN no use any American bank receive awa kontri membership fee.

eng: Alternatively, this organization guarantee the financial transfer channel, Iran International News quoted Khatibzadeh as saying.
pcm: As an alternative, dis organization dey guarantee di financial transfer channel, Iran International News quote Khatibzadeh.

eng: BREAKING: Paris Saint-Germain win French Cup
pcm: BREAKING: Paris Saint-Germain win French Cup

eng: Paris Saint-Germain have won the French Cup by beating Monaco 2-0 in Wednesdays
pcm: Paris Saint-Germain don win di French Cup as dem beat Monaco 2-0 for Wednesday

eng: final at the Stade de France.
pcm: final wey dem play for di Stade de France.

eng: Goals from Mauro Icardi and Kylian Mbappe won a largely uninspiring final for PSG who now go into the weekends final round of Ligue 1 fixtures with a record-equalling 10th league title still a possibility.
pcm: Goal wey Mauro Icardi and Kylian Mbappe score won a largely uninspiring final for PSG who now go into the weekends final round of Ligue 1 fixtures with a record-equalling 10th league title still a possibility.

eng: The French champions have now won the French Cup six times in the last seven seasons having reached the final every year since 2015.
pcm: The French champions have now won the French Cup six times in the last seven seasons having reached the final every year since 2015.

eng: It was also the second trophy of coach Mauricio Pochettinos managerial career after he won the Champions Trophy for PSG in January, although this will for many count as his first major honour.
pcm: It was also the second trophy of coach Mauricio Pochettinos managerial career after he won the Champions Trophy for PSG in January, although this will for many count as his first major honour.

eng: We work every day to experience this kind of feeling, reward and recognition, said Mbappe.
pcm: We work every day to experience this kind of feeling, reward and recognition, said Mbappe.

eng: Its the work of a whole group, staff, all the people who work every day for us, the club and of course the supporters who couldnt be there.
pcm: Its the work of a whole group, staff, all the people who work every day for us, the club and of course the supporters who couldnt be there.

eng: We think a lot about the fans and this title is for them as well.
pcm: We think a lot about the fans and this title is for them as well.

eng: Monaco meanwhile continue their wait to win the French Cup for the first time since 1991, in their first final since 2010 when they were also beaten by PSG.
pcm: Monaco meanwhile continue their wait to win the French Cup for the first time since 1991, in their first final since 2010 when they were also beaten by PSG.

eng: Niko Kovacs side have however had a positive season and can finish it on a happier note at the weekend by qualifying for the Champions League for the first time since 2018.
pcm: Niko Kovacs side have however had a positive season and can finish it on a happier note at the weekend by qualifying for the Champions League for the first time since 2018.

eng: Maiden Davnotch Tennis Championship attracts 300 players
pcm: Maiden Davnotch Tennis Championship attract 300 players

eng: No fewer than 300 players are expected to participate in the maiden Davnotch National Open Tennis Championship coming up between May 14 and 22 at tennis courts of the Moshood Abiola National Stadium, Abuja.
pcm: At least 300 players go participate for di maiden Davnotch National Open Tennis Championship wey go kom up between May 14 and 22 for di tennis court of Moshood Abiola National Stadium wey dey Abuja.

eng: Ifedayo Akindoju, Chairman Caretaker Committee of the Nigeria Tennis Federation (NTF) said this in Abuja on Monday while briefing newsmen on preparations for the championship.
pcm: Ifedayo Akindoju, Chairman Caretaker Committee of di Nigeria Tennis Federation (NTF) yarn dis for Abuja on Monday wen e dey follow tori-men tok on di preparations for di championship.

eng: He said about a N3.5million would be raked at the end of the championship as prize by the winners of the various categories.
pcm: E tok say about N3.5million na im be di prize wey winners of different category go win for di end of di championship.

eng: Akindoju also said that the championship would serve as the federations hunting ground for talents for the national team ahead of several international competitions lined up for the federation this year.
pcm: Akindoju also tok say di championship go serve as di huntin ground for talent wey go dey di national team, to prepare for di plenti international competition wey dey for di federation dis year.

eng: I can tell you the winner of the mens singles and the ladies singles will go home with N500,000 and for the Wheelchair event (male and female), it is N150, 000 each.
pcm: I fit tell you say di winner of di mens singles and di ladies singles go carry N500,000 go house, and for di Wheelchair event (male and female), na N150, 000 each.

eng: Wheelchair event is not actually an open event, and as such it is for the top 16 athletes in the ladder.
pcm: Di Wheelchair event no be open event, so na for di top 16 athletes wey dey di ladder.

eng: Recently in Lagos, we had a ladder tournament on wheelchair alone, so we have the latest rankings of all wheelchair players in Nigeria, and because it is closed, we have top 16 in men and top 16 in women to compete in this event.
pcm: Recently for Lagos, we host ladder tournament for wheelchair only, so we get di latest ranking of all wheelchair players for Nigeria, and becos say e don end, we get top 16 for men and top 16 for women wey go compete for dis event.

eng: We equally have the doubles event for the men; the winner will take home N100,000 and this will be the same for the ladies, Akindoju said.
pcm: We get di doubles event for di men too; di winner go carry N100,000 go house and dis go be di same tin for di ladies too, Akindoju tok.

eng: According to him, the championship is open for athletes who are 14 years and above.
pcm: As e yarn, di championship dey open for athletes wey be 14 years and above.

eng: Also speaking, Emmanuel Ochei, a representative of Davnotch Nigeria Ltd, said the company was sponsoring the championship as part of its Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) and that it would not relent in lending support for sports development.
pcm: Also speakin, Emmanuel Ochei, wey be representative of Davnotch Nigeria Ltd, tok say di company go sponsor di championship as part of im Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) and say e no go stop to dey give support for di development of sports.

eng: The Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation (NNPC) has revealed that it is currently considering equity participation in a number of private refineries in the country.
pcm: Di Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation (NNPC) don yarn say e dey consider equity participation for som private refineries wey dey di kontri.

eng: The NNPC in a statement Monday night said the move is in line with a Federal Governments policy directive, which stipulates the mandatory participation of the Corporation in any privately-owned refinery that exceeds 50,000 barrels per day capacity in keeping with its statutory role of safeguarding national energy security.
pcm: Di NNPC tok am for one statement on Monday night say di move dey in line wit one Federal Government policy directive, wey tok say di compulsory participation of di Corporation for any privately-owned refinery wey don pass 50,000 barrel per day capacity to keep wit e statutory role of safeguardin national energy security.

eng: In this regard, the Corporation has identified at least six refinery projects in which it intends to seek equity participation, five of them are at the development stage with the Dangote Refinery being the largest of them, the statement said.
pcm: Ontop dis one, di Corporation don identify at least six refinery projects wey e won get equity participation. Five of dem dey di development stage, and na Dangote Refinery be di biggest. Di statement yarn.

eng: The statement by the Corporations spokesperson, Dr Kennie Obateru, explained that NNPCs National Oil Company of Nigeria primarily has a dual role of providing stewardship for the nations hydrocarbon resources and adding value to the resources for the benefit of all Nigerians and other stakeholders.
pcm: Di statement by di tok-tok pesin of di Corporation, Dr Kennie Obateru, explain say NNPC National Oil Company of Nigeria get double role; to manage di nation hydrocarbon resources, and to add value to di resources for di benefit of all Nigerians and oda stakeholders.

eng: These roles enable it to achieve the twin objectives of providing energy security for the country and stimulating the nations economic development and growth, Obateru said.
pcm: Dis function dey make am achieve di double objective of providin energy security for di kontri and to stimulate di nation economic development and growth. Obateru yarn.

eng: He said that NNPCs strategic objective to ensure energy security and stimulate economic growth with limited resources requires it to consider strategic partnerships with competent investors in sectors of the oil and gas value chain especially where it currently operates on a sole risk basis.
pcm: E tok say NNPC strategic objective to ensure energy security and stimulate economic growth wit limited resources require say make e consider strategic partnership wit competent investors for sectors of di oil and gas value chain especially wia e currently dey operate on sole risk basis.

eng: The oil refining sector is one of such segments where NNPC is revisiting its strategy in order to strengthen domestic refining capacity and guarantee National Energy Security, he added.
pcm: E add am join say; Di oil refinin sector na one of dose segment wia NNPC dey revisit e strategy, so e go fit strengthen domestic refinin capacity and also guarantee National Energy Security.

eng: He said the new vision is to grow domestic refining capacity, improve petroleum products supply from our local refineries and become a net exporter of petroleum products.
pcm: E tok am say di new vision na to develop domestic refinin capacity, improve petroleum products supply from awa local refineries and to becom a net exporter of petroleum products.

eng: The Corporation assured that the move to seek equity participation in the private refineries would not undercut its commitment to the rehabilitation of its own refineries and strengthen the domestic refining sector.
pcm: Di Corporation assure say di move to get equity participation for di private refineries no go reduce di commitment to revive e own refineries and strengthen di domestic refinin sector.

eng: Obateru stressed that the overall goal is to boost the nations refining capacity with a view to becoming a net exporter of petroleum products in the soonest possible time and boosting the nations economy.
pcm: Obateru emphasise am say di main goal na to boost di nation refinin capacity to become a net exporter of petroleum products in di closest possible time and to also boost di nation economy.

eng: Amaechi, Lai Mohammed inspect Lagos-Ibadan rail project ahead of commissioning
pcm: Amaechi, Lai Mohammed inspect Lagos-Ibadan rail project in preparation for commissionin.

eng: Minister of Transportation, Mr Rotimi Amaechi and his Information and Culture counterpart,
pcm: Di Minista of Transportation, Mr Rotimi Amaechi and im Information and Culture colleague,

eng: Alhaji Lai Mohammed are inspecting the Lagos-Ibadan standard gauge project ahead of the commissioning by President Muhammadu Buhari.
pcm: Alhaji Lai Mohammed dey inspect di Lagos-Ibadan standard gauge project in preparation for di commissionin by President Muhammadu Buhari.

eng: Daily Trust reports that though no specific date has been fixed for the commissioning, it has been slated for June.
pcm: Daily Trust report say; even say dem neva fix one particular date for di commissionin, dem don plan am to happun for June.

eng: Our correspondent gathered that the $1.7bn project with extension to the Lagos Ports in Apapa might be commissioned on or before June 12 to commemorate Democracy Day.
pcm: Awa tori-pesin hear say dem fit commission di $1.7bn project wey extend reach di Lagos Ports for Apapa on or befor June 12 to celebrate Democracy Day.

eng: This was why the Ministers are conducting another inspection to ensure that all the finishing touches on the project were fully carried out.
pcm: Na why di Ministas dey do anoda inspection to make sure say dem do all di finishin touches wey di project need.

eng: Daily Trust had earlier reported how the China Civil Engineering and Construction Corporation (CCECC), the contractor handling the project, has been pressured to deliver all the 10 stations ahead of the commissioning.
pcm: Daily Trust don tok am befor, how dem don pressure di China Civil Engineering and Construction Corporation (CCECC), di contractor wey dey handle di project, say make dem deliver all di 10 stations before di commissionin.

eng: The stations are Ebute-Metta, Apapa, Agege, Agbado, Kajola, Papalanto, Abeokuta, Omi Adio, Olodo and Moniya.
pcm: Di stations na Ebute-Metta, Apapa, Agege, Agbado, Kajola, Papalanto, Abeokuta, Omi Adio, Olodo and Moniya.

eng: Most of the stations have reached almost 90 to 100 percent completion stage while only finishing touches were being done.
pcm: Most of di station don almost reach 90 to 100 percent completion stage, and na only finishin touches dem dey do.

eng: The Ministers, as well as the Permanent Secretary in the Ministry of Transport, Dr Magdalene Ajani, Managing Director of the Nigerian Railway Corporation (NRC), Engr Fidet Okhiria and other officials of the Ministry, started the inspection from the Mobolaji Johnson Station (Ebute-Metta) before heading to the Bola Tinubu Station (Apapa).
pcm: Di Ministas, plus di Permanent Secretary of di Ministri of Transport, Dr Magdalene Ajani, Managing Director of di Nigerian Railway Corporation (NRC), Engr Fidet Okhiria and oda officials of di Ministry, begin di inspection from di Mobolaji Johnson Station (Ebute-Metta) befor dem move to di Bola Tinubu Station for Apapa.

eng: The Ebute-Metta Station is the biggest station in the train corridor.
pcm: Di Ebute-Metta Station na di biggest station for di train corridor.

eng: The Ministerial team inspected all the convenience facilities, the operational rooms, the nursing room, the waiting areas, among others.
pcm: Di Ministerial team inspect all di convenience facilities, di operational rooms, di nursin room, di waitin areas, and odas.

eng: Zimbabwe loses 2 more ministers to COVID-19
pcm: Zimbabwe don lose 2 more ministas to COVID-19

eng: Two ministers serving in the Zimbabwean government died of the Coronavirus (COVID-19) within a matter of days, prompting the country to announce on Saturday plans to further tighten lockdown measures.
pcm: Two ministas wey dey serve for di Zimbabwean government don die of di Coronavirus (COVID-19) within few days, and dis don make di kontri announce on Saturday, dia plan to tighten lockdown measures.

eng: Late on Friday, the government announced that Transport Minister, Joel Matiza, had died after falling ill with COVID-19, less than two days after the country lost Foreign minister Sibusiso Moyo to the same disease.
pcm: Late on Friday, di government announce say Transport Minista, Joel Matiza, don die had afta e fall sick wit COVID-19. Dis na less dan two days afta di kontri lose Foreign minista Sibusiso Moyo to di same disease.

eng: Four government ministers have succumbed to the coronavirus in Zimbabwe so far.
pcm: Four government ministas don die for Zimbabwe becos of di coronavirus.

eng: According to unconfirmed media reports, several other cabinet ministers are fighting for their lives in a private hospital.
pcm: Accordin to som report from di media, plenti oda cabinet ministas dey fight for dia lives for different private hospital.

eng: We are in a dark cloud that we have to clear very soon, deputy health minister John Mangwiro told dpa.
pcm: We dey inside dark cloud wey we need clear veri soon, deputy health minista John Mangwiro tell dpa.

eng: Mangwiro revealed plans to intensify the current lockdown, which has been in place since early January and includes a strict nightly curfew.
pcm: Mangwiro tok dia plans to intensify di current lockdown  and compulsory night curfew, wey don dey since early January.

eng: Restaurants, bars and gyms have also been forced to close.
pcm: Dem don force Restaurants, bars and gyms say make dem close.

eng: We have seen people not adhering to the lockdown regulations announced early this month, he added.
pcm: E add am say; We don see pipo wey no dey obey di lockdown regulations wey dem announce early dis month.

eng: Zimbabwe has registered 30,523 cases of infection since the start of the pandemic, including 962 deaths.
pcm: Zimbabwe don register 30,523 case of infection plus 962 deaths since wey di pandemic start.

eng: The numbers may seem relatively low compared to other countries.
pcm: Di numbers fit dey low if u compare am to oda kontri.

eng: However, the outbreak is putting the nations health system under considerable pressure.
pcm: But, di outbreak dey put di nation health system under big pressure.

eng: Zimbabweans have taken to the social media to blame President Emmerson Mnangagwa and his predecessor, the late Robert Mugabe, for the countrys dilapidated health infrastructure.
pcm: Zimbabweans don blame President Emmerson Mnangagwa and im predecessor, di late Robert Mugabe, for social media, untop di kontri bad health infrastructure.

eng: Health workers recently went on strike over a lack of protective equipment and poor salaries.
