pcm: Health workers go on strike recently untop di lack of protective equipment and poor salary.

eng: How Kadunas N2tr economy struggles with shutdown
pcm: How Kaduna N2tr economy dey struggle wit shutdown

eng: Kaduna state, especially its metropolis witnessed what was described as a major shutdown on Monday as the Nigerian Labour Congress (NLC) protested the mass sack of workers by the state government.
pcm: Kaduna state, especially di city witness wetin we fit call major shutdown on Monday wen di Nigerian Labour Congress (NLC) protest di mass sack of workers by di state government.

eng: There are fears that the shutdown which affected the transport, finance and power sectors could affect the robust economy of the state believed to be among the top performers in Nigeria.
pcm: Pipo get fear say di shutdown wey affect di transport, finance and power sector fit affect di robust economy of di state, wey we feel say e dey part of di top performers for Nigeria.

eng: According to a statistics report by the National Bureau of Statistics (NBS) released in 2019, as of 2017, Kaduna has a nominal Gross Domestic Product (GDP) of N2.69 trillion and ranked as the 10th largest economy in Nigeria.
pcm: Accordin to one statistics report by di National Bureau of Statistics (NBS) wey dem release for 2019, as of 2017, Kaduna get nominal Gross Domestic Product (GDP) of N2.69 trillion and dem rank am as di 10th largest economy for Nigeria.

eng: Services and agriculture dominated the GDP by N1.37tr.
pcm: Services and agriculture na im dominate di GDP by N1.37tr.

eng: However, these services were worst affected by the mass shutdown yesterday which became widespread since Sunday.
pcm: Howeva, dis services dey affected by di mass shutdown wey happun yesterday, and dem don dey announce am since Sunday.

eng: According to a 2020 report by the Oxford Business Group, since 2015, the state has attracted investments in excess of $800 million.
pcm: Accordin to one report by di Oxford Business Group for 2020 , na since 2015 di state don get investment, in excess of $800 million.

eng: At the moment, companies have committed to investing about $2.1 billion over the next two years.
pcm: Presently, companies don plan to invest about $2.1 billion ova di next two years.

eng: In terms of IGR, the Oxford Business Group report quoted Governor Nasir el-Rufai as saying the state doubled its IGR from N13bn in 2015 to N26bn in 2017.
pcm: For IGR, di Oxford Business Group report quote wetin Governor Nasir el-Rufai tok say di state double im IGR from N13bn for 2015 to N26bn for 2017.

eng: It further rose to N44bn in taxes in 2019 after the tax process became simplified through legislation.
pcm: E still increase to N44bn wit tax, for 2019 afta dem make di tax process simplethroughlegislation.

eng: Daily Trust further learnt that some of the industries outside the city centre were not affected.
pcm: Daily Trust hear say som of di industry wey dey outside di city centre no dey affected.

eng: Olam Farms located on the outskirt of the Kaduna  Abuja road was not affected as its staff members were in the office yesterday after the Sallah break
pcm: Olam Farms wey dey for di outskirt of Kaduna-Abuja road no dey affected becos im staff members dey office yestaday afta di Sallah break

eng: We are aware of the situation
pcm: We know about di situation

eng: but you know we are not really in the city centre
pcm: but u know say we no really dey di city centre

eng: , so I dont think we need to bother ourselves at least for now, said a senior official.
pcm: so I no tink say we need boda awasef for now. One senior official tok.

eng: Billions lost already
pcm: Dem don lose Billions already.

eng: Meanwhile, experts said billions of naira would have been lost to the grounding of businesses in the state.
pcm: Meanwhile, experts tok am say na billions of naira dem go don lose untop di groundin of businesses for di state.

eng: An ex banker and economist said the strike would have been avoided if the state governor had negotiated with the unions.
pcm: One former banker and economist tok say dem for don avoid di strike if di state governor don negotiate wit di union.

eng: Goods are transported to the north through Kaduna and from the north through Kaduna to other parts of Nigeria.
pcm: Na Kaduna Goods wey dey go north dey pass, and from di north, e go pass Kaduna go oda part of Nigeria.

eng: Imagine the losses because of the power outage, the logistics, transportation and others.
pcm: Imagine di loss wey happun becos of di power outage, di logistics, transportation and odas.

eng: It runs into billions imagine the hospitals, hotels, transportation, micro businesses that have shut down.
pcm: Na billions e go be. Imagine di hospitals, hotels, transportation, small businesses wey shut down.

eng: The economy is crippled.
pcm: Di economy don crash.

eng: It will further increase the very bad security situation.
pcm: E go increase di veri bad security situation more.

eng: John Okon, another analyst said over N50 million may have been lost in the two days so far especially as power outages persisted and fuel stations were shutting down.
pcm: John Okon, wey be anoda analyst yarn say na more dan N50 million dem go don lose for di two days, especially as light no dey, and fuel stations don shut down.

eng: By Chris Agabi, Simon Echewofun Sunday & Hussein Yahaya
pcm: By Chris Agabi, Simon Echewofun Sunday & Hussein Yahaya

eng: Arteta must deliver next season
pcm: Arteta must deliver next season

eng: As I have already mentioned, Arsenal do not intend to sack Mikel Arteta and the club management will back him to turn the Gunners around next season.
pcm: As I don mention befor, Arsenal no get am for mind to sack Mikel Arteta and di club management go back am to turn di Gunners around next season.

eng: No one can say for certain if Arsenal have made the right decision but the club intends to bring in more talented players this summer.
pcm: Nobodi dey sure if Arsenal don take di right decision, but di club dey plan bring more talented players dis summer.

eng: Serious questions are being asked about the managers ability and even in his own dressing room players are looking at him and wondering if he is the right man for the job.
pcm: Pipo dey ask serious questions about di manager ability, and even e own dressin room players dey look am dey wonder if na im be di right man for di job.

eng: At 39 years-of-age Arteta has a reputation, built alongside Pep Guardiola, as a brilliant coach.
pcm: For 39 years, Arteta get reputation, wey e build wit Pep Guardiola, as a brilliant coach.

eng: However, after seventeen months in charge the fortunes of Arsenal have not progressed and many would argue that the team performances are inferior to those of Unai Emery, the man he replaced and who knocked him out of the Europa League.
pcm: But, afta seventeen months wey e don dey in charge, di fortune of Arsenal neva improve and plenti pipo go argue say di performance of di team dey low pass wen Unai Emery, di man wey e replace, wey knock am out of Europa League dey dia.

eng: Arteta captained Arsenal and was welcomed by the fans as their new champion but they are getting restless and agitated as they watch Chelsea and Tottenham move further ahead.
pcm: Arteta na captain for Arsenal befor and di fans welcome am as dia new champion. But dem don dey lose patience and dem dey agitated as dem see sayChelsea and Tottenham done move ahead.

eng: The Super League disaster will not be forgotten for a long time
pcm: Di Super League disaster  no be sometin wey pipo go forget for a long time

eng: but I can tell you that the Kroenke owners are going nowhere
pcm: but I fit tell u say di Kroenke owners no dey go anywia.

eng: so it is up to Arteta to mend bridges, build a strong team and get his tactics right next season otherwise the proud Gunners could well crash and burn.
pcm: So, e dey Arteta hand to improve tins, build strong team and get im tactics right next season, if not di proud Gunners fit crash and burn.

eng: De Gea wont accept being No2
pcm: De Gea no go gree to be No 2

eng: Despite Manchester United goalkeeper David De Gea having a contract until 2023 his agents are testing the waters to see which clubs would be interested in signing him.
pcm: Even say Manchester United goalkeeper David De Gea get im contract till 2023, im agent dey test microphone, to see di club wey go wan sign am.

eng: I am hearing from inside Old Trafford that despite being on good terms with current No1 Dean Henderson, De Gea will not sit back and accept a role on the bench for much longer.
pcm: I dey hear for inside Old Trafford say even say e get gud parole wit di current No 1 Dean Henderson, De Gea no go siddun take bench for long.

eng: I am picking up interest from Atletico Madrid, Paris Saint Germain and Real Madrid.
pcm: I dey hear say Atletico Madrid, Paris Saint Germain and Real Madrid get interest.

eng: The 30-year-old is arguably at the peak of his career although some inside the club believe he has declined slightly over the past two years.
pcm: We no go deny say di 30-year-old dey on top of im career, even say som pipo for inside di club believe say e don drop small for di past two years.

eng: Manager Solskjaer said, Goalkeeper departments are a very tight knit group.
pcm: Manager Solskjaer tok say, Goalkeeper departments dey veri tight knit group.

eng: They work in preparation, they have different gym sessions, individual sessions to the rest of the squad and they stay together more.
pcm: Dem dey work for preparation, dem get different gym session, personal session to di rest of di squad and dem dey stay togeda more.

eng: Naturally they create a bond and the spirit in the goalkeeping department has been top.
pcm: Naturally dem dey create a bond and di spirit for di goalkeepin department dey high.

eng: Its a healthy competition.
pcm: Na beta competition.

eng: I am sure the coach is right however if De Gea doesnt regain recognition for the No1 stitched onto the back of his shirt and is left on the bench in crucial games, I am reliably informed he will move out of Old Trafford.
pcm: I am sure the coach is right however if De Gea doesnt regain recognition for the No1 stitched onto the back of his shirt and is left on the bench in crucial games, I am reliably informed he will move out of Old Trafford.

eng: I take West Brom to bounce back yet again
pcm: I take West Brom to bounce back yet again

eng: After one season back in the Premier League we again say goodbye to West Bromwich Albion.
pcm: After one season back in the Premier League we again say goodbye to West Bromwich Albion.

eng: The key to yet another quick bounce back from the Championship will be whether or not fire-fighting manager Sam Allardyce can be persuaded to stay.
pcm: The key to yet another quick bounce back from the Championship will be whether or not fire-fighting manager Sam Allardyce can be persuaded to stay.

eng: He is disappointed to have lost his reputation as never having been relegated with any club and the board at West Brom have a lot of work to do if they want to keep him.
pcm: He is disappointed to have lost his reputation as never having been relegated with any club and the board at West Brom have a lot of work to do if they want to keep him.

eng: Ainsley Maitland-Niles, Conor Gallagher and Okay Yokuslu will return to their parent clubs after being on loan but Matheus Pereira, Callum Robinson, Hal Robson-Kanu and Karlan Grant can impress in the lower league.
pcm: Ainsley Maitland-Niles, Conor Gallagher and Okay Yokuslu will return to their parent clubs after being on loan but Matheus Pereira, Callum Robinson, Hal Robson-Kanu and Karlan Grant can impress in the lower league.

eng: Who is the fastest player in the Manchester City squad?
pcm: Who is the fastest player in the Manchester City squad?

eng: No, it isnt Raheem Sterling.
pcm: No, it isnt Raheem Sterling.

eng: Manager Pep Guardiola set up a practice whereby each player had to control the ball and sprint 10 yards.
pcm: Manager Pep Guardiola set up a practice whereby each player had to control the ball and sprint 10 yards.

eng: There are some very fast movers in the City squad but Gabriel Jesus proved he was the fastest.
pcm: There are some very fast movers in the City squad but Gabriel Jesus proved he was the fastest.

eng: The best is yet to come from Havertz
pcm: The best is yet to come from Havertz

eng: Thomas Tuchel has been singing the praises of Kai Havertz and pointed to his two goals recently scored against Fulham.
pcm: Thomas Tuchel has been singing the praises of Kai Havertz and pointed to his two goals recently scored against Fulham.

eng: Tuchel recognises that since Kai arrived at Stamford Bridge from Bayer Leverkusen, things have not gone well for the German.
pcm: Tuchel recognises that since Kai arrived at Stamford Bridge from Bayer Leverkusen, things have not gone well for the German.

eng: Moving from a foreign country and having to handle lockdown restrictions made things difficult and of course he caught Covid-19 and had to battle back to fitness.
pcm: Moving from a foreign country and having to handle lockdown restrictions made things difficult and of course he caught Covid-19 and had to battle back to fitness.

eng: If they do not win their next game, Sheffield United will become the first team since the 1904-05 season to have gone without winning two consecutive games.
pcm: If they do not win their next game, Sheffield United will become the first team since the 1904-05 season to have gone without winning two consecutive games.

eng: Kane is keen to move on from his boyhood club after Tottenham also missed out on the Champions League for a second straight year.
pcm: Kane is keen to move on from his boyhood club after Tottenham also missed out on the Champions League for a second straight year.

eng: Chairman of the Economic and Financial Crimes Commission (EFCC), Abdurasheed Bawa, made a declaration that the Bank Employees Assets Declaration Act of 1986 would be resuscitated to block loopholes created by bankers to sanitise the countrys financial system.
pcm: Chairman for di economic and financial crimes commission (EFCC) Abdulrasheed Bawa don make declaration say dem go resuscitate di Bank Employees Assets Declaration Act of 1986 to block loopholes wey bankers don create to sanitise di kontri's financial system

eng: According to Bawa, the decision was taken due to the role bankers are expected to play in the fight against corruption, as the EFCC is mandated to ensure compliance with the Act.
pcm: According to wetin Bawa tok, dem take di decision due to di role wey dem dey expect make bankers play for di fight against corruption, as di EFCC don mandate am to ensure say dem comply wit di Act.

eng: Section 1 of the Bank Employees Declaration of Assets Act 1986 makes it mandatory for every employee of the bank to make full disclosure of assets upon employment on an annual basis.
pcm: Section 1 for di Bank Employees Declaration of Assets Act 1986 don make am mandatory for Evri employee for di bank to make full disclosure of assets upon employment for annual basis.

eng: The law under Section 7 Sub-Section 1 stipulates that it shall be an offence for an employee of a bank to own assets in excess of their legitimate and probable income.
pcm: Di law wey dey under Section 7 Sub-Section 1 stipulates say na offence e go be for an employee of a bank make e own assets in excess of dia legitimate and probable income

eng: After the deadline as stipulated by the EFCC Chairman, there are consequences that will arise as a result of non-declaration of assets by bank employees.
pcm: Afta di EFCC chairman don stipulate di deadline, consequences go arise as a result of non-declaration by bank employees

eng: For instance, there is a spelt out penalty of 10 years imprisonment upon conviction as well as forfeiture of assets beyond and above legitimate income and probable earnings of such bank employees.
pcm: Spelt out penealty of 10 years inprisonment upon conviction as well as forfeiture of assets wey dey beyond and above legitimate income and probable earnings for dat kain bank employees.

eng: This piece of legislation has been in existence since 1986 under the military.
pcm: Dis piece of legislature don dey so tey 1986 under di military

eng: For a long time, this part of the constitution was rendered ineffective by those who ordinarily should implement it.
pcm: So tey, dis part of di constitution don dey ineeffective by those wey suppose dey implement am ordinarily

eng: Bankers have always been aware of this legislation but the level of compliance has not been encouraging.
pcm: Bankers don aware of dis legislation but di level wey dem dey comply no dey encouraging

eng: In the 80s, bankers were handed such forms which they completed and submitted.
pcm: For di 80s, dem dey hand form to bankers wey dem go complete and submit

eng: But as its always the case in the country, the implementation of that provision of the law was more or less abandoned, and it was no longer considered as a fundamental part of the banking profession.
pcm: But as e dey go for awa kontri, dem don abandon di implementation of dat provision for di law , and dem no longer consideram as a fundamental part for di banking profession.

eng: Stakeholders blame the failure of authorities including the CBN, Chartered Institute of Bankers of Nigeria (CIBN) and Bankers Committee for certain abnormalities in the industry.
pcm: Stakeholders dey blame di failure on top di authorities wey include di CBN, Chartered Institute of Bank of Naija (CIBN) and Bankers Committee for some kain abnormalities wey dey di industry.

eng: According to them, these regulators rely on the banks they are supposed to supervise, to supply them information.
pcm: According to wetin dem dey tok, dem say diz regulators dey rely on di bank wey dem suppose supervise, make e supply information

eng: For instance, they argued that the failed banks episode happened barely some months after the regulators had given those banks clean bills of health.
pcm: For instance, dem don argue am say di failed banks episode apun some months afta dem give di regulator for diz banks clean bill of health

eng: This suggests that the information supplied by the banks may have been doctored.
pcm: Dis suggest say dem don doctor di information wey di bank supplied

eng: Nigeria has been battling with cases of corruption and money laundering, with bankers and bank officials accused of being accomplices.
pcm: Naija don dey battle case like corruption and money laundering and dem dey accuse bankers and banking officials say dem be part of it

eng: Some monies have remained redundant in many accounts due to the death of the owners of the accounts, which some bank officials convert to theirs while leaving families of the account owners in penury.
pcm: Some moni don remain redundant for plenti accounts bikos some account owners don kpeme which some bank officials go convert to dia own as dem go leave families of di account owners for penury.

eng: This is in spite of the fact that the banking sector is no stranger to self-regulation, given its tempting, delicate and fragile operating system.
pcm: Dis dey in spite of di fact say di banking sector no strange to self-regulation,given its tempting, delicate and di operating system wey dey fragile

eng: As a matter of fact, the CIBN Act of 2007 has been regulating the banking system.
pcm: Di CIBN Act of 2007 don dey regulate di banking system

eng: It has a code of conduct to which bankers agreed with the CBN.
pcm: E get code of conduct wey bankers don agree pon wit CBN

eng: There is a disciplinary tribunal that has the power of the High Court, which ensures that reported infractions, unethical conduct and indiscipline are brought before the tribunal, and sanctions recommended for formal prosecution.
pcm: Disciplinary tribunal wey get power for di high court dey and e dey ensure say dem bring reported infractions, unethical conduct and indiscipline before di tribunal, and sanctions wey dem recommended for formal prosecution.

eng: But one of the challenges has been the weak reporting system by bankers, leading to the inability of CIBN to take appropriate actions.
pcm: But one of di challenges be di weak reporting system wey bankers get wey dey lead to di inability of CIBN make dem take appropriate actions.

eng: The spirit behimd the Act of 1986 is to make clear, the financial standing of bank employees at the time of employment, and after years of service, in a bid to ascertain that their legitimate earnings are commensurate with their current lifestyles.
pcm: Di spirit wey stan gidigba for di back of di Act of 1986 na to make clear, di financial standing wey bank employee get for di time of employment, and afta years of service, in a bid wey go make dem ascertain say dem dey commensurate dia legitimate earnings wit dia lifestyles wey dey current

eng: This is coming on the heels of allegations that some bankers are direct beneficiaries of fraudulent transactions that are carried out in the bank.
pcm: Na dis dey kom on top di heels of allegation say some bankers be direct beneficiaries for fraudulent transactions wey dem dey carry out for di bank

eng: What is common knowledge is the asset declaration by public officers including civil servants, politically exposed persons and those who work in the Ministries, Departments and Agencies (MDAs).
pcm: Wetin be common knowledge be say di declaration of assests by public officers wey include di civil servants, pesin wey dey politically exposed and those wey dey for di Ministries, Departments and Agencies (MDAs).

eng: They are required to declare their assets every four years.
pcm: Dem require dem make dem declare dia assets evri four years

eng: For political officeholders, upon their election or appointment, before they assume office, they are supposed to declare their assets at the point of entry and also at the point of exit.
pcm: On top di election and appointment of political office holders, before dem assume office dem suppose declare di assets wey dey get pon entry kom declare am again for di exit point

eng: This declaration is done on oath.
pcm: Dem do dis declaration by oath

eng: In other words, there is execution and attestation before a High Court or some other superior officer of the law.
pcm: For anoda word, execution and attestation before di high court or some oda superior officer for di law dey

eng: The Nigeria Customs Service (NCS), Nigeria Immigration Service (NIS), among others, are already covered by the Code of Conduct Act with regard to the declaration of their assets.
pcm: Di Naija customs service (NCS), Naija Immigration Service (NIS), among odas, dem don covered by di Code of Conduct Act wit regard to di declaration of dia assets.

eng: As it stands, financial experts believe that the impression created by the directive to bankers to comply with the pre-existing piece of legislation amounts to stigmatisation and also isolates bank employees, which puts them in the limelight.
pcm: As e dey so finacial experts believe say di impression wey di directive to bankers create make dem comply wit di of legislation wey dey pre-exist dey amount to stigmatisation and e dey also isolates bank employees, wey dey puts dem in di limelight.

eng: In other words, there is the belief that the revisiting of the Act of 1986 encourages the policy of isolation that is causing apprehension in the industry.
pcm: In oda words, d belief of revisiting of di Act of 1986 dey encourage di policy of isolation wey dey kos apprehension in di industry.

eng: There are concerns that the Act may cause enrolment into the banking profession to further go down as a result of stigmatisation.
pcm: Dis na di concern say di Act fit kos enrolment into di banking profession to further go down as a result of stigmatisation.

eng: However, some stakeholders caution against the drama about stigmatisation, arguing that a lot of bankers, from the highest cadre to the lowest level, are living above their means.
pcm: Some stakeholders don caution against di drama about stigmatisation, arguing say plenti bankers, from di highest cadre to di level wey low pass, dey live above dia means.

eng: According to them, an average banker even from their early point of calling, cuts corners by conniving with customers that want to beat the system.
pcm: According to wetin dem tok , an average banker even from dia early point of calling, dey cut corners by conniving wit customers say dem go beat di system.

eng: They insist that for every major corruption, there is a banker that has facilitated the transaction.
pcm: Dem insist say for evri major corruption, banker wey dey facilitate di transaction dey

eng: It is laudable that the EFCC is trying to use the Act for good reasons.
pcm: E dey laudible say di EFCC dey try use di Act for reason wey good

eng: But the worry is that the banks essentially are not owned by the government per se although the government has shares in them.
pcm: Di worry be say di banks wey di goment no own per se although di goverment get shares in dem

eng: Banks are used for saving money
pcm: Dem dey use bank save moni

eng: More importantly, there are existing laws that can check illicit enrichment.
pcm: Di koko be say laws wey dey check illicit enrichment dey

eng: Article 20 of the UN Convention Against Corruption is explicit on this.
pcm: Article 20 for di UN Convention Against Corruption dey explicit on top dis

eng: Section 7 of the EFCC Act empowers EFCC to investigate persons whose lifestyles are not commensurate with their means of income.
pcm: Section 7 for di EFCC act don empower EFCC make e dey investigate pesin wey hin lifestyle no commensurate wit di means of income wey dem get

eng: It is believed in certain quarters that the assets of this country have been plundered the most by politically exposed persons, many of whom remain untouchable.
pcm: Dem believe am for some part say di politically exposed person dey plunder di assests for dis kontri plenti of dem dey untouchable

eng: As such, EFCC has been accused of not being fair and even-handed in its mandate on tackling public sector corruption including false declaration.
pcm: Dem accuse EFCC say e no fair and even-handed

eng: If the banking sector is sanitised, it will have a ripple effect on all other sectors of the economy.
pcm: If dem sanitise di banking sector, we go get ripple effect for oda sectors of di economy

eng: All these measures are taken to strengthen the fight against corruption, and not to stigmatise the banking profession or portray it as the scapegoat withim the system.
pcm: Dem take all diz measure to strengden di fight against corruption, and not to stigmatise di banking profession or portray it as di scapegoat wey dey witin di system.

eng: Besides, the banking career is not a roguish profession.
pcm: Besides, di banking career no be one kain rouguish profession

eng: Some bankers are at the forefront of exposing some of the mega corruption issues that we have seen the EFCC making headway.
pcm: Some bankers be di forefront of exposing some of di mega corruption issues wey wedon see di EFCC making headway.

eng: Part of the essence of this law is to ensure that the country is free from financial crimes, and also to block the loopholes being exploited by unscrupulous players
pcm: Part of why dis law dey be say e dey ensure make di kontri dey free from financial crimes, and make e dey also block loopholes wey unscrupulous players dey esploit

eng: While it is hoped that the Act of 1986 is a sincere attempt at sanitising the system, there should be a platform created to report thresholds of deposits on a daily basis, and the regulators should be able to access it to know the declarations made.
pcm: While dem dey hope say make di Act of 1986 na sincere attempt at sanitising di system , dem suppose create platform wey go report thresholds of deposits on a daily basis, and di regulator suppose dey able to access it to know di declarations wey dem make.

eng: This makes for easy reference to what has been declared as legitimate income to check those living above their means.
pcm: E dey make am easy reference to wetin dem don declare as legitimate income to check those wey dey live above dia means

eng: Moses Amadi, a researcher, sent this piece from Lagos
pcm: Moses Amadi wey be researcher na hin send dis piece from Lagos

eng: The houe rent is sue and I don’t have money to give to the landlord
pcm: Houserent don due and I no get moni/shingbain wey I go give di landlord

eng: I mistakenly killed a passerby but a robbery suspect was my target vigilante
pcm: Vigilante tok say na mistake hin use kill passerby but na robbery suspect be my target

eng: A 30-year-old member of a local vigilante, Lukma Rasak, who was arrested for killing a passerby in Ijora, a Lagos suburb, said he made a mistake.
pcm: One 30-year-old member of a local vigilante , Lukma Rasak wey dem arrest for kilin a passerby for Ijora wey be a Lagos suburb, say na mistake.

eng: The suspect was alleged to have shot dead a 28-year-old man, Musa Yahaya, in the area.
pcm: Dem allege di suspect say hin shoot one 28-year-old man, Musa Yahaya , for di area

eng: The suspect had allegedly fled the scene of the crime having realized his mistake.
pcm: Di suspect wey dem allege don flee commot for scene of di crime afta hin don realise hin mistake

eng: He was allegedly tracked down to his hiding place by policemen attached to Ijora Police Station, Lagos State Police Command.
pcm: Policemen track am down to wia hin dey hide wey dey attached to Ijora police station , Lagos state police command

eng: Lagos State Police spokesman, Muyiwa Adejobi, in a statement issued on Wednesday night, said the crime occurred in the early hours of Tuesday, April 13, 2021.
pcm: Muyiwa Adejobi wey be Lagos State tok tok pesin don yarn for one statement wey dem issues for Wednesday night say di crime occur for di early hours for Tuesday, April 13 2021

eng: Adejobi said the suspect was eventually arrested at about 2 pm after the victim, who was rushed to the hospital, was confirmed dead.
pcm: Adejobi yarn say dem eventually arrest di suspect about 2pm afta dem rush di victim go hospital kom confirm am say hin don kpeme

eng: He said detectives tracked the suspect to his hiding place, where he was arrested and his gun with some cartridges were recovered.
pcm: Hin say detectives track di suspect go hin hiding place, wia dem arrest am and hin gun and some catridge wey dem recovered

eng: I haven't gone pass that phase
pcm: I neva pass dat phase

eng: Constitution review: Senate holds public hearing in 12 states
pcm: Constitutuion review; Senate don hold public hearing for 12 states

eng: The Senate Constitution Review Committee has said that a zonal public hearing on the review two public hearings per geopolitical zone.
pcm: Di senate constitution review don tok am say di zonal public hearing on di review two public hearings per geopolitical zone.

eng: The event which would be held simultaneously across 12 states in Nigeria would witness two public hearings per geopolitical zone.
pcm: Di event wey go simultaenously across 12 states for Naija go witness two public hearings per geopolitical zone.

eng: Also, a national public hearing is expected to be held in Abuja, the nations capital.
pcm: Also a national public hearing suppose hold for Abuja wey be di nation a capital

eng: Chairman, Senate Committee on Constitution Review and Deputy President of the Senate, Senator Ovie Omo-Agege, disclosed this yesterday in Abuja.
pcm: Chairman, Senate Committee on Constitution Review and Deputy President of di Senate, Senator Ovie Omo-Agege disclose am yesterday for Abuja

eng: Speaking while hosting members of the Legal Defence and Assistance Project (LEPAD) in his office led by its National Coordinator, Chimo Obiagwu (SAN), Senator Omo-Agege called on those who have already submitted memoranda to speak at the events.
pcm: Speaking as hin dey host members of di legal defence and assistance projrct (LEPAD) for hin office wey na National Coordinator, Chino Obiagwu (SAN)lead am , Senator Omo-Agege called on those wey don already submit memeoranda to speak for di event

eng: They dance really hard at the carnival
pcm: Dem dance taya for di carnival

eng: According to him, the South East would hold the hearing in Owerri and Enugu, while the South South and South West would do it in Port Harcourt and Asaba as well as Akure and Lagos respectively.
pcm: According to wetin hin tok , di South East go hold di hearing for Owerri and Enugu , while di South South and South West go do am for Port Harcourt and Asaba as well as Akure and Lagos respectively.

eng: My mummy works at the bakery down the street
pcm: My male dey work for di bakery wey dey down di street

eng: Rabbit farming booms in Plateau
pcm: Rabbit farming don boom for plateau

eng: The Secretary, Plateau Rabbit Breeders Association, Mr Pam Gyang, says rabbit farming has become popular in the state with many residents engaging in it.
pcm: Di secretary, Plateau Rabbit Breeders Association, Mr Pam Gyang tok say rabbit farming don bikom popular for di state wit plenti residents engaging in it.

eng: Gyang who said this in an interview with the News Agency of Nigeria (NAN) on Tuesday in Jos, said it has become a household business just like poultry farming.
pcm: Gyang tok am for an interview wit di News Agency of Naija on Tuesday for Jos, say e don bikom a household business just like poultry farming.

eng: Gyang said that many training outfits involved in the breeding and selling of live rabbits were springing up across the state.
pcm: Gyang tok say plenti trainnig outfits wey dey involved for di breeding and selling of live rabbit don spring up across di state.

eng: The secretary said that rabbit rearing as a lucrative business could increase an individuals income and impact positively on the economy.
pcm: Di secretary tok say rabbit rearing na lucrative business wey fit increase pesin income and impact positively on di economy.

eng: Rabbits are highly fertile and farmers sell according to their weight ranging from N1,800 to N5,000 or even more, he said.
pcm: Hin tok say rabbits dey highly fertile and farmers dey sell according to dia weight as e dey range from N1,800 to N5,000 or even more

eng: He said that during the lockdown occasioned by COVID-19 families came to the farm to request for rabbits cages and rabbits to startup farms at their backyards.
pcm: Hin tok say for di lockdown wey COVID-19 occassioned families dey kom farm kom request for rabbits cages and rabbits to startup farms for dia backyards.

eng: He said that the high demand for rabbits meat as a result of its numerous health benefits over red meat aroused the interest of many farmers.
pcm: Hin say di high demand for rabbits meat so tey di numerous health benefit over red meat don arouse di interest of plenti farmers.

eng: Gyang said that rabbit has low mortality rate and required minimal handling, adding that many people invested in rearing them to meet international market standard.
pcm: Gyang say di get low mortality rate and e require minimal handling adding say plenti pipo don invest in rearing dem so e go meet international market standard.

eng: Our rabbit meat had gone as far as London and we still export them whenever they were demanded, â€œhe said.
pcm: Hin say, awa rabbit meat don go as far as London and we go still export dem weneva dem demand for dem

eng: He also said that farmers could generate resources from the sale of the hide and skin of rabbit for textile industries and its faeces as source of fertilizer.
pcm: Hin tok am say farmers dey generate resources from di sale of di hide and skin of rabbit for textile industries and hin faeces na source of fertilizer.

pcm: Aero don follow Abuja-Bauchi expand flight

eng: Nigeria's oldest airline, Aero Contractors, has concluded an arrangement to commence flights from Abuja to Bauchi four times weekly beginning from Wednesday as part of its route expansion programme.
pcm: Naijas oldest airline wey old pass don conclude for an arrangement say dem go commence flights from Abuja to Bauchi four times weekly beginning from Wednesday as part of its route expansion programme.

eng: The Bauchi flight would be closely followed by those of Maiduguri in Borno State and Calabar in Cross River on dates to be announced soon, according to the airline.
pcm: According to di airline say dem go follow di Bauchi flight closely by those of Maiaduguri wey dey Borno state and Calabar wey dey Cross River on dates wey dem go announce soon

eng: The Managing Director of the Aero, Capt Abdullahi Mahmood, at a press conference in Lagos, said the Abuja-Bauchi flights would be operated every Monday, Wednesday, Friday and Sunday.
pcm: Di managing Director for di Aero, Capt Abdullahi Mahmood don tok am for one conference for Lagos say Dem go dey operate di Abuja-Bauchi flights Evri Monday, Wednesday, Friday and Sunday.

eng: According to the schedule, the Bauchi flight will depart Abuja at 09:10 am, arriving at Bauchi at 10:10 am.
pcm: According to wetin dem schedule, di Bauchi flight go depart Abuja at 09:10am and e go arrive for Bauchi at 10:10 am.

eng: The return leg will then depart Bauchi at 10:40 am, and arrive in Abuja at 11:40 on weekdays, while on Sunday the flight will depart Abuja for Bauchi at 09:50 am, with the return flight from Bauchi at 11:20 am.
pcm: Di return leg do depart Bauchi for 10:40 and e go arrive for Abuja at 11:40 for weekdays , while for Sunday di flight go commot Abuja for Bauchi at 09:50 am, wit di return flight from Bauchi at 11:20 am.

eng: The MD explained that passengers from Lagos could fly to Bauchi via Abuja using the 06:45 am flight out of Lagos.
pcm: Di MD don explain say di passengers wey dey kom from Lagos fit fly to Bauchi via Abuja using di di 06:45 am flight wey dey commot Lagos.

eng: I'm gonna sing for my life
pcm: I go sing for my life

pcm: Bauchi and Maiduguri na some of di undeserving cities for di Northern Naija

pcm: Hin add am say na airlines Boeing 737-400 wey dem just release from C-Check conduct for di Aero maintenance hangar go be di one wey dem go use for di new routes

pcm: Chicken feed don too cost

eng: Farmers raise concerns as CBN suspends Anchor Borrowers loans
pcm: Farmers don raise concern as CBN don suspend anchor Borrowers loans

eng: Farmers and other stakeholders in the agricultural sector are expressing concern over the suspension of agricultural loans accessed through the Nigeria Incentive-Based Risk Sharing System for Agricultural Lending (NIRSAL) by the Central Bank of Nigeria (CBN) recently.
pcm: Farmers and oda stakeholders for di agricultural sector dey express dia concern over di suspension of agricultural loans wey dem dey access through di Naija Incentive-Based Risk Sharing System for Agricultural Lending (NIRSAL) by di Central Bank of Naija (CBN) recently

eng: I thought you were running from me
pcm: I dey think say una dey run/jappa for me

eng: It handles most of the agric loans to farmers by the CBN, especially its popular Anchor Borrower Programme (ABP).
pcm: E dey handle most of di agric loans to di farmers by di CBN especially its popular Anchor Borrower Programme (ABP).

eng: Now, the apex bank has said it suspects fraudulent activities in NIRSAL loans under the ABP and ordered for the suspension of such loans until all previously beneficiaries have paid back.
pcm: Di apex bank say di fraudulent activities for NIRSAL loans under di ABP and dem order for di suspension of such loans until dem don pay all previous beneficiaries back.

eng: It is not yet clear if the suspension is on the CBN Anchor Borrowers Programme alone or also includes those of Micro finance banks through NIRSAL.
pcm: E no dey clear yet if di suspension dey only on di Anchor Borrowers Programme alone or e also include those of Micro finance banks through NIRSAL.

eng: The suspension has grounded loan activities in NIRSAL and farmers are worried that, among others, the timing was wrong, as many of them have already gone far with plans to expand their agricultural production.
pcm: Di suspension don ground loan activities fror NIRSAL and farmers dey worried say among odas, di timing dey wrong, as many of dem don go far wit plans say dem go expand dia agricultural production

eng: A farmer, Remini Femi, who appeared visibly worried said whats happening now is economically threatening and called on the CBN to please step in and save millions of Nigerians to access these loans for agricultural production.
pcm: One farmer wey dey really worried say wetin dey apun now dey threaten di economy and e dey call on top di CBN make dem please step in and save millions of Naija pipo make dem access diS loans for agricultural production.

eng: Many farmers waiting for NIRSAL disbursement through their social media handle expressed sadness over the suspension of the loan facility as it threatened to ground their dreams for expansion.
pcm: Plenti farmers wey dey wait for NIRSAL disbursement for di social media handle don express sadness over di suspension of di loan facility as e dey threaten to ground dia dreams for expansion.

eng: Reacting to the development in a chat with our Agric Editor, the leadership of the All Farmer Association of Nigeria, headed by Architect Kabiru Ibrahim, said though the CBN blames NIRSAL in the non-performance of the ABP, it should do the needful in fishimg out those responsible.
pcm: As hin dey react to di development for di chat wit awa Agric Editor, di leadership of all di farmers association of Naija, wey Architect Kabiru Ibrahin dey head am, tok say thoughdi CBN dey blames NIRSAL for di non-performance of di ABP, make dem do di needful in fishing out those wey dey responsible.

eng: It should continue to provide qualified farmers the much-needed support.
pcm: Make e dey kontinu to provide qualified farmers di support wey dem need

eng: â€œWe urge the CBN to do due diligence in prequalifying farmers who participate in the programme because several cases of briefcase farmers who pose as real farmers abound.
pcm: We dey urge di CBN make dem do due dilligence in prequalifying farmers wey dey participate for di programme bikos several cases of briefcase farmers wey dey pose as real farmers abound.

eng: These collude with some NIRSAL officials to defraud the programme.
pcm: Dem collude wit some NIRSAL officials make dem defraud di programme

eng: â€œTimely repayment which is not forthcoming in the ABP is largely due to this fraud.
pcm: Timely repayment no dey forthkoming for di ABP bikos of di fraud

eng: Anyone who gives bribe to take a loan with an interest component has no desire to repay it.
pcm: Anyone wey give bribe to take a loan wit an interest component no get desire to repay am

eng: â€œOur initial understanding of the role of NIRSAL was to primarily incentivize commercial banks to embrace lending for agricultural production but certainly not to prequalify prospective loan seeking companies.
pcm: awa initial understanding of di role of di NIRSAL na to primarily incentivize commercial banks make dem embrace lending for agricultural production but certainly no be to prequalify prospective loan seeking companies.

eng: This is how corruption took over and the farmers are now the worse for it.
pcm: dis na how corruption take take over and di farmers now be di worst for it

eng: We call on the CBN to reverse its decision on the disbursement of the ABP support to farmers, he said.
pcm: Hin say we dey call on top di CBN make e reverse di decision on top di disbursement of di ABP support to farmers

eng: Dr Femi Oke, AFAN chairman, South-west Zone, said the suspension of the NIRSAL loans would greatly impact food production in the country.
pcm: Dr Femi Oke wey be di AFAN chairman for South-west zone say di suspension of di NIRSAL loans go impact food production for di kontri greatly

eng: Oke, speaking to the News Agency of Nigeria (NAN), in Lagos, urged the CBN to investigate the allegations against NIRSAL without undermining the various efforts of farmers toward achieving food security and self-sufficiency.
pcm: As Oke dey follow di News Agency of Naija (NAN) for Lagos don urge di CBN make dem investigate di allegations wey dey against NIRSAL witout undermining di various efforts wey farmers get toward achieving food security and self-sufficiency.

eng: He called on the CBN to resolve the issues surrounding the suspension of the NIRSAL loans
pcm: Hin call on top di CBN make dem resolve di issues wey dey surround di suspension of di NIRSAL loans

eng: The AFAN official said many farmers were disappointed by the sudden suspension of the Anchor Borrowers Programme (ABP) and NIRSAL loans, as they provided a lot of support to smallholder farmers.
pcm: Di AFAN official say dem disappointed plenti farmers by di suspension of di Anchor Borrowers Programme (ABP) and NIRSAL loans, as dem dey provide a lot of support to smallholder farmers.

eng: The CBN recently suspended all loans disbursed by NIRSAL, following widespread allegations of corruption by its officials, NAN also reported.
pcm: NAN also reported say di CBN recently suspend all loans wey di NIRSAL disburse following di allegation of corruption by its officials

eng: Whats on your mind
pcm: Wetin dey una mind

eng: The memo said the decision would only be reversed after all outstanding loans disbursed to farmers through NIRSAL were paid.
pcm: Di memo say dem go only reverse di decision afta dem pay all outstanding loan wey farmers neva pay back

eng: According to Oke, â€œwhen we heard about the suspension of NIRSAL loans, we knew immediately that this is not good for the farmers and the sector.
pcm: According to wetin Oke yarn wen we hear about di suspension of di NIRSAL loans, we don know immediately say dis no good for di farmers and di sector.

eng: From what we heard, the suspension is based upon the ABP.
pcm: for wetin we hear, dem base di suspension for di ABP

eng: We want CBN to lay more emphasis on how it will go about it because some of the farmers have done their interview on NIRSAL loans, while others are awaiting disbursement of the funds.
pcm: We want make CBN lay more emphasis on how dem go go about am bikos some of di farmers don go do interview on NIRSAL loans, while odas dey await di disbursement of di funds.

eng: What will be their fate now?
pcm: wetin go be dia fate now?

eng: This is not good and we implore government to look into the issue and address it, he said.
pcm: hin say, e no good and we dey implore make goverment chook mouth for di mata and address am

eng: Oke urged the federal government to intervene, in order not to jeopardise the efforts of farmers that have already invested in their farms, and those already waiting for the loans to enable them to prepare for the planting season.
pcm: Oke don urge di goverment make di federal goverment intervene, in order make e no jeopardise di efforts wey farmers wey don invest for hin farm, and those wey dey wait for di loans wey go make dem plant dis season

eng: â€œSomethimg needs to be done immediately in order not to jeopardise the effort of the farmers that are still ready to go back to the farm.
pcm: Dem need do something immediately make e no go jeopardise di effort of di farmers say dem ready to go back to di farm

eng: Very many farmers, specifically in the South-West, are waiting for the loan and they expect that by now it should have been disbursed.
pcm: Plenti farmers specifically in di South-West dey wait on top di loan and dem dey expect say by now dem suppose disburse am

eng: Very few of our members have been able to access the loan, a very large number have not even gotten access to the interview.
pcm: Very few of awa members don get access to di loan, plenti neva get access to di interview

eng: I have also not done the interview myself.
pcm: me self neva do di interview

eng: I am still waiting to be selected.
pcm: I still dey wait make dem select me

eng: Farmers are not happy about the suspension of the loan,â€ he stressed.
pcm: hin stressed am say, farmers no dey hapi on top di suspension of loan

pcm: Hunger, poverty and di challenge for innovative food storage

eng: If you visit many offices across Nigeria at lunchtime during the months of May, June, July and August, chances are high that you will find a good number of workers munchimg away at mouth
pcm: If una visit plenti offices across di kontri for lunchtime during di months of may, june, july and August, chances dey high say una go find a good number of workers wey dey munch am for mouth.

eng: Yes, with corn in season, one of the most popular delicacies at this time is the combination of roasted corn (popularly code-named as â€œmouth organâ€) and the African pear.
pcm: True as corn don dey season one of di delicacies for dis time na di combination of roasted corn ( wey dem popularly code-name as mouth organ) and di pear for Africa pear.

eng: Coconut is an occasional close substitute for pear and this writer has it on good authority that many people find the coconut and â€œmouth-organâ€ combination, just as delicious too.
pcm: Coconut na ocassional substitute wey dey close to pear dis writer get good authority ova am say plenti pipo dey find di coconut and a mouth-organ combination say e delicious

eng: Outside of those months when both corn and pear are in season, this delicious combination is unavailable.
pcm: Outside dis months wey corn and pear dey season di combination no dey dey available

eng: Interestingly, during those harvest months, enough corn and pear to sustain the country for a substantial period, perhaps even an entire year, may have been harvested.
pcm: During di harvest months enough corn and pear wey go sustain di kontri for a substantial period, perhaps na an entire year, dem go don harvest am

eng: But with inadequate knowledge and utilisation of modern and cost-effective storage and preservation methods, tonnes of maize and pear end up wasted every year.
pcm: But wit inadequate knowledge and how dem go utilize modern and cost-effective storage and preservation methods, tonnes of maize and pear just dey waste Evri year.

eng: The same applies to many other agricultural commodities in Nigeria.
pcm: Di same dey apply to oda agricultural commodities for Naija

eng: At harvest periods, there is often a surplus, but in the absence of proper storage, a huge proportion of these harvests eventually goes to waste.
pcm: For harvest periods, surplus dey often dey, but in di absence of proper storage, a huge proportion of dis harvest dey waste.

eng: These perennial losses pose a huge threat to the economic wellbeing of farmers, the majority of whom operate at the subsistence level.
pcm: Dis perennial issues don pose one huge threat to di economic well-being of farmers, di major wey dey operate for di subsistence level.

eng: The challenge, which this problem of poor storage and preservation of food poses to our country, becomes even more haunting when one considers the difficulties with which we are likely to be confronted in the post-COVID era.
pcm: Di challenge wey be di kwanta of poor storge and preservation of food dey pose to awa kontri, don bekom more haunting wen pesin dey consider di difficulties wey confront us for di post-COVID era

eng: It is, therefore, imperative that beyond improving the volumes of our agricultural output, we look critically at how to empower farmers across the country to better manage their harvests.
pcm: E dey imperative say beyond di volume of awa agricultural output wey dey improve make we look critically at how we go empower farmers across di kontri manage dia harvests beta

eng: This will translate to immense economic value not only to the farmers themselves whose livelihoods will be enhanced, but also to the country as a whole, as more food will become more widely available and for extended periods, for consumption and export.
pcm: Na dis go translate to immense economic value not only to di farmers demselves wey go enhance dia livelihoods, but also to di kontri as a whole, as plenti food go dey available for extended periods , for consumption and export

eng: Instructively, a number of research organisations and universities have over the years introduced different solutions to the problem of post-harvest losses.
pcm: Plenti research organisations and universities don introduce different solutions to di kwanta of post-harvest losses as di years dey pass

eng: The innovations that have been developed, being home-grown, are unique because they reflect the realities of our local environment.
pcm: Di innovations wey dem don develop, being home-grown dey unique bikos dem dey reflect di reality of awa local goverment

eng: Not only are they relatively cheap, as they are also often technically uncomplicated, but farmers can adopt them readily.
pcm: No be say dem dey relatively cheap, as dem dey often dey technically uncomplicated, but farmers fit adopt dem readily

eng: In the area of fish farming for instance, there is an innovation known as the iced-fish box with which harvested fish may be stored in order to remain fresh on transportation to the market from the farm or ahead of processing and storage.
pcm: For di area of fish farming, one innovation dey wey dem dey call am iced-fish box wey dem go use harvest fish go store am so e go remain fresh on transportation to di market from di farm or ahead of processing and storage.

eng: In addition, specialised smoking kilns have been developed to replace the labour-intensive, yet inefficient and unhealthy traditional fish smoking methods.
pcm: Dem don develop special smoking kilns wey go replace di labour-intensive, traditional fish smoking methods wey no dey efficient and e dey unhealthy

eng: Output from these kilns is good enough for export and is several multiples of what is ordinarily obtainable by traditional fish-smoking methods.
pcm: Outputs wey dey commot for dis kilns be good enough for export and e dey several multiples of wetin dem dey ordinarily obtain for traditional fish-smoking methods.

eng: Nigerian researchers have also produced composite packaging material that can be used for packaging such smoked fish or even smoked meat as the case may be, preserving the end-product and boosting its commercial appeal.
pcm: Naija researchers don also produce composite packaging material wey dem fit use package dat kain smoked fish or even smoked meat as di case fit be, preserving di end-product and e dey boost di commercial appeal

eng: Whether it is beans, corn or rice that become discoloured, mouldy, smelly or infested with weevils, grains pose problems of storage for farmers, often leading to considerable financial losses.
pcm: If to say na beans, corn or rice wey don discoloured, mouldy, smelly or e dey infected wit weevils, grains dey pose gbege of storage for farmers and e dey lead to considerable financial losses

eng: In the past, grains exported from Nigeria have also faced rejection because of the unacceptable levels of residual pesticides they contain.
pcm: For di past, grains wey dem dey export from Naija don face rejection bikos of di unacceptable level of residual pesticides wey dem contain

eng: Local researchers have been active in the area of grain preservation, churning out a handful of innovative solutions over the years.
pcm: Local researchers wey dey active for di area of grain preservation, churning out of a handful of innovative solutions ova di years

eng: For instance, there are solar dryers that have been developed for different products.
pcm: For instance, solar dryers wey dem develop for different products dey

eng: Given the abundance of sunshime in our country and the simplicity of construction of these dryers, they are relatively affordable by the average farmer.
pcm: If to say di abundance of sunshine wey dey awa kontri and di simplicity of construction of dis dryers, dem dey available for average farmers

eng: Construction can also be easily replicated in local settings.
pcm: Dem fit replicate construction easily for di local setin

eng: Essentially, these solar dryers work to enhance the efficiency of drying of agricultural produce.
pcm: Dis solar dryers work dey enhance di efficiency of drying of agricultural produce

eng: They do this by concentrating the rays of the sun on a particular surface, enhancing drying efficiency over the traditional method of spreading grains, cassava and plantain peelings and others, indiscriminately under the sun.
pcm: Dem dey do dis as dem dey concentrate di rays of di sun on a particular surface, wey go dey enhance drying efficiency over di traditional method wey dem dey take use spread grains, cassava, plantain peeling and odas indiscriminately under di sun

pcm: local researchers don develop specially constructed steel drums wey wen dem shut am bikom airtight (hermit) and e dey allow make farmers store grains ova several months

eng: There are specialised storage silos as well, which can help store and preserve grains over many months.
pcm: Dem be specialised storage silos wey fit help store and preserve grains over plenti months

eng: There is in fact, a particular twin silo, which can jointly accommodate up to 100 tonnes of grains at a time.
pcm: In fact one twin silo dey, wey fit accommodate 100 tonnes of grains at a time

pcm: Local researchers don also develop bio-pesticide as an alternative to chemical pesticides

eng: Commonly available chemical pesticides though effective against pests are often harmful to man and the environment, too.
pcm: Chemical pesticides wey dey available though effective against pest dey harmful to man and hin environment, too

pcm: Bio-pesticide for di oda hand, dey much safer and dem dey constitute no hazard for environment

pcm: Dem make One of such pesticide (NSPRIDUST) wey be an innovation by di Naija stored product research institute, from diatomaceous earth, wey be a powdery form wey dey occure for rock naturally for Naija

pcm: Bio-pesticides go help make Naija grains potentially dey more acceptable for di export market

pcm: Again, over time Naija researchers don herald different solutions to dis yawa wey dey ground

eng: Local researchers are working fervently on fruit and vegetable conservation using the principle of evaporative cooling

pcm: Incidentally, di use of evaporative cooling for fruit and vegetable preservation no be new thing, as dem don dey practice am for traditional setin for Naija

pcm: Researchers don dey find way wey dem go take use enhance di efficiency of traditional evaporative cooling systems wey dem go use preserve di shelf life of fruits and vegetables ova a duration of time

pcm: Doubt no dey say widespread adoption of dis technologies by farmers across di kontri go help to considerably stem di tide of post-harvest losses for Naija

pcm: Na dis, one suppose repeat go transalate to significant economic value wey no go be for only farmers and di agricultural chain rate wey wide but also for di entire kontri as well

eng: Unlike last year when, by this time, maize was between N8,000 and N9,500, sorghum was N7,000, they are now sold at N14,000 and N13,000 respectively.
pcm: E no be like last year we, by dis time, maize dey around N8,000 and N9,500, sorghum dey N7,000, nah N14,000 and N13,000 dem dey sell dem now.

eng: The recent announcement of border reopening has crashed down the price of paddy rice from N14,000 to N12,000, sorghum from N14,500 to N13,000 and maize from N15,500 to N14,000.
pcm: Dis shout of open border again wey dem shout down spoil di price of paddy rice from N14,000 go N12,000, sorghum from N14,500 go N13,000 and maize from N15,500 go N14,000.

eng: Tarzana added that most merchants withdrew from bulk purchase of the produce after the announcement, expecting that waivers for the importation of food items would follow anytime soon.
pcm: Tarzana add join say many market pipo comot hand to dey buy market bigbig afta dem shout am, get am for mind say di breeze from importation of food go enta anytime.

eng: Our correspondent observed that there are mixed reactions to the land border opening.
pcm: Our news pipo see say di land border wey dem open again get many eyes.

eng: Majority of the farmers and merchants prefer the borders to be closed so that they would continue to exploit the numerous value chains of our local agricultural produce.
pcm: Plenti of di farmer and market pipo want make di border dey lock so dat dem go dey chop beta for di market wey we dey do for awa  house.

eng: Consumers, on the other hand, welcomed the recent development, in anticipation that government would allow importation of rice and other food items.
pcm: Pipo wey dey chop am and some other pipo hapi wit di development and dey expect say goment go allow make dem dey import rice and other food.

eng: But their expectation was shattered by governments reiteration that rice, poultry, cooking oil and other food items remained banned from importation.
pcm: But goment kon fall dia hand as im tok say rice, chicken and turkey, oil for cook and other food still dey under ban to dey import.

eng: Sani Muazu Hunkuyi, an agric expert, enjoined the Federal Government not to bow to pressure and give waivers for food importation.
pcm: Sani Muazu Hunkuyi, wey be one agric expert, beg di goment make dem sumit give di pressure, allow food to dey enter.

eng: Government has invested a lot in the agricultural sector and we should not allow such huge investment to go down the drain by wavering food importation in this country.
pcm: Goment don invest plenti agric sector and make we nor allow dat big investment enta water wit breeze of importation inside dis kontri

eng: It is true that there is palpable fear of food crisis, but we can mitigate that through irrigation farming.
pcm: Na true say fear for food crisis don burst evriwia, but we fit reduce am wit farming wit water.

eng: Besides, food importation will only worsen the already economic recession the country is battling with, Muazu said.
pcm: To dey import food go make dis economic recession wey dey di kontri worst to tackle, na im Muazu tok

eng: He added that farmers would be seriously affected if government reversed its policy on food sufficiency.
pcm: E add join say yawa go gas for farmers dem if goment cancel dia policy ontop to make food plenti.

eng: Why flood-resistant rice is crucial to farmers
pcm: Why rice wey flood nor dey important to farmers dem.

eng: The threat to food security in Nigeria as a result of flood will soon be an issue of the past following the release of the FARO 66, a variety of rice that is resistant to flood.
pcm: Di threat ontop food for Nigeria bikos of flood go soon be tin of di past as dem release FARO 66, one type of rice wey flood no fit kari.

eng: FARO 66, recently released to rice farming communities by the National Cereal Research Institute (NCRI), is a variety that has characteristics and traits that are different from what local farmers are used to.
pcm: FARO 66, wey National Cereal Research Institute (NCRI) release give farming pipo dem be type wey get some tins wey dey different from wetin farmers for here sabi before.

eng: This variety is taller than other ones known to the farmers.
pcm: Dis type tall pass other one wey farmers sabi.

eng: With its height, coupled with effective ecological farming management, it is capable of withstanding the stress of flood to a larger extent.
pcm: Witi how im tall and some betabeta farming mata, e get power to survive palava of flood wella.

eng: Acceptability of new varieties among farmers has always been a huge challenge, and the introduction of the FARO 66 is no exception.
pcm: To kolet new tins among farmers dem dey always be big problem and as dem introduce FARO66 no dey different.

eng: However, when fully embraced by the farmers, the threat to food security in terms of rice production would be reduced.
pcm: But if dem farmer kolet am finish, di threat ontop food about rice mata go reduce.

eng: During this years Field Day, organised by the NCRI station in Birnin Kebbi, the capital of Kebbi State, farmers and other stakeholders were introduced to the new variety after a field trip to the institutes demonstration farm in the metropolis.
pcm: For dis year field trip wey NCRI station for Birnin Kebbi, capital of Kebbi State organise, farmers and dem oga dey introduced to dis new type afta a field trip wey dem do for di institute demonstration farm for di city.

eng: At the demonstration farm, farmers were exposed to FARO 66, which withstood the stress of the recent flood, side by side with the farm of other rice varieties that were washed away by the same flood.
pcm: For di demonstration farm, farmers dey expose to FARO66, wey stand gidigba wit flood inside farm and other rice follow di same flood waka.

eng: The two farms, which are situated side by side, revealed the flood disaster tolerant capability of the FARO 66 variety, as despite all stress, it grew to maturity.
pcm: Di two farm wey dey near each oda show di power to tanda wit flood wey FARO66 type get, wit all di wahala, e grow and strong.

eng: On the farm of the other rice variety, only the remnants of the rice plant could be seen.
pcm: One di farm of other type of rice, na di remaining of rice wey die remain dem see.

eng: Speaking to our correspondent, the head of the NCRI station in Birnin Kebbi, Andrew Shema, said the FARO 66 variety could best resist flood if planted early.
pcm: As im follow awa  news pipo talk, di oga for di NCRI station for Birnin Kebbi, Andrew Shema, say di FARO 66 go tanda wit flood if dem quick plant am.

eng: He added that with its hard stem and height, if planted early, the variety could grow to a size that when flood sets in, the plant could resist the condition.
pcm: E add join say, im stem wey hard and as e tall, if dem part am quick, di type go don grow reach size wey be say if flood com, di plant nor go gree for am.

eng: He said FARO 66 was released two years ago, but acceptability, as is the case with any new variety, must be gradual, noting that when it becomes widely accepted among farmers, flooding would not be a threat to rice farming any more.
pcm: He tok say FARO66 dey release two years ago but to kolet, as for di case wit any new tin, must be small small, tok say, if farmers dem don accept am wella, flood nor go be threat to rice farming again.

eng: According to him, to sensitise the farmers as research on the improved variety progressed, they were carried along to appreciate the processes and results recorded.
pcm: As im take tok, to open di eyes of farmers dem as research ontop dis new type dey go front, dem carry dem join bodi to see how e dey go and to record result.

eng: He added that the scientists on the research work were optimistic that if farmers were allowed to appreciate the ability of the plant to withstand flood, acceptance of the new variety among them would not only be fast but also effective.
pcm: E add join say science pipo wey dey ontop di research get sense say if dem allow farmers dem to see how dis plant fit take tanda wit flood, no be only to accept am go dey fast, to dey use sef go dey.

eng: Shema, who said lack of sufficient funding had been their major constraint in the research work, called on all stakeholders to invest in the initiative for a better tomorrow as research is not only limited to the development of improved varieties but also created jobs, as well as developed the economy of a nation.
pcm: Shema wey tok say as dem nor give dem plenti moni be dia major wahala for di research work, e call stakeholders dem to kom invest ontop dia idea for beta tomorrow as di research no go only develop di new type but e go still create job, and still develop economy for di kontri.

eng: He explained that public lectures were also conducted as part of the day one Field Day activities, saying the essence of introducing public lectures in this years activities is to bring to the notice of stakeholders that research only comes to fruition with sufficient funding
pcm: E explain say dem still do public lecture wey dey among program wey dem do for di first day of di field day wey dem do, e say why dem introduce public lecture join dis year program na to show stakeholders dem say nah if moni wey reach dey n aim research fit get head.

eng: He appealed to well-meaning Nigerians and organisations to inject enough into research.
pcm: E beg pipo wey get mouth for Nigeria and organization to kom drop put for research.

eng: The day two was on exhibition and application of technology in farming.
pcm: Di two days nah ontop to show how technology take enter farming

eng: When we said flood-tolerant, we are not saying it will not be affected by flood completely.
pcm: Wen we tok say he dey tanda wit flood, we no tok say flood no go affect am patapata.

eng: What we are saying is that with its characteristics and desirable trends, it would withstand flood stress to some extent.
pcm: Wetin we dey tok be say wit all di tin wey e get for bodi, e go tanda wit flood wahala reach one side.

eng: FARO 66 is tolerant to flood because it is taller than FARO 44 and FARO 52.
pcm: FARO 66 go tanda wit flood wahala bikos e tall pass FARO 44 and FARO 52.

eng: Its stem is also harder than the other varieties.
pcm: Im stem still hard pass other one.

eng: Ecological management in term of timing for planting is key in resisting flood.
pcm: To manage sky as in to plant quickquick na im be di key to tanda wit flood.

eng: Early planting saves a larger proportion of the crop when flood sets in.
pcm: To plant quickquick dey save bigbig if flood come.

eng: The moment rain starts, farmers dont need to waste time.
pcm: If rain don starts, farmers dem no need to dey waste time.

eng: They should immediately mobilise for planting.
pcm: Dis one go make crop dey strong and hold leg for ground wella before flood go com, as im tok.

eng: This enables the crop to have good vigour and be established well before the flood comes, he stated.
pcm: Dem suppose start to dey plant sharpsharp.

eng: Chelsea and Leicester charged over players clash
pcm: Dem fine Chelsea and Leichester as dem players fight

eng: Chelsea and Leicester City have been charged by the Football Association (FA) following a stoppage-time clash between players and staff from both teams during their Premier League game on Tuesday, the governing body said on Thursday.
pcm: Football Association (FA)  don fine Chelsea and Leichester as dem players and staff bin fight for stoppage time for dia Premier League game on Tuesday, na so di governing body tok.

eng: Three days after Leicester beat Chelsea in the FA Cup final at Wembley, the sides met again at Stamford Bridge in a match key to their hopes of finishing in the top four.
pcm: Three days after Leichester beat Chelsea for FA Cup final for Wembly, di two side meet again for Stamford Bridge for one march wey be card to dia hope to finish for top four.

eng: It is alleged that both clubs failed to ensure their players and /or club officials conducted themselves in an orderly fashion and/or refrained from provocative behaviour during the 93rd minute, the FA said.
pcm: Dem tok say di two team nor get mouth tok to dia players and/abi club officials make dem do dem sef well and/abi comot hand for jagajaga behavior for di 93 minute, na so FA tok.

eng: Para-athletics team charged to be worthy ambassadors
pcm: Dem tell Para-athletics team to be worthy ambassadors.

eng: The Minister of Sports, Sunday Dare has charged the Nigerian Para-athletics team to Nowil, Switzerland to be worthy ambassadors of the country as they seek to qualify for the Tokyo 2020 Paralympics.
pcm: Di minister for Sports, Sunday Dare don tell Para-athletics team wey dey go Nowil, Switzerland to be worthy ambassadors of di kontri as dem dey tri to qualify enta Tokyo 2020 Paralympics.

eng: The Minister gave the charge on Sunday when he bade farewell to the team for the Qualifiers at the Nnamdi Azikiwe International Airport, Abuja.
pcm: Di minister tok am on Sunday wen e dey do save journey to dis team for di qualify, inside Nnamdi Azikiwe International Airport, Abuja.

eng: He said, Nigeria is solidly behind your bid for qualification for the Para- Athletics event in Notwil, Switzerland.
pcm: E say, Nigeria dey your back well well to qualify enta di Para- Athletics event for Notwil, Switzerland.

eng: In addition, he commended the special athletes as he said There is no doubt about your abilities which you have always proved over the years.
pcm: To add, e praise dis special athletes as E tok say, Una ability no get double mind, wey una don dey show tey tey

eng: You must be worthy ambassadors of our dear country by conducting yourselves very well to attain the best standards for Qualifiers.
pcm: Make una be worthy ambassadors of awa  kontri ontop to do una self well to reach di best for qualifier.

eng: Dont be distracted.
pcm: No dey disturb.

eng: Nigerians are solidly behind you.
pcm: Nigeria  dey your back gidigba

eng: You have always made us proud and we are confident that you will not disappoint this time by reaching the qualification threshold.
pcm: U don dey do to make us do yanga and we get mind say u no go fall awa  hand dis time as u go qualify.

eng: We have done our bit, now the ball is in your court to ensure that Nigerias flag flies high.
pcm: We don try small, na your hand e dey naw to see say Nigeria flag fly for up

eng: 10 Athletes will be seeking to qualify in the para-athletics event taking place from 11th -17th
pcm: 10 athletes go dey look to qualify for di para-athletics wey go hapun from 11th reach 17th.

eng: May 2021 at Notwil in Switzerland.
pcm: May 2021 for Notwil wey dey Switzerland.

eng: Sasakawa moves to cushion COVID-19 effects on farmers
pcm: Sasakawa dey do make Corona no get power ontop farmers dem

eng: Sasakawa Global 2000 (SG 2000) said it had initiated a process through which farmers are linked with commodity buyers as a way of cushioning the effect of the COVID-19 pandemic.
pcm: Sasakawa Global 2000( SG) don tok say im don find way wey farmers dem fit take colabo wit buyers to see say di wahala wey Covid-19 kos no get power ontop farmers dem

eng: This was disclosed by the organisations research and training officer, Mr Benjamin Shamaki, during a media field tour they organised.
pcm: Na dis tin di research and training officer for di organization, Mr Benjamin Shamaki yarn inside one media field tour wey dem do.

eng: According to him, Sasakawa has trained farmers in Kano and Gombe states on effective utilisation of the aggregator facilities, as well as linking farmer associations with prospective buyers to ensure value for their produce, as well as ensure quality of what the farmers are selling during the pandemic period.
pcm: As im take talk, Sasakawa don train farmers dem for Kano and Gombe state to dey use di aggregator facilities and to colabo di association of  dem farmer join wit buyer wey go give beta value, give dem wey dem dey plant and to see say wetin dem dey sell Corona time beta wella.

eng: We have trained women farmer groups, not only in modern farming techniques but also on value addition to their produce.
pcm: We don train women wey bi farmer, no be for only new-school farming, but also to take give dia crop beta value.

eng: We have encouraged them in the formation of associations, through which we successfully linked them up with buyers of their produce.
pcm: We don encourage dem ontop how dem go dey form association, ontop wetin we don successfully colabo dem wit buyers.

eng: They also produced along the value chain of a particular crop, he revealed.
pcm: E tok say dem dey don still produce along di value chain of one crop

eng: Similarly, the chairman of Bagwai Farmers Association, Malam Danladi Yahaya Bagwai, said farmers in the area were ready to make good use of the aggregator facilities provided for their agricultural sustainability by SG 2000, adding that they would ensure proper utilisation of the aggregator facilities.
pcm: As e be, di chairman for dem Bagwai farmer association, Malam Danladi Yahaya Bagwa tok say dem farmer for dat area dey ready to use di aggregator facilities wey SG 2000 give dem for dia agricultural stability wella, e add join say dem go see say dem use di facilities wella.

eng: According to him the COVID-19 pandemic has indeed negatively affected farming activities in various states of the federation, including Kano.
pcm: As im take tok say Covid-19 don kos bad-market ontop farming for different different state for di kontri, for Kano too.

eng: He added that without Sasakawas intervention, farmers in the area would have been out of business for long.
pcm: E add join say if no be for Sasakawa put hand, dem farmer for di area go don forget dia work tey tey.

eng: He further revealed that during the pandemic, farmers in the area were assisted with improved seed varieties, fertilizer and pesticides, which he said had helped them tremendously during the period.
pcm: E still tok say for di pandemic time, dem give farmer for di area different different beta seed, fertilizer and otapiapia for plant wey im tok say e help dem wella for di time.

eng: The chairman also stated that the introduction of an aggregator facility, which serves as service providers to eliminate some of the marketing effort issues in the area, had helped farmers to store and access their produce with ease, as well as sell with high market value.
pcm: Di chairman still tok say as dem carry aggregator facility cum, wey stand gidigba as dia help to comot some marketing palava for di area, don help farmers dem keep dia produce witout gbege and to sell for big price for market.

eng: He said the aggregator facility had enabled farmers to collectively put their produce together in one centre and Sasakawa would connect them with mega companies that would buy the produce with value and in good market value.
pcm: E tok say di aggregator facility don help farmers dem gather wetin dem dey produce for one place and Sasakawa go help colabo dem wit big big companies wey go buy am for plenty money.

eng: It has been on record that farmers in this area have been producing, but due to lack of proper marketing strategies, they usually ended up getting virtually small value of no value for their produce.
pcm: E don dey on record say farmers for dis area as dem no get marketing skil, e dey make dem get small value on top dia produce.

eng: Sasakawa has established for us an effective aggregator centre, and it has equally provided us with the knowledge on how to effectively utilise this facility to increase our products market value.
pcm: Sasakawa don establish one aggregator centre for us,  wey dey give us wisdom wey we go take use dis facilities take make pipo buy awa  market wella.

eng: No doubt our initial inability to put into practice a proper marketing strategy that will ensure effective gain in sale of our produce in the open market has negatively affected our productivity, he said.
pcm: E dey sure say as we no get marketing skil before wey go help us make moni wella for wetin we dey farm  don cause plenty kasala for us, na so im tok.

eng: Similarly, according to the Sarkin Noma of Bagwai, Alhaji Bello Gurdo, in the irrigation site of Kano State, COVID-19 and its aftermath has made things harder for farmers.
pcm: As e be, Sakin Noma of Bagwai, Alhaji Bello Gurdo don tok say for di irrigation site for Kano State, Corona burst kasala for farmers dem.
