eng: Museveni, who has led the East African country with a population of nearly 46 million for 34 years, had not made any statement by noon.
pcm: Museveni, wey don lead di kontri for inside East Africa for wey get 46 million pipo for 34 years neva tok anytin as at noon.

eng: Internet blackout
pcm: Internet blackout

eng: On Wednesday, the government ordered an internet blackout until further notice, a day after banning all social media and messaging apps.
pcm: For Wednesday, di goment order say make dem block internet till further notice, a day afta dem ban all social media and messagin app dem.

eng: Wine and his supporters used Facebook to relay live coverage of his campaigns and news conference after he said many media outlets had declined to host him.
pcm: Wine and im supporters use Facebook to take show live coverage of im campaigns and news conference afta he tok say many media outlets no gree to host am.

eng: The election campaign was marred by deadly crackdowns by security forces on opposition candidates and their supporters.
pcm: Dem spoil di election campaign wit deadly crackdown on top opposition candidates and dem supporters dem.

eng: Uganda's normally bustling capital Kampala was quiet on Friday, a public holiday after Thursday's poll, with shops mostly closed.
pcm: Di capital for Uganda wey be Kampala wey dey buble normally dey quiet for Friday, wey be public holiday afta di vote for Thursday, as dem close most shop dem.

eng: Soldiers patrolled on foot in the rain in a suburb visited by Reuters.
pcm: Soldiers dem patroll wit  leg  for  inside rain in a suburb wey Reuters visit.

eng: Commission head, Simon Byabakama, assured the nation on live TV on Thursday evening after polls closed that results were arriving at the national tally centre despite the nationwide internet blackout.
pcm: Commission head, Simon Byabakama, assure di nation on top live TV for Thursday evening afta polls don close say result don dey  enter for di national tally centre despite di nationwide internet blackout.

eng: We are not using local internet to transmit our results, we are using our own system, he said, without giving details of that system.
pcm: We no dey use local internet to take transmit result, we dey use awa own system,  as e tok, without say we give details of di system.

eng: Don't worry, results will come, Byabakama added
pcm: No wori, result go come, Byabakama tok join

eng: New wave of pandemic hits more of Japan's prefectures
pcm: New wave of pandemic don hit more for inside Japan prefecture dem.

eng: Japan is set to expand the current state of emergency to three more prefectures, the government said on Friday,
pcm: Japan donreadi to expand di present state of emergency to cover three more prefectur dem, as di goment tok for Friday.

eng: This is as the coronavirus infections continued to hit wider regions of the country ahead of this summer's Tokyo Olympics.
pcm: Dis dey follow as di infection of coronavirus don dey wide for inside di kontri ahead of Tokyo Olympics for summer.

eng: The prefectures of Hokkaido, Okayama and Hiroshima were likely to be under the measure from Sunday to the end of May, Economic Revitalisation Minister, Yasutoshi Nishimura, told reporters.
pcm: Di prefecture for inside Hokkaido, Okayama and Hiroshima dey likely to get di measure from Sunday go enter end of May, as Economic Revitalisation Minister, Yasutoshi Nishimura, tell news pipo.

eng: A panel of experts endorsed the proposal, said Nishimura, who was in charge of the government's coronavirus response.
pcm: One panel of experts endorse di proposal, as Nishimura wey dey in charge of di coronavirus response by di goment take tok.

eng: The northern island of Hokkaido reported a record 712 new infections on Thursday while the western prefecture of Hiroshima also saw a record 219 new cases on Wednesday.
pcm: Di northern island of Hokkaido report recordof  712 new infection on  Thursday as di western prefecture of Hiroshima also see record of 219 new cases for Wednesday.

eng: Surging infections prompted Hiroshima and Okayama to cancel next week's torch relay on their public roads.
pcm: As di infection dey grow make Hiroshima and Okayama cancel torch relay wey suppose apun for nest week for dem public road dem.

eng: International Olympic Committee President, Thomas Bach, was scheduled to participate in a torch relay event in Hiroshima on May 17.
pcm: International Olympic Committee President, Thomas Bach, suppose to participate for di torch relay event in Hiroshima on May 17.

eng: However, Bach's travel to Japan ahead of the Games has been postponed, local organisers said.
pcm: However, local organizer dem tok say dem don postpone Bach travel to Japan before di games.

eng: The postponement is coming as the government extended the state of emergency in Tokyo and three other prefectures until the end of May and added two more regions Aichi, Fukuoka to the measure.
pcm: Di postpone na as di goment take extend di state of emergency inside Tokyo plus three oda prefectures dem until until di end of May, and dem add two more regions wey be Aichi, Fukuoka for inside di measure.

eng: The government declared the state of emergency in the four prefectures in late April, requesting bars and restaurants refrain from serving alcohol and offering a karaoke service.
pcm: Di goment declare di state of emergency for di four prefectures dem for inside April, dem request make bar and restaurant stop to dey serve alchohol and make dem no dye offer karaoke service again.

eng: Experts warned of the rapid spread of more contagious variants, especially as the roll-out of coronavirus vaccines has been extremely slow in Japan since its launch in mid-February.
pcm: Experts dem don give warning of say variants wey dey more contagious fit spread quick, especially as dem dey take roll coronavirus vaccine dey very slowsince dem launch am for mid-February.

eng: Only one per cent of Japan's
pcm: Only one per cent of Japan's

eng: 125 million populations have been fully vaccinated.
pcm: Dem don vaccinate 125 million of pipo fully.

eng: Jigawa's mechanised farm to benefit local farmers
pcm: Farmers go benefit from mechanised farm for inside Jigawa

eng: The Malam Alu Agro Allied Company, a farm sitting on a 100-hectare land in Faru village, along Maiduguri road, Birnin Kudu Local Government Area of Jigawa State, is changing the perception of mechanised farming in Nigeria, Mansur Dau Aliyu, the company's Group General Manager (GGM) said.
pcm: Di Malam Alu Agro Allied Company, wey be farm wey dey on top 100-hectare of land inside Faru village, along Maiduguri road, Birnin Kudu Local Government Area of Jigawa State, don dey change di prception inside mechanised farming for Nigeria, di GM for di Mansur Dau Aliyu tok.

eng: The establishment of the farm almost five years ago, it was gathered, was a direct response to the call by the President Muhammadu Buhari-led administration for Nigerians to return to agriculture as the mainstay of the nation's economy, rather than relying solely on oil as the only source of revenue for the country.
pcm: As dem take establish di farm almost five years ago, as we gather, na direct response to di call by di administration of President Muhammadu Buhari tok say make Nigeria return to agriculture as di mainstay of di economy for inside di nation, pass as dem dey rely on top iol as di source of revenue for inside di kontri.

eng: Each cattle has a number tag attached to its ear
pcm: Each cattle get nomba tag wey dem attach to am for ear.

eng: The company's founder, Farouk Adamu Aliyu, a former member of the House of Representatives keyed into this, the GGM added.
pcm: Founder for di company, Farouk Adamu Aliyu, wey be former member for inside House of Representative key into am, di GGM add.

eng: We do greenhouse farming.
pcm: We dey do greenhouse farming.

eng: We have a 10,000 square-metre fully automated soilless greenhouse, where we produce tomatoes.
pcm: We get 10,000 square-metre wey be fully automated soilles greenhouse, wia we dey produce tomato.

eng: We also have two 250 square-metre greenhouses where we produce other greenhouse vegetables, and another 500 square-metre greenhouse, which is being used as a nursery.
pcm: We also get two 250 square-metre greenhouses wia we dey produce oda greenhouse vegetable dem, plus anoda 500 square-metre greenhouse, wey we dey use as nursery.

eng: These greenhouses are all foreign-oriented, which have been installed to produce a variety of vegetables.
pcm: Dis greenhouse dem na all dey foreign-oriented, wey we don install to take produce variety of vegetable.

eng: We produce only tomatoes from the 10,000 square automated soilless greenhouses; and we produce an average of 10 to 11 tons of tomatoes every week.
pcm: Na only tomato wey dey produce for di 10,000 square automated soilless greenhousedem; and we produce an average of 10 to 11 ton of tomato evri week.

eng: We also have another 10,000 square-metre locally fabricated greenhouse.
pcm: We be get anoda 10,000 square-metre locally fabricated greenhouse.

eng: We also have a livestock section, where we have about 300 herds of cattle, some camels, goats and sheep, he said.
pcm: We also get livestock section, wia we get over 300 herds of cattle, some camel, goat and sheep, as e take tok am.

eng: Daily Trust gathered that the farm also has a fishery unit, with about 50,000 fishes inside the pond.
pcm: Daily Trust hear say di farm also get fishery unit, with about 50,000 fish inside di pond.

eng: Similarly, a forty-ton per hour fertilizer blending plant installed earlier in the year, it was gathered, now produces close to 300 loads of NPK fertilizer under the Presidential Fertilizer Initiative.
pcm: Similarly, one forty-ton per hour fertilizer blending plant wey dem install for early part of di year, as we take hear, don dey produce reach 300 loads of NPK fertilizer under di Presidential Fertilizer Initiative.

eng: We have also imported equipment for the installation of 120,000 capacity poultry system.
pcm: We don import equipment wey fit install 120,000 capacity for poultry system.

eng: We hope to be producing between 3,000-4,000 crates of eggs daily, Mansur said.
pcm: We hope say we go dey produce reach between 3,000-4,000 crates of egg for inside one day, as Mansur take tok.

eng: The farm, he said, also has a diary production plant, which is for the production of about 2,000 litres of milk a day, adding that there are also about 150-200 hectares of land elsewhere meant for open field farming for real cultivation of rice and other crops.
pcm: He tok say di farm, also get plant wia dem dey do diary, wey dey produce 2,000 litres of milk inside one day, he add say dem also get about 150-200 hectres of land elsewia wey dem leave for open field farming plus cultivation of rice and oda crops dem.

eng: Mansur disclosed that the major clientele for the tomato are premium customers, notably big hotels in Abuja, Lagos, and some other locations.
pcm: Masur tok say major pipo wey dey buy di tomato na premium customers, notably, big big hotel for inside Abuja and Lagos, plus some oda location.

eng: He confirmed, however, that the main market for the products was mainly in the eastern part of the country, such as Enugu, Onitsha, Owerri.
pcm: He confirm, however, say di main market for di product na mainly inside eastern part of di kontri like Enugu, Onitsha, Owerri.

eng: He admitted, however, that besides the few customers they have in Kano, their tomato products are rarely seen in the local markets for some reason.
pcm: However, he admit say apart from di small customers dem wey dem get for Kano, dem no too dey see dem tomato product for local market fpr some kind reason.

eng: First is the fact that the tomato produced from the farm is of special species and the second reason is the fact that Jigawa is a major tomato-producing area.
pcm: First na di fact say di tomato wey dem produce form dem farm na special specie and di second reason be di fact say Jigawa na major area wey dem for dey produce tomato.

eng: You know that tomato is a common product around here, so our price is a little higher than what is obtained normally in the open market.
pcm: You know say tomato na common product for here, so ouw price high small pass wetin dey open market.

eng: So, essentially, people don't actually look at us, they feel apprehensive of what we have because they believe they are expensive.
pcm: So, essentially, pipo no actually dye look awa side, dem dey fell apprehensive wit wetin we get bikos dem believe say e dey cost.

eng: And when you have a product that is commonly available, people will surely go for the cheaper brand.
pcm: And when you get product wey dey available for evriwia, e sure say pipo go buy di one wey cheap pass.

eng: A farm hand feeds the fishes
pcm: Na one farm hand dey feed di fish dem.

eng: Asked of the average lifespan of their tomato products, he said, If you give the tomato all it requires, I mean nutritional supplements you feed it with while it is growing, if you give it all those things, this tomato could last up to three weeks post-harvest.
pcm: As dem ask about di average lifespan of dem tomato product, he tok say, if you give di tomato evritin wey e take, i mean say nutrional supplement wey you take feed am as e dey grow, if you give am all of dis things dem, di tomato fit last reach three weeks afta harvest.

eng: But even without that, it lasts for a minimum of a week, not under any refrigeration, but surely not under intense pressure and heat.
pcm: But even without am, e go last for minimum of one week, no be for refrigeration, and no be for inside presure and plenty heat.

eng: You can keep it on the table where you have good ventilation.
pcm: You fit put am on top table wia better ventilation dey.

eng: It can last an average of 10 days, but with everything provided as required (all nutrients) it could last up to one month.
pcm: E fit last for average of 10 days, but if dem provide evritin as e take require (evri nutrient) e fit last reach one month.

eng: This we have experimented, but then, you don't get it as you always want it.
pcm: We don experiment am, but then, e no dey apun as you dey always want.

eng: The farm is also a source of employment for as many as 200 people in the village where it is located.
pcm: Di farm na source of employment for pipo wey reach 200 inside di village wia dem locate am.

eng: He also said the company got some people to train the youth in the area on information technology skills.
pcm: He also tok say di company get some pipo to kom train di youth for di araea on information technology skil dem.

eng: He further said most of the equipment used on the farm were imported from Turkey, except the fertilizer-blending machine, which was imported from China.
pcm: He tok further say most of di equipment wey dem use for di farm na from Turkey, except di fertilizer-blending machine, wey dem import from China.

eng: Even the farming method is modeled after the Turkish style of operation because we have a Turkish partner that is helping in maintaining the standards, he said, but quickly added that the company was conscious of the need to have Nigerians run the technical aspect of its operations.
pcm: He tok say even di farming method na like as e be for Turkey, bikos dem get Turkish partner wey dey help dem to maintain di standard, but quickly he add say di company dey conscious to allow Nigeria pipo to dey run di tachnical aspect of im operation.

eng: Reflecting on the effect of COVID-19 on the operations of the company, Mansur said, Malam Alu, just like other corporate entities in the country, suffered from the devastating effects of the virus.
pcm: As e dey reflect on top di effect of COVID-19 on top di operation of di company, Mansur tok say, Malam Alu, as oda corporate entities for di kontri, suffer from devastating effect of di virus.

eng: For Mansur, youths in Nigeria have no excuse to remain unemployed with the opportunity provided by agriculture, noting that those hoping to secure a white-collar job should adjust to the reality and go back to agriculture.
pcm: For Mansur, youth for Nigeria no get excuse to remain unemployed with di kind opportunity wey agriculture dey provide, e note say di pipo wey dey lokk for white-collar job make dem adjust to di reality and go back to agriculture.

eng: He believes Nigeria is now doing what it ought to have done a long time ago, noting that if the country had taken this step, the current economic crisis would have been averted.
pcm: He believe say Nigeria don dey do wetin im suppose to done do long time before, e note say if di kontri don take dis step, dem for don corner di present economic wahala.

eng: 2023: Lawmaker seeks better deal for Southern Kaduna
pcm: 2023: Lawmaker to seek better deal for Southern Kaduna

eng: The member representing Jaba Constituency in the Kaduna State House of Assembly, Samson Monday Dikko, has called on people of goodwill to come together and map out strategies that would salvage the Southern Kaduna Senatorial District and its people in 2023.
pcm: Di member wey dey represent Jaba Constituency for di State House of Assembly for inside Kaduna, wey be Samson Monday Dikko, he call on better pipo to kom togeda and map out strategies wey go salvage Southern Kaduna Senatorial District and dem pipo for 2023.

eng: Speaking after a meeting with stakeholders in Kagoro, Kaura Local Government Area of Kaduna State at the weekend, Dikko, who is aspiring to be a senator on the platform of the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP), said Southern Kaduna people have been abandoned by those who ought to take care of them.
pcm: As e tok afta one meeting wit stakeholders for Kagoro, Kaura Local Government Area for Kaduna State for di weekend, Dikko, wey dey aspire to be senator for inside di Peoples Democratic party (PDP), tok say di pipo wey suppose care for Southern Kaduna pipo don abandon dem.

eng: This is the time for the entire Southern Kaduna people to get it right.
pcm: Na di time for di entire Southern Kaduna pipo to get am right.

eng: We need to transform our region and improve security, education, health, agriculture, economy, employment and empowerment for the teeming youths in conjunction with reputable non-governmental organizations, he added.
pcm: We need to transform awa region and improve security, education, health, agriculture, economy, employment and empowerment for di teeming youth and we go do am wit non-governmnetal organization wey get name, as e take add.

eng: The Director-General of the Dikko Campaign Organisation, Timothy Chindo Kwassam, said the destiny of the people of Kaduna South Senatorial District would be in their own hands if Dikko represents them at the Senate in 2023.
pcm: Di Director-General of di Campaign Organisation for Dikko, wey be Timothy Chindo Kwassam, tok say di destiny of di pipo of Kaduna South Senatorial District go deu dem own hand if Dikko represent dem for inside senate for 2023.

eng: For everything under the sun, there is a season.
pcm: For evrithing wey dey under di sun, e get reason.

eng: So, the coming of Dikko at this critical period of time is not a mere coincidence, but a divine plan by God to liberate the region from all that has hindered it from growing and competing with other regions, Kwassam said.
pcm: So as Dikko dey kom for dis critical period of time no be ordinary coincidence, but na divine play from God to take liberate di region from evrithing wey dey hinder am from growing and to compete with oda region dem, na so Kwassam tok.

eng: 3 Africans, no Nigerian as City, Chelsea contest UEFA Champions League finals
pcm: 3 Africa pesin, no Nigeria pesin dey among, as City, Chelsea dey contest UEFA Champions League final

eng: Without doubt, enthusiastic football fans in Nigeria are eagerly awaiting tonights finals of the 2020/2021 UEFA Champions League finals to be contested between two English clubs, Manchester City and Chelsea at the Estadio do Dragao, Porto in Portugal.
pcm: No doubt say football fans dem for inside Nigeria dey wait eagerly for di 2020/2021 UEFA Champions League finals wey go apun tonight wey two English clubs dem Manchester City and Chelsea go contest for inside di Estadio do Dragao, Porto in Portugal.

eng: In view of the fact that the UEFA Champions League is one of the world's biggest football competitions only next to the FIFA World Cup and the Olympics football event, there is increasing level of expectations as the giants of the English Premier League get set to tussle for the prestigious diadem.
pcm: With view of di fact say UEFA Champions League na one of di biggest football competition only next to FIFA World Cup and di Olympic football event, level of expectation don dey increase as giant for inside English Premier League don dey set to fight for di di prestigious diadem.

eng: While Manchester City are yet to win the Champions League title, Chelsea won their first and only title so far in 2012.
pcm: As Manchestre City neva win Champions league title before, chelsea win dem first and only title for 2012.

eng: Therefore, even as football pundits have tipped City who have just won their seventh Premiership title to win tonight, Chelsea will be coming into the contest with better credentials.
pcm: Therefore, even as football pundits dem don tip City wey just win premiership number seven to win dis night, Chelsea go enter into di contest wit betta credentials.

eng: They are former champions.
pcm: Dem be former chsmpion.

eng: However, while Thomas Tuchel who leads the Chelsea technical crew is yet to taste Champions League victory, his opponent in the Manchester City dugout, Pep Guardiola is a two time winner.
pcm: However, as Thomas Tuchel wey dey lead technical crew for inside Chelsea neva win Champions league, im opponent for inside Manchester City dugout, Pep Guardiola don win am two times.

eng: He won it in 2009 and 2010 with Barcelona.
pcm: He win am with Barcelona for 2009 and for 2010.

eng: Therefore, there is so much to expect from the actors who will be out there on the field of Estadio
pcm: Therefore, plenty dey to expect from di actors dem wey go komot enter di field for Estadio.

eng: do Dragao in Porto and the men in charge of the technical areas.
pcm: do Dragao for Porto and di men dem wey go take charge of di technical area.

eng: Interestingly, even as both contestants parade only three African players in Riyad Mahrez (Algeria, Manchester City), Hakim Ziyech (Morococo, Chelsea) and Edourad Menday (
pcm: Interestingly, even as both contestants get only three African players in Riyad Mahrez (Algeria, Manchester City), Hakim Ziyech (Morococo, Chelsea) and Edourad Menday (

eng: Senegal, Chelsea) Africans interest in the finals has dropped.
pcm: Senegal, Chelsea) di interest of Africa for di final don drop.

eng: Here in Nigerian where Chelsea and Manchester City enjoy a large following from passionate football fans, expectations have reached feverish point, leading to interesting re-alignments.
pcm: For Nigeria here, wia Chelsea and Manchester City dey enjoy plenty followers dem from passionate football fans dem, expection don dey cause fever, and e don lead to interestin realignment.

eng: Fans of those European clubs that were eliminated from the Champions League at different stages have re-aligned themselves with either Chelsea or Manchester City based on divergent interests.
pcm: Fans of di oda clubus wey dem don komot for oda stages of di Champions League do re-align demselve with either Chelsea or Manchester City as dem interest take dey diverse reach.

eng: Consequently, the finals is one of the most discussed topics in sporting circles in Nigeria at the moment as fans of the Premiership clubs continue to predict what would be the final result.
pcm: Di consequence be say di final na one of di topic wey dem dey tok pass for inside sports at di moment and fans of di premiereship club don kontinu to dey predict as di finalresult fit be.

eng: However, while almost everyone is waiting to savour the football artistry that is possibly going to be on display, some pundits are worried by the increasing decline in the number of African players in the finals of one of the biggest football competitions on earth.
pcm: However, as be like say almost evribodi don dey wait to savour the football artistry wey dem fit display, some pundits dem dey as nomba of African players for di final of di biggest football competition for earth don dey reduce.

eng: Going by the history of the UEFA Champions League, only 24 African footballers have contested and won the trophy with their European clubs.
pcm: If we follow history for inside UEFA Champions League, na only 24 African footballer dem don contest and win di trophy with dem European clubs.

eng: Sadly African football  legends like Liberia's George Weah who was voted World Footballer of the year in 1995,
pcm: E sad say African football  legends like Liberia's George Weah wey dem vote as World Footballer of di year for 1995,

eng: Nigeria's Rashidi Yekini, Egypt's Mohamed Aboutrika, Roger Mila of Cameroon, Jay-Jay Okocha, Sunday Oliseh, Taribo West and Victor Ikpeba of Nigeria, Rigobert Song of Cameroon and Hassam Hassan of Egypt failed to win the Champions League despite their football prowess.
pcm: Rashidi Yekini of Nigeria, Mohamed Aboutrika of Egypt, Roger Mila of Cameroon, Jay-Jay Okocha, Sunday Oliseh, Taribo West and Victor Ikpeba of Nigeria, Rigobert Song of Cameroon and Hassam Hassan of Egypt no win Champions League as dem sabi ball reach.

eng: Although Mo Salah (Egypt), Sadio Mane (Senegal), Joel Matip (Cameroon) and Naby Keita (Guinea) were on the big stage when Liverpool won their 6th UEFA Champions League title in 2019, the first African to have won the trophy was Bruce Grobbelaar of Zimbabwe.
pcm: Although Mo Salah (Egypt), Sadio Mane (Senegal), Joel Matip (Cameroon) and Naby Keita (Guinea) dey di big stage when Liverpool be win dem 6th UEFa Champions league title for 2019, di first African wey win di trophy na Bruce Grobbelaar of Zimbabwe.

eng: He achieved the feat in 1984 with Liverpool.
pcm: He achieve di feat with Liverpool for 1984.

eng: He was followed by Algerian legend Rabah Madjer who won it with FC Porto in 1987 and Abedi Pele (Ghana) in 1993 with Olympique Marseille before Nigeria's
pcm: Na Algerian legend Rabah Madjer wey win am with FC Porto for 1987 and Abedi Pele (Ghana) for 1993 with Olympique Marseille follow am, before Nigeria

eng: duo of George Findi and Nwankwo Kanu lifted it with Ajax Amsterdam in 1995.
pcm: duo of George Findi and Nwankwo Kanu lift am  with Ajax Amsterdam for 1995.

eng: It is also on record that Geremi Njitap of Cameroon was the first African to win the title twice in 2000 and 2002 with Spanish giants Real Madrid before Samuel Eto'o of Cameroon won it thrice with Barcelona 2006, 2009 and 2010 with Inter Milan.
pcm: E also dey record say na Geremi Njitap of Cameroon be di first African to win di title twice in 2000 and 2002 with Spanish giants Real Madrid, Samuel Eto'o of Cameroon kom win am three times with Barcelona 2006, 2009 and 2010 with Inter Milan.

eng: Other African winners of the highly coveted trophy are Ibrahim Tanko (Ghana)
pcm: Oda African wey don win di highky coveted trophy na Ibrahim Tanko (Ghana)

eng: Borussia Dortmund 1997, Samuel Kuffour (Ghana) Bayern Munich 2001, Benni McCarthy (South Africa) FC Porto 2004, Djimi Traore (Mali
pcm: Borussia Dortmund 1997, Samuel Kuffour (Ghana) Bayern Munich 2001, Benni McCarthy (South Africa) FC Porto 2004, Djimi Traore (Mali

eng: ) Liverpool 2005, Yaya Toure (Cote d'Ivoire)
pcm: ) Liverpool 2005, Yaya Toure (Cote d'Ivoire)

eng: Barcelona 2009 & 2011, Seydou Keita (Mali) Barcelona 2009 & 2011, Sully Muntari (Ghana)
pcm: Barcelona 2009 & 2011, Seydou Keita (Mali) Barcelona 2009 & 2011, Sully Muntari (Ghana)

eng: Inter Milan 2010 and McDonald Mariga (Kenya) 2010.
pcm: Inter Milan 2010 and McDonald Mariga (Kenya) 2010.

eng: John Mikel Obi (Nigeria), Michael Essien (Ghana), Salomon Kalou (Cote d'Ivoire), Didier Drogba (Cote d'Ivoire) who won it with Chelsea in 2012 and Achraf Hakimi (Morocco), with Real Madrid 2018 complete the list of Africans who have won the UEFA Champions League.
pcm: John Mikel Obi (Nigeria), Michael Essien (Ghana), Salomon Kalou (Cote d'Ivoire), Didier Drogba (Cote d'Ivoire) wey win am with Chelsea for 2012 and Achraf Hakimi (Morocco), with Real Madrid 2018 complete di list of Africans wey don win di UEFA Champions League.

eng: Coming closer home, the last time a Nigerian won the trophy was in 2012 when Mikel Obi was among the quartet of Africans who lifted it with Chelsea at the expense of Bayern Munich.
pcm: To come close to home, di last time wey Nigeria pesin win di trophy na 2012 when Mikel Obi dey among AFricans wey lift di trophy with Chelsea at di expense of Bayern Munich.

eng: After that achievement by the former captain of the Super Eagles, Nigeria has seen the rise of other immensely talented players like Ahmed Musa, Wilfred Ndidi, Kelechi Iheanacho, Alex Iwobi, William Troost-Ekong, Leon Balogun, Ola Aina, Isaac Success, Chigozie Awaziem, Tyrone Ebuehi, Moses Simon and lately Victor Osimhen
pcm: Afta dat achievement by di former captain of Super Eagles, Nigeria do see oda talented players dem rise, like Ahmed Musa, Wilfred Ndidi, Kelechi Iheanacho, Alex Iwobi, William Troost-Ekong, Leon Balogun, Ola Aina, Isaac Success, Chigozie Awaziem, Tyrone Ebuehi, Moses Simon and lately Victor Osimhen

eng: but none is yet to feature in the finals of Europe's biggest club competition.
pcm: But none of dem don feature for di final of biggest club competition for Europe.

eng: The reason for this is not farfetched.
pcm: Di reason no dey clear.

eng: The competition is dominated by the top five clubs in Europe, Real Madrid, Bayern Munich, Barcelona, Manchester United and Liverpool.
pcm: Na di di top five club for Europe Real Madrid, Bayern Munich, Barcelona, Manchester United and Liverpool dominate di competition.

eng: Unfortunately, Nigerian players have over the years failed to get into these highly rated European clubs.
pcm: Unfortunately, Nigeria players dem don fail to enter highly rated clubs dem for Europe.

eng: It is, therefore, the hope of Nigerian football stakeholders that in no distant future the new generation of players will break all barriers and begin to play for clubs that have potential to win the UEFA Champions League.
pcm: Na hope of Nigeria football stakeholder say very soon di new generation of players dem go break barrier and begin to play for clubs wey get potential to win di UEFA Champions League.

eng: If this fails, then football fans in Nigeria will continue to live with the agony of watching finals of the UEFA Champions League come and go without the presence of any Nigerian player.
pcm: If dis one fail, den di football fans wey dey for Nigeria go kontinu to dey live with di agony of watchin finakls of di UEFA Champion League dey kom and dey go, without di presence of any Nigeria player.

eng: As Nigerians wait for the next Super Eagles player who will rise to the pinnacle of European club competition the way Find George, Nwankwo Kanu did with Ajax in 1995 and Chelsea's Mikel Obi in 2012, the 2021 all English clubs finals is a few hours away.
pcm: As Nigeria pipo dey wait for di next Super Eagle player wey go rise to di top of di European club competition di way Find George, Nwankwo Kanu do am with Ajax for 1995 and Mikel Obi for 2012, na few hours remain for di 2021 all English clubs final.

eng: For di end, victory go dey for di Manchester club wey dey hunt for dem first title ot di Londeners wey dey prime for di second itle and di football league wey dem dey watch pass for di world, Premiership go be ultimate winner.
pcm: For di end, victory go dey for di Manchester club wey dey hunt for dem first title ot di Londeners wey dey prime for di second itle and di football league wey dem dey watch pass for di world, Premiership go be ultimate winner.

eng: Enyimba force FC IfeanyiUbah to 2-2 draw in Oriental derby
pcm: Eyimba don force FC IfeanyiUbah to 2-2 draw for di Oriental derby

eng: Enyimba FC came from behind to secure a well deserved 2-2 draw in their rescheduled Week 14 fixture against Oriental brothers FC IfeanyiUbah at the Aba International Stadium, Aba,
pcm: Enyimba FC be kom from behind to secure one 2- draw wey dem deserve for dem week 14 fixture wey dem reschedule against oriental broda dem FC IfeanyiUbah for di Aba international stadium,

eng: The Oriental Derby saw Enyimba make three changes to the team that lost at Rivers United on Sunday.
pcm: Di orietal derby see say Eyimba make three changes to di team wey loss for Rivers United on Sunday.

eng: Sadiq Abubakar returned after weeks of layoff while Anthony Omaka and Victor Mbaoma were restored to the starting lineup.
pcm: Sadiq Abubakar be return afta weeks wey dem don lay am off while Anthony Omaka and Victor Mbaoma enter di starting line up again.

eng: The first 28 minutes of the game saw both sides seeking to hit first but the visiting side drew the first blood in the 29th minute through Saidu Adamu who poked home from close range after Uche Onuoha had headed Evans Ogbonda's cross to his path.
pcm: Di first 28 minutes of di game see as both sides dem dey try to hit first but na di visitin side draw first blood through Saidu Adamu wey pokee am home from close range afta Uche Onuoha be head Evans Ogbonda cross go meet am.

eng: With the away side in full control of the game, their confidence grew more leaving the hosts scrambling to get back into the game as the first half ended 1-0 in favour of the visitors.
pcm: As di away side get full kontrol of di game, dem get more confidence and dat one leave di host to dey scramble to get back into di game as di first end for 1-0 in favour of di visitors.

eng: At the restart of the second half, IfeanyiUbah continued to press for the second goal and were duly rewarded when Saidu Adamu got his brace after getting Awazie's square pass over the line in the 61st minute.
pcm: As dem restart di second half, IfeanyiUbah kontinu to dey press for di second goal and dem get di reward wey dem deserve when Saidu Adamu get im brace afta im get Awazie square pass over di line for di 61st minute.

eng: Stung to life by the second goal, Enyimba began to throw in everything in their arsenal to get back into the game.
pcm: As di second goal sting dem to life, Eyimba begin throw evrithing for dem arsenal to get back inside di game.

eng: In the 78th minute, their pressure paid off when Reuben Bala reduced the deficit for Enyimba in a rather fortuitous fashion.
pcm: For inside di 78th minute, dem presence pay off as Reuben Bala reduce di deficit for Eyimba for one lucky fashion.

eng: His initial header was kept out by Sharp Uzoigwe but the ball ricocheted back to him and over the line.
pcm: Na Sharp Uzoigwe keep out im initial header but di ball roll back to am and ovr di line.

eng: The goal gave Enyimba some hope as they continued to press in numbers to at least secure a point
pcm: Di goal be give Eyimba some hope as dem kontinu to press for plunty nomba to secure a point at least

eng: and this they got in the 90th minute through Imoh Obot.
pcm: And dem get dis for 90th minute through Imot Obot.

eng: Following this result, Enyimba have moved up to 5th position with 31 points from 17 games with two more outstanding matches.
pcm: Following dis result, Eyimba don move up to 5th position with 31 points from 17 games with two more outstandin matches dem.

eng: Meanwhile, FC IfeanyiUbah are still rooted in the relegation zone with 17 points from 19 games.
pcm: Meanwhile, FC IfeanyiUbah still dey inside relegation zone as dem get 17 points inside 19 games.

eng: Farmers apprehensive as planting season begins with erratic rains
pcm: Farmers dem dey apprehensive as planting season begin with erratic rain dem

eng: As wet season begins in most parts of the country, farmers have commenced, planting, albeit with fear following erratic rains, which may threaten production.
pcm: As wet season don begin for most part of di season, farmer don begin palntin with fear as rain dey erratic and e fit threaten production.

eng: The rains have been unstable in Benue, Nasarawa, Niger, Kaduna and parts of the Federal Capital Territory (FCT), and many farmers have planted their crops.
pcm: Rain dey unsatble for Benue, Nasarawa, Niger, Kaduna and part of di Federal Capital Territory (FCT), and plenty farmer dem don plant dem crop.

eng: In the 2019/2020 wet season, erratic rains in the North and mid-season draught in the South-West made farmers lose their money due to crop failure.
pcm: For di 2019/2020 wet season, erratic rain for di north and mid-season draught for di south-west make farmers dem loss money due to crop failure.

eng: Musa Yohana and Halima Thomas, farmers in Doma and Lafia, Nasarawa State, said they had planted maize, groundnut and other tuber crops like cassava and yam, but feared they might have another horrible experience like last season when they were forced to plant maize and groundnut two times.
pcm: Musa Yohana and Halima Thomas, farmers for  inside  Doma and Lafia, Nasarawa State, tok say dem don plant maize, groundnut plus oda crops dem like casava and yam but fear say dem fit get anoda horrible experience like last season when dem dey forced to plant maize and groundnut two times.

eng: I lost most of my yams last year due to excessive heat as a result of inconsistent rainfall.
pcm: I loss my yam last year due to heat wey dey too much bikos rain no fall welwel.

eng: This year, we are in the second week of May but we are yet to have stable rains.
pcm: Dis year, we don dey second week for May but rain neva dey fall welwel.

eng: And I have planted 15 measures (about 20kg) of groundnut already.
pcm: And I don already plant 15 measure (about 20kg) of groundnut.

eng: If it continues like this for another week, I may lose the seeds, Mr Yohana said.
pcm: If e kontinu like dis for anoda one week, I fit loss all di seed dem, as Mr Yohana take tok.

eng: Like them, many farmers around the FCT have also planted, but the fear of crop failure is heightened by their experiences of last year.
pcm: Like dem, plenty farmer around di FCT don plant too, but dem get big fear for crop failure as experience last year.

eng: In Benue State, our correspondent reports that farmers have begun to cultivate their lands and plant crops amid complaints of scanty rainfall.
pcm: For Benue state, For Benue state, awa correspondent reprot say farmer don begin to cultivate land and plant crop on top complain say rain no fall.

eng: Some farmers who had prepared their farms earlier in the year said they could not start planting crops until one week ago, while others have just begun to till their lands at the wake of rainfall (thrice) within the past two weeks.
pcm: Some farmer wey don prepare dem farm earlier in di tear tok say dem no fit begin to dey plant until one week ago, as odas dem just begin to clear land at di wake of di rainfall three times withing two weeks wey pass.

eng: A farmer in Otukpo, Ada Hyacinth, said the ground was still too strong to cultivate because the rains hadn't been frequent.
pcm: One farmer for Otukpo, Ada hyacinth, tok say di ground still dey too strong to cultivate bikos di rain no dey fall frequent.

eng: Another farmer, Felix Tor, in Makurdi, said he had just planted melon and maize on his recently ploughed farm despite the inconsistency of the rains.
pcm: Anoda farmer wey be Felix Tor, for Makurdi tok say im just plant melon and maize on di farm wey im just clear despite as rain no dey consistent.

eng: Tor, however, expressed fears that the nature of the rainfall might affect the well-being of the crop.
pcm: Tor be however express fear say di nature of di rainfall fit affect di well-being of di crop.

eng: He prayed that the yield would turn out good in the end.
pcm: He pray make di yield do better in di end.

eng: But Vitalis Tarnongu, who is currently ploughing his 1,000 hectares of farmland at the Federal University of Agriculture, Makurdi (FUAM), posited that the manner of rainfall this year would require him to begin sowing maize towards the end of May.
pcm: But Vitalis Tarnongu, we don dey clear im 1,000 hectares of farmland for di federal Unversity of Agriculture, inside Makurdi (FUAM), tok say as di rain dey fall dis year go make am begin to plant maize towards di end of May.

eng: Tarnongu said a plant breeder in the university had advised him to wait until May 20 to begin planting his maize because the nature of the rainfall since the season set in suggested that there could be a two-week drought.
pcm: Tarnongu tok say one plant breeder for inside University don advise am to wait until May 20 to start to dey plant im maize bikos di nature of di rainfall since di season don suggest say e possible make rain no fall for two weeks.

eng: The state chairman of the All Farmers Association of Nigeria (AFAN), Aondongu Saaku, described farming as a business worth taking risk on.
pcm: Di sate chairman of di All Farmers Association of Nigeria (AFAN), Aondongu Saaku, describe farmin as business wey worth make dem take risk on.

eng: Saaku said farmers who saw it as business had already taken the risk to plant their crops because without such risk, they won't reap at the end of the day.
pcm: Saaku tok say farmers wey dey see am as business don take di risk to plent dia crop already bikos without dat kind risk dem no go reap at di end of di day.

eng: Meanwhile, Dr Teryima Iorlamen, a seed systems specialist at the FUAM, said farmers could go ahead to plant their root and tuber crops in line with the NIMET's rainfall prediction for this year.
pcm: Meanwhile, Dr Teryima Iorlamen, wey be seed system specialist for FUAm, tok say farmers dem fit go ahead to plant dem root and tuber crops as e follow di prediction of rainfall wey NIMET make dis year.

eng: Iorlamen said the period during which the farmers were expected to wait awhile before sowing had gone, stressing that NIMET's prediction for rainfall pattern in Benue State, which they (experts) work with, indicated that the rains would stabilise in the state between April 18 and 30, 2021.
pcm: Iorlamen tok say di period wey dem expect say farmers dem go wait don pass, e stress say di prediction of NIMET on top rainfall pattern inside Benue State, which dem (experts) dey work wit, don indicate say rain go stabilise for di state between April 18 and April 30, 2021.

eng: We can assure farmers now that the rains have stabilized, according to NIMET predictions.
pcm: We fit assure farmers now say rain don stabilise, accordin to prediction wey NIMET make.

eng: Anything otherwise now would be dry spell.
pcm: Anything wey different for now go be dry spell.

eng: I have advised farmers to check water logging capacity in their fields so that they plant their crops accordingly.
pcm: I don advise farmers dem to check water logging capacity for inside dem field so dem go fit plant dem crops as dem suppose plant am.

eng: Rice loves much water, so it is not yet time to plant it.
pcm: Rice like plenty water, so time neva reach to plant am.

eng: But farmers can go into roots and tubers now, such as yam, cassava, maize and melon.
pcm: But farmers dem fit enter root and tuber now, dat one include yam, cassava, maize and melon.

eng: We believe that the rain have stabilised.
pcm: We believe say di rain don stabilise.

eng: Senate mourns late Army chief, Ahmed Gulak
pcm: Senate dey mourn late Army Chief, Ahmed Gulak

eng: The Senate, on Tuesday, held a minute silence in honour of the demise of a former presidential aide, Ahmed Gulak, who was gruesomely murdered on Sunday in Owerri, Imo State capital.
pcm: Di Senate, on Tueday, be hold one minute silence to take honour di demise of former presidential aide, Ahmed Gulak, wey dem kill with strong eye on sunday for Owerri, Imo state capital.

eng: This followed a motion by Deputy Senate President and Chairman of the Senate Constitution Review Committee, Ovie Omo-Agege, on the floor of the Red Chamber.
pcm: Dis one follow motion of  Deputy Senate President and chairman of di senate on top senate Constitution review Committee, Ovie Omo-Agege, for di floor of di Red Chamber.

eng: Omo-Agege drew the attention of his colleagues to the assassination of Gulak, who, the lawmaker said, was hired to assist his committee to work on the amendments being sought by Nigerians to the constitution.
pcm: Omo-Agege be draw attention of im colleagues dem to di kill wey dem kill Gulak, wey di lawmaker dem hire to assist im committee on top di amendment wey Nigeria pipo one do for inside di constitution.

eng: Gulak served as a consultant to the committee and was in Owerri for the public hearing on the review of the 1999 constitution.
pcm: Gulak be serve as consultant to di committee and e enter Owerri for di public hearin on top di review of di 199 constitution.

eng: Though the programme ended on Thursday, Gulak stayed behind and left on Sunday.
pcm: Though di programme be don  end on Thursday, Gulak stay behind and komot on Sunday.

eng: He was murdered on his way to the airport in Owerri en route Abuja.
pcm: Dem kill am as e dey go airport for Owerri  on im way to Abuja.

eng: Omo-Agege described Gulak as a detribalised Nigerian, who gave his best to the service of the country.
pcm: Omo-Agege described Gulak as Nigerian wey no dey do tribal something, wey give im best to di service of di kontri.

eng: Also on Tuesday, the Senate urged the federal government to immortalise the late Chief of Army Staff, Lt. Gen. Ibrahim Attahiru.
pcm: Also, on Tuesday, di Senate be urge federal goment to immortalise di late Chief of Army Staff, Lt. Gen. Ibrahim Attahiru.

eng: The red chamber also observed a one minute silence in honour of Lt. Gen. Attahiru, who died in a plane crash near Kaduna International Airport.
pcm: Di red chamber be also observe one minute silence to take honuor Lt. Gen. Attahiru, wey die for plane crash near Kaduna International Airport.

eng: This followed a point of order raised by the Chairman, Senate Committee on Army, Senator Ali Ndume.
pcm: Dis one follow point of order by di Chairman, Senate Committee on to Army matter, Senator Ali Ndume.

eng: NIN/profile code: NANS raises alarm over disenfranchisement of students by JAMB
pcm: NIN/profile code: NANS don raise voice concerning disenfranchisement of students by JAMB

eng: The Kaduna State Chapter of the National Association of Nigerian Students (NANS) on Tuesday said thousands of candidates would not take part in this year's Joint Admission and Matriculation Board (JAMB)
pcm: Di Kaduna State Chapter of di National Association of Nigerian Students (NANS) for Tuesday tok say thousands of candidates no go take part for di Joint Admission and Matriculation Board (JAMB) dis year

eng: examination due to hitches in their NIN/Profile code.
pcm: examination on top  hitches for dem  NIN/Profile code.

eng: The state NANS chairman, Axiz Huziafa Bello, in a statement issued yesterday in Kaduna, disagreed with the JAMB.
pcm: NANS chairman for inside di stste, Axiz Huziafa Bello, for inside one statement weu dem issue  yesterday for Kaduna be disagree with di JAMB.

eng: Bello called for an extension of the electronic registration instead of risking students lives to travel to JAMB headquarters in their respective states for manual registration.
pcm: Bello be call for extension of di electronic registration instead of as dem dey risk di life of students dem to travel to di headquarter of JAMB for dem states for manual registration.

eng: He noted that the news bulletin released on Monday, May 31, 2021, titled Issues surrounding the 2021 UTME registration: Option available for genuine candidates who made attempts but could not register, showed that the management had failed to show empathy for the hardship and agony of the candidates.
pcm: He note say di news bulletin wey dem release on Monday wit di title Issues surrounding the 2021 UTME registration: Option available for genuine candidates who made attempts but could not register, show say di management don fail to show sorry face for di hardship and agony wey di candidates dem dey face.

eng: He appealed to prominent Nigerians to prevail on the management of JAMB to desist from unleashing hardship on Nigerian students in their noble quest for higher education and self-development.
pcm: He appeal give prominent Nigeria pipo to prevail on top di management of JAMB to stop to make things hard for students dem inside Nigeria as dem dey try to get higher education and develop demsef.

eng: He urged the examination body to extend the registration period and postpone the exam in the interest of justice and fairness.
pcm: He urge di examination bodi to extend di registration period and postpone di exam to do justice and fairness.

eng: Police arrest 16 suspects over cultism, recover firearms in Enugu
pcm: Police don arrest 16 pipo as suspect for cultism matter for Enugu, dem recover firearms

eng: The Police Command in Enugu State has arrested 16 suspects within two weeks, one female inclusive, for cultism and unlawful possession of firearms.
pcm: DI police command for Enugu state don arrest 16 suspect dem withing two weeks, one female sef dey there, for cultism and say dem get firearms wey dem no suppose get.

eng: The command also recovered two cut-to-size locally-made guns, one locally-made pistol, two live cartridges, six mobile phones, a powdery substance suspected to be heroin and weeds suspected to be Indian Hemp.
pcm: Di command be also recovertwo cut-to-size locally-made guns,one locally-made pistol, two live cartridges, six mobile phones, on powder subsatnce wey dem suspect say na heroin and weed wey dem suspect say na Indian Hemp.

eng: The Command's Public Relations Officer, ASP Daniel Ndukwe, said this in a statement made available to the News Agency of Nigeria (NAN) on Sunday in Enugu.
pcm: Di Public Relations Officer for di Command, ASP Daniel Ndukwe, tok am inside one statement wey dem carry give di News Agency of Nigeria (NAN)  inside Enugu on sunday.

eng: Ndukwe said that the feat was achieved by joint operations carried out by police operatives attached to 9th Mile Police Division, Anti-Cult Unit and personnel of the Nigerian Army, 82 Division in Enugu.
pcm: Ndukwe tok say na joint operation wey police of di 9th Mile Police Division dem carry out make dem achieve di feat, Anti-Cult Unit and personnel of di Nigerian Army, 82 Division for Enugu.

eng: He said that the joint operation took place between April 19 and May 4, within a span of three council areas in the state.
pcm: He tok say di joint operation be take place between April 19 and may 4, and e stretch hand reach council area for inside di state.

eng: They included: Cornelius Uche, 31; Ifeanyi Umeneze, 22; Chijioke Anachuna, 34; Chibuzor Umeayo, 28; Chinedu Okeke, 23; Ozinachi Obadike, 22; Ifeanyi Nwagbo, 27; Chigozie Okeke, 18, and Chikamso Odinwankpa, 18; were all arrested.
pcm: dem included: Cornelius Uche, 31; Ifeanyi Umeneze, 22; Chijioke Anachuna, 34; Chibuzor Umeayo, 28; Chinedu Okeke, 23; Ozinachi Obadike, 22; Ifeanyi Nwagbo, 27; Chigozie Okeke, 18, and Chikamso Odinwankpa, 18; dem arrest all of dem.

eng: They were arrested on May 4 within Ezeagu Local Government Area following their alleged involvement in bloody cult clashes.
pcm: Dem arrest dem for May 4 withing Ezeagu Local Goment Area afta dem do plenty bloody cult clash dem.

eng: Others included: Ozor Chidubem, 22; Amina Inalegwu (female), 18; Benard Bright, 20; Ugwu Chidera, 21; Ani Chukwuebuka, 23; and Onoh Obumneme, 20; who were all arrested on April 19 at about 3:30 a.m.
pcm: Oda dem included: Ozor Chidubem, 22; Amina Inalegwu (female), 18; Benard Bright, 20; Ugwu Chidera, 21; Ani Chukwuebuka, 23; and Onoh Obumneme, 20; wey dem arrest on April 19 at about 3:30 a.m.

eng: They were arrested along Enugu-Makurdi Expressway, 9th Mile, Udi L.G.A. on their way to plan and perfect a heinous cult activity, as preliminary investigation reveals.
pcm: Dem arrest dem along Enugu-Makurdi Expressway, 9th Mile, Udi L.G.A. as dem wan go plan one bad cult activity, according to wetin preliminary investigate don show.

eng: Another of the suspect, one Uchenna Aniagozie, 28, was arrested on April 28 for his alleged involvement in a deadly cult clash sometime in January 2021.
pcm: Anoda of di suspect, one Uchenna Aniagozie, 28, wey dem arrest on April 28  say im involve for one deadly cult clash sometime wey don pass for January.

eng: Preliminary investigation shows that they all confessed to being members of Vikings Confraternity, he said.
pcm: He tok say preliminary investigation don show say all of dem confess say dem be member for inside Vikings Confraternity.

eng: The police spokesman said that the suspects would be prosecuted accordingly once ongoing investigations into their nefarious activities were concluded.
pcm: Di toktok pesin for police tok say dem go prosecute di suspect dem as dem suppose do am once di investigation wey dem dey do don conclude.

eng: To this end, residents of the state have been called upon to remain law-abiding, vigilant and quickly report suspected criminals and their activities to the nearest police station.
pcm: To dis end, dem don call upon residents for di state to dey follow wetin law tok, make dem dey vigilant and make dem report suspect quick quick for police station wey near pass.

eng: Residents can call the Command's emergency hotlines on 08032003702, 08075390883, 08086671202 or 08098880172, he added.
pcm: He add say residents dem fit call di Command emergency hotlines on top 08032003702, 08075390883, 08086671202 or 08098880172.

eng: How cassava is becoming gold in Benue
pcm: How cassava don dey  is become gold inside Benue

eng: In Benue State, farmers are expanding their fields almost every season to increase production as cassava farming becomes a thriving business in all the three senatorial districts.
pcm: For inside Benue State, farmers don dey expand dem fields almos evri season to take increase production as cassava farin don bikom better business for inside di three senatorial district dem.

eng: Although the state is largely known as the highest producer and consumer of yam in the country, cassava consumption now gradually reigns.
pcm: Although na di state dem know as state wey dey produce and chop yam pass for inside di kontri, cassava don dey reign gradually.

eng: As such, more farmers are said to be cultivating cassava.
pcm: As such, dem tok say more farmers dem don dey plant cassava.

eng: A cassava farmer in the Gboko area of the state, Titus Atondo, said he started cultivating the crop for many years now.
pcm: One cassava farmer for di Gboko area of di stste, Titus Atondo, tok say he begin to plant di crop for many years now.

eng: Atondo said cassava farming posed little or no challenge because farmers only need to spray the farm once to repel weed, then wait for harvest.
pcm: Atondo tok say cassava farming no dey too get plenty challenge bikos farmers only need to spray di farm once to repel weed, den dem go wait for harvest.

eng: Cassava chips are very expensive now.
pcm: Cassava chips don dey very expensive now.

eng: I have a large cassava farm where I make money and my family consumes some of the produce, he said.
pcm: I get large cassava farm wia I dey make money and my family sef dey chop some of di produce, as e take tok am.

eng: Faith Ben is now preparing a large expanse of land in the Ugboju area of Otukpo Local Government Area to cultivate cassava as soon as the rain begins, following the high demand of the by-product in her vicinity.
pcm: Faith Ben don dey prepare large land for inside di Ugboju area of Otukpo Local Goment Area to take cultivate cassava as soon as rain start to fall, dis one na as dem dey demand for di product welwel for her vicinity.

eng: The demand for cassava is usually high these days.
pcm: Di demand for cassava dey high welwel nowadays.

eng: From the tubers to the processed produce, it has become a money-spinning crop.
pcm: From di tubers go enter di di one wey dem don process, e don bikom crop wey dey bring money.

eng: That's why I am going into the farming.
pcm: Na y I dey enter di farming be dat.

eng: And I am doing so purely for business, she added.
pcm: She add say na for business alone she dey do am.

eng: On his part, the state chairman of the All Farmers Association of Nigeria (AFAN), Aondongu Saaku, admitted that cassava consumption in the state had become more than yam in recent times.
pcm: For im own part, di stste chairman of di All Farmers Association of Nigeria (AFAN), Aondongu Saaku, admit say dem don dey chop cassava for di state pass yam sef.

eng: Saaku said this is because cassava is eaten in varieties, unlike yam.
pcm: Saaku tok dis one bikos dem dey chop cassava for many variety, unlike yam.

eng: Meanwhile, the Director of Agric Science in the Ministry of Agriculture and Natural Resources, Thomas Unongo, explained that cassava farming has been thriving in the state in recent times because no aspect of the crop is wasted.
pcm: Meanwhile, di Director  of Agric Science for di Ministry of Agriculture and Natural Resources, Thomas Unongo, explain say cassava farming don dey do well for di state in recent times bikos no aspekt for di crop dey wasted.

eng: Unongo, whose farm occupies three and a half hectares in Apir, Makurdi, said that for the past two years, he had been cultivating the land with new varieties of cassava released by the International Institute of Tropical Agriculture (IITA).
pcm: Unongo wey get farm wey be three and  half hectres for Apir, Makurdi tok say for di past two years, im don dey cultivate di land with new varieties of cassava wey di International Institute of Tropical Agriculture (IITA) dem release.

eng: Apart from weed control, it is one of the cheapest crops to grow.
pcm: Apart from say dem dey kontrol weed, na one of di crops wey cheap pass to grow.

eng: Rice production costs between N200,000 and N300,000 per hectare, while yam costs between N150,000 and N200,000 per hectare, but inputs for cassava production for farmers with stems cost only about N150,000.
pcm: To produce rice dey cost between N200,000 and N300,000 for one hectare, as yam dey cost between N150,000 and N200,00 per hectare, but input for cassava production with stems for farmer dey only cost N150,000.

eng: And where there is light vegetation, it could be as low as N100,000.
pcm: And wia dem get light vegetation, e fit low reach N100,000.

eng: It is really cheap and the output/return on investment is one of the highest in Benue now, he said.
pcm: He tok say e dey chaep and di output/return on top investment na one of di highest for Benue now.

eng: Unongo further noted that the challenges of farming cassava in the state hinged on insecurity as herders attacks worsened.
pcm: Unongo further note say  di challenge of farming cassava for di state dey on top  insecurity as herders attack dey worse.

eng: He alleged that herders usually removed the stems and tubers for their cattle.
pcm: He allege say herders dem dey komot di stem and tuber for dem cattle.

eng: He, however, advised that to get a better yield, one would have to apply weed control three months after planting, stressing that when weeds are allowed to grow in the farm, they invite pests, such as grasshoppers.
pcm: However, he advise say to get better yield, pesin go need to apply weed kontrol three months afta dem palnt am, e stress say wen dem allow weed to grow for insie di farm, dem dey invite pest like grasshoppers dem.

eng: He said inputs like fertiliser, herbicides, among others, are necessary, adding that there's the need to observe farm sanitation, which would help against attacks by rodents.
pcm: He tok say inputs like fertlizer, herbicides dem, among oda things dey necessary, he add say need dey to dey do farm sanitation, wey go help against attack of rodents dem.

eng: Unongo maintained that while the conventional old varieties of cassava would last up to two years before harvest, with one-year maturity, the new improved varieties have a maturity period of five and seven months; but the eight months are superb for harvest.
pcm: Unongo maintain say as d old variety of cassava go last reach two years before harvest, with one year maturity, di new improved varieties get maturity period of five and seven months, but na eight month better pass for harvest.

eng: Cassava farming is turning to gold in Benue because the state is nearer to the North, where the crop is not produced.
pcm: Cassava farming don dey turn to gold for inside Benue bikos di state dey near to north, wia dem no dey produce di crop.

eng: Also, the produce, especially garri, is becoming costlier because vendors are everywhere in villages mopping up the chips desired more for the Northern market, he noted.
pcm: Also, the produce, especially garri, don dey cost more bikos  vendors dem don dey  evriwia for villages dem mopping up di chips wey dem desire to sell go Northern market, as he take note am.

eng: Start agric revolution now, Bode George, Gen Olanrewaju tell Sanwo-Olu
pcm: Begin agric revolution now, na wetin Bode George and Gen Olanrewaju tell Sanwo-Olu

eng: Prominent Lagos indigenes under the aegis of Eko Pataki have asked Governor Babajide Sanwo-Olu to immediately begin a move towards revolutionising agriculture in the state.
pcm: Prominent indigene for Lagos under di name of Eko Pataki don ask Governor Babajide Sanwo-Olu to begin to revolution for agriculture inside di state.

eng: The indigenes made the call against the backdrop of the recent decision to block food supply to the South by the Amalgamated Union of Food Stuff and Cattle Dealers in Nigeria (AUFCDN).
pcm: Di indigene dem make dis call against as di recent decision to take block supply of food to di south by di Amalgamated Union of Food Stuff and Cattle Dealers in Nigeria (AUFCDN).

eng: Reacting to the development yesterday, the group said there was the need for the government to redirect its policies towards broadening agricultural investment in order to enhance food sufficiency in the state.
pcm: As dem dey raect on top di development yesterday, di group tok say need dey for goment to redirect dem policy towards to broad agriculture investment in order to help food surficiency for di state.

eng: This was contained in a joint statement by the leader of the group, Chief Bode George, and its trustees, Gen Tajudeen Olanrewaju and Mr Gbadebo Dallas.
pcm: Dis one dey inside joint statement by di leader of di group Chief Bode George, and its trustees, Gen Tajudeen Olanrewaju and Mr Gbadebo Dallas.

eng: The group charged the governor to engage the huge unemployed youths in the state to drive the agricultural revolution.
pcm: Di group cahrge di governor to engage di plenty youth wey no get employment for di state to take drive di agricultural revolution.

eng: The statement reads in part: The recent action of the Amalgamated Union of Food Stuff and Cattle Dealers in Nigeria which halted the convoy of trailers from bringing tomatoes, pepper, onions and all kinds of foodstuff to the South should awaken the leadership of Lagos State to redirect its policies in widening its agricultural investments.
pcm: Part of di statement read say: di recent action of di Amalgamated Union of Food Stuff and Cattle Dealers in Nigeria wey no allow trailers dem to bring tomatoes, pepper, onions and all kind o foodstuff enter south suppose wake di leadership of lagos State to redirect dem policies to take widen dem investment for inside agriculture.

eng: Lagos State which is naturally our foremost concern as Eko Pataki should henceforth impress into immediate duty a massive workforce of her unemployed youths across the IBILE traditional enclave, whipping our vast and enriched lands into a huge agricultural holding.
pcm: Lagos State wey be awa foremost concern as Eko Pataki make dem begin impress into immediate duty for huge workforce of di youth wey no get employement for inside di IBILE traditional enclave, as dem dey turn awa vast and enriched land into agricultural holding.

eng: From Ifako-Ijaiye to Imota, from Epe to the rolling fields to the mangroves of Badagry, Lagos State is blessed with nutrient-rich agricultural fields that can quickly be marshaled into farmlands where various kinds of crops from tomatoes, lettuce, pepper, beans, rice, corn, yam, potatoes, cassava to many others can be planted to enhance our self-sufficiency in food production.
pcm: From Ifako-Ijaiye to Imota, from Epe to di rolling fields to di mangroves of Badagry, Lagos State dey blessed wit agricultural fields wey get nutrient wey fit quickly turn to farmland wia different kind of crop like  tomatoes, lettuce, pepper, beans, rice, corn, yam, potatoes, cassava go reach many odas wey dem fit plant to take enhance awa sef-sufficiency for food production.

eng: It is our candid advice to Governor Sanwo-Olu to quickly reorder the state's priorities in ensuring that our state becomes the new food basket of the country thereby triggering a new agricultural revolution in the state of excellence.
pcm: Na awa candid advise to Governor Sanwo-Olu to quickly re-order di state priority to take make sure say awa state bikom di new food basket for di kontri to thereby trigger new agricultural revolution for inside di state of excellence.

eng: China to raise proportion of middle-income earners
pcm: China wan raise di proportion of middle-income earners

eng: China's consumption has been on a continuous rise in recent years, and its consumption structure is also being optimized.
pcm: Di consumption of China don dey continue to rise for recent years, and dem dey optimise im conumption structure.

eng: Last year, the country's total retail sales of consumer goods reached 39.2 trillion yuan ($6 trillion), and final consumption contributed 54.3 per cent to China's GDP.
pcm: Last year, di total retail sales of consumer goods for inside di kontri  reach 39.2 trillion yuan ($6 trillion), and final consumption be contribute 54.3 per cent to di GDP of China.

eng: As a result, China maintained its position as the second-largest consumption market in the world.
pcm: DI result na say China still be di second-largest consumption market for di world.

eng: New business forms such as online shopping and influencer marketing experienced rapid development.
pcm: New business like online shopping and influencer marketing don experience rapid development.

eng: In 2020, a total of over 24 million Livestream shows were aired on e-commerce platforms; online sales of national entity bucked the trend and grew 14.8 per cent; the express delivery industry handled 31.2 per cent more parcels than it did a year ago.
pcm: For 2020, dem show over 24 million levestream on top e-commerce platforms, online sales of national entity becked di trend and grow reach 14.8 per cent. di express delivery industry handle 31.2 per cent more parcels dan last year.

eng: China has become the world's largest market of online retailing for eight consecutive years.
pcm: China don turn largest market for online retailing for eight years straight.

eng: The robust recovery of China's consumption, despite the severe impacts from COVID-19, showcased the strong resilience and huge development potential of the Chinese market.
pcm: Di robust recovery of China's consumption, despite di severe impact of COVID-19 don show di strong resilience and huge development potential of di Chinese market.

eng: As a major force of consumption, the middle-income group is a pillar of the economy.
pcm: As major force for consumption, na pillar di middle-income group be for di economy.

eng: At present, China has 400 million middle-income earners that account for around 30 per cent of its population.
pcm: For present, China get 400 million middle-income earner dem wey dey account for around 30 per cent of dem population.

eng: In developed countries, the distribution of household income is always in an olive shape that is sharp at both ends and plump in the middle.
pcm: For kontri dem wey don develop, di distribution of household income dey always come for olive shape form wey dey sharp for di two end and e plump for di middle.

eng: In other words, the middle-income group usually accounts for 60 per cent to 70 per cent of the population in developed countries.
pcm: For oda words, for kontri wey don develop di middle-income group dey usually accpount for 60 per cent go reach 70 percent of di population.

eng: Such a structure is considered healthy and good for economic and social development.
pcm: Dem dey consider dat kind structure as say dem dey healthy and good for economic and social development.

eng: In contrast, China still has a long way to go to expand the size of its middle-income group.
pcm: In contrast, China way still far to take expand di size of im middle-income group.

eng: Vice-Minister of Commerce Qian Keming said that with 1.4 billion people, China boasts a super large market and huge development potential.
pcm: Vice-Minister of Commerce Qian Keming tok say with 1.4 billion pipo, China get large market and huge development potential.

eng: In the next 15 years, the number of Chinese middle-income earners is expected to reach 800 million, which will generate robust momentum for consumption upgrading and bright prospects.
pcm: For di next fifteen years, dem expect say make di nomba of Chinese middle-income don reach 800 million, wey go generate robust momentum for consumption upgrading plus bright prospects.

eng: According to China's 14th Five-Year Plan, China will work to increase the income for graduates of universities and vocational schools, skilled workers and migrant workers in the next five years.
pcm: According to di 14th Five-Year Plan of China, China go work to increase di income for graduates of universeties dem and vocational schools, skiled workers and migrants workers dem for di next five years.

eng: Experts believe that it's both possible and necessary to include them in the middle-income group.
pcm: Experts dem believe say e dey possible and necessary to put dem for di middle-income group.

eng: Graduates of universities and vocational schools come in huge size and are well educated and skilful, which makes them possible to become middle-income earners.
pcm: Graduates of university and vocational school dem  plenty and are dey well  educated and get skil, wey make am possible for dem to  become middle-income earners.

eng: Most people from this group, with their degree of education and competence, will not work simple and repetitive jobs, so it's possible that they become middle-income earners, Su Hainan, a contract research fellow with China Association for Labor Studies, told People's Daily during an interview.
pcm: Most pipo for dis group, with dem degree of education and competence no go wan do simple and repetive work, so e dey possible say make dem bikom middle-income earners, Su Hainan, wey be contract research fellow with China Association for Labor Studies, tell People's Daily during one interview.

eng: According to the latest statistics from the Ministry of Human Resources and Social Security (MOHRSS), China has over 200 million skilled workers, who take 26 per cent of its total jobs, up from 20 per cent a few years ago.
pcm: According to di latest statistics from di Ministry of Human Resources and Social Security (MOHRSS), China get over 200 million skiled workers wey take 26 per cent of dem total job, up from 20 per cent few years ago.

eng: More than 50 million of them are highly skilled workers.
pcm: More dan 50 million of dem be skiled worker.

eng: In recent years, skilled workers are in a short supply in China, and their income keeps rising.
pcm: For recent years, skiled workers no reach for China, and dem income don kontinu to det rise.

eng: The MOHRSS recently issued a guideline, encouraging enterprises to institute an annual salary system and offer special awards for skilled talents, especially highly skilled ones.
pcm: Di MOHRSS issue one guideline recently, wey dem encourage enterprises to institute annual salary system and offer special award for skiled talents, esecially di ones wey get high skil.

eng: Migrant workers are a major part of China's workforce, many of whom are also well educated and skilful, and are able to work complicated and innovative jobs, Su said.
pcm: Su tok say migrant workers na major part of workforce for inside China, many of dem sef dey well educated and dem get skil, and dem no dey able to do complicated and innovative works dem.

eng: Last year, the number of migrant workers in China reached 280 million, including 170 million who worked out-of-town.
pcm: Last year, di nomba of migrant worker for inside China reach 280 million, plus 180 wey work out of town.

eng: The average monthly income of them stood at 4,072 yuan.
pcm: Di average income wey dem dey get per month stay for 4,072 yuan.

eng: Many of them are getting close to the threshold of middle income if calculated in terms of household.
pcm: Plenty among dem don dey get close to di threshold of middle income if dem take terms of household calculate am.

eng: To make a part of migrant workers middle-income earners is necessary for narrowing the rural-urban income gap, improving the competence of workforce and accelerating rural vitalization, and it's also feasible to do that, Su noted.
pcm: To make part of dem imigrant worker to become middle-income earners dey necessary to take marrow di rural-urban income gap, to take improve di competence of workforce and accelerate rural vitalization, and e lso dey feasible to am, as Su take note

eng: As the income of these major groups rises in the future, the size of China's middle-income group will be further expanded, turning the country's household income distribution into the olive shape.
pcm: As di income of dis major group go rise for future, dem go expand di size di middle-income group for China, dat one go turn di household income distribution to olive shape.

eng: By that time, China's consumption vitality will have been further activated, and the country will also release more dividends to the world.
pcm: By dat time, dem go don further actuvate di consumption vitality of China, and di kontri go release more dividends to di world.

eng: Aba agog as maiden Gov Ikpeazu golf tourney tees off
pcm: Aba dey go agog as Gov Ikpeazu golf tourney don start

eng: Over 2,500 players from across Nigeria and West Africa are currently vying for laurels in the maiden edition of Governor Okezie Ikpeazu open golf championship which teed off on Wednesday, May 19 and will end on May 23at the famous Aba Golf Course.
pcm: Over 25,000 players dem from across Nigeria and West Africa dey try get laurels currently for inside di maiden edition of Governor Okezie Ikpeazu open golf championship wey start on wednesday, May 19 and e go end for May 23 for di famous Aba Golf Course.

eng: The Governor who teed off the tournament charged the players to enjoy the game and also the hospitality of the people.
pcm: Di Governor wey start di tournament charge di player say make dem enjoy di game plus di hospitality of di pipo.

eng: He said they should find time to visit major shopping centres in Aba to buy memorabilia to take to their respective homes.
pcm: He tok say make dem find time to take visit major shopping centers dem for Aba to buy memorable things to dem houses.

eng: The governor also promised to continue to support the sport and assured that his administration will construct a new golf course in Ohafia to further deepen awareness and participation in the game.
pcm: Di governor be also promise say im go kontinu to dey support di sport and assure say im administration go construct new golf course for Ohafia to help awareness and participation for di game.

eng: He said,I pray that golf which is a unifying game will continue to unify us in Nigeria and also avail us of the health benefits of engaging in this gentlemen's game.
pcm: He tok say, I pray say golf wey be unifyin game go kontinu to dey unify us for Nigeria and also give di health benefit of engaging for di gentleman game.

eng: In his remarks, the National Director of Competitions, Professional Golfers Association of Nigeria (PGAN), Johnbull Dangofa informed Ikpeazu that having gone round the historic city, he was pleased with the prevailing peace and the good infrastructure put in place by the governor.
pcm: For im remark, di National Director of Competitions, Professional Golfers Association of Nigeria (PGAN), Johnbull Dangofa inform Ikpeazu say as im don go round di historic city, di peace ey dey and di good infrastructure wey di governor do please am.

eng: The President of Aba Sports Club, Chief Jerry Kalu, expressed members appreciation to the governor for the support given by the state government to ensure the smooth take-off of the competition.
pcm: Di president of Aba sports club,Chief Jerry Kalu don express di appreciation of members to di governor for di support wey di state goment give to take make sure say di take off of di competition smooth.

eng: He said more than 250 golfers had registered to take part in the tournament.
pcm: He tok say more than 250 golfers don register to take part for inside di tournament.

eng: A letter to DSS and other intelligence agencies
pcm: One letter to DSS and oda intelligence agencies dem

eng: You guys are supposed to be smart.
pcm: Una suppose dey smart.

eng: I know you evolved from the police  just as did many other agencies.
pcm: I know say na from police you for evolve just as many oda agency dem.

eng: By splintering from the police you were meant to be cleaner, and smarter, much quicker on your feet.
pcm: As you take komot from di police you suppose clean pass dem, make you smart, make you dey quick for your feet.

eng: Is it politics that overcame you guys?
pcm: Shey na politics come over una?

eng: I heard the National Security Adviser, Monguno, for the first time since he was appointed years ago the other day, sounding very eloquent with his Queen's English.
pcm: I hear say di National Security Adviser, Monguno, for di first time since dem appoint am years ago, wey he dey sound very eloquent with im Queen's English.

eng: He should be polished, after all he was one of those privileged ajebutter Nigerian children who attended Kings College back in the day.
pcm: Make dem polish am, afta all im na one of dis ajebutter Nigerian wey get priviledge to attend Kings College back in di day.

eng: From his speech I could hear and see an organised mind and an intelligent, functional brain, and I wondered at length why and how Abba Kyari managed to cage such a person while Buhari looked on.
pcm: From im speech I dey hear and I dey see one mind wey dey organised and intelligent, functional brain, and i wonder why and how Abba Kyari take manage to cage dat kain pesin and Buhari dey look.

eng: Monguno, later went on to allege that quite a number of the arms and ammunition that Nigeria paid for under the recently ambassadorised military chiefs were nowhere to be found.
pcm: Munguno later go on to allege say plenty inside di arms wey Nigeria pay for under di recent military chiefs wey don turn ambassador na im dem no fit find.

eng: When he saw that feathers were ruffled, he tried to walk back what he was alleged to have said.
pcm: When im see say dem don dey ruffle feathers, im try to walk back wetin dem allege say im tok.
